-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18292
Sender:Mark Derricutt <mark@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 09:38:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

I've been reading this thread whilst writing up some blog posts on the
subject and was rereading the specs for "Content-Disposition", and it the
spec mentions:

disposition := "Content-Disposition" ":"
                    disposition-type
                    *(";" disposition-parm)

disposition-type := "inline"
                  / "attachment"
                  / extension-token
                  ; values are not case-sensitive

Looking at the extension-token specs elsewhere it would look like it'd be
acceptable for us rest-nazi's to adopt something like:

Content-Type: application/json
Content-Disposition: inline; concept=customer

(or even rel=customer if we wanted to keep some form of consistent naming
).  This at least covers declaring the disposition / concept we're
returning, and it looks like the SIP protocol proposed the
Accept-Disposition header [1] and from cursory reading around this looks
like this would be a valid (existing) method for defining these concept.s

Am I wrong?


[1]
http://www.softarmor.com/wgdb/docs/draft-camarillo-sip-accept-disposition-00.txt

-- 
"Great artists are extremely selfish and arrogant things" â€” Steven Wilson,
Porcupine Tree

On Fri, Dec 30, 2011 at 10:46 PM, Paul Cohen <pacoispaco@...> wrote:

> Maybe the term "conceptual type" was unfortunate. My point in the
> discussion was that it may be of interest to talk about the concepts
> and information a service is meant to provide in order to then be able
> to reason about what media types to use or invent for a given service.
>
>

On Mon, Jan 2, 2012 at 9:38 AM, Mark Derricutt <mark@...> wrote:

>
> Content-Type: application/json
> Content-Disposition: inline; concept=customer

x-concept maybe?

> [1] http://www.softarmor.com/wgdb/docs/draft-camarillo-sip-accept-disposition-00.txt

See also Julian's recent draft:

http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/draft-reschke-rfc2183-in-http-latest.html

Benjamin Hawkes-Lewis

Post ID:18295
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 10:36:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 12/30/2011 1:26 AM, Mike Kelly wrote:
> On Thu, Dec 29, 2011 at 11:44 PM, Jan Algermissen
> <jan.algermissen@... <mailto:jan.algermissen%40nordsc.com>> wrote:
>  >
>  > On Dec 29, 2011, at 8:37 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>  >
>  >> Yes, the link relation of the referring link should be documented so
> the client can interpret the targeted resource.
>  >>
>  >> Is that controversial? :)
>  >
>  > No - REST's constraints explicitly forbid this form of coupling. The
> client interprets the response based on the current response. NOT based
> on expectations about the resource.
>  >
>
> I disagree, which constraint are you claiming is explicit about this?

+1

Cheers,

Bo

> Are there any specific quotes from the dissertation you are thinking
> about?
>
>  >
>  > Expectations about resources (made due to discovered link semantics)
> drive the construction of the request. They do not apply to the response
> (aka 'self describing messages constraint').
>  >
>
> The purpose of self-descriptiveness is to enable intermediate
> processing, so why do you insist application semantics in the message
> body must be processable by intermediaries?
>
> In fact, the kind of semantics that should be self-descriptive in the
> message body are general mechanisms like ESI (not application
> semantics). Incidentally, a capability I'm looking work into HAL is
> something equivalent to ESI - for that very reason.
>
> couple of relevant quotes from the dissertation:
>
> "REST enables intermediate processing by constraining messages to be
> self-descriptive"
>
> "Within REST, intermediary components can actively transform the
> content of messages because the messages are self-descriptive and
> their semantics are visible to intermediaries"
>
> Cheers,
> Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18296
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 11:28:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 12/31/2011 2:08 AM, Jï¿½rn Wildt wrote:
> Duh! It is the examples that are wrong. Media types should not describe
> objects like "sales order" or "bill". They should be more general like
> "e-procurement". The fact that its a sales order can be derived from the
> rel-type (as argued earlier on).
>
> So my previous little step-be-step list becomes:
>
> 1) The client follows a link-rel "this-is-the-sales-order" and assumes it
> will get, well, a sales order - in some yet unknown format.
>
> 2) The client does not need to specify "I want a sales order" in the accept
> header (it does so by the URL it has selected).
>
> 3) The client must specify its capabilities (or the context in which it will
> process the sales order). So it sends Accept: application/e-procurement+xml
> (not application/salesorder+xml).
>
> 4) The server replies with a sales order and content-type
> application/e-procurement+xml.
>
> 5) The client knows that a sales order in the context of
> application/e-procurement+xml should be decoded in a certain way and does
> so.
>
> Repeat step 1-5 with "sales order" replaced with
> "bill/quote/reservation/etc" - but do not change the media type.
>
> Better now?

Well, you can still go with more generic types, such as 
application/rdf+xml, where "shared understanding" ((domain) knowledge) 
is described in linked ontology specifications. However, besides concept 
definitions, additional descriptions for specific actions are probably 
required, e.g., by extending existing property (relations) definitions 
with this kind of information (e.g. as it can be realized with HAL or ALPS).

Cheers,


Bo





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18297
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 11:46:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 2 January 2012 13:28, Bob Ferris <zazi@...> wrote:

> On 12/31/2011 2:08 AM, JÃ¸rn Wildt wrote:
> > Duh! It is the examples that are wrong. Media types should not describe
> > objects like "sales order" or "bill". They should be more general like
> > "e-procurement". The fact that its a sales order can be derived from the
> > rel-type (as argued earlier on).
> >
> > So my previous little step-be-step list becomes:
> >
> > 1) The client follows a link-rel "this-is-the-sales-order" and assumes it
> > will get, well, a sales order - in some yet unknown format.
> >
> > 2) The client does not need to specify "I want a sales order" in the
> accept
> > header (it does so by the URL it has selected).
> >
> > 3) The client must specify its capabilities (or the context in which it
> will
> > process the sales order). So it sends Accept:
> application/e-procurement+xml
> > (not application/salesorder+xml).
> >
> > 4) The server replies with a sales order and content-type
> > application/e-procurement+xml.
> >
> > 5) The client knows that a sales order in the context of
> > application/e-procurement+xml should be decoded in a certain way and does
> > so.
> >
> > Repeat step 1-5 with "sales order" replaced with
> > "bill/quote/reservation/etc" - but do not change the media type.
> >
> > Better now?
>
> Well, you can still go with more generic types, such as
> application/rdf+xml, where "shared understanding" ((domain) knowledge)
> is described in linked ontology specifications. However, besides concept
> definitions, additional descriptions for specific actions are probably
> required, e.g., by extending existing property (relations) definitions
> with this kind of information (e.g. as it can be realized with HAL or
> ALPS).
>


or we define (in the linked ontology spec or somewhere else; ideally
globally)  what is the meaning of each of the fixed set of operations
(GET/PUT/POST/DELETE)  for each concept. This is not usually defined by a
media type, and is prone to different interpretations, thus leading
to incompatibilities.

Regards,
Nina


>
> Cheers,
>
>
> Bo

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18298
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 12:05:40
Subject:Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> > Well, you can still go with more generic types, such as
> > application/rdf+xml, where "shared understanding" ((domain) knowledge)
> > is described in linked ontology specifications.

> or we define (in the linked ontology spec or somewhere else; ideally
> globally)  what is the meaning of each of the fixed set of operations
> (GET/PUT/POST/DELETE)  for each concept.

> This is not usually defined by a media type

Sorry, but isn't that exactly what is supposed to be defined by a media type? See for instance http://bitworking.org/projects/atom/rfc5023.html#collection_resource where POST/PUT/DELETE is defined for AtomPub

This seems more and more like re-inventing the exact reason for having media types - but hiding/tunneling it inside some generic format like application/xml.

You are right in the way that, yes, it can be done. But there should be no need for it when the same thing can be done with a properly defined media type.

If you build your application on top of HTTP, using it only for transport of data and using only predefined domain-agnostic formats like application/xml, then, yes, you would have to put the domain specific semantics "somewhere else".

If, on the other hand, you accept HTTP as an application protocol, then you can use the media type for defining your semantics.

But, apparently there are different views of HTTP as an application protocol or a simple data transfer layer?

/Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18299
Sender:Mark Derricutt <mark@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 12:33:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

My intention would be to tell the customer that he's been sent a
"customer", in JSON format.

What is a "customer", well - that would agreed upon by whatever contact
your service has.  Whether "customer" is something that gets IANA
registered as having a specific set of attributes or locally "registered"
for your service/enterprise, such as you would ( or should ) register link
rel types.

I'd see this is a vague intermediary step - just as a client makes
assumptions based on a spec on what following a link rel of "edit" may
return, so two could the assumptions of parsing a "customer" object.

If need be - the header could specialized further with:

Content-Disposition: inline; concept=customer; version=1.2; schema=http://
.....customer12.xsd


-- 
"Great artists are extremely selfish and arrogant things" â€” Steven Wilson,
Porcupine Tree

On Mon, Jan 2, 2012 at 11:14 PM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...
> wrote:

>  > Content-Type: application/json
> > Content-Disposition: inline; concept=customer
>
> And what exactly is this telling the consumer?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18300
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 12:39:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Jan 2, 2012, at 1:05 PM, Jorn Wildt wrote:

> > or we define (in the linked ontology spec or somewhere else; ideally
> > globally) what is the meaning of each of the fixed set of operations
> > (GET/PUT/POST/DELETE) for each concept.
> 
> > This is not usually defined by a media type
> 
> Sorry, but isn't that exactly what is supposed to be defined by a media type? See for instance http://bitworking.org/projects/atom/rfc5023.html#collection_resource where POST/PUT/DELETE is defined for AtomPub
> 

Yes, correct. Or more exactly: HTTP methods mean the same thing regardless of context (uniform interface). Resource semantics (the stuff you learn about resources from hypermedia references) is what is defined in media types (or link relation specs).

Media types ideally do not specify what methods to use for resources with certain semantics. That would be an over-specification because it is up to the server to make these decisions (and change them anytime).

Media type specs however can fruitfully provide hints to the canonical/intended use cases that informed the design of the media type in the first place. SHOULD requirements often reflect that and inform server developers about the most sensible implementation choices.

What you can specifiy in media types is which method a user agent developer should use for the implementation of a control (e.g. GET on HTML <a> links or <img>es, POST/GET for <form>s, depending on action parameter, etc. But there is no guarantee (aka coupling) that the server will actually support that message. (It should of course, because it sent the previous hypermedia in the first place :-)

If a request fails, HTTP provides error codes to hint the client how to fix its own configuration to match a particular service's implementation. This is an aspect that is unlikely to change and likely needs only be adjusted once per live time of the service.
(BTW, this IMHO indicates a conceptual third 'xxx-time' between design-time and run-time. You might think of it as 'introspection time' or 'configuration time'. OPTIONS requests relate to this. Nice area for research, IMO).

> This seems more and more like re-inventing the exact reason for having media types - but hiding/tunneling it inside some generic format like application/xml.
> 

Yes, exactly.

> You are right in the way that, yes, it can be done. But there should be no need for it when the same thing can be done with a properly defined media type.

Actually, strictly speaking there is no need for this in the media type either.

> 
> If you build your application on top of HTTP, using it only for transport of data and using only predefined domain-agnostic formats like application/xml, then, yes, you would have to put the domain specific semantics "somewhere else".

Yes, exactly.

> 
> If, on the other hand, you accept HTTP as an application protocol, then you can use the media type for defining your semantics.

Yes.

> 
> But, apparently there are different views of HTTP as an application protocol or a simple data transfer layer?

In my experience, it is still very common that people try to bend REST in order to match their view of a problem - instead of bending their view of the problem to make sense from a REST POV. Such bent-versions ('views' in your sentence) of REST are not necessarily bad, but they are not REST as it has been defined[1]. This can sometimes make approaching REST more confusing as it already usually is.

Jan


[1] And they consequently do not guarantee that you end up with a system that has the properties REST guarantees.

> 
> /Jørn
> 
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18301
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 12:55:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 2 January 2012 14:05, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> > > Well, you can still go with more generic types, such as
> > > application/rdf+xml, where "shared understanding" ((domain) knowledge)
> > > is described in linked ontology specifications.
>
> > or we define (in the linked ontology spec or somewhere else; ideally
> > globally) what is the meaning of each of the fixed set of operations
> > (GET/PUT/POST/DELETE) for each concept.
>
> > This is not usually defined by a media type
>
> Sorry, but isn't that exactly what is supposed to be defined by a media
> type? See for instance
> http://bitworking.org/projects/atom/rfc5023.html#collection_resourcewhere POST/PUT/DELETE is defined for AtomPub
>
> This seems more and more like re-inventing the exact reason for having
> media types - but hiding/tunneling it inside some generic format like
> application/xml.
>
> You are right in the way that, yes, it can be done. But there should be no
> need for it when the same thing can be done with a properly defined media
> type.
>
> If you build your application on top of HTTP, using it only for transport
> of data and using only predefined domain-agnostic formats like
> application/xml, then, yes, you would have to put the domain specific
> semantics "somewhere else".
>
> If, on the other hand, you accept HTTP as an application protocol, then
> you can use the media type for defining your semantics.
>

Speaking from experience,  POST/PUT/DELETE are (relatively) well defined
for document-style resources, which is absolutely to be expected.  AtomPub
fits the document/collection of documents design quite well. For anything
else, requiring slightly more sophisticated processing than just adding a
resource to a collection of resources, the semantic of the operations is
not defined by the HTTP RFC/media types, and in the best case is defined by
human readable means only ( API documentation).



>
>
> But, apparently there are different views of HTTP as an application
> protocol or a simple data transfer layer?
>

I find REST an elegant architecture style, especially because of the
addressable resources and the uniform interface.

However, HTTP as an application protocol is biased towards document
management.  Of course one could bend one's point of view, invent domain
specific media type and adopt the uniform interface for the domain
operations. This, however, does not mean the semantic of the HTTP methods
is the same regardless of context.

For example a POST operation may start some calculations, generating a new
resource, or start a whole new virtual machine instance.    Does that mean
the semantic of starting a virtual machine is the same as the semantic of
adding a new PDF document to a collection of documents ?


Regards,
Nina

P.S. my opinion may be of course biased.

>
> /JÃ¸rn
>
>  
>

Post ID:18302
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 13:05:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Jan 2, 2012, at 1:55 PM, Nina Jeliazkova wrote:

> For example a POST operation may start some calculations, generating a new resource, or start a whole new virtual machine instance.    Does that mean the semantic of starting a virtual machine is the same as the semantic of adding a new PDF document to a collection of documents ? 

The semantic of POST is always 'process this' no more, no less.


Jan




>

This is slightly different than what is defined by
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec9.html#sec9.5

Well, it 'process this' is the intention behind that. (POST is HTTP's catch-all
method if no other is specific enough)
Â 
The forthcoming HTTP spec clarifies this:
Â 
"

   The POST method requests that the origin server accept the representation
enclosed in the request as data to be processed by the target resource."


Â 
http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p2-semantics-17#section-6.5
Â 
Â POST has no visibility - the only thing you know as an observer is that the
target resource will deal with the request entity as it likes.
Â

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18305
Sender:Benjamin Hawkes-Lewis <bhawkeslewis@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 13:33:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Mon, Jan 2, 2012 at 12:33 PM, Mark Derricutt <mark@...> wrote:
> My intention would be to tell the customer that he's been sent a "customer", in JSON format.

[snip]

> I'd see this is a vague intermediary step - just as a client makes assumptions based on a spec on what following a link rel of "edit" may return, so two could the assumptions of parsing a "customer" object.
>
> If need be - the header could specialized further with:
>
> Content-Disposition: inline; concept=customer; version=1.2; schema=http://.....customer12.xsd

It looks suspiciously like you're trying to solve the same problem as:

   - The "profile" content-type parameter in JSON schema:

       https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-zyp-json-schema-03

       http://json-schema.org/

   - The "profile" link relationship (seemingly not IANA registered):

       http://microformats.org/wiki/profile-uris

       http://microformats.org/wiki/rel-profile

       http://microformats.org/wiki/existing-rel-values

Media type specialisation (via a "profile" parameter) allows
server-side content negotiation based on Accept.

I guess the "profile" and "alternate" link relationships require
clients to download multiple versions to perform client-side content
selection. But if the goal is less content negotiation than defining
which vocabulary is actually in use, the profile relationship works
fine and can provided out-of-band via the Link HTTP header.

--
Benjamin Hawkes-Lewis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Post ID:18307
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 13:55:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:


Â 


Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...> hat am 2. Januar 2012 um 14:34
geschrieben:

> On 2 January 2012 15:27, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
>
> > **
> >
> >
> >
> > Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...> hat am 2. Januar 2012 um
> > 14:11 geschrieben:
> >
> > > On 2 January 2012 15:05, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > >
> > > > On Jan 2, 2012, at 1:55 PM, Nina Jeliazkova wrote:
> > > >
> > > > > For example a POST operation may start some calculations, generating
> > a
> > > > new resource, or start a whole new virtual machine instance.Â  Â  Does
> > that
> > > > mean the semantic of starting a virtual machine is the same as the
> > semantic
> > > > of adding a new PDF document to a collection of documents ?
> > > >
> > > > The semantic of POST is always 'process this' no more, no less.
> > > >
> > >
> > >
> > > This is slightly different than what is defined by
> > > http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec9.html#sec9.5
> >
> >
> >
> > Well, it 'process this' is the intention behind that. (POST is HTTP's
> > catch-all method if no other is specific enough)
> >
>
>
> Yes, but having to look for the "intention behind" is exactly the problem
> of not-well-defined protocol forÂ  the purposes of specific application.Â 
Nina, you have to understand that 'process this' *is* the purpose of the
specific application (from the application protocol POV).
Â 
What you are looking for is intent and that is manifested in the choice of
target resource in the first place.
Â 
Jan
Â 
Â 

>
> Regards,
> Nina
>
>
>
> >
> >
> > The forthcoming HTTP spec clarifies this:
> >
> >
> >
> > "
> >
> >Â  Â  The POST method requests that the origin server accept the representation
> >enclosed in the request as data to be processed by the target resource."
> >
> >
> >
> > http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p2-semantics-17#section-6.5
> >
> >
> >
> >Â  POST has no visibility - the only thing you know as an observer is that
> > the target resource will deal with the request entity as it likes.
> >
> >
> >
> > Jan
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >Â  >
> > > Regards,
> > > Nina

Post ID:18310
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-02 18:01:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Different vocabularies, same media type
Message:

Hi,

maybe the new HTML Data Guide draft will also give some interesting 
impressions on that topic, see

https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/htmldata/raw-file/default/html-data-guide/index.html

Cheers,


Bo


On 12/28/2011 11:05 PM, mike amundsen wrote:
> Jorn:
>
> i think you did a good job of summing up the opinions presented here.
>
> since i don't run into this often in my current work (using a single
> media type and multiple "vocabularies" to represent the same problem
> domain details), i am most interested in the solution you end up
> creating. hopefully, you will be able to share not just the outcome
> ("we decided to go with 'x' approach and here's why...") but also the
> process ("at first we did y, then discovered it didn't work for z, so
> we adjusted to x...").
>
> i think your adventure would be very interesting and i suspect many
> others would, too.
>
> thanks.
>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
> On Wed, Dec 28, 2011 at 16:22, Jorn Wildt <jw@...
> <mailto:jw%40fjeldgruppen.dk>> wrote:
>  > There has been lots of valuable feed back on this thread. Thanks a
> lot to everybody who has contributed! Hopefully you now understand the
> problem :-)
>  >
>  > The suggested solutions has been:
>  >
>  > 1) Mint a new media type.
>  >
>  > Apparently there are two different schools here. Some say, yes, go
> for a new media type. Some say, no don't. And there is no agreement upon
> which is best. See
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/18183 for a
> discussion of this.
>  >
>  > 2) Use different URIs for the different vocabularies.
>  >
>  > This seems like an easy and well understood solution. As Mike puts
> it: "in my experience, attempts to do "multiple things" while using the
> same URI are not often successful" (meaning, "go for multiple URIs").
>  >
>  > 3) Switch on a media type parameter in the accept header (as for
> instance "application/xhtml+xml;profile=xxx").
>  >
>  > To me this seems like the most elegant solution - if it works. Some
> people argue that the ";profile=xxx" parameter may get stripped by
> intermediaries in the network. It has the advantages of minting a new
> media type, but none of the drawbacks since it is still a well known
> media type (if this is the right interpretation of the syntax!)
>  >
>  > 4) Switch on other headers like for instance the user-agent.
>  >
>  > Not a generally used solution.
>  >
>  > 5) Use all vocabularies in the same document.
>  >
>  > To me this seems too clumsy.
>  >
>  > /Jï¿½rn

terminology here more than anything.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18313
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 03:38:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hiya,

"Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> I know what you meant. I also know what Nina meant, and I'm pretty
> sure you did too. This kind of pedantry doesn't help anyone; it's just
distracting.

Hmm, this isn't pedantry; this is about getting it right, repeated often
and yet - for some infuriating reason - seldom practiced. REST has a bunch
of constraints and concepts, and all the crap "REST" out there is *because*
people don't tak these details seriously. I think these subtle details are
*immensely* important to point out and to take seriously. Otherwise, you
aren't doing REST but some hybrid nonsense crap wannabe pretend REST. I
prefer and will always promote the former, and I'm mighty glad there's
people on this list who won't back down just because someone doesn't like
the level of detail at various parts of the stack.

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18314
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 09:54:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:38 AM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
> Hiya,
>
> "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> I know what you meant. I also know what Nina meant, and I'm pretty
>> sure you did too. This kind of pedantry doesn't help anyone; it's just
>> distracting.
>
> Hmm, this isn't pedantry; this is about getting it right, repeated often and
> yet - for some infuriating reason - seldom practiced. REST has a bunch of
> constraints and concepts, and all the crap "REST" out there is *because*
> people don't tak these details seriously. I think these subtle details are
> *immensely* important to point out and to take seriously. Otherwise, you
> aren't doing REST but some hybrid nonsense crap wannabe pretend REST. I
> prefer and will always promote the former, and I'm mighty glad there's
> people on this list who won't back down just because someone doesn't like
> the level of detail at various parts of the stack.
>

No, not in this particular case.

There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
of POST requests vary for different resources". The key is that those
varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
clarification.

I definitely agree though, there are some REST constraints and
concepts that are misused. This seems to happen frequently with terms
like 'visibility' and 'self-descriptive' :)

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18315
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 10:31:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 11:54, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:38 AM, Alexander Johannesen
> <alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
>> Hiya,
>>
>> "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>>> I know what you meant. I also know what Nina meant, and I'm pretty
>>> sure you did too. This kind of pedantry doesn't help anyone; it's just
>>> distracting.
>>
>> Hmm, this isn't pedantry; this is about getting it right, repeated often and
>> yet - for some infuriating reason - seldom practiced. REST has a bunch of
>> constraints and concepts, and all the crap "REST" out there is *because*
>> people don't tak these details seriously. I think these subtle details are
>> *immensely* important to point out and to take seriously. Otherwise, you
>> aren't doing REST but some hybrid nonsense crap wannabe pretend REST. I
>> prefer and will always promote the former, and I'm mighty glad there's
>> people on this list who won't back down just because someone doesn't like
>> the level of detail at various parts of the stack.
>>
>
> No, not in this particular case.
>
> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
> of POST requests vary for different resources". The key is that those
> varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
> only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
> not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
> clarification.
>

Thank you.

The critical point is how the shared understanding between client and
server is achieved, and whether the "network-visible" semantic is
sufficient for the shared understanding.

In this thread it was argued the the semantic of REST operations
should be defined by media type.  I would argue this is impractical,
unless one has full control of the media types definitions one works
with.

Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
generated image could be retrieved.  Where should the rich semantic of
the POST be defined, behind the network-level-visible "process this" ?
I guess it doesn't make sense to define it in the generic image/*
media type. Another option is the resource API documentation (most
probably not machine readable).  Yet another option is to define a
separate image media type, which is handled by this specific resource
only.  Any other options?
How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
only?

Now replace the image with any domain-specific scientific data
representation (meaning one would not like to invent new media types
to represent complex data which already exists in multiple formats and
could be processed in multiple ways). Where do we define the semantic
of the "type of processing"?   Human readable documentation of what is
the processing resource intent?

> I definitely agree though, there are some REST constraints and
> concepts that are misused. This seems to happen frequently with terms
> like 'visibility' and 'self-descriptive' :)
>

IMHO any software architecture would benefit enormously, if defining
all critical points explicitly, rather than playing the game of
interpretation.

Regards,
Nina

> Cheers,
> Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18316
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:07:53
Subject:Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> The critical point is how the shared understanding between client and
> server is achieved, and whether the "network-visible" semantic is
> sufficient for the shared understanding.

Yes.

> Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
> certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
> generated image could be retrieved.

> How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
> wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
> only?

I would say the link-reltype that points to the page that accepts the POST.

The link-reltypes would be documented in the media-type spec.

It could go like this:

1) Client GETs image processing descriptor resource.

2) Server returns media-type "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml". Now the client has a shared understanding with server about the server's capabilities.

3) The client selects a proper link from the response using link-reltypes documented in the media-type spec.

4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.

All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.

/Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18317
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:10:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hola,

"Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> No, not in this particular case.

I dare say, that is your opinion, of course. However, there's something
slightly bigger at stake here. IMHO, of course.

> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
> of POST requests vary for different resources".

The semantics of *what* about POST, exactly? This is where I see a subtle
rift in the space-time continuum that threatens to divide RESTafarians
everywhere. There's choices in resources as gateways into larger HATEOS
frameworks or as those subtler resources themselves, resources as APIs
themselves, and so on, all along the scale of correctness from bad to good;
the only semantics that REST cares about is "process this". Whatever you
place on top is your business, and exist in the ontology layer (with vocab
names / schemas / RDF(x) / whatever.

Again; it is *important* to point out that *REST* has no more semantics on
a resource than "process this". Get this wrong, and you start blaming REST
for problems that exists elsewhere.

> The key is that those
> varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
> only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
> not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
> clarification.

You think it is small. Some of us think it is subtle - for sure - but
rather important. As soon as you think REST (or your favourite REST
implementation, like HTTP) carries semantics outside of the generic methods
and the generic response codes, you will blame it for all of your own
failings, and you might just miss out on the magic of REST in the process.

Again, all those semantics you talk about are supposed to be in the
content-type of the request and the content negotiation with given
resources. This is one area in which cool URIs are misleading.

> I definitely agree though, there are some REST constraints and
> concepts that are misused. This seems to happen frequently with terms
> like 'visibility' and 'self-descriptive' :)

Well, I personally think that most people who understand REST, do not
understand REST, most probably myself included. It's a nice set of
constraints and methods that, when combined, gives awesome benefits, but
trying to explain the whole cake by pointing out its ingrediants will never
convince anyone.

The terms you point to are, in fact, quite often used more correct when
spoken, but not so much when heard, but that's just a side effect of having
poorly separated the REST fundamentals from the ontology and the
application specific noise. In terms of REST, visibility and portions being
self-descriptive is spot on - but in a strict REST sense, not the ontology
sense.

In other words, I can claim that POST on a given resource is
self-descriptive, as in "process this", but when other people hear me say
it, it comes across as "the ontology payload describes the resource and its
links", which is a different beast all-together.

Anyway, that was a long-winded way of agree with you on that sentiment. :)

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18318
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:17:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 13:07, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> > The critical point is how the shared understanding between client and
> > server is achieved, and whether the "network-visible" semantic is
> > sufficient for the shared understanding.
>
> Yes.
>
>
> > Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
> > certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
> > generated image could be retrieved.
>
> > How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
> > wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
> > only?
>
> I would say the link-reltype that points to the page that accepts the POST.
>
> The link-reltypes would be documented in the media-type spec.
>
> It could go like this:
>
> 1) Client GETs image processing descriptor resource.
>
> 2) Server returns media-type "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml". Now the
> client has a shared understanding with server about the server's
> capabilities.
>
> 3) The client selects a proper link from the response using link-reltypes
> documented in the media-type spec.
>
> 4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.
>
> All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.
>

OK, sounds theoretically reasonable.

Except still being impractical.  It will not be
"application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml"
, but hundreds of  "application/vnd.image_blur+xml" ,
"application/vnd.image_crop+xml"
,  "application/vnd.image_wavelet+xml", you name it, to represent every
single image processing supported.

Nina


>
> /JÃ¸rn
>
>  
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18319
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:20:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hiya,

"Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
> Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
> certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
> generated image could be retrieved.  Where should the rich semantic of
> the POST be defined, behind the network-level-visible "process this" ?

What beyond "process this" are you referring to? Because I'm starting to
suspect you're talking about something more like API documentation?

> How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
> wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
> only?

Well, we're back to the moniker "this isn't a REST problem". Here's how I
do it, though; I've got certain resources as gateways into HATEOAS, and
further resources are documented as XHTML forms with links and RDFa as to
what to do with those resources and what to expect. There's a small
ontology of RDF which documents the API. That's it. It's small, RESTful,
and I can change it at will and with need - provided my clients are smart
enough to be RESTful first, and worry about semantics of resources second.

Kind regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18320
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:40:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 11:10 AM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
> Hola,
>
> "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> No, not in this particular case.
>
> I dare say, that is your opinion, of course. However, there's something
> slightly bigger at stake here. IMHO, of course.
>
>> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
>> of POST requests vary for different resources".
>
> The semantics of *what* about POST, exactly?

No, no - this is about the semantics of *specific requests* that use
the POST method. Not about the semantics of POST itself.

> This is where I see a subtle
> rift in the space-time continuum that threatens to divide RESTafarians
> everywhere. There's choices in resources as gateways into larger HATEOS
> frameworks or as those subtler resources themselves, resources as APIs
> themselves, and so on, all along the scale of correctness from bad to good;
> the only semantics that REST cares about is "process this". Whatever you
> place on top is your business, and exist in the ontology layer (with vocab
> names / schemas / RDF(x) / whatever.
>
> Again; it is *important* to point out that *REST* has no more semantics on a
> resource than "process this". Get this wrong, and you start blaming REST for
> problems that exists elsewhere.

REST is an architectural style, I guess you mean HTTP. If so, I agree
with you and that was basically my point. There are more semantics in
a given request than those that HTTP gives us. HTTP gives us
network-visible semantics, that is its purpose. The additional
semantics in a given request are not network-visible (but,
importantly, so what?).

>> The key is that those
>> varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
>> only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
>> not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
>> clarification.
>
> You think it is small. Some of us think it is subtle - for sure - but rather
> important. As soon as you think REST (or your favourite REST implementation,
> like HTTP) carries semantics outside of the generic methods and the generic
> response codes, you will blame it for all of your own failings, and you
> might just miss out on the magic of REST in the process.
>
> Again, all those semantics you talk about are supposed to be in the
> content-type of the request and the content negotiation with given
> resources. This is one area in which cool URIs are misleading.

Unless you have a distinct media type identifier to cover every single
semantic in your application (or intent, etc.), then those semantics
will not be visible and can only be determined by the client and
server (via a contextual, shared understanding about the resource in
question) - whether that shared understanding is buried within the
semantics of a media type or a preceding link relation does not change
this.

The actually important consideration (which I have tried to bring up
several times now and had no response on) is whether or not this loss
in network visibility of intended semantics in the request is actually
a concern. The argument in favour of using new specific types seems to
imply that making the intent visible on the network is both possible
and desirable. I don't think either of those assumptions holds true:

1. network visibility is valuable because it facilitates intermediate
processing (stuff like caching, ESI, etc.)  all of these mechanisms
are generic and non-specific.
2. as I argued above; unless you have a specific media type for every
individual semantic, there is still ambiguity in the message and you
won't get more 'visibility' anyway.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18321
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:48:48
Subject:Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> > 3) The client selects a proper link from the response using link-reltypes
> > documented in the media-type spec.
> >
> > 4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.
> >
> > All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.
> >
> 
> OK, sounds theoretically reasonable.
> 
> Except still being impractical.  It will not be
> "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml"
> , but hundreds of  "application/vnd.image_blur+xml" ,
> "application/vnd.image_crop+xml"
> ,  "application/vnd.image_wavelet+xml", you name it, to represent every
> single image processing supported.

No, sorry, you got this wrong. Check step (3) again: "The client selects a proper link from the response using link-reltypes.

So the variation is on the link-reltype NOT the media-type. That's very very different. There's a gazillion link-reltypes, but only a small-ish set of media-types.

The client will POST the image as standard media-type image/png (or image/[jpg|gif|tiff|...]) - not as "application/vnd.image_blur+xml".

The server will know what to do with the image by knowing what URL it was posted to.

/Jørn

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
>
> On 3 January 2012 13:07, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> > > The critical point is how the shared understanding between client and
> > > server is achieved, and whether the "network-visible" semantic is
> > > sufficient for the shared understanding.
> >
> > Yes.
> >
> >
> > > Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
> > > certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
> > > generated image could be retrieved.
> >
> > > How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
> > > wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
> > > only?
> >
> > I would say the link-reltype that points to the page that accepts the POST.
> >
> > The link-reltypes would be documented in the media-type spec.
> >
> > It could go like this:
> >
> > 1) Client GETs image processing descriptor resource.
> >
> > 2) Server returns media-type "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml". Now the
> > client has a shared understanding with server about the server's
> > capabilities.
> >
> > 3) The client selects a proper link from the response using link-reltypes
> > documented in the media-type spec.
> >
> > 4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.
> >
> > All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.
> >
> 
> OK, sounds theoretically reasonable.
> 
> Except still being impractical.  It will not be
> "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml"
> , but hundreds of  "application/vnd.image_blur+xml" ,
> "application/vnd.image_crop+xml"
> ,  "application/vnd.image_wavelet+xml", you name it, to represent every
> single image processing supported.
> 
> Nina

Post ID:18322
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 11:50:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 13:07, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:
>
>> **
>>
>>
>> > The critical point is how the shared understanding between client and
>> > server is achieved, and whether the "network-visible" semantic is
>> > sufficient for the shared understanding.
>>
>> Yes.
>>
>>
>> > Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
>> > certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
>> > generated image could be retrieved.
>>
>> > How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
>> > wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
>> > only?
>>
>> I would say the link-reltype that points to the page that accepts the
>> POST.
>>
>> The link-reltypes would be documented in the media-type spec.
>>
>> It could go like this:
>>
>> 1) Client GETs image processing descriptor resource.
>>
>> 2) Server returns media-type "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml". Now
>> the client has a shared understanding with server about the server's
>> capabilities.
>>
>> 3) The client selects a proper link from the response using link-reltypes
>> documented in the media-type spec.
>>
>> 4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.
>>
>> All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.
>>
>
Hi Jorn,

In this example the shared understanding is really coming from the link
relations. Link relations can exist independently from the media type,
which is how shared understanding is established when using generic
(hyper)media types.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18323
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:04:09
Subject:Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

>The argument in favour of using new specific types seems to
> imply that making the intent visible on the network is both possible
> and desirable. I don't think either of those assumptions holds true

And this is also a critical question of this discussion.

Media-types like images benefit from network visibility - for instance when using the Opera Mini browser that depends on Operas servers to reduce the size of the images on the network.

But it is hard to argue that network visibility is desirable with examples of more problem domain specific media types (like for instance application/vnd.imageprocessing+xml) since we cannot come up with good use cases for that. But allow me to try anyway ...

Assume we have two companies working together on e-commerce, but due to historical reasons they use different domain specific media-types. If these types are visible on the network then we can (in theory) have transparent/invisible intermediates that transform back-and-forth when communicating with the other business. Just as we can transform images.

The same could of course be done on the clients instead of inside the network - but Opera Mini do not do that for good reasons.

Using network visible media-types opens up for use cases that we cannot imagine right now. Like the Opera Mini use case.

/Jørn

Post ID:18324
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:10:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 13:48, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> > > 3) The client selects a proper link from the response using
> link-reltypes
> > > documented in the media-type spec.
> > >
> > > 4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.
> > >
> > > All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.
> > >
> >
> > OK, sounds theoretically reasonable.
> >
> > Except still being impractical. It will not be
> > "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml"
> > , but hundreds of "application/vnd.image_blur+xml" ,
> > "application/vnd.image_crop+xml"
> > , "application/vnd.image_wavelet+xml", you name it, to represent every
> > single image processing supported.
>
> No, sorry, you got this wrong. Check step (3) again: "The client selects a
> proper link from the response using link-reltypes.
>
> So the variation is on the link-reltype NOT the media-type. That's very
> very different. There's a gazillion link-reltypes, but only a small-ish set
> of media-types.

> posted to.

Agree, my bad, it's link-reltypes.

Next step is to imagine there is somebody else' resource, also offering
similar type of processing.  A client would like to compare results , when
applying similar processing by both services (very typical use case, if
thinking of scientific data processing).

What would make the second service use the same shared understanding of
image processing media type / link-reltypes, if he is free to invent its
own?  This is what I call semantic - shared meaning of certain operations.
 Without this, all single REST resources live in their own silos,
regardless of how RESTful they are.

Nina

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18325
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:13:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Jan 3, 2012, at 10:54 AM, Mike Kelly wrote:

> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
> of POST requests vary for different resources".

See, this is where you get it wrong. The semantics of the request are always the same. The is no shared understanding that the server needs to know about. The server only receives a 'process this' request and the target resource will process the request entity. The server does not need to care about anything else.

The client develops an expectation (from previous hypermedia) about the effect of the POST request, but that expectation is just that: an expectation. And it might fail anytime.

Talking about 'shared understanding' or 'varying semantics of POST requests' implies that there are application level semantics on top of HTTP. There are not, HTTP is all the contract there is.



> The key is that those
> varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
> only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
> not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
> clarification.

HTTP is not 'the network' (transport) it is an application protocol (transfer) and there are no application semantics layered on top. (Except when you treat HTTP as transfer, of course. As WS-* does)

What you are getting wrong, I think, is who knows about the particular applications being executed. You seem to think that server and client have a shared understanding about the application (e.g. buying a book at Amazon). They do not. Knowledge about the application in a RESTful system is only located on the client. The server has no idea what application a client is progressing through when it sends that POST. The POST means just this 'process this' and the given target resource will act on the POST as it sees fit.

The client then processes the response with expectations originating from the application the client is in. The server knows nor shares absolutely nothing about these expectations and has no obligation other than to 'process this'.

--

The hypermedia you learned from that /123 is an 'image processor' need not even come from the same server, you might have received it any number of ways. The server of that /123 resource will not expect that you learned anything about this resource. It will just invoke the mapping function (the resource) based on the current request.

There is no context and no shared understanding.

Jan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18326
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:21:00
Subject:Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> What would make the second service use the same shared understanding of
> image processing media type / link-reltypes, if he is free to invent its
> own?

Regarding the media-type: REST states that media-types should be registered with a central authority (IANA, Enterprise, what ever). When registering new media-types the authority checks for duplicates - or sets up a procedure for avoiding them. This is REST's way of reducing the problem (I don't believe it goes away completely - but the problem becomes smaller).

Some link-reltypes are document together with the media type (as Mike points out, link-reltypes can exist outside any media-type - see http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xml).

So when the client originally sent the Accept-header with application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml) it told the server to return a representation that contains link-reltypes documented in the media-type spec. Other link-reltypes are of course allowed, but may be ignored by the client.

So, again, the media-type becomes the turning point.

/Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18327
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:38:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 14:21, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> > What would make the second service use the same shared understanding of
> > image processing media type / link-reltypes, if he is free to invent its
> > own?
>
> Regarding the media-type: REST states that media-types should be
> registered with a central authority (IANA, Enterprise, what ever). When
> registering new media-types the authority checks for duplicates - or sets
> up a procedure for avoiding them. This is REST's way of reducing the
> problem (I don't believe it goes away completely - but the problem becomes
> smaller).
>
> Some link-reltypes are document together with the media type (as Mike
> points out, link-reltypes can exist outside any media-type - see
> http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xml).
>
> So when the client originally sent the Accept-header with
> application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml) it told the server to return a
> representation that contains link-reltypes documented in the media-type
> spec. Other link-reltypes are of course allowed, but may be ignored by the
> client.
>
> So, again, the media-type becomes the turning point.
>


OK, then it takes a centralized global registry to allow / enforce a shared
semantic.  Which is not necessary REST related problem at all and is often
futile, when there is no incentive from the participating players.

Besides, I doubt registering new specific media types is universally
practiced by REST services developers. Otherwise, IANA registry would have
been sufficient, and no need for catalogues as
http://www.programmableweb.com/ or http://www.biocatalogue.org/ .

Nina


>
> /JÃ¸rn
>
>  
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18328
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:47:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 13:20, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hiya,
>
> "Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
>> Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
>> certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
>> generated image could be retrieved. Â Where should the rich semantic of
>> the POST be defined, behind the network-level-visible "process this" ?
>
> What beyond "process this" are you referring to? Because I'm starting to
> suspect you're talking about something more like API documentation?
>

Machine readable API documentation as a start. With semantic capabilities ;)

e.g.  I am able to search and find web pages under certain criteria,
but not for web services, providing certain functionality.
There are registration sites for APIs, which roughly reminds me the
pre-search engines epoch of the WWW, or manually updating  'hosts'
files for managing IP address - domain name resolving.

>> How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
>> wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
>> only?
>
> Well, we're back to the moniker "this isn't a REST problem".

Well, it should be, otherwise a distributed architecture is largely
useless. Unless we are assuming any REST system is an isolated server
or server farm, running under single authority, and all potential
users and clients are aware of it and love to read its documentation.

Finding resources is critical part of any network architecture. If I
do not know nothing of Amazon, and there is no any search engine
available,  how I am supposed to find where to buy online books? Even
how I am supposed to know I _could_ buy books online?


> Here's how I do
> it, though; I've got certain resources as gateways into HATEOAS, and further
> resources are documented as XHTML forms with links and RDFa as to what to do
> with those resources and what to expect. There's a small ontology of RDF
> which documents the API. That's it. It's small, RESTful, and I can change it
> at will and with need - provided my clients are smart enough to be RESTful
> first, and worry about semantics of resources second.
>

Well, we do roughly the same, each resource describing itself with
RDF, according to a specific ontology. But I would not say this is the
mainstream approach.

Best regards,
Nina

> Kind regards,
>
> Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18329
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 12:51:09
Subject:Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> OK, then it takes a centralized global registry to allow / enforce a shared
> semantic.  Which is not necessary REST related problem at all and is often
> futile, when there is no incentive from the participating players.

Yep. Its not a perfect world. And it is a perfect example of what happens when you break the REST constraints: by not registering with a central authority (and sticking to it) we get too many overlapping media-types.

> Besides, I doubt registering new specific media types is universally
> practiced by REST services developers. 

Certainly not (and I am guilty as charged in this matter).

> Otherwise, IANA registry would have
> been sufficient, and no need for catalogues as
> http://www.programmableweb.com/ or http://www.biocatalogue.org/ .

Well, to be a bit pedantic: these are not media-type catalogues, they are service catalouges, meaning they tell you where to find a specific service. Had it been a perfect world then all the "life science" services would communicate using the same set of media-types - but it would still be useful with catalogoues for discovery of the services.

It is more or less the same as the difference between a phone book and the network protocol used by the phones.

/Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18330
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 13:01:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi Jan,

Comments inline:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 12:13 PM, Jan Algermissen
<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
>
> On Jan 3, 2012, at 10:54 AM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>
>> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
>> of POST requests vary for different resources".
>
> See, this is where you get it wrong. The semantics of the request are always the same.

As I explained; the _network-visible semantics_ are always the same
from POST's definition in HTTP. HTTP will likely provide other types
of visible semantic such as conditionality, content-length, etc.

But - the intent/application semantics/whatever-word-you-want of POST
requests aren't the same between resources. For example; the meaning
of a POST to a resource that constructs hover-donkeys is not the same
as the meaning of a POST to a resource which submits condescending,
rhetoric-filled posts to a mailing list.

> The is no shared understanding that the server needs to know about.

Of course there is - a server has to establish a specific
understanding of an incoming POST body to a resource in order to
process it in a specific way.

> The server only receives a 'process this' request and the target resource will process the request entity. The server does not need to care about anything else.

What distinction are you drawing between the processing the 'server'
does and the processing the 'resource' does, and why? I find your
interpretation extremely confused, personally.

> The client develops an expectation (from previous hypermedia) about the effect of the POST request, but that expectation is just that: an expectation. And it might fail anytime.

Yes, this should comprise part of a shared understanding.

> Talking about 'shared understanding' or 'varying semantics of POST requests' implies that there are application level semantics on top of HTTP. There are not, HTTP is all the contract there is.
>

If by 'application level' you mean 'Layer 7 in the OSI model', then
what are we required to use for this? There are already uses of
"application" beyond OSI; such as the one in 'hypermedia as the engine
of application state'.

>> The key is that those
>> varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
>> only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
>> not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
>> clarification.
>
> HTTP is not 'the network' (transport) it is an application protocol (transfer) and there are no application semantics layered on top. (Except when you treat HTTP as transfer, of course. As WS-* does)
>
> What you are getting wrong, I think, is who knows about the particular applications being executed. You seem to think that server and client have a shared understanding about the application (e.g. buying a book at Amazon). They do not. Knowledge about the application in a RESTful system is only located on the client. The server has no idea what application a client is progressing through when it sends that POST. The POST means just this 'process this' and the given target resource will act on the POST as it sees fit.
>

Is there another way to express this, I can't make head nor tail of
it. I think the confusion might relate to your distinction between
processing 'by the server' vs by 'the resource'?

> The client then processes the response with expectations originating from the application the client is in. The server knows nor shares absolutely nothing about these expectations and has no obligation other than to 'process this'.

How can the clients expectation about what and how a given resource
will process a request (success or failure), and how that resource
actually processes the requests not involve shared understanding?

> The hypermedia you learned from that /123 is an 'image processor' need not even come from the same server, you might have received it any number of ways. The server of that /123 resource will not expect that you learned anything about this resource. It will just invoke the mapping function (the resource) based on the current request.
>

Unless it was an entry point, a client needs some for of shared
understanding in order to know what it was meant to POST there?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18331
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 13:44:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Jan 3, 2012, at 2:01 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:

>> The is no shared understanding that the server needs to know about.
> 
> Of course there is - a server has to establish a specific
> understanding of an incoming POST body to a resource in order to
> process it in a specific way.

When was the last time you implemented a POST handler of a resource and thought in any way about what the client expects?

Answer: "never"; because it is completely up to the resource what to do upon POST.

What you call 'shared understanding' is not shared (no obligation on the server) it is only an expectation the client has.

That expectation manifests itself by the particular choice of resource, yes - but the server knows nothing about that expectation nor does it care.

What I am trying to say: there is no contract layered on top of HTTP that ensures successful interaction. Instead, REST deliberately lets go of that kind of coupling because it cannot be achieved in networked systems.

REST only makes explicit that the server cannot be guaranteed to adhere to such a contract without introducing a level of coupling that makes it impossible for the server to evolve without telling all clients up-front.

Jan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18332
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 13:43:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> > The semantics of *what* about POST, exactly?

"Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> No, no - this is about the semantics of *specific requests* that use
> the POST method. Not about the semantics of POST itself.

Ahem, I think you're responding a bit fast. :)  My point was exactly this;
in REST, there are no semantics to specific requests any more than to
generic ones. Every POST is "process this" to the server, the payload is
interpreted and processed, but the POST is still the ambigous, context-free
(apart from the URI and content-type) request. All POSTs are the same to
REST, and that IS ITS SECRET WEAPON!

> There are more semantics in
> a given request than those that HTTP gives us. HTTP gives us
> network-visible semantics, that is its purpose. The additional
> semantics in a given request are not network-visible (but,
> importantly, so what?).

Well, I think we agree on the statement that there's more to the POST than
what REST / HTTP gives us ... most of the time, however to make the point a
bit more concrete, here's an example ;

   POST /458745485 "46"

For some people here, this lack of specifics looks like a problem. To me,
it looked like a problem for a very long time, until, like Jan, I dived in
and embraced HATEOAS. It's *there* that semantics exists, not in the POST,
not in the request itself. The focus should be on the model, never on the
conversation, so to speak.

I find that until one grasps HATEOAS, you tend to treat things as clients
and servers. After a little while you realize that those roles flip back
and forth depending on your data, that client and server are less carved in
stone. Another thing is also that you stop treating this client / server
divide as a mostly one way communication, like with a more traditional API.

> Unless you have a distinct media type identifier to cover every single
> semantic in your application (or intent, etc.), then those semantics
> will not be visible and can only be determined by the client and
> server (via a contextual, shared understanding about the resource in
> question) - whether that shared understanding is buried within the
> semantics of a media type or a preceding link relation does not change
> this.

If I request a generic resource and get back a map of FORMs with RDFa, what
more do I need?

> The actually important consideration (which I have tried to bring up
> several times now and had no response on) is whether or not this loss
> in network visibility of intended semantics in the request is actually
> a concern.

You have been answered, but I don't think you agree with them, so you keep
fighting the good fight, I assume. :)

> The argument in favour of using new specific types seems to
> imply that making the intent visible on the network is both possible
> and desirable.

I think we all agree that no one solution is fit for all, and that one
should try to balance out the degree to which you split your semantics into
protocol vs. application. New content types makes sense if there isn't one
that adresses what you're doing. I mentioned earlier that the more specific
you can be, the less resources you will need to process them, but I won't
give you a clear binary answer here. Reach out with your feelings, Mike.

> I don't think either of those assumptions holds true:
>
> 1. network visibility is valuable because it facilitates intermediate
> processing (stuff like caching, ESI, etc.)  all of these mechanisms
> are generic and non-specific.

Hmm, I think I've lost you there. How does the content-type mean any HTTP
request is treated as a special case (or, non-specific)?

> 2. as I argued above; unless you have a specific media type for every
> individual semantic, there is still ambiguity in the message and you
> won't get more 'visibility' anyway.

Surely you don't think a black and white answer could possibly be correct?
The job of the good architect is to find the right balance between the
ambiguity of network transparancy and the specificy of application
semantics. Yes?

Regards,

Alex

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Jan 3, 2012, at 2:43 PM, Alexander Johannesen wrote:

> All POSTs are the same to REST, and that IS ITS SECRET WEAPON!

Amen :-)

Jan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18334
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 13:52:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hiya,

> "this isn't a REST problem".

"Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
> Well, it should be, otherwise a distributed architecture is largely
> useless.

Hmm. Sounds like you underestimate the usefulness of the massively
distributed architecture called Internet. :)

> Unless we are assuming any REST system is an isolated server
> or server farm, running under single authority, and all potential
> users and clients are aware of it and love to read its documentation.

The ambiguity of REST/HTTP is exactly why it *is* so powerful as a concept.
Yes, you have to work a little harder on the application semantics and the
glue of the ontology layer, but it comes with the amazing bonus of all the
goodness of WWW. Surely, we can't ignore its success? It's the ease of
working with it, of setting it up, and the ambigous nature of each request
(that can be tunneled through anything) and the constraints on them (for
cacheability, etc.) that makes that possible.

> Finding resources is critical part of any network architecture. If I
> do not know nothing of Amazon, and there is no any search engine
> available,  how I am supposed to find where to buy online books? Even
> how I am supposed to know I _could_ buy books online?

But why are you raising these what-if questions? Do you have some scenarios
that you are concretely struggeling with, or are good examples of HTTP gone
bad? I fear I do not understand "what if there are no search engines",
because there are.

> Well, we do roughly the same, each resource describing itself with
> RDF, according to a specific ontology. But I would not say this is the
> mainstream approach.

Depends on where you dip your toe. But even if that was true, does that
make it wrong?

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18335
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 14:28:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hello,

On 3 January 2012 15:52, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
> Hiya,
>
>> "this isn't a REST problem".
>
> "Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
>> Well, it should be, otherwise a distributed architecture is largely
>> useless.
>
> Hmm. Sounds like you underestimate the usefulness of the massively
> distributed architecture called Internet. :)

Internet became massively useful after 1) distributed name resolution
called DNS was invented and 2) search engines became powerful enough.

>
>> Unless we are assuming any REST system is an isolated server
>> or server farm, running under single authority, and all potential
>> users and clients are aware of it and love to read its documentation.
>
> The ambiguity of REST/HTTP is exactly why it *is* so powerful as a concept.

AFAIK , REST is not defined as HTTP specific, on the contrary.

> Yes, you have to work a little harder on the application semantics and the
> glue of the ontology layer, but it comes with the amazing bonus of all the
> goodness of WWW. Surely, we can't ignore its success? It's the ease of
> working with it, of setting it up, and the ambigous nature of each request
> (that can be tunneled through anything) and the constraints on them (for
> cacheability, etc.) that makes that possible.
>

I don't challenge the usefulness of catch-all POST on network level,
on the contrary.

What I do challenge is the missing semantic level, which makes
impossible to find out what all these resources are about. I don't
understand what's wrong of admitting HTTP is _the_ transport level for
myriad of specific applications, defining their own semantics in the
HTTP message body payload.  Or do we perceive OSI architecture fixed
in stone once and forever?  Sure it is in the textbooks, but not
always as positive example. It is often cited that early in the
Internet history, there were no precise idea what the applications
will appear, so why we insist there could be no layer above OSI 7?

Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
resolving the semantics, compared to software code.

>> Finding resources is critical part of any network architecture. If I
>> do not know nothing of Amazon, and there is no any search engine
>> available, Â how I am supposed to find where to buy online books? Even
>> how I am supposed to know I _could_ buy books online?
>
> But why are you raising these what-if questions? Do you have some scenarios
> that you are concretely struggeling with, or are good examples of HTTP gone
> bad? I fear I do not understand "what if there are no search engines",
> because there are.
>

Well, having used Internet before  Altavista, Google, et al. became
into their force, I do remember times when web sites were
participating in "rings", where each site was happy to include links
to the next one in the ring, thus allowing a new sites to become
visible.  Another way to learn about a web site was for somebody to
share the link by email, or even offline.  The HATEOAS "follow your
nose" approach reminds me exactly this - no global knowledge, just
follow the next step. The power of Internet rose when the web of links
started to be analysed as a whole, not just looking at the next peek.

However, web services (not only REST) are in the pre-search era, quite
possible due to common semantics lacking.  May be because of something
else as well. IMHO only of course.

Scenarios - well, couple of, but details are not necessary in the
scope of this thread. Basically, having number of REST services under
common API running in several places in the world, how do you find if
there is a specific piece of information that could be retrieved from
any of them, or specific processing capability available?  Sure there
are custom solutions, but from this discussion I gather a generic one
is hardly of interest.

>> Well, we do roughly the same, each resource describing itself with
>> RDF, according to a specific ontology. But I would not say this is the
>> mainstream approach.
>
> Depends on where you dip your toe. But even if that was true, does that make
> it wrong?

Of course not.

Regards,
Nina

>
> Regards,
>
> Alex
