Post ID:18336
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 14:32:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Jan 3, 2012, at 3:28 PM, Nina Jeliazkova wrote:

> I don't
> understand what's wrong of admitting HTTP is _the_ transport level for
> myriad of specific applications, defining their own semantics in the
> HTTP message body payload.

See REST vs SOAP battles of 2000-2010 for a more than extensive treatment of *that* subject.

Jan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18337
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 14:43:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 1:43 PM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> > The semantics of *what* about POST, exactly?
>
> "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> No, no - this is about the semantics of *specific requests* that use
>> the POST method. Not about the semantics of POST itself.
>
> Ahem, I think you're responding a bit fast. :)  My point was exactly this;
> in REST, there are no semantics to specific requests any more than to
> generic ones. Every POST is "process this" to the server, the payload is
> interpreted and processed, but the POST is still the ambigous, context-free
> (apart from the URI and content-type) request. All POSTs are the same to
> REST, and that IS ITS SECRET WEAPON!
>

Yes, that is the network perspective of the interaction (aka.
'visibility'). There are also server and client perspectives of the
interaction which *do* include these semantics - *established for a
URI by the server and shared with the client via some hypertext
control*. This has to happen otherwise neither would have a frame of
reference for how to make or receive the request. i.e. hypertext is
the mechanism by which shared understanding is exposed and controlled
in REST applications.

>> There are more semantics in
>> a given request than those that HTTP gives us. HTTP gives us
>> network-visible semantics, that is its purpose. The additional
>> semantics in a given request are not network-visible (but,
>> importantly, so what?).
>
> Well, I think we agree on the statement that there's more to the POST than
> what REST / HTTP gives us ... most of the time, however to make the point a
> bit more concrete, here's an example ;
>
>    POST /458745485 "46"
>
> For some people here, this lack of specifics looks like a problem. To me, it
> looked like a problem for a very long time, until, like Jan, I dived in and
> embraced HATEOAS. It's *there* that semantics exists, not in the POST, not
> in the request itself. The focus should be on the model, never on the
> conversation, so to speak.

Again, you're addressing the separate issue of how semantics are
disseminated in hypertext applications. I absolutely agree with this,
hence:

"HAL is a media type with which applications are described and
controlled via link relations."
http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html#general

The resulting interaction (e.g. the resulting POST request from
submitting a form) still carries the semantics of the hypertext
control that was followed, and that continuity produces a 'flow' which
we call an "application" (the other meaning of application, not OSI
layer 7). Failure is, of course, an important part of that continuity.

>> Unless you have a distinct media type identifier to cover every single
>> semantic in your application (or intent, etc.), then those semantics
>> will not be visible and can only be determined by the client and
>> server (via a contextual, shared understanding about the resource in
>> question) - whether that shared understanding is buried within the
>> semantics of a media type or a preceding link relation does not change
>> this.
>
> If I request a generic resource and get back a map of FORMs with RDFa, what
> more do I need?
>

This should probably be in a separate thread, but I'll post it anyway.. :)

One of the major issues I have with the RDF model is that it's
objective seems to be to make every resource a possible 'starting
point' - i.e. it tries to provide a model for 'bootstrapping' a
machine client into a context for any 'generic' resource on the web.
We don't have this in REST, instead we have a limited set of entry
points and from then on discovery/traversal of an application at run
time. This means there's a tonne of features (read: bloat) and
assumptions that are inherent to implementations like RDFa which, from
a REST pov, are at best distracting and at worst actually corrosive to
the kinds of behaviours we are trying to invoke when designing RESTful
hypertext applications.

REST's perspective on semantics seems to be based on a relational
theory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_theory) whereas RDF's
perspective seems to be based on more of an absolute theory
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_theory). I believe this
difference  is at the root of the apparent schism between REST and RDF
and I can't find a way to reconcile this, so I avoid RDF.

I still wanted a generic media type but without the RDF baggage, so
that's why I created HAL. Some other people seem to prefer it too.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18338
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 15:19:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

<snip>
Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
</snip>

think about what you say here: that there is a "shared semantic"
understanding. and where does this understanding exist? only (and
solely) in the head of humans?

after careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
real-world markers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
real world; ones that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
activated by humans. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
are rendered by common Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
in the most ubiquitous human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
HTML.

"Semantic meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
property is "created" by humans when they observe the visual
"landscape" rendered by  Web browsers.

Does anyone here want to assert that this "semantic meaning" can
_only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in the real-time
interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar) markers? Or
is it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
"affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?

It is my assertion that the latter is the case. I also contend that
making the assumption that this is possible is a key step in advancing
the art and theory of distributed hypermedia.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 09:28, Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:

>

> else as well. IMHO only of course.

> are custom solutions, but from this discussion I gather a generic one

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18339
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 15:42:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:19 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> <snip>
> Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
> </snip>
>
> think about what you say here: that there is a "shared semantic"
> understanding. and where does this understanding exist? only (and
> solely) in the head of humans?
>
> after careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
> real-world markers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
> real world; ones that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
> activated by humans. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
> are rendered by common Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
> in the most ubiquitous human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
> HTML.
>
> "Semantic meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
> property is "created" by humans when they observe the visual
> "landscape" rendered by  Web browsers.
>
> Does anyone here want to assert that this "semantic meaning" can
> _only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in the real-time
> interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar) markers?

Afaict, there's a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven't seen a
client implementation which demonstrates automated capabilities which
come 'close' to that of a human, we're basically talking about the
web's version of a Turing Test.

Most of the evidence so far suggests this is the case, although I am
not an AI expert.

> Or
> is it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
> of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
> "affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?
>
> It is my assertion that the latter is the case. I also contend that
> making the assumption that this is possible is a key step in advancing
> the art and theory of distributed hypermedia.
>

I think it's an interesting research topic but the complexity of
producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's inevitable that only
a small portion of your client base will behave this way (unless you
control them all, in which case your system is not very distributed!).
So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve your application in
a way that caters to the lowest common denominator - undermining the
effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients. This is a big
challenge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of the challenge
of inventing the designs for such an autonomous hypermedia agent.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18340
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 15:52:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 1:44 PM, Jan Algermissen
<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
>
> On Jan 3, 2012, at 2:01 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>
>>> The is no shared understanding that the server needs to know about.
>>
>> Of course there is - a server has to establish a specific
>> understanding of an incoming POST body to a resource in order to
>> process it in a specific way.
>
> When was the last time you implemented a POST handler of a resource and thought in any way about what the client expects?
>
> Answer: "never"; because it is completely up to the resource what to do upon POST.

- What the resource does upon POST is determined by understanding the
semantics of the application it is part of (e.g. processing
form-encoded credit card details).

- What the client POSTs is determined by its understanding of the
semantics of the application it is navigating through (e.g. submitting
form-encoded credit card details via a payment form).

This is a shared understanding, controlled by hypermedia, from two
different perspectives - server vs client.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18341
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 15:52:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Mike:

your responses surprise me (only a bit<g>) since you are the one
person on this list who has designed, and actively promotes, a
hyper-media type which you describe as:  "...machine-readable and
designed to be consumed by automated 'agents'."[1]

[1] http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 10:42, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@gmail.com> wrote:
> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:19 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@yahoo.com> wrote:
>> <snip>
>> Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
>> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
>> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
>> </snip>
>>
>> think about what you say here: that there is a "shared semantic"
>> understanding. and where does this understanding exist? only (and
>> solely) in the head of humans?
>>
>> after careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
>> real-world markers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
>> real world; ones that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
>> activated by humans. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
>> are rendered by common Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
>> in the most ubiquitous human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
>> HTML.
>>
>> "Semantic meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
>> property is "created" by humans when they observe the visual
>> "landscape" rendered by  Web browsers.
>>
>> Does anyone here want to assert that this "semantic meaning" can
>> _only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in the real-time
>> interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar) markers?
>
> Afaict, there's a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven't seen a
> client implementation which demonstrates automated capabilities which
> come 'close' to that of a human, we're basically talking about the
> web's version of a Turing Test.
>
> Most of the evidence so far suggests this is the case, although I am
> not an AI expert.
>
>> Or
>> is it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
>> of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
>> "affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?
>>
>> It is my assertion that the latter is the case. I also contend that
>> making the assumption that this is possible is a key step in advancing
>> the art and theory of distributed hypermedia.
>>
>
> I think it's an interesting research topic but the complexity of
> producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's inevitable that only
> a small portion of your client base will behave this way (unless you
> control them all, in which case your system is not very distributed!).
> So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve your application in
> a way that caters to the lowest common denominator - undermining the
> effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients. This is a big
> challenge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of the challenge
> of inventing the designs for such an autonomous hypermedia agent.
>
> Cheers,
> Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18342
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 16:05:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

HAL is 'lean' because it tackles only a small set of capabilities.
It's controls are essentially limited to outbound links and embedded
content.

There are no forms in HAL and this was a deliberate design decision
based on the assertion that such mechanisms rely on a level of
sophistication that is just not realistic at the moment. Basically,
adding forms wouldn't achieve much and would increase the costs of
adopting it as a format. I am working on a separate design which
extends HAL to add in templated writes or 'forms', but this will be a
separate type and not a new version of HAL.

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:52 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> Mike:
>
> your responses surprise me (only a bit<g>) since you are the one
> person on this list who has designed, and actively promotes, a
> hyper-media type which you describe as:  "...machine-readable and
> designed to be consumed by automated 'agents'."[1]
>
> [1] http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html
>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
>
>
>
> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 10:42, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:19 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>>> <snip>
>>> Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
>>> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
>>> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.

>>> solely) in the head of humans?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18343
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 16:20:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:


Â 


Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> hat am 3. Januar 2012 um 16:52 geschrieben:

>
> - What the resource does upon POST is determined by understanding the
> semantics of the application it is part ofÂ 
No, this is where you get it wrong. The resource has no idea what the
application is. Especially is it not bound to whatever the client expects.
Â 
Hypermedia received by the client tells clients something about the nature of
certain resources (e.g. an HTML <img> element, an AtomPub <collection> element,
an OpenSearch <Query> element or a hypothetical order-processor semantic defined
in some procurement media type).
Â 
An yes, the client chooses to interact with certain resources based on what was
learned from such hypermedia. But beyond that, there is no obligation for the
server, no shared contract, no shared nothing.
Â 
Especially can the client not rely on:
Â 
- the methods supported by the server for that resource
Â 
- the response the server will return for invoking that resource
Â 
- the implementation details or particular state changes that will occur on the
server side.
Â 
E.g. If you POST to an AtomPub collection, the server might well respond with a
202 instead of a 201, no matter what the AtomPub spec chose to say
would/should/might happen.
Â 
E.g. If you PUT to an AtomPub 'edit-URI' the server might well inform you that
PUT is not supported, advising you to use POST instead.
Â 
You are (in my perception of your replies - which might be wrong of course)
trying to fit an RPC mental model onto REST because you are insisting on
*shared* understanding and that the server 'knows the application' (which it
does in RPC style architectures)
Â 
Jan
Â 
Â 





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18344
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 16:28:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

In addition:

Â 


Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...> hat am 3. Januar 2012 um 17:20
geschrieben:


> An yes, the client chooses to interact with certain resources based on what
> was
> learned from such hypermedia. But beyond that, there is no obligation for the
> server, no shared contract, no shared nothing.
> Â Â 
Â 
And this is at the heart of REST's evolvability, because it is the very reason
why e.g. Amazon does not (in no way) need to ask every of its zillions of
customers before making a change to their servers.
Â 
And this is not only true for Browser-based interactions, it is equally well
true for so called machine to machine interactions. (There is just a varying
degree of how often a human actor is given an action step in the execution of
her own use cases).
Â 
Jan
Â 

Â 





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18345
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 16:29:47
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 3 January 2012 17:52, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> Mike:
>
> your responses surprise me (only a bit<g>) since you are the one
> person on this list who has designed, and actively promotes, a
> hyper-media type which you describe as: Â "...machine-readable and
> designed to be consumed by automated 'agents'."[1]
>

Machine readable doesn't necessarily mean the clients extract emerging
semantic; they simply can process already encoded semantic.

> [1] http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html
>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
>
>
>
> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 10:42, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:19 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>>> <snip>
>>> Comparison with WWW is not fair. Â There is a single shared semantic
>>> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
>>> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
>>> </snip>
>>>
>>> think about what you say here: that there is a "shared semantic"
>>> understanding. and where does this understanding exist? only (and
>>> solely) in the head of humans?
>>>


One could argue there are at least two levels:
1) Technically, a common meaning of HTML tags, interpreted uniformly
(well, almost) across browsers
2) A shared meaning conveyed by the language and visual symbols and
eventually emerging, yes, in human heads.  Eventually, because it
depends on the context, culture, etc.

There is an analogy with 1) uniform POST semantics at the network
level and 2) application meaning from the pov of application.

>>> after careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
>>> real-world markers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
>>> real world; ones that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
>>> activated by humans. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
>>> are rendered by common Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
>>> in the most ubiquitous human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
>>> HTML.
>>>
>>> "Semantic meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
>>> property is "created" by humans when they observe the visual
>>> "landscape" rendered by Â Web browsers.

Not necessarily an emergent property only. The meaning can be formally
defined by humans (by logic, common vocabularies, knowledge
representation, etc) and encoded in the software. The encoded semantic
essentially constitutes  the shared understanding between the client
and the server.

>>>
>>> Does anyone here want to assert that this "semantic meaning" can
>>> _only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in the real-time
>>> interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar) markers?
>>

Anybody can create a client, which will read the same HTML tags on a
web page, but it will hardly be expected these days to have full human
reasoning capabilities.

>> Afaict, there's a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven't seen a
>> client implementation which demonstrates automated capabilities which
>> come 'close' to that of a human, we're basically talking about the
>> web's version of a Turing Test.
>>

Indeed.

>> Most of the evidence so far suggests this is the case, although I am
>> not an AI expert.
>>
>>> Or
>>> is it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
>>> of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
>>> "affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?
>>>
>>> It is my assertion that the latter is the case. I also contend that
>>> making the assumption that this is possible is a key step in advancing
>>> the art and theory of distributed hypermedia.
>>>

Well, if regarding hypermedia as one of the instances of knowledge
representation, this is certainly within the research scope of AI /
machine learning.

>>
>> I think it's an interesting research topic but the complexity of
>> producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's inevitable that only
>> a small portion of your client base will behave this way (unless you
>> control them all, in which case your system is not very distributed!).
>> So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve your application in
>> a way that caters to the lowest common denominator - undermining the
>> effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients. This is a big
>> challenge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of the challenge
>> of inventing the designs for such an autonomous hypermedia agent.
>>

Agree.

Regards,
Nina

>> Cheers,
>> Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18346
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 16:47:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Nina:

i suspect i've dragged this thread way off course. Mike Kelly and i
have had a similar convo many times over the last year or so and i was
really just "poking the bear" w/ my post; my bad<g>.

suffice to say that, for the most part, i concur w/ your observations.

the power and flexibility of machines does not match that of humans;
that is not needed in order to "code" hypermedia agents to accomplish
[selected|limited|simple|etc] tasks on behalf of humans.this is
already happening today and will continue to grow overtime. most of
the work is being down "outside" the "hypermedia space" right now, but
i am finding some very interesting research that leads me to think
apply hypermedia is not out of the question. [1]

whether "meaning" exists within a message or is derived from the
message by some means ("interpretation", etc.) is well beyond the
scope of this list. my current thoughts are influenced greatly by the
work of James Gibson[2] and and Donald Norman[3]. i'll leave off this
part of the convo as i have little tangle proof for my POV at this
time.

sorry for the detour.

[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent#Examples_of_intelligent_software_agents
[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Gibson
[3] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Norman

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

Post ID:18347
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 16:57:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 4:28 PM, Jan Algermissen
<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
> In addition:
>
>
>
>
> Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...> hat am 3. Januar 2012 um 17:20
> geschrieben:
>
>
>> An yes, the client chooses to interact with certain resources based on
>> what was
>> learned from such hypermedia. But beyond that, there is no obligation for
>> the
>> server, no shared contract, no shared nothing.
>>
>
>
>
>
>
> And this is at the heart of REST's evolvability, because it is the very
> reason why e.g. Amazon does not (in no way) need to ask every of its
> zillions of customers before making a change to their servers.
>

I assume you mean they can do stuff like 'safely' altering their
checkout flow? Fwiw, making sweeping changes like this to web apps is
generally a risky business - ask any e-commerce company's customer
services department for confirmation.

This ability to evolve the application flow of web apps is due almost
entirely to the sophistication of the human brain. Machine agents do
not behave this way. If you have evidence showing they can, please
share it.

>
> And this is not only true for Browser-based interactions, it is equally well
> true for so called machine to machine interactions. (There is just a varying
> degree of how often a human actor is given an action step in the execution
> of her own use cases).
>

No it's not, it's a completely different kettle of fish.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18348
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 17:18:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:


Â 


Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> hat am 3. Januar 2012 um 17:57 geschrieben:


> This ability to evolve the application flow of web apps is due almost
> entirely to the sophistication of the human brain. Machine agents do
> not behave this way. If you have evidence showing they can, please
> share it.Â 
Not sure where you take this 'evolve the application flow of web apps' from. For
one, there are lots of changes that do not involve changing the order in which
interactions occur (which I assume you mean by flow) and secondly, I did not
mean to say that such changes would magically be enabled by REST.
Â 
The thing is however, that REST enables communication to *happen* even if the
intended application fails to run into a success state in the end. REST clients
(i.e. HTTP clients) will be able to handle all possible kinds of error states
(by virtue of implementing HTTP completely) and we will generally be able to
proceed(!) from failure states at a much more sophisticated level than with a
broken RPC application. The latter just dies with some convoluted exception in
some log in some obscure location.
Â 
For me, leveraging the power of HTTP as-is is at the heart of applying REST
successfully - we need not seek for building AI into clients - that's an
illusion anyhow.
Â 
jan
Â 





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18349
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 17:34:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 5:18 PM, Jan Algermissen
<jan.algermissen@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
>
>
> Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> hat am 3. Januar 2012 um 17:57
> geschrieben:
>
>
> > This ability to evolve the application flow of web apps is due almost
> > entirely to the sophistication of the human brain. Machine agents do
> > not behave this way. If you have evidence showing they can, please
> > share it.
>
>
>
> The thing is however, that REST enables communication to *happen* even if
> the intended application fails to run into a success state in the end. REST
> clients (i.e. HTTP clients) will be able to handle all possible kinds of
> error states (by virtue of implementing HTTP completely) and we will
> generally be able to proceed(!) from failure states at a much more
> sophisticated level than with a broken RPC application. The latter just
> dies with some convoluted exception in some log in some obscure location.
>
>
>
> For me, leveraging the power of HTTP as-is is at the heart of applying
> REST successfully - we need not seek for building AI into clients - that's
> an illusion anyhow.
>
>
>

Ok, this is all fine - I'm not sure that anyone was suggesting this is not
the case. We got to this point because we were discussing whether or not a
server should 'know' about the part of an application it is responsible for
dealing with. I'm still not convinced that a server can 'know nothing'
about a given resource's role but, at the same time, be able to process
requests to it in a specific way.

To be honest, this conversation isn't really going anywhere and hasn't been
for some time. I still feel there are unanswered questions from much
further back in the thread that are worth exploring, maybe we should head
back to them or just drop this entirely?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18350
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-03 21:33:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Mike, you argue quite a lot in favour of only using link-reltypes. For 
instance in http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/18337:

> There are also server and client perspectives of the
> interaction which *do* include these semantics - *established for a
> URI by the server and shared with the client via some hypertext
> control*. This has to happen otherwise neither would have a frame of
> reference for how to make or receive the request. i.e. hypertext is
> the mechanism by which shared understanding is exposed and controlled
> in REST applications.

And in http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/18322:

> In this example the shared understanding is really coming from the link 
> relations.
> Link relations can exist independently from the media type, which is how
> shared understanding is established when using generic (hyper)media types.

So, in short, "hypertext is the mechanism by which shared understanding is 
exposed and controlled in REST applications.".

If you follow this logic then you could even argue that media-types in 
headers are completely irrelevant. All you need to do is to decorate the 
link-reltypes with the possible media-type. Instead of one link with reltype 
"salesorder" you could have "salesorder-xml", "salesorder-pdf", 
"salesorder-IBM", and so on - and throw away content negotiation at the same 
time.

But it builds on a false assumption of always following a link-reltype. Here 
is a couple of examples where it won't work:

- A friend sends you a link to an image. You click on it and have absolutely 
no link-reltype to indicate what kind of stuff you will get. "Luckily" the 
server returns content-type: image/jpeg such that your browser knows how to 
handle it.

- A spidering service is presented with a bunch of URLs it should index. It 
has no apriori knowledge of what to get from those URLs. Again the server 
returns a usefull content-type and magic happens (and application/xml is not 
usefull from this prspective).

- The <img src="..."/> has no link-reltype stating "this is a JPEG" or "this 
is a GIF". It relies on the returned content-type (and content negotiation 
with the accept header).

- A paper bussiness card contains a URL to the digital representation of it. 
What if the server returns "application/xml"? How would you know how to 
decode it? Luckily it returns "application/vcard+xml" (or "text/vcard" or 
...).

- A price comparing services trawls through whatever URLs it can pick up 
from the internet, looking for media-types "application/vnd.sap.pricing+xml" 
(fictive) and "application/open-pricing+xml" (also fictive). When ever it 
finds those it will read prices and accumulate a database of them.

My last example is what I think is most important. Here is what would happen 
if we only use application/xml and link-reltypes:

a) The client retrieves a hypertext document from server A.

b) The hypertext document contains a link with reltype 
"this-is-an-imageprocessor-of-type-X" that links to server B which is not 
under the control of server A.

c) The client follows the link sending an accept header with "Accept: 
application/xml".

d) The server returns "Content-type: application/xml" and, well, some XML.

e) Unfortunately server B has been upgraded without informing server A (how 
should it, it is a truely distributed system with independent components). 
So it instead of returning XML for "imageprocessor-of-type-X" (as the 
link-reltype told the client) it now returns XML for 
"imageprocessor-of-type-Y".

f) The client breaks.

If instead the client had sent "Accept: application/imageprocesser-x+xml" 
then the server would have known that it should return the old format - or a 
redirect to a server capable of working with the expected format.

By utilizing not only link-reltypes but also media-types we make it possible 
to work in a truely distributed network system where the servers as well as 
clients are free to change over time without any kind of coordination.

The link-reltype tells the client what link to follow - the media-type in 
the accept header tells the server what the client expects from it - 
something that the server cannot know otherwise.

The fact is that link-reltypes are not enough. Thinking so does not take the 
nature of truely distributed applications into account. It builds on the 
assumption that the resource that contains the link is coupled/synchronized 
with the resource that it points to. I think Jan has been trying to say this 
a couple of times - here is my interpretation of it.

We need something more than link-reltypes and media-types is the answer to 
that.

/Jï¿½rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18351
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 05:48:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hola,

"Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
> Internet became massively useful after 1) distributed name resolution
> called DNS was invented and 2) search engines became powerful enough.

Sorry, don't buy it. 1) DNS was important for sure, but not crucial to the
initial success, and 2) search engines became poweful *because* of REST,
not despite it.

> > The ambiguity of REST/HTTP is exactly why it *is* so powerful as a
concept.
>
> AFAIK , REST is not defined as HTTP specific, on the contrary.

Uh, no, it's the other way around; HTTP is defined as REST. I often say
REST/HTTP because we mostly blur the lines between the two in most of these
discussions, but yes, HTTP is an implementation of a RESTful protocol.

> What I do challenge is the missing semantic level, which makes
> impossible to find out what all these resources are about.

Impossible?

> I don't
> understand what's wrong of admitting HTTP is _the_ transport level for
> myriad of specific applications, defining their own semantics in the
> HTTP message body payload.

Is anyone denying this? *puzzled*

>  Or do we perceive OSI architecture fixed
> in stone once and forever?  Sure it is in the textbooks, but not
> always as positive example. It is often cited that early in the
> Internet history, there were no precise idea what the applications
> will appear, so why we insist there could be no layer above OSI 7?

No one is denying that there is a layer above. It's just not REST, it's
something else. Currently, it's a mess, but with some good clues and a
growing best-practice, and early manifestations of specs.

What puzzles me is the insistence that this semantic layer belongs in REST.

> Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.

As much as I'd like to agree with you, I don't. There's plenty of known and
heavvily used content types that are not meant for human digestion, such as
images, CSS and JS files, JSON, and XML and further up into abstraction.
Only the *browser* is human readable; the markup, images and code is not
(unless you're a geek).

> I do remember times when web sites were
> participating in "rings", where each site was happy to include links
> to the next one in the ring, thus allowing a new sites to become
> visible.

It was also a very early example of social engineering.

> Another way to learn about a web site was for somebody to
> share the link by email, or even offline.  The HATEOAS "follow your
> nose" approach reminds me exactly this - no global knowledge, just
> follow the next step.

There's a difference between a trail laid down in bread-crumbs, and one
that is carved in stone. "Follow-your-nose" is not the same as abandon
common knowledge. Ever written a FOAF crawler? The principle is to follow
your nose, but using an established ontology. Whether you're traversing
nodes or resources (some times orthagonal to each other) doesn't matter to
the HATEOAS concept.

> The power of Internet rose when the web of links
> started to be analysed as a whole, not just looking at the next peek.

Not sure if I can agree with this, either. Even the web crawlers are
looking for the next peek, so I don't see a sharp edge between the past and
present here.

> However, web services (not only REST) are in the pre-search era, quite
> possible due to common semantics lacking.  May be because of something
> else as well. IMHO only of course.

Big vendors and lock-in, I think. RESTful thinking has been around for a
long time, even in the pre-search era, but just like with good wine ...

> Scenarios - well, couple of, but details are not necessary in the
> scope of this thread. Basically, having number of REST services under
> common API running in several places in the world, how do you find if
> there is a specific piece of information that could be retrieved from
> any of them, or specific processing capability available?  Sure there
> are custom solutions, but from this discussion I gather a generic one
> is hardly of interest.

Well, again, it depends on what you're after. This sounds more like a
problem of persistent global identiy management more than semantics of a
specific service, but it's hard to tell without a bit more info. Feel free
to raise another thread; it's RESTful, after all.

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18352
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 06:06:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hola,

"Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> There are also server and client perspectives of the
> interaction which *do* include these semantics - *established for a
> URI by the server and shared with the client via some hypertext
> control*.

Yes, but you are the one who has decided well in advance that there is some
specific semantics required for this, something that is missing from REST
itself and the generic interface. Maybe you could provide a more concrete
example?

> One of the major issues I have with the RDF model is that it's
> objective seems to be to make every resource a possible 'starting
> point' - i.e. it tries to provide a model for 'bootstrapping' a
> machine client into a context for any 'generic' resource on the web.

Oh, don't get me wrong; I hate RDF myself, a bunch of sissy triplets
(triplets! Hah!) and anonymous nodes trying to act all-encompassing and
shareable, but with deep fundamental problems (persistent identifiers, and
the aboutness of resources) ... :)

However. RDF's heart is in the right place; ontology. And it is through a
separate ontology you get your semantics.

> We don't have this in REST, instead we have a limited set of entry
> points and from then on discovery/traversal of an application at run
> time. This means there's a tonne of features (read: bloat) and
> assumptions that are inherent to implementations like RDFa which, from
> a REST pov, are at best distracting and at worst actually corrosive to
> the kinds of behaviours we are trying to invoke when designing RESTful
> hypertext applications.

Hmm, big words. Sure, the HTTP payload can be vexing, but far from hard to
solve (caching, being a big one) using a multitude of ways; cached maps,
cached resource mapping, cached vocabulary mappings, cached result-sets (of
generics), and so on.

I tend to say; create a crap HTTP client, and you'll get a crap HTTP
system. There is no need to create a crap HTTP client.

> REST's perspective on semantics seems to be based on a relational
> theory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_theory) whereas RDF's
> perspective seems to be based on more of an absolute theory
> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_theory). I believe this
> difference  is at the root of the apparent schism between REST and RDF
> and I can't find a way to reconcile this, so I avoid RDF.

It now depends on what you mean by RDF; the model (triplets, namespaces,
etc.), the RDF ontology, the RDFS, OWL (any of the three levels), or some
model that uses the RDF family model to create something else (possibly
meta). I can map RDF to Topic Maps just dandy, and create full-blown frames
theory graphs (named or otherwise) with cumulative histographical node
hopping just fine, so for me there is no limitation that RDF itself is a
faulty model. (And, truth be told, I don't use an RDF inferencer, I use
Topic Maps all the way down, including plural persistent identification
management and separation of concerns between ontology, meta-data and data)
I don't shun RDF (or, more specifically, RDFa) as it's a well-known, often
used (well, more these days) method of creating key-value pairs attached to
an ontology, and so just map those to whatever you need it for. I seriously
fear that bringing these kinds of semantics anywhere near REST will be the
end of all that is good on the web.

> I still wanted a generic media type but without the RDF baggage, so
> that's why I created HAL. Some other people seem to prefer it too.

Tooling, mostly.

Kind regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18353
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 09:57:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 6:06 AM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hola,
>
> "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> There are also server and client perspectives of the
>> interaction which *do* include these semantics - *established for a
>> URI by the server and shared with the client via some hypertext
>> control*.
>
> Yes, but you are the one who has decided well in advance that there is some
> specific semantics required for this, something that is missing from REST
> itself and the generic interface.

I don't think I did, I've just been trying to make the point that you
just agreed with - which is that POST requests to different resources
do carry different semantics (determined by a hypertext application).
Not from a network perspective (i.e. visibility), but from the client
and server persepctive.

There's nothing wrong with that, it doesn't undermine HTTP or REST.
Hypertext is definitely a concern of REST, which is why 'hypertext as
the engine of application state' appears in its definition. I'm pretty
sure Roy has stated a couple of times that hypertext should've been
fleshed out in his dissertation but never made it because of time
constraints i.e. not because it 'hypertext is a layer above REST'.

>
>> One of the major issues I have with the RDF model is that it's
>> objective seems to be to make every resource a possible 'starting
>> point' - i.e. it tries to provide a model for 'bootstrapping' a
>> machine client into a context for any 'generic' resource on the web.
>
> Oh, don't get me wrong; I hate RDF myself, a bunch of sissy triplets
> (triplets! Hah!) and anonymous nodes trying to act all-encompassing and
> shareable, but with deep fundamental problems (persistent identifiers, and
> the aboutness of resources) ... :)
>
> However. RDF's heart is in the right place; ontology. And it is through a
> separate ontology you get your semantics.
>

Don't really mind what we call it; as long as it is capable of
presenting a succinct, coherent, human-readable description of the
various ways a hypertext application can be traversed.

not very fond 'ontology' though because the word stinks a bit of
esotericism, and I prefer to think and talk about hypertext
applications in terms of happening rather than being anyway.

>> We don't have this in REST, instead we have a limited set of entry
>> points and from then on discovery/traversal of an application at run
>> time. This means there's a tonne of features (read: bloat) and
>> assumptions that are inherent to implementations like RDFa which, from
>> a REST pov, are at best distracting and at worst actually corrosive to
>> the kinds of behaviours we are trying to invoke when designing RESTful
>> hypertext applications.
>
> Hmm, big words. Sure, the HTTP payload can be vexing, but far from hard to
> solve (caching, being a big one) using a multitude of ways; cached maps,
> cached resource mapping, cached vocabulary mappings, cached result-sets (of
> generics), and so on.
>
> I tend to say; create a crap HTTP client, and you'll get a crap HTTP system.
> There is no need to create a crap HTTP client.
>

The problem I have with this advice is that in a distributed context
(e.g. a big SaaS API) the clients will be not be written by me,
they'll be written by other people with their own (crappy) opinions
and (crappy) technology stacks.

The real art of designing a REST application is in coaxing/herding the
clients you don't control into adopting behaviours which will afford
you the flexibility to evolve. In many cases this means an application
design that compromises on 'perfection' in order to lower the barrier
to all the stupid clients e.g. this is exactly the reason there are no
'forms' in HAL.

>> REST's perspective on semantics seems to be based on a relational
>> theory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_theory) whereas RDF's
>> perspective seems to be based on more of an absolute theory
>> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_theory). I believe this
>> difference  is at the root of the apparent schism between REST and RDF
>> and I can't find a way to reconcile this, so I avoid RDF.
>
> It now depends on what you mean by RDF; the model (triplets, namespaces,
> etc.), the RDF ontology, the RDFS, OWL (any of the three levels), or some
> model that uses the RDF family model to create something else (possibly
> meta). I can map RDF to Topic Maps just dandy, and create full-blown frames
> theory graphs (named or otherwise) with cumulative histographical node
> hopping just fine, so for me there is no limitation that RDF itself is a
> faulty model. (And, truth be told, I don't use an RDF inferencer, I use
> Topic Maps all the way down, including plural persistent identification
> management and separation of concerns between ontology, meta-data and data)
> I don't shun RDF (or, more specifically, RDFa) as it's a well-known, often
> used (well, more these days) method of creating key-value pairs attached to
> an ontology, and so just map those to whatever you need it for. I seriously
> fear that bringing these kinds of semantics anywhere near REST will be the
> end of all that is good on the web.
>

Are these read/write applications or just read?

Do you have many external clients to your application? Did any of them
have no experience with RDF before interacting with your application?
If so how did the 'on-boarding' process go for them wrt RDF?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18354
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 10:49:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hola,

"Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> I've just been trying to make the point that you
> just agreed with - which is that POST requests to different resources
> do carry different semantics (determined by a hypertext application).
> Not from a network perspective (i.e. visibility), but from the client
> and server persepctive.

Hmm, I can see that I haven't been clear enough, but I'm not sure it's that
important. For me, POST doesn't carry any semantics but the generic
"process this" on the server side, not as an API nor as a stand-alone
resource. All its semantics are pre-determined by the client, the package
gets wrapped up snug, kissed for good luck, and sent to a resource hoping
it understands what the server is going to do with it.

The reason I bang on a bit about this is that there is a slight reversal of
responsibility as to the outcome of the request. In a traditional RPC or
SOAP those responsibilities lies with the client knowing upfront the ins
and outs of the API. HATEOAS changes the responsibility around, and forces
(in lack of a better word) the clients to not couple, to not make those
resource static. In a roundabout way it makes the client think in more
generic terms about the request, and that's a (IMHO) good thing.

> Hypertext is definitely a concern of REST, which is why 'hypertext as
> the engine of application state' appears in its definition. I'm pretty
> sure Roy has stated a couple of times that hypertext should've been
> fleshed out in his dissertation but never made it because of time
> constraints i.e. not because it 'hypertext is a layer above REST'.

Yes, any package that defines a URI to other things are hypertext, of which
HTML is the most used one. There are some good formats out there which does
this (or reuse the URI definitions from XML Schema), including RDF and XTF
(Topic Maps).

> > However. RDF's heart is in the right place; ontology. And it is through
a
> > separate ontology you get your semantics.
>
> Don't really mind what we call it; as long as it is capable of
> presenting a succinct, coherent, human-readable description of the
> various ways a hypertext application can be traversed.

Why the human-readable part? View sourceness?

> not very fond 'ontology' though because the word stinks a bit of
> esotericism, and I prefer to think and talk about hypertext
> applications in terms of happening rather than being anyway.

It has a defined use in information technology, so get used to it. :)

> > I tend to say; create a crap HTTP client, and you'll get a crap HTTP
system.
> > There is no need to create a crap HTTP client.
>
> The problem I have with this advice is that in a distributed context
> (e.g. a big SaaS API) the clients will be not be written by me,
> they'll be written by other people with their own (crappy) opinions
> and (crappy) technology stacks.

For sure. On the other side, you can create beautiful stuff with SOAP, and
have a really good API as RPC. In other words, I'm not sure that "other
people" is a measure of correctness. Most people don't get HTML right.
Crikey, most people don't get English right! :)

> The real art of designing a REST application is in coaxing/herding the
> clients you don't control into adopting behaviours which will afford
> you the flexibility to evolve. In many cases this means an application
> design that compromises on 'perfection' in order to lower the barrier
> to all the stupid clients e.g. this is exactly the reason there are no
> 'forms' in HAL.

What's wrong with forms? I have a system which uses XHTML responses with
embedded forms and RDFa, and it's a self-documenting, self-describing,
browsable, searchable system to be used by humans (browsers) and computers
(API) both. (I have to admit I haven't looked into HAL. What was that link
again? :) )

> Are these read/write applications or just read?

Read and write.

> Do you have many external clients to your application?

Yes, hundreds.

> Did any of them
> have no experience with RDF before interacting with your application?

Don't know, but I'm pretty sure the answer is 'yes'.

> If so how did the 'on-boarding' process go for them wrt RDF?

I don't rely on RDF, I only use it to expose the ontology, but that is
available in many different formats, including Topic Maps, generic XML and
JSON, and text. Don't think of RDF in the means of graph theory, though.
It's more like a vocabulary and relationships mapped up as an API.

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18355
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 12:18:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 10:49 AM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
>> > However. RDF's heart is in the right place; ontology. And it is through
>> > a
>> > separate ontology you get your semantics.
>>
>> Don't really mind what we call it; as long as it is capable of
>> presenting a succinct, coherent, human-readable description of the
>> various ways a hypertext application can be traversed.
>
> Why the human-readable part? View sourceness?
>

No. It's key because those semantics are really being broadcast to
humans (developers writing the consuming agents' logic). If I produce
an hypertext application and expose its semantics as an 'ontology',
those semantics will be consumed by developers first and foremost in
order to develop their understanding of the way the application flows.
The developers will then crystalize that understanding into code which
will fulfil the application on their behalf (aka an 'agent' or
'client' to the application). The important thing there is that the
exchange of application semantics occurred between the human author
and the human consumer of the application; this is where the
coaxing/herding takes place - it's a form of social engineering. This
is why the mechanical semantics of HTML or AtomPub are written in
human language.

A link relation provides a standard level of indirection; developers
can refer to them as they construct an understanding of the semantics
of a set of links which comprise an application, and the automated
agents they create can use them as tokens for distinguishing the links
in mechanising the developer's understanding. I use a generic media
type to and expose my application as a set of link relations, I can
then evolve my application by making non-breaking changes to the
semantics of existing links, or inject brand new or breaking semantics
by introducing new link relations - link relations are much more
granular and easier to control than media types in this regard, which
is why I design applications that way.

I don't think it needs to get more complex than that, and I'm not 100%
on whether that lack of complexity fails to satisfy the definition of
an "ontology"

>> not very fond 'ontology' though because the word stinks a bit of
>> esotericism, and I prefer to think and talk about hypertext
>> applications in terms of happening rather than being anyway.
>
> It has a defined use in information technology, so get used to it. :)
>

As an application author my concern would be that presenting my
application to client developers as an 'ontology' would either confuse
them or scare them off completely. But, like I said, I don't think the
word we use matters /that/ much.

>> > I tend to say; create a crap HTTP client, and you'll get a crap HTTP
>> > system.
>> > There is no need to create a crap HTTP client.
>>
>> The problem I have with this advice is that in a distributed context
>> (e.g. a big SaaS API) the clients will be not be written by me,
>> they'll be written by other people with their own (crappy) opinions
>> and (crappy) technology stacks.
>
> For sure. On the other side, you can create beautiful stuff with SOAP, and
> have a really good API as RPC. In other words, I'm not sure that "other
> people" is a measure of correctness. Most people don't get HTML right.
> Crikey, most people don't get English right! :)
>
>> The real art of designing a REST application is in coaxing/herding the
>> clients you don't control into adopting behaviours which will afford
>> you the flexibility to evolve. In many cases this means an application
>> design that compromises on 'perfection' in order to lower the barrier
>> to all the stupid clients e.g. this is exactly the reason there are no
>> 'forms' in HAL.
>
> What's wrong with forms? I have a system which uses XHTML responses with
> embedded forms and RDFa, and it's a self-documenting, self-describing,
> browsable, searchable system to be used by humans (browsers) and computers
> (API) both. (I have to admit I haven't looked into HAL. What was that link
> again? :) )
>

think you may have missed my point a bit here. I wasn't saying there
is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
a machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
effort - it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
adding a requirement to understand form processing rules) without
delivering much by way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
much to the table, and many clients will either get it wrong or hack
around it anyway. This may well improve in the future but right now it
doesn't seem like a good option from the practical, cost-benefit point
of view (not the architecturally pure one).

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18356
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 12:54:38
Subject:Reasons to use forms
Message:

On Jan 4, 2012, at 1:18 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:

>  I wasn't saying there
> is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
> a machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
> effort - it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
> adding a requirement to understand form processing rules) without
> delivering much by way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
> much to the table, and many clients will either get it wrong or hack
> around it anyway. This may well improve in the future but right now it
> doesn't seem like a good option from the practical, cost-benefit point
> of view (not the architecturally pure one).

A benefit of forms is that they can provide data to include in the corresponding submission that needs not or must not (due to volatility) be remembered by the client.

An example would be the current price of an item. Instead of constructing an order and including a remembered price, the current price can be right in the form for the client to review and then put into the submission request.

I was sort of against forms, but Ian S. Robinson totally changed my mind on this about a year ago when pointing the above out to me.

Jan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18357
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 13:29:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Reasons to use forms
Message:

On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 12:54 PM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...
> wrote:

> **
>
>
>
> On Jan 4, 2012, at 1:18 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>
> > I wasn't saying there
> > is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
> > a machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
> > effort - it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
> > adding a requirement to understand form processing rules) without
> > delivering much by way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
> > much to the table, and many clients will either get it wrong or hack
> > around it anyway. This may well improve in the future but right now it
> > doesn't seem like a good option from the practical, cost-benefit point
> > of view (not the architecturally pure one).
>
> A benefit of forms is that they can provide data to include in the
> corresponding submission that needs not or must not (due to volatility) be
> remembered by the client.
>
> An example would be the current price of an item. Instead of constructing
> an order and including a remembered price, the current price can be right
> in the form for the client to review and then put into the submission
> request.
>
>
This is possible without forms by making the carried values a part of the
necessary representations and making the client behaviour (carrying the
value) part of the 'domain application protocol'. The difference with forms
is that the information that the client can potentially carry is arbitrary
with forms as far as the client is concerned, and the control of the
resultant request is completely in the hands of the server presenting the
initial form.

There is a pretty serious security implication of this approach, in that
the integrity of the client's request is lost to the server which in many
cases will belong to an external organisation. I imagine this would raise
security concerns about how far (if at all) such a mechanism should be
allowed to go; e.g. requiring a same-domain policy or removing the ability
for additional, arbitrary inputs to be injected into the resulting request.
These sorts of measures would make a big dent in the benefits of taking the
form approach. If half of your clients were ok with that, and the other
half weren't - could you really make significant changes to those forms
(e.g. changing the domain or adding in another field) and be confident
about the risks?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18358
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 13:44:44
Subject:Re: Reasons to use forms
Message:

Forms are nice if you accept the overhead on the client when requiring it to understand all the elements of a form.

But, Jan, how does this fit into your view of (almost?) always(?) using domain specific media-types? Or is this a different scenario? Or something else ... ?

> An example would be the current price of an item. Instead of constructing an order and including a remembered price, the current price can be right in the form for the client to review and then put into the submission request.

Just remember to add some kind of digital signature to the data, such that clients cannot alter the price once it is given to it.

/Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18359
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 13:51:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Reasons to use forms
Message:

On Jan 4, 2012, at 2:44 PM, Jorn Wildt wrote:

> Forms are nice if you accept the overhead on the client when requiring it to understand all the elements of a form.

What exactly is 'the overhead'?

> 
> But, Jan, how does this fit into your view of (almost?) always(?) using domain specific media-types? Or is this a different scenario? Or something else ... ?

I do not refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that instructs the user agent what data to include in the submission (including fixed (aka 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of the specific media type(s) I define.

> 
> > An example would be the current price of an item. Instead of constructing an order and including a remembered price, the current price can be right in the form for the client to review and then put into the submission request.
> 
> Just remember to add some kind of digital signature to the data, such that clients cannot alter the price once it is given to it.

Why's that? The server can easily check whether the submitted price is a price it accepts. The server need not carelessly send the order to the backend without a check. But, ok, yes - a check-key could be used to verify the data came from a form actually created by the server.

Jan

> 
> /Jørn
> 
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18360
Sender:Will Hartung <willh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 17:39:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Reasons to use forms
Message:

On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 5:51 AM, Jan Algermissen
<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:

> I do not refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that instructs
> the user agent what data to include in the submission (including fixed (aka
> 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of the specific
> media type(s) I define.

What makes the "form" stand out from any other part of the data, and
why should it stand out from any part of the data. The client will
need to "know" how to build the "form" for the payload anyway, and it
can source that data from any part of the original payload as required
by the specifics of the call, whether that source data is from a
"form" or simply part of the data.

Why does the "form" part stand out at all?

Regards,

Will Hartung
(willh@...)





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18361
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 17:53:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Reasons to use forms
Message:

On Jan 4, 2012, at 6:39 PM, Will Hartung wrote:

> On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 5:51 AM, Jan Algermissen
> <jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
> 
>> I do not refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that instructs
>> the user agent what data to include in the submission (including fixed (aka
>> 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of the specific
>> media type(s) I define.
> 
> What makes the "form" stand out from any other part of the data, and
> why should it stand out from any part of the data.

Good question.

To me, this is a matter of who is remembering state. Does the client remember all the aspects of an offer to build the order or is the offer a resource that the client can GET and is then given the offer-data as a submittable form?

Jan

> The client will
> need to "know" how to build the "form" for the payload anyway, and it
> can source that data from any part of the original payload as required
> by the specifics of the call, whether that source data is from a
> "form" or simply part of the data.
> 
> Why does the "form" part stand out at all?
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Will Hartung
> (willh@...)

Post ID:18362
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 18:18:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi,

just imagine, when the link rel type itself can be identified via a URI 
and a machine processable description of it can be retrieved when 
resolving this URI ...

cf. my explanation at [1] :)

Cheers,


Bo


PS: it's all about (binary) relations


[1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17256


Am 03.01.2012 12:07, schrieb Jorn Wildt:
>  > The critical point is how the shared understanding between client and
>  > server is achieved, and whether the "network-visible" semantic is
>  > sufficient for the shared understanding.
>
> Yes.
>
>  > Let's have a resource, which accepts "image/png" on POST and does
>  > certain image processing, returning a resource URI, where the
>  > generated image could be retrieved.
>
>  > How does the client decides where to send the POST command, if it
>  > wants a specific type of image processing? Out-of-band information
>  > only?
>
> I would say the link-reltype that points to the page that accepts the POST.
>
> The link-reltypes would be documented in the media-type spec.
>
> It could go like this:
>
> 1) Client GETs image processing descriptor resource.
>
> 2) Server returns media-type "application/vnd.imageprocessor+xml". Now
> the client has a shared understanding with server about the server's
> capabilities.
>
> 3) The client selects a proper link from the response using
> link-reltypes documented in the media-type spec.
>
> 4) Client POSTs image to the selected URL.
>
> All-in-all ... the shared understanding comes from the media-type.
>
> /Jï¿½rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18363
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 18:54:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Reasons to use forms
Message:

from my POV, using inline client-side "templates" for URIs or entity
bodies makes sense when the problem domain you are implementing has a
substantially high number of variables for either URIs and/or entity
bodies _and_ you want to inform clients at runtime of the possible
options for URIs and.or bodies..

HTML took on the task of providing both URI and entity bodie
termplates by providing the exact same mechanism:  HTML.FORM, but
adding a single "switch". that is, for HTML.FORM@method="get", client
apps are to treat the FORM as a URI template; otherwise, the client
apps are to treat the FORM as an entity body template.

Atom solved this problem by dropping support for templates completely;
servers simply have no way (as defined by Atom/AtomPub) to inform
clients at runtime of any state-transfer option details (other than
identified links such as rel="edit", etc.). this works fine for
problem domains where the options are either non-existent, or the list
of options are simple/stable enough to hard-code all details of each
and every possible option (including _when_ these options are valid)
into the client apps directly.

while it's true that machine-only clients (i.e. no active human in the
driver seat) have additional work to do when supporting templating, i
rarely find this "additional work" is wasted energy. i've been able to
use HTML.FORMs to very good effect in M2M scenarios several times.
this works especially well when the _vocabulary_ of the problem domain
is stable, while the _workflow_ options of the problem domain are
variable/customizable. IOW, machines do not need to learn *new
variables* over time, but instead need to learn *new collections* of
the same variables (i.e. the number of FORMs encountered and the list
of variables in each FORM changes over time, but none of these changes
introduces *unknown* variables to the machine).

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 12:53, Jan Algermissen

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18364
Sender:=?Windows-1252?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-04 20:45:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Reasons to use forms
Message:

> What exactly is 'the overhead'?

 Being able to parse a form definition and dynamically decide what to do 
with it (compared to a media-type that simply states "post this to that 
link-reltype, somewhat like AtomPub which does not include form-defs).

> I do not refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that 
> instructs the user agent what data to include in the submission (including 
> fixed (aka 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of 
> the specific media type(s) I define.

 Cool, that's what I wanted to hear :-)

> The server need not carelessly send the order to the backend without a 
> check.

 If it can check it - why include it at all? Okay, I know Ian's example - 
its because the target of the form need not have access to the price (it 
could be a completely different system). In this case a check-key/signature 
is a must to avoid tampering.

 /Jï¿½rn

On Jan 4, 2012, at 9:45 PM, Jørn Wildt wrote:

> Being able to parse a form definition and dynamically decide what to do with it (compared to a media-type that simply states "post this to that link-reltype, somewhat like AtomPub which does not include form-defs).

Ah, ok. I would personally not consider that significant overhead, but I get your point.
