-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18366
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-05 14:39:37
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Reasons to use forms
Message:

"And yet the forms post"


________________________________
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] on behalf of Mike Kelly [mikekelly321@...]
Sent: 04 January 2012 13:29
To: Jan Algermissen
Cc: REST Discuss; iansrobinson@...
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Reasons to use forms





On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 12:54 PM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...<mailto:jan.algermissen@...>> wrote:


On Jan 4, 2012, at 1:18 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:

> I wasn't saying there
> is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
> a machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
> effort - it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
> adding a requirement to understand form processing rules) without
> delivering much by way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
> much to the table, and many clients will either get it wrong or hack
> around it anyway. This may well improve in the future but right now it
> doesn't seem like a good option from the practical, cost-benefit point
> of view (not the architecturally pure one).

A benefit of forms is that they can provide data to include in the corresponding submission that needs not or must not (due to volatility) be remembered by the client.

An example would be the current price of an item. Instead of constructing an order and including a remembered price, the current price can be right in the form for the client to review and then put into the submission request.


This is possible without forms by making the carried values a part of the necessary representations and making the client behaviour (carrying the value) part of the 'domain application protocol'. The difference with forms is that the information that the client can potentially carry is arbitrary with forms as far as the client is concerned, and the control of the resultant request is completely in the hands of the server presenting the initial form.

There is a pretty serious security implication of this approach, in that the integrity of the client's request is lost to the server which in many cases will belong to an external organisation. I imagine this would raise security concerns about how far (if at all) such a mechanism should be allowed to go; e.g. requiring a same-domain policy or removing the ability for additional, arbitrary inputs to be injected into the resulting request. These sorts of measures would make a big dent in the benefits of taking the form approach. If half of your clients were ok with that, and the other half weren't - could you really make significant changes to those forms (e.g. changing the domain or adding in another field) and be confident about the risks?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18367
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-06 03:08:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hiya,

Bit late. Still on holidays. :)

On Jan 4, "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> > Why the human-readable part? View sourceness?
>
> No. It's key because those semantics are really being broadcast to
> humans (developers writing the consuming agents' logic).

No, theye're not, an ontology is designed so that C2C works seamlessly. As
long as humans who create programs know how to deal with certain entities
or given relationships, the rest of the nitty-gritty of business processes
do not need any human intervention, not even on the programming side.
That's the pipe we're trying to flow through.

> If I produce
> an hypertext application and expose its semantics as an 'ontology',
> those semantics will be consumed by developers first and foremost in
> order to develop their understanding of the way the application flows.

No, not necessarily, and this is key to the whole semantic schmantic web;
understand a basic part of the ontology (so, the parts that touch the edges
of its API) to avoid needing to know the whole. Derived ontologies infer
from context their applicability, and one can map objects and relationships
to workflows more easily than you can use a traditional API.

Example; My app and your app both speak a small ontology about business
interaction (basic entities, for example). These apps are obviously made by
developers, but here's the clinch; if you speak that ontology, those maps
of your data you've got can be directly reused in more complex frameworks
where underlying ontologies are derived from the basic ontology. An objects
type follows through the ontology, where relationships are specified and
can be acted upon. It basically means that objects that you've defined as
type X can be popped into other systems, and interaction can happen,
without any further devs involved.

More specifically, there's ontologies for working with semantics within
maps, and some apps can enrich your data without any devs. It enables the
creation of evolving ontologies for your applications domain and scope.

> I don't think it needs to get more complex than that, and I'm not 100%
> on whether that lack of complexity fails to satisfy the definition of
> an "ontology"

Ontology is the language you use; the entities you've got, their types, and
the relationships between them. You can make that as complex or simple as
you need, but of course even more subscribe to reuse of models.

> > It has a defined use in information technology, so get used to it. :)
>
> As an application author my concern would be that presenting my
> application to client developers as an 'ontology' would either confuse
> them or scare them off completely. But, like I said, I don't think the
> word we use matters /that/ much.

Call it vocabulary, and relationships. If client developers don't get this,
I suggest you need better clients. :)

> think you may have missed my point a bit here. I wasn't saying there
> is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
> a machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
> effort - it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
> adding a requirement to understand form processing rules) without
> delivering much by way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
> much to the table, and many clients will either get it wrong or hack
> around it anyway.

this sounds ... profoundly wrong to me. Forms are costly and fruitless?
Increases complexities? What exactly is the difference between a form and
RPC call in terms of complexity and bloat?

> This may well improve in the future but right now it
> doesn't seem like a good option from the practical, cost-benefit point
> of view (not the architecturally pure one).

The concept is that the server can prepare and ready-make forms that the
client can choose to instigate on and possibly fill out some blanks if they
exists. The client doesn't need any pre-defined concept of the API; it is
delivered to you, and whether parameters are required, optional, what their
semantic weight is, and so on. You've gt in forms both a
machine-understandable and human-interactionable, self-documenting, and so
on. The client focus more on the entities and relationships between things
(concepts that are rarely to change) rather than the ins and outs of an API
(that might change in the future, causing headaches).

Anyway, I don't think we disagree too much, just on a few reusable things.
:)

regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18368
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-06 03:12:28
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Reasons to use forms
Message:

> "And yet the forms post"

Yes, there seems to be a slight confusion as to why reuse HTML forms. The
main one is that both humans and machines can read it, the server can
pre-make forms the client can use, and thus can be fully self-documenting,
act as a guide through a framework/API, can be browsed, tons of tooling and
knowledge about form interactions, and so on.

You could go the extra mile and do Xforms, but I haven't had the need for
the full monty just quite yet. Basic XHTML forms seems to be quite capable
for most uses.

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18369
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-06 10:12:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi Alex

On Fri, Jan 6, 2012 at 3:08 AM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
> Hiya,
>
> Bit late. Still on holidays. :)
>
> On Jan 4, "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>> > Why the human-readable part? View sourceness?
>>
>> No. It's key because those semantics are really being broadcast to
>> humans (developers writing the consuming agents' logic).
>
> No, theye're not, an ontology is designed so that C2C works seamlessly. As
> long as humans who create programs know how to deal with certain entities or
> given relationships, the rest of the nitty-gritty of business processes do
> not need any human intervention

I don't think we can step over "certain entities or given
relationships" just like that..

What are the nitty-gritty of business processes in a hypertext
application if they're _not_ the entities and relationships? Surely,
the semantics of entities and their relationships _are_ the
application?

>> If I produce
>> an hypertext application and expose its semantics as an 'ontology',
>> those semantics will be consumed by developers first and foremost in
>> order to develop their understanding of the way the application flows.
>
> No, not necessarily, and this is key to the whole semantic schmantic web;
> understand a basic part of the ontology (so, the parts that touch the edges
> of its API) to avoid needing to know the whole.

Are there any practical examples of applications that actually work
this way? Can any of them be easily comprehended and coded against by
average devs (i.e. devs that aren't semweb Zen-masters)?

> Derived ontologies infer
> from context their applicability, and one can map objects and relationships
> to workflows more easily than you can use a traditional API.
>
> Example; My app and your app both speak a small ontology about business
> interaction (basic entities, for example). These apps are obviously made by
> developers, but here's the clinch; if you speak that ontology, those maps of
> your data you've got can be directly reused in more complex frameworks where
> underlying ontologies are derived from the basic ontology. An objects type
> follows through the ontology, where relationships are specified and can be
> acted upon. It basically means that objects that you've defined as type X
> can be popped into other systems, and interaction can happen, without any
> further devs involved.
>
> More specifically, there's ontologies for working with semantics within
> maps, and some apps can enrich your data without any devs. It enables the
> creation of evolving ontologies for your applications domain and scope.
>

I agree that the potential for re-using/re-mixing code written against
applications is improved by defining the application in terms of link
relations (vs. domain specific media types). That is one of the key
reasons I prefer generic media types, so we definitely agree on that.
However, I don't follow your logic about this re-use somehow
overcoming a need for human interaction; since the applications and
code being re-used had to be created by /people/ expressing (author
dev) and comprehending (consumer dev) the semantics in the first
place.

>> I don't think it needs to get more complex than that, and I'm not 100%
>> on whether that lack of complexity fails to satisfy the definition of
>> an "ontology"
>
> Ontology is the language you use; the entities you've got, their types, and
> the relationships between them. You can make that as complex or simple as
> you need, but of course even more subscribe to reuse of models.

That being the case, where does that leave us wrt your previous
statement: "As long as humans who create programs know how to deal
with certain entities or given relationships, the rest of the
nitty-gritty of business processes do not need any human
intervention"?

I think you are over-stating the importance of machines wrt the actual
applications - perhaps this is a general semweb thing?

I find it easiest to think about hypertext applications in terms of
'agent intent'. The job of application semantics are to instruct
agents how their intent should translate into interactions with a
server.  In the case of machine agents - their intent is actually the
codified intent of their developers, so the semantics should speak to
those developer(s) since they are the ones performing the translation
into the codified interactions the machine agent is performing.

>> > It has a defined use in information technology, so get used to it. :)
>>
>> As an application author my concern would be that presenting my
>> application to client developers as an 'ontology' would either confuse
>> them or scare them off completely. But, like I said, I don't think the
>> word we use matters /that/ much.
>
> Call it vocabulary, and relationships. If client developers don't get this,
> I suggest you need better clients. :)
>

Is it ok if I use "representations" and "link relations" instead?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18370
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-06 12:59:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hiya,

On Jan 6, 2012 9:12 PM, "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> > No, theye're not, an ontology is designed so that C2C works seamlessly.
As
> > long as humans who create programs know how to deal with certain
entities or
> > given relationships, the rest of the nitty-gritty of business processes
do
> > not need any human intervention
>
> I don't think we can step over "certain entities or given
> relationships" just like that..

Oh, I'm happy to drive droves of drivel down deprived drones for days on
end ... :)

> What are the nitty-gritty of business processes in a hypertext
> application if they're _not_ the entities and relationships? Surely,
> the semantics of entities and their relationships _are_ the
> application?

Hmm, we're getting a tad off-topic, but I always welcome a dive into data
modeling (and not the RDBMS kind). As with most data modeling, it's about
defining entities and relationships. Entities in an ontology are mostly
"type", ie. abstract notions that you declare your data to be a type of, so
for example the ontology will have "person", and a data specific definition
would be "Alex" is_a "person", and so on. And when they're not a type,
they're a relationship, like "is_a". More complex ontologies have a lot of
constraints right in it, so for example objects of type "person" must have
a relationship X attached to it, or never in a relationship with an object
of type Y, and on and on. From all of this you create a model of your
domain, and link your data to that model.

But these are still conceptual things (objects and ontologies) that I don't
necessarily map directly to HTTP resources and link relationships, but more
on that later. But now more directly to your question, then of course in an
ideal world we all do semantic mapping in our applications, re-use a good
few ontologies, and things woud be much smoother, and yes, a hyper-text
business process definitly has entities and relationships that we could map
to resources ... but it isn't always what you want to do, especially not
the fine-grained details of a full business model. Not saying you can't,
and I have done it before, but mostly I do a more abstract mapping between
resources that represent a cluster of entities and relationships, and then
tunnel the business models through that. (This was harder to explain than
it should be, and I may not be making much sense, either)

> Are there any practical examples of applications that actually work
> this way? Can any of them be easily comprehended and coded against by
> average devs (i.e. devs that aren't semweb Zen-masters)?

I don't know much about industries doing this (I've seen papers at
conferences, and I've talked to people who are doing or wanted to do this,
but no real details on that), only what I myself have been doing for
clients and for back-end systems I can't reveal much about (and I wish I
could; it's not a cop out :) ). As to the need for Zen-masters, no, but I
do find that there's a good percentage of people who can't think in any
term that doesn't include a table and rows. Models, be it complex or
otherwise, seems to be easier understood by certain people, and that surely
impacts who does it well. Having said that, though, the tons of truly
crappy relational modeling I've seen through the years tell me that
modeling in *general* is misunderstood, and not just the semantic modeling
that's a little bit more fashionable these days.

> > More specifically, there's ontologies for working with semantics within
> > maps, and some apps can enrich your data without any devs. It enables
the
> > creation of evolving ontologies for your applications domain and scope.
> >
>
> I agree that the potential for re-using/re-mixing code written against
> applications is improved by defining the application in terms of link
> relations (vs. domain specific media types). That is one of the key
> reasons I prefer generic media types, so we definitely agree on that.
> However, I don't follow your logic about this re-use somehow
> overcoming a need for human interaction; since the applications and
> code being re-used had to be created by /people/ expressing (author
> dev) and comprehending (consumer dev) the semantics in the first
> place.

Well, it's not so much that I think it will remove devs from app design
completely, but I sure think it could offer an applicable revolution in the
way apps interact. Like I said, instead of writing your app to understand
given APIs that are bound to change, write them towards models that are
less likely to change. An example is again "Alex" is_a "person". If "Alex"
is an object with a host of properties attached, any piece of code who can
understand and process objects of type "person" can have a go at it. The
key is also that "Pedro" is_a "customer" can run the same code; "customer"
is_a "person" is defined in perhaps some middle ontology, making objects
constrained and / or compatible against other through merging of ontologies.

In other words, I can create a service in my SOA that understands how to
deal with "person" objects. Maybe it searches the web, and attaches certain
data to objects that correlates, and adds properties or relationships to
*other* objects. Little by little you can enrich your original "person"
object by, say, changing its type from "person" to "human being" or
"company" (in liue of the crazy US definition that companies have personal
rights :) ). You pass around the same object, but different processes apply
to their typification.

People objects are one thing, but say you start out with something more
abstract, like "transaction"; you pass the object around, and it gets
enriched as it passes through your system. Same object, different
processes, driven by the objects type relationship and how it fits into
your model. (Different rules if your object has X relationship rather than
a Y)

And now we come to the reusability aspect more directly. I can send a
"person" object through your system if you understand "person" objects, and
you can enrich it with stuff I don't support under the surface. For
example, let's say that the upper ontology defines "person", and maybe
basic date of birth and death. Your service finds out that I love
Monteverdi, and adds this relationship and others in your special music
ontology (which I don't support), like the subjects "opera" and "vespers".
I can't deal much with these relationships because I don't understand them
(I only understand the upper ontology we share). However, I can infer from
type "composer" that it is a person, and I can infer generic subjects from
special subject "vespers". So I can give an unprocessed view of objects,
and even do business logic across them, inferred from the layers of
typification.

In a business context this is fantastic for transaction handling shared
between clients back and forth. But none of this has much to do with REST,
of course.

> I think you are over-stating the importance of machines wrt the actual
> applications - perhaps this is a general semweb thing?

It's definitly the way the semweb is going, and one usually separate
between upper, core and data ontologies. Upper deals with the semantics of
language, core with a mapping between concepts and real life, and the data
ontologies map between data and the concepts. Sharing of ontologies are
getting traction, too, but mostly of data ontologies, sharing models and
trying to map them to either intermediate platforms. The library world is
modeling up FRBR and RDA, for example, which will finally free them to
share different models of their bibliographical data through a more fluid
ontology layer rather than the hard-coded MARC[21] / AACR2 nightmare
they're currently in.

> I find it easiest to think about hypertext applications in terms of
> 'agent intent'.

Well, yes, but who is the agent? It's not always a person on the other end.

> > Call it vocabulary, and relationships. If client developers don't get
this,
> > I suggest you need better clients. :)
>
> Is it ok if I use "representations" and "link relations" instead?

Well, you can of course do what you want, and you don't need my permission
... :) Representation is one of those ugly words, though, that we can't
seem to all agree on, and I hardly think it smart to represent everything
in a model as a resource ... and then you get into problems of clustering
(named graphs) and so on. Ugh. Link relations are a bit easier, though.

Talking with devs I simply call them objects. SemWeb people call them
nodes. Topic Mappers call them topics. And I guess RESTafarians could call
them resources, but that distinction between a resource and the
representation is a bit close to the fundamental problem of RDF of
"aboutness" when you use an URI for it; are you talking about the website,
the resource or whatever that resource is meant to represent? It's still an
unresolved problem (the 304 solution is an ugly hack)

IMHO, of course.

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18371
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 09:38:02
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Paul Cohen wrote:
> Having said that, I would be satisifed with one single new media type;
> one that combines JSON:s simple expressiveness with native support for
> hyperlinks! :-)

Have you had a look at JSON-LD? It offers much more than just support for
hyperlinks but you could "abuse" it just for getting that:
http://www.json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-syntax/

Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

Post ID:18373
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 09:48:15
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Thursday, December 29, 2011 10:45 AM, mike amundsen wrote: 
> it is my suspicion that the work of SemWeb and REST have the potential
> to meet in a way that comes close to this goal; the ability enable M2M
> interactions to consistently share understanding about a problem
> domain independent of the format of the shared understanding of the
> message format.
>
> if anyone is working on such a project, or knows of one, please let me
know.

Mike, I share your opinion. I think that Sematic Web technologies provide a
great potential to bring RESTful systems forward. Of course, it won't change
REST but augment it by a semantic layer on top of it.

I'm actively working on this, see http://bit.ly/seredasj,
http://bit.ly/sparql2rest or
http://www.json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-syntax/


> the notion of expressing a problem domain independent of the message
> format itself (via vocabularies, ontologies, etc) in a way that
> enables M2M communication and collaboration is a compelling one but,
> IMO, not easy to accomplish. i've taken a couple stabs at it over the
> last year and have yet to find my efforts successful.

I would love to know more about your efforts..


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

> than JSON-LD"?

Hi Markus, the main reasons I can think of are that it's:

- not RDF
- deliberately designed to be minimal and easy to grok





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18376
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 10:57:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi Markus,

at a first glance your referred papers are looking very promising. They 
remind me to a discussion we had appr. one year ago about the 
REST-i-ness of SPARQL (see [1]).
However, the problem with JSON-LD still is, that it doesn't utilise link 
relation types (as it is the same problem with all RDF serialisation 
formats ATM). In contrast, HAL makes use of link relations types 
("href", ...), and, hence, supports the HATEOAS constraint of REST.
So my solution proposal for this problem still is to design a vocabulary 
to describe link relation type definitions in a machine processable way 
and attach these definitions to our well-known RDF property definitions, 
i.e., then we have knowledge about the property (relation) itself and 
how it can be processed by a client.

Cheers,


Bo


[1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17281


On 1/8/2012 11:38 AM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> Mike, could you elaborate on what exactly makes HAL "much less
> convoluted than JSON-LD"?
>
> --
>
> Markus Lanthaler
>
> @markuslanthaler

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18377
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 12:08:53
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Sunday, January 08, 2012 6:49 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
> On Sun, Jan 8, 2012 at 10:38 AM, Markus Lanthaler
> <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> > Mike, could you elaborate on what exactly makes HAL "much less
> convoluted
> > than JSON-LD"?
> 
> Hi Markus, the main reasons I can think of are that it's:
> 
> - not RDF

JSON-LD is not RDF, it is just a way to serialize directed graphs which
really resembles data on the Web IMHO - think of entities/resources/nodes
(or whatever you like to call them) interconnected by links. Since RDF is
capable of doing the same, it is trivial to transform JSON-LD to RDF - the
same applies to CSV e.g.

A lot of effort was put into hiding RDF as much as possible, I am just one
of the proponents to take that as far as possible but we also have people
thinking more in RDF in the group.



> - deliberately designed to be minimal and easy to grok

These are explicit design goals of JSON-LD [1] as well.


[1] http://www.json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-syntax/#goals-and-rationale



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18378
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 12:17:54
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi,

Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are just more
terse. Let's look at an example:

{
  "@context": {
    "homepage": { "@id": http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type": "@id"
}
    }
  },
  "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
  "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
}


This (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON object
which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepage according to the FOAF
vocabulary - that's the rel part, isn't it!? The value of it is
"http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/". The coercion in the context tells a
JSON-LD parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus allows a
client to follow that link.

See also Manu Sporny's comment on Mark Notthingsham's blog post about
"Linking in JSON" [1]. I think there is still some confusion about what
JSON-LD is (intended to be).


[1] http://www.mnot.net/blog/2011/11/25/linking_in_json#comment-1737



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

Post ID:18379
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 13:06:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi Markus,

link relation type definition are not (RDF) property definitions. Where 
the latter ones define something about the properties (relations) it 
themselves, the former ones include something about the processing of 
these relations, i.e., how to handle the referred object.
To sum up, link relation type definitions are usually orthogonal to 
(RDF) property definitions. See also, e.g., [1] for a detailed 
discussion on this issue and related ones.

Cheers,


Bo


[1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17242


On 1/8/2012 1:17 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> Hi,
>
> Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are just more
> terse. Let's look at an example:
>
> {
> "@context": {
> "homepage": { "@id": http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type": "@id"
> }
> }
> },
> "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
> "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
> }
>
> This (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON object
> which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepage according to the FOAF
> vocabulary - that's the rel part, isn't it!? The value of it is
> "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/". The coercion in the context tells a
> JSON-LD parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus allows a
> client to follow that link.

Post ID:18380
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 17:56:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On 8 Jan 2012, at 12:17 PM, "Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are just more terse. 

Hi Markus,

Being 'more terse' here is an example of the convolution I referred to before that you don't get with HAL.

what's the simplest way of representing an 'embedded resource' with JSON-LD?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18381
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-08 18:54:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi Mike,

On 1/8/2012 6:56 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>
> On 8 Jan 2012, at 12:17 PM, "Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...
> <mailto:markus.lanthaler%40gmx.net>> wrote:
>
>  > Hi,
>  >
>  > Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are
> just more terse.
>
> Hi Markus,
>
> Being 'more terse' here is an example of the convolution I referred to
> before that you don't get with HAL.
>
> what's the simplest way of representing an 'embedded resource' with JSON-LD?


I tried to roughly translate the HAL example at [1] to JSON-LD markup:

{
     "@context": {
		"ex": "http://example.com",
         "ex:customer": {
             "@type": "@id"
         },
         "ex:quantity": {
             "@type": "xsd:integer"
         },
         "ex:price": {
             "@type": "xsd:float"
		},
		"ex:total": {
             "@type": "xsd:float"
		},
		"ex:placed": {
             "@type": "xsd:date"
		},
         "xsd": "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#"
     },
	"@id": "/orders",
	"@type": "ex:Orders",
	"ex:order": {
		"@id":	"/orders/123"
		"@type": "ex:Order",
		"ex:customer": "/customer/bob",
		"ex:basket": {
			"@id": "/orderds/123/basket",
			"@type": "ex:Basket",
			"ex:item": {
				"@type": "ex:Item",
				"ex:sku": "ABC123",
				"ex:quantity": "2",
				"ex:price": "9.50"
			},
			"ex:item": {
				"@type": "ex:Item",
				"ex:sku": "GFZT111",
				"ex:quantity": "1",
				"ex:price": "11.00"
			},
		},
		"ex:total": "30.00",
		"ex:currency": "USD",
		"ex:status": "shipped",
		"ex:placed": "2011-01-16"
	},
	"ex:order": {
		"@id":	"/orders/124"
		"@type": "ex:Order",
		"ex:customer": "/customer/jen",
		"ex:basket": {
			"@id": "/orderds/124/basket",
			"@type": "ex:Basket",
			"ex:item": {
				"@type": "ex:Item",
				"ex:sku": "KLM222",
				"ex:quantity": "1",
				"ex:price": "9.00"
			},
			"ex:item": {
				"@type": "ex:Item",
				"ex:sku": "HHI50",
				"ex:quantity": "1",
				"ex:price": "11.00"
			},
		},
		"ex:total": "20.00",
		"ex:currency": "USD",
		"ex:status": "processing",
		"ex:placed": "2011-01-16"
	}
}

See also [2].

I'm no JSON-LD expert at all. So there are maybe some errors in the 
markup above. Furthermore, I guess, this example can even be shortened. 
A hyperlink relation is simply expressed via its coercion (as pointed by 
Markus), e.g., "ex:customer": "/customer/jen" would be a link relation. 
An 'embedded resource' is in this example, e.g., "/orders/124". The 
JSON-LD knowledge representation is even more expressive, since it 
includes resource and literal types (which, I guess, are optional).
All property and resource type definitions should be de-referencable 
themselves.

Cheers,


Bo


PS: Where are the link relation type definitions of your HAL example?


[1] https://gist.github.com/572481
[2] https://gist.github.com/1579271

If any of you could spare some time to review this article and perhaps also the second part once it is written, please get in touch either through this thread or direct to my email, dan AT developerfusion DOT co DOT uk.

hypermedia links/embedded forms and queries.

On Sun, Jan 8, 2012 at 9:38 AM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
> Paul Cohen wrote:
> > Having said that, I would be satisifed with one single new media type;
> > one that combines JSON:s simple expressiveness with native support for
> > hyperlinks! :-)
>
> Have you had a look at JSON-LD? It offers much more than just support for
> hyperlinks but you could "abuse" it just for getting that:
> http://www.json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-syntax/
>
> Hi Paul,

If you only need links and embedding then HAL is much less convoluted than
JSON-LD:

http://blog.stateless.co/post/13296666138/json-linking-with-hal

Cheers,
Mike

Post ID:18386
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 15:28:50
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi,

Yes, this is a good translation to JSON-LD. Probably you would define terms
for the JSON-LD document instead of using the "ex" prefix for every field.
Also, as you mentioned, the type coercions are optional (JSON-LD handles the
native JSON types automatically).

The advantage of such an approach is that you can look up the "rel"
definitions whereas in other approaches they are (usually) just tokens
defined somewhere out of band. If you don't know where you can find the API
description you will have hard times understanding them.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler




> -----Original Message-----
> From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [mailto:rest-
> discuss@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Bob Ferris
> Sent: Monday, January 09, 2012 2:55 AM
> To: REST-Discuss Discussion Group
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
> 
> Hi Mike,
> 
> On 1/8/2012 6:56 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:

> >  >
> >  > Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are
> > just more terse.
> >
> > Hi Markus,
> >
> > Being 'more terse' here is an example of the convolution I referred
> to
> > before that you don't get with HAL.
> >
> > what's the simplest way of representing an 'embedded resource' with
> JSON-LD?
> 
> 
> I tried to roughly translate the HAL example at [1] to JSON-LD markup:
> 
> {
>      "@context": {
> 		"ex": "http://example.com",
>          "ex:customer": {
>              "@type": "@id"
>          },
>          "ex:quantity": {
>              "@type": "xsd:integer"
>          },
>          "ex:price": {
>              "@type": "xsd:float"
> 		},
> 		"ex:total": {
>              "@type": "xsd:float"
> 		},
> 		"ex:placed": {
>              "@type": "xsd:date"
> 		},
>          "xsd": "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#"
>      },
> 	"@id": "/orders",
> 	"@type": "ex:Orders",
> 	"ex:order": {
> 		"@id":	"/orders/123"
> 		"@type": "ex:Order",
> 		"ex:customer": "/customer/bob",
> 		"ex:basket": {
> 			"@id": "/orderds/123/basket",
> 			"@type": "ex:Basket",
> 			"ex:item": {
> 				"@type": "ex:Item",
> 				"ex:sku": "ABC123",
> 				"ex:quantity": "2",
> 				"ex:price": "9.50"
> 			},
> 			"ex:item": {
> 				"@type": "ex:Item",
> 				"ex:sku": "GFZT111",
> 				"ex:quantity": "1",
> 				"ex:price": "11.00"
> 			},
> 		},
> 		"ex:total": "30.00",
> 		"ex:currency": "USD",
> 		"ex:status": "shipped",
> 		"ex:placed": "2011-01-16"
> 	},
> 	"ex:order": {
> 		"@id":	"/orders/124"
> 		"@type": "ex:Order",
> 		"ex:customer": "/customer/jen",
> 		"ex:basket": {
> 			"@id": "/orderds/124/basket",
> 			"@type": "ex:Basket",
> 			"ex:item": {
> 				"@type": "ex:Item",
> 				"ex:sku": "KLM222",
> 				"ex:quantity": "1",
> 				"ex:price": "9.00"
> 			},
> 			"ex:item": {
> 				"@type": "ex:Item",
> 				"ex:sku": "HHI50",
> 				"ex:quantity": "1",
> 				"ex:price": "11.00"
> 			},
> 		},
> 		"ex:total": "20.00",
> 		"ex:currency": "USD",
> 		"ex:status": "processing",
> 		"ex:placed": "2011-01-16"
> 	}
> }
> 
> See also [2].
> 
> I'm no JSON-LD expert at all. So there are maybe some errors in the
> markup above. Furthermore, I guess, this example can even be shortened.
> A hyperlink relation is simply expressed via its coercion (as pointed
> by
> Markus), e.g., "ex:customer": "/customer/jen" would be a link relation.
> An 'embedded resource' is in this example, e.g., "/orders/124". The
> JSON-LD knowledge representation is even more expressive, since it
> includes resource and literal types (which, I guess, are optional).
> All property and resource type definitions should be de-referencable
> themselves.
> 
> Cheers,

Post ID:18387
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 16:13:03
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Bob,

I've read the thread you referenced but I still don't understand why link
relations should any different. A predicate (or a labeled edge in a graph)
does nothing else than connecting two (data) nodes. If I know the
relationship of node B to node A I also know how to process it or if I would
be interested in following that link.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler




> -----Original Message-----
> From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [mailto:rest-
> discuss@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Bob Ferris
> Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2012 9:06 PM
> Cc: 'REST-Discuss Discussion Group'
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
> 
> Hi Markus,
> 
> link relation type definition are not (RDF) property definitions. Where
> the latter ones define something about the properties (relations) it
> themselves, the former ones include something about the processing of
> these relations, i.e., how to handle the referred object.
> To sum up, link relation type definitions are usually orthogonal to
> (RDF) property definitions. See also, e.g., [1] for a detailed
> discussion on this issue and related ones.
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> 
> Bo
> 
> 
> [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17242
> 
> 
> On 1/8/2012 1:17 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are
> just more
> > terse. Let's look at an example:
> >
> > {
> > "@context": {
> > "homepage": { "@id": http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type":
> "@id"
> > }
> > }
> > },
> > "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
> > "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
> > }
> >
> > This (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON
> object
> > which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepage according to
> the FOAF
> > vocabulary - that's the rel part, isn't it!? The value of it is
> > "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/". The coercion in the context tells
> a
> > JSON-LD parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus
> allows a
> > client to follow that link.
> >
> > See also Manu Sporny's comment on Mark Notthingsham's blog post about
> > "Linking in JSON" [1]. I think there is still some confusion about
> what
> > JSON-LD is (intended to be).
> >
> > [1] http://www.mnot.net/blog/2011/11/25/linking_in_json#comment-1737
> >
> > --
> > Markus Lanthaler
> > @markuslanthaler
> >
> >  > -----Original Message-----
> >  > From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> > <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:rest-
> >  > discuss@yahoogroups.com <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>] On
> Behalf
> > Of Bob Ferris
> >  > Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2012 6:58 PM
> >  > Cc: 'REST-Discuss Discussion Group'
> >  > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
> >  >
> >  > Hi Markus,
> >  >
> >  > at a first glance your referred papers are looking very promising.
> They
> >  > remind me to a discussion we had appr. one year ago about the
> >  > REST-i-ness of SPARQL (see [1]).
> >  > However, the problem with JSON-LD still is, that it doesn't
> utilise
> >  > link
> >  > relation types (as it is the same problem with all RDF
> serialisation
> >  > formats ATM). In contrast, HAL makes use of link relations types
> >  > ("href", ...), and, hence, supports the HATEOAS constraint of
> REST.
> >  > So my solution proposal for this problem still is to design a
> >  > vocabulary
> >  > to describe link relation type definitions in a machine
> processable way
> >  > and attach these definitions to our well-known RDF property
> >  > definitions,
> >  > i.e., then we have knowledge about the property (relation) itself
> and
> >  > how it can be processed by a client.
> >  >
> >  > Cheers,
> >  >
> >  >
> >  > Bo
> >  >
> >  >
> >  > [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17281
> >  >
> >  >
> >  > On 1/8/2012 11:38 AM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> >  > > Mike, could you elaborate on what exactly makes HAL "much less
> >  > > convoluted than JSON-LD"?
> >  > >
> >  > > --
> >  > >

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18388
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 16:57:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Initially I included CURIEs in HAL with a _curies property, and used it in
some examples. I've since removed it on the basis that it is not
particularly useful, people apparently found the colon syntax
confusing/alarming.

There are a few ways to achieve discoverable rels. The first is to simply
use URIs for the link relations. Another approach is to make sure that the
documentation for your application is linked from the entry point of your
app, and explains where the rel tokens can be found in the documentation
(i.e. URI generation).

Probably the 'best' approach would be to have a URI template presented at
the entry point which instructs clients how CURIEs should be built, i.e:

request:
GET /

response:
{
...
  "_links" : {
    "curie": { "href": "http://example.com/rels/{relation}", "title": "ex" }
  },
...
}

which would instruct the client on how to resolve the 'CURIEs' elsewhere in
your application, e.g:

{
...
  "_links" : {
    "ex:foo" : { "href": "/bar" }
  },
...
}

This uses URI templates, and the title property of the link to emulate
CURIEs without having to burden everyone using HAL with an extra CURIE
mechanism.

Cheers,
Mike

On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 3:28 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
> Hi,
>
> Yes, this is a good translation to JSON-LD. Probably you would define terms
> for the JSON-LD document instead of using the "ex" prefix for every field.
> Also, as you mentioned, the type coercions are optional (JSON-LD handles
> the
> native JSON types automatically).
>
> The advantage of such an approach is that you can look up the "rel"
> definitions whereas in other approaches they are (usually) just tokens
> defined somewhere out of band. If you don't know where you can find the API
> description you will have hard times understanding them.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18389
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 17:30:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hi Markus,

well, from my POV (a Semantic Web biased one), I would agree. However, I 
always got and get the impression that the REST/hypermedia community 
doesn't agree on this equation*.
I guess, it has something to do with the hypermedia support that 
surrounds the utilisation of link relation types, i.e. they are values 
of rel attributes of tags, e.g., "link", "a", or "area". These tags and 
their attributes define the processing (e.g. enc-type, method, ...) of 
referred resources (in the media type definition). Furthermore, in such 
a hypermedia context a client should know whether it is a navigational 
link, an embedded link, etc.
On the other side, RDF is a data model or knowledge representation 
structure, which should be embeddable into other existing hypermedia 
media types (as it already can done with RDFa, see XHTML+RDFa). So RDF 
serialisation (/representation) formats doesn't need this 
functionalities themselves.
I somehow believe that is better, if these two concerns are separable 
and one could mix them as needed, because not every client needs the 
knowledge of the underlying resource/model description.

Cheers,


Bo


*) which is so obvious from my POV :) (because it's all about binary 
relations in that context)

PS: Interesting to read in that context: 
http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1065 + 
http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1083

PPS: I still believe that H-Factor is a very good measurement for 
hypermedia, see http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/


On 1/9/2012 5:13 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> Bob,
>
> I've read the thread you referenced but I still don't understand why link
> relations should any different. A predicate (or a labeled edge in a graph)
> does nothing else than connecting two (data) nodes. If I know the
> relationship of node B to node A I also know how to process it or if I would
> be interested in following that link.
>
> --
> Markus Lanthaler
> @markuslanthaler
>
>  > -----Original Message-----
>  > From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:rest-
>  > discuss@yahoogroups.com <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>] On Behalf
> Of Bob Ferris
>  > Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2012 9:06 PM
>  > Cc: 'REST-Discuss Discussion Group'
>  > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
>  >
>  > Hi Markus,
>  >
>  > link relation type definition are not (RDF) property definitions. Where
>  > the latter ones define something about the properties (relations) it
>  > themselves, the former ones include something about the processing of
>  > these relations, i.e., how to handle the referred object.
>  > To sum up, link relation type definitions are usually orthogonal to
>  > (RDF) property definitions. See also, e.g., [1] for a detailed
>  > discussion on this issue and related ones.
>  >
>  > Cheers,
>  >
>  >
>  > Bo
>  >
>  >
>  > [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17242
>  >
>  >
>  > On 1/8/2012 1:17 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>  > > Hi,
>  > >
>  > > Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are
>  > just more
>  > > terse. Let's look at an example:
>  > >
>  > > {
>  > > "@context": {
>  > > "homepage": { "@id": http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type":
>  > "@id"
>  > > }
>  > > }
>  > > },
>  > > "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
>  > > "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
>  > > }
>  > >
>  > > This (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON
>  > object
>  > > which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepage according to
>  > the FOAF
>  > > vocabulary - that's the rel part, isn't it!? The value of it is
>  > > "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/". The coercion in the context tells
>  > a
>  > > JSON-LD parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus
>  > allows a
>  > > client to follow that link.
>  > >
>  > > See also Manu Sporny's comment on Mark Notthingsham's blog post about
>  > > "Linking in JSON" [1]. I think there is still some confusion about
>  > what
>  > > JSON-LD is (intended to be).
>  > >
>  > > [1] http://www.mnot.net/blog/2011/11/25/linking_in_json#comment-1737
>  > >
>  > > --
>  > > Markus Lanthaler
>  > > @markuslanthaler
>  > >
>  > > > -----Original Message-----
>  > > > From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com>
>  > > <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:rest-
>  > > > discuss@yahoogroups.com <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>
> <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>] On
>  > Behalf
>  > > Of Bob Ferris
>  > > > Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2012 6:58 PM
>  > > > Cc: 'REST-Discuss Discussion Group'
>  > > > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
>  > > >
>  > > > Hi Markus,
>  > > >
>  > > > at a first glance your referred papers are looking very promising.
>  > They
>  > > > remind me to a discussion we had appr. one year ago about the
>  > > > REST-i-ness of SPARQL (see [1]).
>  > > > However, the problem with JSON-LD still is, that it doesn't
>  > utilise
>  > > > link
>  > > > relation types (as it is the same problem with all RDF
>  > serialisation
>  > > > formats ATM). In contrast, HAL makes use of link relations types
>  > > > ("href", ...), and, hence, supports the HATEOAS constraint of
>  > REST.
>  > > > So my solution proposal for this problem still is to design a
>  > > > vocabulary
>  > > > to describe link relation type definitions in a machine
>  > processable way
>  > > > and attach these definitions to our well-known RDF property
>  > > > definitions,
>  > > > i.e., then we have knowledge about the property (relation) itself
>  > and
>  > > > how it can be processed by a client.
>  > > >
>  > > > Cheers,
>  > > >
>  > > >
>  > > > Bo
>  > > >
>  > > >
>  > > > [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17281
>  > > >
>  > > >
>  > > > On 1/8/2012 11:38 AM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>  > > > > Mike, could you elaborate on what exactly makes HAL "much less
>  > > > > convoluted than JSON-LD"?
>  > > > >
>  > > > > --
>  > > > >
>  > > > > Markus Lanthaler
>  > > > >
>  > > > > @markuslanthaler

>  > meme

>  > > <mailto:markus.lanthaler@... <mailto:markus.lanthaler%40gmx.net>
>  > <mailto:markus.lanthaler%40gmx.net>>>
>  > > wrote:

>  > > > > > Having said that, I would be satisifed with one single new
>  > media

>  > > > > > one that combines JSON:s simple expressiveness with native
>  > support
>  > > > for
>  > > > > > hyperlinks! :-)
>  > > > >
>  > > > > Have you had a look at JSON-LD? It offers much more than just
>  > support
>  > > > for
>  > > > > hyperlinks but you could "abuse" it just for getting that:
>  > > > > http://www.json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-syntax/

>  > > > > Hi Paul,
>  > > > >
>  > > > > If you only need links and embedding then HAL is much less
>  > convoluted
>  > > > > than JSON-LD:
>  > > > >
>  > > > > http://blog.stateless.co/post/13296666138/json-linking-with-hal

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18390
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 19:08:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

<snip>
> I somehow believe that is better, if these two concerns are separable
> and one could mix them as needed, because not every client needs the
> knowledge of the underlying resource/model description.
</snip>

From my POV, a key diff between RDF message designs and hypermedia
message designs is that RDF design focuses on domain-level semantics
and hypermedia design focuses on protocol-level semantics,

Without too much trouble, I have been able to design hypermedia types
that _also_ express domain semantics (i.e. domain-specific elements,
attributes, etc.) that a wide range of clients can consume (even those
who are not "interested in" the domain semantics available in the
hypermedia type).

However, I've not yet been able to design an RDF media type that
_also_ expresses protocol-level semantics (i.e. navigate|embed,
protocol method, body|uri variables, idempotency, etc.) that a wide
range of clients can consume (even those not "interested in" the
protocol semantics available in the RDF media type).

RDFa seems to come the closest to mixing both design goals and it
starts from the hypermedia design then adds RDF elements.  I haven't
found an inverse of the RDFa model.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:30, Bob Ferris <zazi@...> wrote:
> Hi Markus,
>
> well, from my POV (a Semantic Web biased one), I would agree. However, I
> always got and get the impression that the REST/hypermedia community
> doesn't agree on this equation*.
> I guess, it has something to do with the hypermedia support that
> surrounds the utilisation of link relation types, i.e. they are values
> of rel attributes of tags, e.g., "link", "a", or "area". These tags and
> their attributes define the processing (e.g. enc-type, method, ...) of
> referred resources (in the media type definition). Furthermore, in such
> a hypermedia context a client should know whether it is a navigational
> link, an embedded link, etc.
> On the other side, RDF is a data model or knowledge representation
> structure, which should be embeddable into other existing hypermedia
> media types (as it already can done with RDFa, see XHTML+RDFa). So RDF
> serialisation (/representation) formats doesn't need this
> functionalities themselves.
> I somehow believe that is better, if these two concerns are separable
> and one could mix them as needed, because not every client needs the
> knowledge of the underlying resource/model description.
>
> Cheers,
>
>
> Bo
>
>
> *) which is so obvious from my POV :) (because it's all about binary
> relations in that context)
>
> PS: Interesting to read in that context:
> http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1065 +
> http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1083
>
> PPS: I still believe that H-Factor is a very good measurement for
> hypermedia, see http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/
>
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18391
Sender:Peter Williams <pezra@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 20:15:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

I'm not sure

On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:08 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@yahoo.com> wrote:
> However, I've not yet been able to design an RDF media type that
> _also_ expresses protocol-level semantics (i.e. navigate|embed,
> protocol method, body|uri variables, idempotency, etc.) that a wide
> range of clients can consume (even those not "interested in" the
> protocol semantics available in the RDF media type).

I don't think i understand the issues you mention.

 * I dont know what you mean by "navigate|embed" means. If i have an
HTTP link to a resource then i can, by virtue of the uniform
interface, try to navigate to that url. If the resource does not
support GET it will respond with 405. Embedding is a very different
issue that seem deeply related to the media type. For example it is
trivial with RDF-ish media types and impossible with HTML (at least
formally).

 * I am not sure why protocol method is important. We have the uniform
interface so any method may be called on any resource. It might be a
useful hint sometimes but is it every required?

 * I don't know of any form-ish vocabularies for RDF, but it doesn't
seem like that would be all that difficult to implement. That being
said, i don't feel like that not having forms is a show stopper for a
media type.

 * Idempotency is defined by the uniform interface (at least in HTTP),
not by the media type. Why would a media type need to encode this type
of information?

Maybe i am missing your point?

I don't know if RDF-ish approaches are a good way to build RESTful
HTTP systems but they seem like they might be. `@rel` really is very
similar to the property id in RDF. Otherwise RDFa would not be able to
use it for that purpose so effortlessly.

I suppose RDF does make finding navigable links in a tad more
difficult. You have to look at all the properties and find the ones
whose value is a resource, rather than having a separate list of
properties with resources as values vs properties with other types of
values. OTOH, I have always thought it weird that the REST community
treats links a magically special. Unifying the model make me more
comfortable: a link is nothing more, or less, than a property of a
resource whose value is another resource.

Peter

> RDFa seems to come the closest to mixing both design goals and it
> starts from the hypermedia design then adds RDF elements.  I haven't
> found an inverse of the RDFa model.
>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
>
>
>
> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:30, Bob Ferris <zazi@...> wrote:

>> well, from my POV (a Semantic Web biased one), I would agree. However, I
>> always got and get the impression that the REST/hypermedia community
>> doesn't agree on this equation*.
>> I guess, it has something to do with the hypermedia support that
>> surrounds the utilisation of link relation types, i.e. they are values
>> of rel attributes of tags, e.g., "link", "a", or "area". These tags and
>> their attributes define the processing (e.g. enc-type, method, ...) of
>> referred resources (in the media type definition). Furthermore, in such
>> a hypermedia context a client should know whether it is a navigational
>> link, an embedded link, etc.
>> On the other side, RDF is a data model or knowledge representation
>> structure, which should be embeddable into other existing hypermedia
>> media types (as it already can done with RDFa, see XHTML+RDFa). So RDF
>> serialisation (/representation) formats doesn't need this

>>>  > [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17242
>>>  >
>>>  >
>>>  > On 1/8/2012 1:17 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>>>  > > Hi,
>>>  > >
>>>  > > Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are
>>>  > just more
>>>  > > terse. Let's look at an example:
>>>  > >
>>>  > > {
>>>  > > "@context": {
>>>  > > "homepage": { "@id": http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type":
>>>  > "@id"
>>>  > > }
>>>  > > }
>>>  > > },
>>>  > > "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
>>>  > > "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
>>>  > > }
>>>  > >
>>>  > > This (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON
>>>  > object
>>>  > > which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepage according to
>>>  > the FOAF
>>>  > > vocabulary - that's the rel part, isn't it!? The value of it is
>>>  > > "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/". The coercion in the context tells
>>>  > a
>>>  > > JSON-LD parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus
>>>  > allows a
>>>  > > client to follow that link.
>>>  > >
>>>  > > See also Manu Sporny's comment on Mark Notthingsham's blog post about
>>>  > > "Linking in JSON" [1]. I think there is still some confusion about
>>>  > what
>>>  > > JSON-LD is (intended to be).
>>>  > >
>>>  > > [1] http://www.mnot.net/blog/2011/11/25/linking_in_json#comment-1737
>>>  > >
>>>  > > --
>>>  > > Markus Lanthaler
>>>  > > @markuslanthaler
>>>  > >
>>>  > > > -----Original Message-----
>>>  > > > From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
>>> <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com>
>>>  > > <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:rest-
>>>  > > > discuss@yahoogroups.com <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>
>>> <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>] On
>>>  > Behalf
>>>  > > Of Bob Ferris
>>>  > > > Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2012 6:58 PM
>>>  > > > Cc: 'REST-Discuss Discussion Group'
>>>  > > > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > > Hi Markus,
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > > at a first glance your referred papers are looking very promising.
>>>  > They
>>>  > > > remind me to a discussion we had appr. one year ago about the
>>>  > > > REST-i-ness of SPARQL (see [1]).
>>>  > > > However, the problem with JSON-LD still is, that it doesn't
>>>  > utilise
>>>  > > > link
>>>  > > > relation types (as it is the same problem with all RDF
>>>  > serialisation
>>>  > > > formats ATM). In contrast, HAL makes use of link relations types
>>>  > > > ("href", ...), and, hence, supports the HATEOAS constraint of
>>>  > REST.
>>>  > > > So my solution proposal for this problem still is to design a
>>>  > > > vocabulary
>>>  > > > to describe link relation type definitions in a machine
>>>  > processable way
>>>  > > > and attach these definitions to our well-known RDF property
>>>  > > > definitions,
>>>  > > > i.e., then we have knowledge about the property (relation) itself
>>>  > and
>>>  > > > how it can be processed by a client.
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > > Cheers,
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > > Bo
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > > [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17281
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > >
>>>  > > > On 1/8/2012 11:38 AM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>>>  > > > > Mike, could you elaborate on what exactly makes HAL "much less
>>>  > > > > convoluted than JSON-LD"?
>>>  > > > >
>>>  > > > > --

>>>  > media
>>>  > > > type;
>>>  > > > > > one that combines JSON:s simple expressiveness with native
>>>  > support
>>>  > > > for
>>>  > > > > > hyperlinks! :-)

>>>  > support

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18392
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 20:42:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Peter:

my comment here is not about designing messages where _all_
possibilities exist at _all_ times, but is instead about designing
messages where the server can indicate to the client what options are
available and valid "at this point in time." (i.e. you don't see the
"details" link in the message because you are not yet logged in" or
"you don't see the "markup for adding an invoice because you are not
authorized to do so" or 'You don't see the link for reports because
the reports are not yet avaialble" and so forth).

Here are some examples:
HTML.IMG
means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"

X.INCLUDE
means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"

HTML.A
means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"

ATOM.LINK@rel="alternate"
means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"

HTML.FORM@method=":get"
means "collect the arguments, construct a URI and navigate to that
resource using the HTTP method "get" (don't make a body w/ the args)"

HTML.FORM@method="post"
means "collect the arguments, construct a body and navigate to that
resource using the HTTP method "post" (don't construct a URI w/ the
args)"

ATOM:LINK@rel="edit"
means "use this link to PUT or DELETE the indicated resource using
guidlines set out in AtomPub

none of the RDF media types i have encountered have these affordances
built in; there is no universal way for servers to inform clients of
the valid/appropriate possibilities at any point in time. Clients must
have this information hard-coded instead.

FWIW, Mark Baker built the RDF Forms[1] ontology, but i've not seen
that in production use. I've seen an attempt to mimic HTTP GET & POST
using an RDF conversion[1], but not seen that in production use.


[1] http://www.markbaker.ca/2003/05/RDF-Forms/
[2] http://www.lsrn.org/semweb/rdfpost.html

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 15:15, Peter Williams <pezra@barelyenough.org> wrote:
> I'm not sure
>
> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:08 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>> However, I've not yet been able to design an RDF media type that
>> _also_ expresses protocol-level semantics (i.e. navigate|embed,
>> protocol method, body|uri variables, idempotency, etc.) that a wide
>> range of clients can consume (even those not "interested in" the
>> protocol semantics available in the RDF media type).
>
> I don't think i understand the issues you mention.
>
>  * I dont know what you mean by "navigate|embed" means. If i have an
> HTTP link to a resource then i can, by virtue of the uniform
> interface, try to navigate to that url. If the resource does not
> support GET it will respond with 405. Embedding is a very different
> issue that seem deeply related to the media type. For example it is
> trivial with RDF-ish media types and impossible with HTML (at least
> formally).
>
>  * I am not sure why protocol method is important. We have the uniform
> interface so any method may be called on any resource. It might be a
> useful hint sometimes but is it every required?
>
>  * I don't know of any form-ish vocabularies for RDF, but it doesn't
> seem like that would be all that difficult to implement. That being
> said, i don't feel like that not having forms is a show stopper for a
> media type.
>
>  * Idempotency is defined by the uniform interface (at least in HTTP),
> not by the media type. Why would a media type need to encode this type
> of information?
>
> Maybe i am missing your point?
>
> I don't know if RDF-ish approaches are a good way to build RESTful
> HTTP systems but they seem like they might be. `@rel` really is very
> similar to the property id in RDF. Otherwise RDFa would not be able to
> use it for that purpose so effortlessly.
>
> I suppose RDF does make finding navigable links in a tad more
> difficult. You have to look at all the properties and find the ones
> whose value is a resource, rather than having a separate list of
> properties with resources as values vs properties with other types of
> values. OTOH, I have always thought it weird that the REST community
> treats links a magically special. Unifying the model make me more
> comfortable: a link is nothing more, or less, than a property of a
> resource whose value is another resource.
>
> Peter
>
>> RDFa seems to come the closest to mixing both design goals and it
>> starts from the hypermedia design then adds RDF elements.  I haven't
>> found an inverse of the RDFa model.
>>
>> mca
>> http://amundsen.com/blog/
>> http://twitter.com@mamund
>> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:30, Bob Ferris <zazi@smiy.org> wrote:
>>> Hi Markus,
>>>
>>> well, from my POV (a Semantic Web biased one), I would agree. However, I
>>> always got and get the impression that the REST/hypermedia community
>>> doesn't agree on this equation*.
>>> I guess, it has something to do with the hypermedia support that
>>> surrounds the utilisation of link relation types, i.e. they are values
>>> of rel attributes of tags, e.g., "link", "a", or "area". These tags and
>>> their attributes define the processing (e.g. enc-type, method, ...) of
>>> referred resources (in the media type definition). Furthermore, in such
>>> a hypermedia context a client should know whether it is a navigational
>>> link, an embedded link, etc.
>>> On the other side, RDF is a data model or knowledge representation
>>> structure, which should be embeddable into other existing hypermedia
>>> media types (as it already can done with RDFa, see XHTML+RDFa). So RDF
>>> serialisation (/representation) formats doesn't need this
>>> functionalities themselves.
>>> I somehow believe that is better, if these two concerns are separable
>>> and one could mix them as needed, because not every client needs the
>>> knowledge of the underlying resource/model description.
>>>
>>> Cheers,
>>>
>>>
>>> Bo
>>>
>>>
>>> *) which is so obvious from my POV :) (because it's all about binary
>>> relations in that context)
>>>
>>> PS: Interesting to read in that context:
>>> http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1065 +
>>> http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1083
>>>
>>> PPS: I still believe that H-Factor is a very good measurement for
>>> hypermedia, see http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/
>>>
>>>
>>> On 1/9/2012 5:13 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>>>> Bob,
>>>>
>>>> I've read the thread you referenced but I still don't understand why link
>>>> relations should any different. A predicate (or a labeled edge in a graph)
>>>> does nothing else than connecting two (data) nodes. If I know the
>>>> relationship of node B to node A I also know how to process it or if I would
>>>> be interested in following that link.
>>>>
>>>> --
>>>> Markus Lanthaler
>>>> @markuslanthaler
>>>>
>>>>  > -----Original Message-----
>>>>  > From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
>>>> <mailto:rest-discuss%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:rest-
>>>>  > discuss@yahoogroups.com <mailto:discuss%40yahoogroups.com>] On Behalf
>>>> Of Bob Ferris
>>>>  > Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2012 9:06 PM
>>>>  > Cc: 'REST-Discuss Discussion Group'
>>>>  > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
>>>>  >
>>>>  > Hi Markus,
>>>>  >
>>>>  > link relation type definition are not (RDF) property definitions. Where
>>>>  > the latter ones define something about the properties (relations) it
>>>>  > themselves, the former ones include something about the processing of
>>>>  > these relations, i.e., how to handle the referred object.
>>>>  > To sum up, link relation type definitions are usually orthogonal to
>>>>  > (RDF) property definitions. See also, e.g., [1] for a detailed
>>>>  > discussion on this issue and related ones.
>>>>  >
>>>>  > Cheers,
>>>>  >
>>>>  >
>>>>  > Bo
>>>>  >
>>>>  >
>>>>  > [1] http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/17242
>>>>  >
>>>>  >
>>>>  > On 1/8/2012 1:17 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>>>>  > > Hi,
>>>>  > >
>>>>  > > Why do you think JSON-LD doesn't utilize link relations? They are
>>>>  > just more
>>>>  > > terse. Let's look at an example:
>>>>  > >
>>>>  > > {
>>>>  > > "@context": {
>>>>  > > "homepage": { "@id": http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type":
>>>>  > "@id"
>>>>  > > }
>>>>  > > }
>>>>  > > },
>>>>  > > "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
>>>>  > > "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
>>>>  > > }
>>>>  > >
>>>>  > > This (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON
>>>>  > object
>>>>  > > which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepage according to
>>>>  > the FOAF
>>>>  > > vocabulary - that's the rel part, isn't it!? The value of it is
>>>>  > > "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/". The coercion in the context tells
>>>>  > a
>>>>  > > JSON-LD parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus
>>>>  > allows a
>>>>  > > client to follow that link.
>>>>  > >
>>>>  > > See also Manu Sporny's comment on Mark Notthingsham's blog post about
>>>>  > > "Linking in JSON" [1]. I think there is still some confusion about
>>>>  > what
>>>>  > > JSON-LD is (intended to be).
>>>>  > >
>>>>  > > [1] http://www.mnot.net/blog/2011/11/25/linking_in_json#comment-1737
>>>>  > >
>>>>  > > --
>>>>  > > Markus Lanthaler
>>>>  > > @markuslanthaler

>>>>  > > >
>>>>  > > > Hi Markus,
>>>>  > > >
>>>>  > > > at a first glance your referred papers are looking very promising.
>>>>  > They
>>>>  > > > remind me to a discussion we had appr. one year ago about the
>>>>  > > > REST-i-ness of SPARQL (see [1]).
>>>>  > > > However, the problem with JSON-LD still is, that it doesn't
>>>>  > utilise
>>>>  > > > link
>>>>  > > > relation types (as it is the same problem with all RDF
>>>>  > serialisation
>>>>  > > > formats ATM). In contrast, HAL makes use of link relations types
>>>>  > > > ("href", ...), and, hence, supports the HATEOAS constraint of
>>>>  > REST.
>>>>  > > > So my solution proposal for this problem still is to design a
>>>>  > > > vocabulary
>>>>  > > > to describe link relation type definitions in a machine
>>>>  > processable way
>>>>  > > > and attach these definitions to our well-known RDF property
>>>>  > > > definitions,
>>>>  > > > i.e., then we have knowledge about the property (relation) itself
>>>>  > and
>>>>  > > > how it can be processed by a client.
>>>>  > > >

>>>>  > > >
>>>>  > > >
>>>>  > > > Bo
