-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18393
Sender:Peter Williams <pezra@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-09 23:52:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 1:42 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> Peter:
>
> my comment here is not about designing messages where _all_
> possibilities exist at _all_ times, but is instead about designing
> messages where the server can indicate to the client what options are
> available and valid "at this point in time." (i.e. you don't see the
> "details" link in the message because you are not yet logged in" or
> "you don't see the "markup for adding an invoice because you are not
> authorized to do so" or 'You don't see the link for reports because
> the reports are not yet avaialble" and so forth).

What is the problem with a server simply omitting properties that a
requester is not allowed to see? This is usually how we handling this
in HTML.  Why would the same approach not work with an RDF-ish media
type?

> Here are some examples:
> HTML.IMG
> means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"
>
> X.INCLUDE
> means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"

If the embedded image feature of HTML had been implemented as `<link
rel="embedded-image" href="..."/>` would we be worse off (from a REST
perspective)?  If a `link` with a specific rel is pretty much the same
as the `img` tag then it seems that we could achieve that result with
RDF-ish formats. If you think there is a material difference, please
example that in more details

My gut feeling is that retrieve vs navigate is a distinction without
much of a difference in the context of automated user agents. The
distinction is obviously important for certain clients (ie, browsers)
but not for others (ie, proxies, screen readers, etc).

> HTML.A
> means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"
>
> ATOM.LINK@rel="alternate"
> means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"

Seems like most links are either the "navigate" flavor or have some
specific semantics to the user agent that could be specified with an
`@rel`. Given the markup nature of HTML it probably needs a special
form of link to "linkify some text". I don't see the need for more
than two kinds of links in HTML, and in more automata oriented formats
it seems that one flavor of link should be sufficient.

> HTML.FORM@method=":get"
> means "collect the arguments, construct a URI and navigate to that
> resource using the HTTP method "get" (don't make a body w/ the args)"
>
> HTML.FORM@method="post"
> means "collect the arguments, construct a body and navigate to that
> resource using the HTTP method "post" (don't construct a URI w/ the
> args)"

Yeah, uri template support and a form vocabulary would be useful.
However, may systems do not require that set of capabilities. I don't
see the method paramater as all that important.

A get form is really just a specification for how to render a UI for a
URI template. For an automated user agent such a specification is
superflous, the same thing can be accomplished with just a link whose
target is a URI template. (Possibly with a couple of extra resources
representing the set of valid values for the various options.)

Similarly, in the context of automated user agents, anything you can
do with a form, you can do without form by sufficiently specifying the
media type and/or relationships.

(Though in some situations a form might better than either of the
above choices.)

> ATOM:LINK@rel="edit"
> means "use this link to PUT or DELETE the indicated resource using
> guidlines set out in AtomPub
>
> none of the RDF media types i have encountered have these affordances
> built in; there is no universal way for servers to inform clients of
> the valid/appropriate possibilities at any point in time. Clients must
> have this information hard-coded instead.

So is your point that no one has bothered to put together a decent RDF
based media type?  Or that it would be very difficult/impossible to do
so?

These affordances you've mentioned are either built on link+@rel which
is, at least to me, semantically indistinguishable from an RDF triple,
or they are media type specific, and therefore not "universal".  Even
the ones that seem particularly distinctive don't always mean what
they are specified to mean.

For example, if my automated user agent reads in an HTML page it does
*not* retrieve and embed image resources linked to by that page.
Neither do the accelerating proxies though which it passes, they just
retrieve and cache. Interestingly they do exactly the same thing with
the `a` tags in the HTML. For the proxies there is no distinction
between `img` and `a` tags except perhaps in prioritization.

Peter
barelyenough.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18394
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 01:09:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

[cross-posting to hypermedia-web]

Peter:

good to see your reply.

- omitting _properties_ of the message? not following you here. maybe an example you can point to would clear this up for me.
 
- seems you assume M2M here in several of your replies. is it your POV that RDF is only to be used in M2M scenarios? or do you mean to say that some of the affordances is describe have no value in M2M cases?

- IME, transclusion is not exclusively a H2M (human-to-machine) affordance, i use "x:include" quite often in M2M cases

- templates (URI or body) are of mixed value in M2M, IME. as long as the vocab is stable and the templates are used to control timing and flow, this has worked well for me. of course H2M templates are much easier to support since the selector is not in the code, but in the head of the human.

finally:
<snip>
> So is your point that no one has bothered to put together a decent RDF
> based media type? Â Or that it would be very difficult/impossible to do
> so?
</snip>

i cited cases where people "bothered" to add affordances (i.e. Baker), made a value judgement on it's usefulness, and mentioned that they are not in production (that i can find). feel free to point out my blind spot there.

is it possible? not sure. my first attempts have not been good, but that's proly *me*<g>. 

is it *important*? not really. CSV doesn't provide affordances and it does quite well. my comment here is really about my particular experience. 

i am writing apps where clients are expected to recognize, parse, and (in some cases) render and/or activate affordances in responses. When i implement those apps, RDF is not something i find fits the bill; that's all.

now, i am quite ready to be shown a fool on this last point; to be given proof that i _can_ write clients that recognize hypermedia affordances in RDF-based media types. would be way cool.  

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 18:52, Peter Williams <pezra@barelyenough.org> wrote:
> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 1:42 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@yahoo.com> wrote:
>> Peter:
>>
>> my comment here is not about designing messages where _all_
>> possibilities exist at _all_ times, but is instead about designing
>> messages where the server can indicate to the client what options are
>> available and valid "at this point in time." (i.e. you don't see the
>> "details" link in the message because you are not yet logged in" or
>> "you don't see the "markup for adding an invoice because you are not
>> authorized to do so" or 'You don't see the link for reports because
>> the reports are not yet avaialble" and so forth).
>
> What is the problem with a server simply omitting properties that a
> requester is not allowed to see? This is usually how we handling this
> in HTML. Â Why would the same approach not work with an RDF-ish media
> type?
>
>> Here are some examples:
>> HTML.IMG
>> means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"
>>
>> X.INCLUDE
>> means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"
>
> If the embedded image feature of HTML had been implemented as `<link
> rel="embedded-image" href="..."/>` would we be worse off (from a REST
> perspective)? Â If a `link` with a specific rel is pretty much the same
> as the `img` tag then it seems that we could achieve that result with
> RDF-ish formats. If you think there is a material difference, please
> example that in more details
>
> My gut feeling is that retrieve vs navigate is a distinction without
> much of a difference in the context of automated user agents. The
> distinction is obviously important for certain clients (ie, browsers)
> but not for others (ie, proxies, screen readers, etc).
>
>> HTML.A
>> means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"
>>
>> ATOM.LINK@rel="alternate"
>> means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"
>
> Seems like most links are either the "navigate" flavor or have some
> specific semantics to the user agent that could be specified with an
> `@rel`. Given the markup nature of HTML it probably needs a special
> form of link to "linkify some text". I don't see the need for more
> than two kinds of links in HTML, and in more automata oriented formats
> it seems that one flavor of link should be sufficient.
>
>> HTML.FORM@method=":get"
>> means "collect the arguments, construct a URI and navigate to that
>> resource using the HTTP method "get" (don't make a body w/ the args)"
>>
>> HTML.FORM@method="post"
>> means "collect the arguments, construct a body and navigate to that
>> resource using the HTTP method "post" (don't construct a URI w/ the
>> args)"
>
> Yeah, uri template support and a form vocabulary would be useful.
> However, may systems do not require that set of capabilities. I don't
> see the method paramater as all that important.
>
> A get form is really just a specification for how to render a UI for a
> URI template. For an automated user agent such a specification is
> superflous, the same thing can be accomplished with just a link whose
> target is a URI template. (Possibly with a couple of extra resources
> representing the set of valid values for the various options.)
>
> Similarly, in the context of automated user agents, anything you can
> do with a form, you can do without form by sufficiently specifying the
> media type and/or relationships.
>
> (Though in some situations a form might better than either of the
> above choices.)
>
>> ATOM:LINK@rel="edit"
>> means "use this link to PUT or DELETE the indicated resource using
>> guidlines set out in AtomPub
>>
>> none of the RDF media types i have encountered have these affordances
>> built in; there is no universal way for servers to inform clients of
>> the valid/appropriate possibilities at any point in time. Clients must
>> have this information hard-coded instead.
>
> So is your point that no one has bothered to put together a decent RDF
> based media type? Â Or that it would be very difficult/impossible to do
> so?
>
> These affordances you've mentioned are either built on link+@rel which
> is, at least to me, semantically indistinguishable from an RDF triple,
> or they are media type specific, and therefore not "universal". Â Even
> the ones that seem particularly distinctive don't always mean what
> they are specified to mean.
>
> For example, if my automated user agent reads in an HTML page it does
> *not* retrieve and embed image resources linked to by that page.
> Neither do the accelerating proxies though which it passes, they just
> retrieve and cache. Interestingly they do exactly the same thing with
> the `a` tags in the HTML. For the proxies there is no distinction
> between `img` and `a` tags except perhaps in prioritization.
>
> Peter
> barelyenough.org
>
>
> ------------------------------------
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18395
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 01:32:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Yep. But RDF(a) also brings a load of baggage most APIs don't need, the same way HTML does. The real issue with them both, as far as machine apps go, is their over-affordance with features that aren't relevant to the real needs of RESTful APIs. Call it terseness or bloat, they aren't really fit for purpose and there's not enough benefits to keep most people from looking elsewhere for a simpler option that will keep their app easy to consume. This has lead most people  to use either plain XML/JSON or roll their own domain specific media type - both of which are bad outcomes for the web. They're also potentially avoidable outcomes in future if we provide a media type with only the very essential affordances built in - which is exactly what we are doing with HAL. 

On 9 Jan 2012, at 11:52 PM, Peter Williams <pezra@barelyenough.org> wrote:

> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 1:42 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> > Peter:
> >
> > my comment here is not about designing messages where _all_
> > possibilities exist at _all_ times, but is instead about designing
> > messages where the server can indicate to the client what options are
> > available and valid "at this point in time." (i.e. you don't see the
> > "details" link in the message because you are not yet logged in" or
> > "you don't see the "markup for adding an invoice because you are not
> > authorized to do so" or 'You don't see the link for reports because
> > the reports are not yet avaialble" and so forth).
> 
> What is the problem with a server simply omitting properties that a
> requester is not allowed to see? This is usually how we handling this
> in HTML. Why would the same approach not work with an RDF-ish media
> type?
> 
> > Here are some examples:
> > HTML.IMG
> > means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"
> >
> > X.INCLUDE
> > means "retrieve the resource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"
> 
> If the embedded image feature of HTML had been implemented as `<link
> rel="embedded-image" href="..."/>` would we be worse off (from a REST
> perspective)? If a `link` with a specific rel is pretty much the same
> as the `img` tag then it seems that we could achieve that result with
> RDF-ish formats. If you think there is a material difference, please
> example that in more details
> 
> My gut feeling is that retrieve vs navigate is a distinction without
> much of a difference in the context of automated user agents. The
> distinction is obviously important for certain clients (ie, browsers)
> but not for others (ie, proxies, screen readers, etc).
> 
> > HTML.A
> > means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"
> >
> > ATOM.LINK@rel="alternate"
> > means "navigate to the resource (don't embed it)"
> 
> Seems like most links are either the "navigate" flavor or have some
> specific semantics to the user agent that could be specified with an
> `@rel`. Given the markup nature of HTML it probably needs a special
> form of link to "linkify some text". I don't see the need for more
> than two kinds of links in HTML, and in more automata oriented formats
> it seems that one flavor of link should be sufficient.
> 
> > HTML.FORM@method=":get"
> > means "collect the arguments, construct a URI and navigate to that
> > resource using the HTTP method "get" (don't make a body w/ the args)"
> >
> > HTML.FORM@method="post"
> > means "collect the arguments, construct a body and navigate to that
> > resource using the HTTP method "post" (don't construct a URI w/ the
> > args)"
> 
> Yeah, uri template support and a form vocabulary would be useful.
> However, may systems do not require that set of capabilities. I don't
> see the method paramater as all that important.
> 
> A get form is really just a specification for how to render a UI for a
> URI template. For an automated user agent such a specification is
> superflous, the same thing can be accomplished with just a link whose
> target is a URI template. (Possibly with a couple of extra resources
> representing the set of valid values for the various options.)
> 
> Similarly, in the context of automated user agents, anything you can
> do with a form, you can do without form by sufficiently specifying the
> media type and/or relationships.
> 
> (Though in some situations a form might better than either of the
> above choices.)
> 
> > ATOM:LINK@rel="edit"
> > means "use this link to PUT or DELETE the indicated resource using
> > guidlines set out in AtomPub
> >
> > none of the RDF media types i have encountered have these affordances
> > built in; there is no universal way for servers to inform clients of
> > the valid/appropriate possibilities at any point in time. Clients must
> > have this information hard-coded instead.
> 
> So is your point that no one has bothered to put together a decent RDF
> based media type? Or that it would be very difficult/impossible to do
> so?
> 
> These affordances you've mentioned are either built on link+@rel which
> is, at least to me, semantically indistinguishable from an RDF triple,
> or they are media type specific, and therefore not "universal". Even
> the ones that seem particularly distinctive don't always mean what
> they are specified to mean.
> 
> For example, if my automated user agent reads in an HTML page it does
> *not* retrieve and embed image resources linked to by that page.
> Neither do the accelerating proxies though which it passes, they just
> retrieve and cache. Interestingly they do exactly the same thing with
> the `a` tags in the HTML. For the proxies there is no distinction
> between `img` and `a` tags except perhaps in prioritization.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18396
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 01:52:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Mike:

Check my understanding of the HAL design:

HAL offers just one hypermedia affordance: link navigation (or LO in the
H-Factor[1] list) with a @rel decorator(or CL in the H-factor list). The
value of the @rel provides the sole association with _all_ the semantic
details for the link (both protocol-level and domain-level).

The semantic details are spelled out in human-readable formz9in some
external Out-of-band document) and it is up to the developer to code this
human-readable information into the client before releasing the client
"into the wild". The response message contains no templates/forms, no
indications of transclusion, safety, or idempotency; that information is
always in the documentation alone.

For example, if the resource at the other end of the link allows one or
more optional arguments to be included, this is in documentation and not
indicated in the message. If the resource expects a DELETE or PUT to be
used along w/ a body, the details on determining which (DELETE or PUT is
used) is in the documentation. If there are required elements when sending
a body, it's in the documentation, and so forth.

Do I have this pretty much correct?

[1] http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 20:32, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> Yep. But RDF(a) also brings a load of baggage most APIs don't need, the
> same way HTML does. The real issue with them both, as far as machine apps
> go, is their over-affordance with features that aren't relevant to the real
> needs of RESTful APIs. Call it terseness or bloat, they aren't really fit
> for purpose and there's not enough benefits to keep most people from
> looking elsewhere for a simpler option that will keep their app easy to
> consume. This has lead most people  to use either plain XML/JSON or roll
> their own domain specific media type - both of which are bad outcomes for
> the web. They're also potentially avoidable outcomes in future if we
> provide a media type with only the very essential affordances built in -
> which is exactly what we are doing with HAL.

> > means "collect the arguments, construct a body and navigate to that
> > resource using the HTTP method "post" (don't construct a URI w/ the
> > args)"

> However, may systems do not require that set of capabilities. I don't
> see the method paramater as all that important.

> A get form is really just a specification for how to render a UI for a
> URI template. For an automated user agent such a specification is
> superflous, the same thing can be accomplished with just a link whose
> target is a URI template. (Possibly with a couple of extra resources
> representing the set of valid values for the various options.)
>

> do with a form, you can do without form by sufficiently specifying the
> media type and/or relationships.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18397
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 04:28:45
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tuesday, January 10, 2012 9:52 AM, mike amundsen wrote:
> The semantic details are spelled out in human-readable formz9in
> some external Out-of-band document) and it is up to the developer
> to code this human-readable information into the client before
> releasing the client "into the wild". The response message contains
> no templates/forms, no indications of transclusion, safety, or 
> idempotency; that information is always in the documentation alone. 

That is exactly how I understand HAL as well. And since all of this is not
machine-readable at all the only real option is to hardcode those "rel"
values into the client. I could as well use a plain old JSON object property
whose value is the URI instead of having to put it into a special "_links"
property.

So, how is HAL e.g. different from using POX with Atom's link element?



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18398
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 04:47:39
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Mike,

I think we should differentiate between the data (model?) layer and the
presentation layer in this discussion. The difference between LO and LE in
this instance really just matters if a human being is looking at a rendered
representation of the data (should the image be rendered or not?). Or do I
misunderstand you in this regard?

> - omitting _properties_ of the message? not following you here. maybe
> an example you can point to would clear this up for me.

I think what Peter meant here was that just as in, e.g., HTML you could
ommit certain RDF properties in the message if you don't want that a client
follows/knows those URIs. It's similar to removing an <a> from an HTML
representation if you wanna remove that state transition.

Simple example in pseudo-code

{
  "@type": "order",
  "@id": "/orders/13574",
  "total": 150.69,
  "payment": "/payment/49840"
}

If you would omit the payment property the client wouldn't be able to follow
that link, which is similar to omitting an

  <a href="/payment/49840" rel="payment">Payment</a>

from an HTML representation.


> - seems you assume M2M here in several of your replies. is it your POV
> that RDF is only to be used in M2M scenarios? or do you mean to say
> that some of the affordances is describe have no value in M2M cases?

I don't know about Peter's POV but mine is that RDF has a great potential to
allow both, M2M and H2M, much better than, e.g., HTML where the link
relations are just described in a human readable fashion. We are far away
from that but since in RDF everything is machine processable a client could
"learn" (or maybe better infer) the meaning of new link relations based on
his already existing knowledge for instance.


> - IME, transclusion is not exclusively a H2M (human-to-machine)
> affordance, i use "x:include" quite often in M2M cases

Hmm... Could you elaborate a bit on this? Why don't you simply include it,
i.e., merge it into the response instead of just linking to it?


> - templates (URI or body) are of mixed value in M2M, IME. as long as
> the vocab is stable and the templates are used to control timing and
> flow, this has worked well for me. of course H2M templates are much
> easier to support since the selector is not in the code, but in the
> head of the human.

Again, IMHO this is part of the presentational logic which is unimportant in
M2M scenarios. As long as a M2M client is able to understand the template's
variables and fill them with concrete values there isn't really any
difference to a form, right?


> i am writing apps where clients are expected to recognize, parse, and
> (in some cases) render and/or activate affordances in responses. When i
> implement those apps, RDF is not something i find fits the bill; that's
> all.

But you need to program those client apps to look for specific
links/forms/affordances, right? So why do you think this is any different?
The only difference I see is that instead of having just a human readable
documentation you make (parts of) it also machine-processable.

But I agree, there is a need for a small and simple vocabulary to describe
basic control flows - something I planned to work on rather sooner than
later.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18399
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 05:43:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

inline....

On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 23:47, Markus Lanthaler <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> Mike,
>
> I think we should differentiate between the data (model?) layer and the
> presentation layer in this discussion. The difference between LO and LE in
> this instance really just matters if a human being is looking at a rendered
> representation of the data (should the image be rendered or not?). Or do I
> misunderstand you in this regard?

while i used HTML in some examples, the idea of transclusion and
navigation are not limited to visual affordances. i cited x:include as
one example and could have using LINK, X:LINK, etc. in others. in an
M2M scenario i have in mind (a real life example, btw), a set of
machines make requests of a server in order to get "work" to complete
(in this case documents and/or images to process in various ways as
indicated by data returned by the servers). these bots recognize (in
one case) affordances that instruct the client to gather other data
from other locations in order to complete a single document that is to
be sent to the server for additional work. in another case, the client
recognizes affordances that instruct the client to go evaluate the
current state of the resource, select optimal values and submit them
to one or more servers for additional processing. and so forth.

in the example i offer here, the number and type of affordance varies
per request, the number of varible arguments (i.e. members of
templates/forms) can vary, too. in some cases idempotent requests are
appropriate, in others non-idempotent requests are the "correct"
choice. most of the requests are "safe", but some are not. this
information appears in the messages clients receive.

it's their job to recognize, parse, evaluate, and activate until
reaching a goal (usually that goal is "all works is done, thanks")


>
>> - omitting _properties_ of the message? not following you here. maybe
>> an example you can point to would clear this up for me.
>
> I think what Peter meant here was that just as in, e.g., HTML you could
> ommit certain RDF properties in the message if you don't want that a client
> follows/knows those URIs. It's similar to removing an <a> from an HTML
> representation if you wanna remove that state transition.
>
> Simple example in pseudo-code
>
> {
>  "@type": "order",
>  "@id": "/orders/13574",
>  "total": 150.69,
>  "payment": "/payment/49840"
> }
>
> If you would omit the payment property the client wouldn't be able to follow
> that link, which is similar to omitting an
>
>  <a href="/payment/49840" rel="payment">Payment</a>
>
> from an HTML representation.

if i understand you, you are making a case for representations that
indicate variance in what selections clients have; what action they
can take. this _seems_ to be at odds w/ what peter indicated to me in
his reply.
<snip>We have the uniform interface so any method may be called on any
resource.</snip>
do you think i am mis-representing peter's reply here?

>
>
>> - seems you assume M2M here in several of your replies. is it your POV
>> that RDF is only to be used in M2M scenarios? or do you mean to say
>> that some of the affordances is describe have no value in M2M cases?
>
> I don't know about Peter's POV but mine is that RDF has a great potential to
> allow both, M2M and H2M, much better than, e.g., HTML where the link
> relations are just described in a human readable fashion. We are far away
> from that but since in RDF everything is machine processable a client could
> "learn" (or maybe better infer) the meaning of new link relations based on
> his already existing knowledge for instance.

let's steer clear of "meaning" and "learn" here. i am not making any
claims or requirements of this type.  what i have stated to this point
is that there are two types of _information_ i am interested in
including in messages sent from server to client: protocol-level
information and domain-specific information. I have given examples of
protocol-level information that i can include in message designs. i
have asserted that i am unable to clearly indicate that same level of
protocol information when using RDF-based media types. am i incorrect?

to be clear, i am not saying RDF-based media types MUST or SHOULD
carry that information, just that i have yet to see examples of this
level of information in RDF-based media type messages.

i also concede that you and Peter question whether the protocol-level
information i have identified is _needed_ in messages from servers.
Peter states:
"I am not sure why protocol method is important. "
and
"Why would a media type need to encode [idempotency] information?"

And you say:
"The difference between LO and LE ... just matters if a human being is
looking at a rendered representation of the data "
and
"[templates are] part of the presentational logic which is unimportant
in M2M scenarios."

have i mis-quoted here or taken these out of context as to abuse their intent?


>
>
>> - IME, transclusion is not exclusively a H2M (human-to-machine)
>> affordance, i use "x:include" quite often in M2M cases
>
> Hmm... Could you elaborate a bit on this? Why don't you simply include it,
> i.e., merge it into the response instead of just linking to it?

i think the scenario i cited at the top of this reply answers to this point.

>
>
>> - templates (URI or body) are of mixed value in M2M, IME. as long as
>> the vocab is stable and the templates are used to control timing and
>> flow, this has worked well for me. of course H2M templates are much
>> easier to support since the selector is not in the code, but in the
>> head of the human.
>
> Again, IMHO this is part of the presentational logic which is unimportant in
> M2M scenarios. As long as a M2M client is able to understand the template's
> variables and fill them with concrete values there isn't really any
> difference to a form, right?

in the implementations i create, not all possible variables are
acceptable in call cases, even if all variables are _known_
beforehand. in my work clients look in the message to see which of the
client's known variables are valid for this instance and (in some
cases) which are required/optional. there is even at least one case
where variables are group--dependent (if you supply x you MUST supply
x, etc.). these are time/instance dependent cases.

>
>
>> i am writing apps where clients are expected to recognize, parse, and
>> (in some cases) render and/or activate affordances in responses. When i
>> implement those apps, RDF is not something i find fits the bill; that's
>> all.
>
> But you need to program those client apps to look for specific
> links/forms/affordances, right? So why do you think this is any different?
> The only difference I see is that instead of having just a human readable
> documentation you make (parts of) it also machine-processable.

i program clients as state machines to be able to recognize
affordances and respond to them. some are quitre simple (immutable
links for navigation). others are more involved (mutable templates for
completing request bodies, URI templates, choices of one or more "next
steps" evaulated against a goal or other workflow of the client,
etc.).

the work i do right now is not a fixed set of  actions w/ static,
pre-defined parameters. knowing a set of static state transitions
ahead of time is insufficient for this work. instead clients need to
be prepared to respond to representations returned by the server.

>
> But I agree, there is a need for a small and simple vocabulary to describe
> basic control flows - something I planned to work on rather sooner than
> later.

i look forward to hearing more on this.

>
>
>
> --
> Markus Lanthaler
> @markuslanthaler
>
>
>
>
>
>
> ------------------------------------
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18400
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 06:39:12
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> while i used HTML in some examples, the idea of transclusion and
> navigation are not limited to visual affordances. i cited x:include as
> one example and could have using LINK, X:LINK, etc. in others. in an
> M2M scenario i have in mind (a real life example, btw), a set of
> machines make requests of a server in order to get "work" to complete
> (in this case documents and/or images to process in various ways as
> indicated by data returned by the servers). these bots recognize (in
> one case) affordances that instruct the client to gather other data
> from other locations in order to complete a single document that is to
> be sent to the server for additional work. in another case, the client
> recognizes affordances that instruct the client to go evaluate the
> current state of the resource, select optimal values and submit them
> to one or more servers for additional processing. and so forth.

This all sounds good but why should it matter if it's a link or an embed if
it's not rendered to a human user? The client nevertheless has to understand
what to do with that specific resource in order to reach its goal - whether
it's LE or LO doesn't really matter IMO. Or am I wrong?


> if i understand you, you are making a case for representations that
> indicate variance in what selections clients have; what action they
> can take. this _seems_ to be at odds w/ what peter indicated to me in
> his reply.
> <snip>We have the uniform interface so any method may be called on any
> resource.</snip>
> do you think i am mis-representing peter's reply here?

I think so. I think Peter was referring to HTTP methods which are uniform
and available on all resource. Nevertheless those methods might not be
supported and/or allowed for certain resources (at certain times).


> let's steer clear of "meaning" and "learn" here. i am not making any
> claims or requirements of this type.  what i have stated to this point
> is that there are two types of _information_ i am interested in
> including in messages sent from server to client: protocol-level
> information and domain-specific information. I have given examples of
> protocol-level information that i can include in message designs. i
> have asserted that i am unable to clearly indicate that same level of
> protocol information when using RDF-based media types. am i incorrect?

That question here that arises for me is if you can really separate it that
way!? Protocol level information is in my opinion in most cases quite
tightly coupled to the domain-specific information, i.e., the application
domain. In HTML e.g. it's hypertext documents and there it surely makes
sense to have general hyperlinks and forms. In RDF you are talking about raw
data which is interlinked. Since the way of presenting this data is entirely
up to the client I doubt that a "form" is an adequate abstraction.


> i also concede that you and Peter question whether the protocol-level
> information i have identified is _needed_ in messages from servers.
> Peter states:
> "I am not sure why protocol method is important. "
> and
> "Why would a media type need to encode [idempotency] information?"
> 
> And you say:
> "The difference between LO and LE ... just matters if a human being is
> looking at a rendered representation of the data "
> and
> "[templates are] part of the presentational logic which is unimportant
> in M2M scenarios."

I don't question whether they are needed but whether it makes sense to
separate them from the domain specific information. A MIME type is
specifying a format for a more or less specific application domain. That
MIME type also specifies how the protocol-level information has to be
interpreted so I'm not sure if you can really separate them in the way you
propose (as I understand it). IOW for me both are at the same level of
abstraction.


> >> - IME, transclusion is not exclusively a H2M (human-to-machine)
> >> affordance, i use "x:include" quite often in M2M cases
> >
> > Hmm... Could you elaborate a bit on this? Why don't you simply
> include it,
> > i.e., merge it into the response instead of just linking to it?
> 
> i think the scenario i cited at the top of this reply answers to this
> point.

I still don't really understand the difference. It is up to the domain
semantics what the client does. Whether the protocol-level information says
embed or link doesn't make any difference IMHO. But maybe you are more
thinking of splitting the semantics into two parts which are: embed (the
client *has* to follow this link) + process it according the remaining
domain semantics!?


> in the implementations i create, not all possible variables are
> acceptable in call cases, even if all variables are _known_
> beforehand. in my work clients look in the message to see which of the
> client's known variables are valid for this instance and (in some
> cases) which are required/optional. there is even at least one case
> where variables are group--dependent (if you supply x you MUST supply
> x, etc.). these are time/instance dependent cases.

I don't see why this should be a problem..


> i program clients as state machines to be able to recognize
> affordances and respond to them. some are quitre simple (immutable
> links for navigation). others are more involved (mutable templates for
> completing request bodies, URI templates, choices of one or more "next
> steps" evaulated against a goal or other workflow of the client,
> etc.).
> 
> the work i do right now is not a fixed set of  actions w/ static,
> pre-defined parameters. knowing a set of static state transitions
> ahead of time is insufficient for this work. instead clients need to
> be prepared to respond to representations returned by the server.

Maybe you misunderstood me slightly here. All I wanted to say is that it
doesn't matter whether your client looks for a link with rel="payment" or a
JSON property "payment": "URI". It's just a different syntax, that's all..


> > But I agree, there is a need for a small and simple vocabulary to
> describe
> > basic control flows - something I planned to work on rather sooner
> than
> > later.
> 
> i look forward to hearing more on this.

If I just would have a bit more time :-(



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

Message:

Markus:
ok, let me ask you directly, can you imagine any circumstance where
the differences between transclusion (LE) and navigation (LO) "matter"
in an M2M scenario? mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18402
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 07:39:18
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tuesday, January 10, 2012 3:11 PM, mike amundsen wrote:
> Markus:
> ok, let me ask you directly, can you imagine any circumstance where
> the differences between transclusion (LE) and navigation (LO) "matter"
> in an M2M scenario? mca

Hmm.. honestly I can't come up with any scenario where the difference
matters. Let's take an example from the H Factor page [1]:

  LE: <img src="http://www.example.org/images/logo" title="company logo" />

Would the following be any different from a M2M POV? Would it render some
functionality impossible?

  LO: <a href="http://www.example.org/images/logo" title="company
logo">company logo</a>

I don't think so. It's up to the client to look for a URI with an associated
title "company logo" and process the resource associated to the found URI
accordingly.


[1] http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18403
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 07:54:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

does your opinion hold the same:

- when the target resources are not binary as in the example you
supplied, but are instead text?
- when there are multiple transclusion links in the same representation?
- when the client's goal is to compare several resources and produce output?
- when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the result?

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 02:39, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> On Tuesday, January 10, 2012 3:11 PM, mike amundsen wrote:
>> Markus:
>> ok, let me ask you directly, can you imagine any circumstance where
>> the differences between transclusion (LE) and navigation (LO) "matter"
>> in an M2M scenario? mca
>
> Hmm.. honestly I can't come up with any scenario where the difference
> matters. Let's take an example from the H Factor page [1]:
>
>  LE: <img src="http://www.example.org/images/logo" title="company logo" />
>
> Would the following be any different from a M2M POV? Would it render some
> functionality impossible?
>
>  LO: <a href="http://www.example.org/images/logo" title="company
> logo">company logo</a>
>
> I don't think so. It's up to the client to look for a URI with an associated
> title "company logo" and process the resource associated to the found URI
> accordingly.
>
>
> [1] http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/
>
>
> --
> Markus Lanthaler
> @markuslanthaler

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18404
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 08:19:32
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> does your opinion hold the same:
> 
> - when the target resources are not binary as in the example you
> supplied, but are instead text?

Yes, that doesn't matter from the client's POV. It either has the required
codec to interpret the representation or not. According to you, what should
that change?


> - when there are multiple transclusion links in the same
> representation?

Yes


> - when the client's goal is to compare several resources and produce
> output?

Yes, because in both cases it has to dereference the resources and compare
the retrieved representations.


> - when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the
> result?

This one might be a bit trickier because if you would really have LE which
is not dependent on a specific MIME-type you could generalize your client to
do just that task. But as far as I know, such a MIME type independent LE
doesn't exist and so again it is up to the client to understand the
semantics associated to that specific element in that specific MIME type to
proceed.
In HTML the LE as e.g. used in the <img> tag is necessary because the client
(browser) has a hardcoded knowledge of what an <img> is and how it should be
rendered.
Looking at the favicon it is not that clear weather that's LE or LO - or is
it? It would as well been possible to reuse the <img> tag in the header for
this. Instead a generic <link> was used and the information on how to
process it was moved into the "rel" attribute. Why was it done that way? IMO
to introduce without needing to change the MIME type, i.e., HTML in this
case. So the semantics in this case are out-of-band and not defined in the
MIME type and yet it works quite well in practice.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18405
Sender:Nina Jeliazkova <jeliazkova.nina@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 08:20:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Hello,

On 10 January 2012 09:54, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

> **
>
>

Sorry to intervene again, but isn't embedding/linking discussion mixing
presentation (user interface, rendering) level and domain objects semantic?

There is usually more than one way to render a domain object, regardless of
it being simple or composite.

>   does your opinion hold the same:
>
> - when the target resources are not binary as in the example you
> supplied, but are instead text?
>
IMHO there is no any difference.

If the client shows only a link inside a text document, but on click
launches an AJAX call to retrieve the transcluded text and show it in
a collapsible widget, is it considered navigating or embedding?


> - when there are multiple transclusion links in the same representation?
>
It depends solely how the client would like process the links in the
representation, as in the AJAX scenario above. Of course it could be
extended beyond simple retrieval.


> - when the client's goal is to compare several resources and produce
> output?
>
I would have a separate REST resource, solely dealing with comparison of
resources (and eventually making the result available under new URI).
   Perhaps with its own media type/ link rel.

> - when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the
> result?
>
>
I would have a separate REST resource, generating the combination and
providing the result under a new URI.  Perhaps with its own media type/
link rel.

Just my 2 cents.

Best regards,
Nina


>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
> On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 02:39, Markus Lanthaler
> <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> > On Tuesday, January 10, 2012 3:11 PM, mike amundsen wrote:
> >> Markus:
> >> ok, let me ask you directly, can you imagine any circumstance where
> >> the differences between transclusion (LE) and navigation (LO) "matter"
> >> in an M2M scenario? mca
> >
> > Hmm.. honestly I can't come up with any scenario where the difference
> > matters. Let's take an example from the H Factor page [1]:
> >
> >  LE: <img src="http://www.example.org/images/logo" title="company logo"
> />
> >
> > Would the following be any different from a M2M POV? Would it render some
> > functionality impossible?
> >
> >  LO: <a href="http://www.example.org/images/logo" title="company
> > logo">company logo</a>
> >
> > I don't think so. It's up to the client to look for a URI with an
> associated
> > title "company logo" and process the resource associated to the found URI
> > accordingly.
> >
> >
> > [1] http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/
> >
> >
> > --
> > Markus Lanthaler
> > @markuslanthaler
> >
>

Post ID:18406
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 08:28:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Markus:

ok, i remain unconvinced that transclusion and navigation are the
same, whether for H2M or M2M implementations, and i can see that you
are quite sure they are.

i also doubt there is anything i can say right now to change our POV.

thanks for your time.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18407
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 09:02:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

mike - does <link rel="stylesheet" ... /> count as transclusion?

Does LE include embedding/framing of other resources ala HAL's resource or Atom's members? If not, is it possible or worth adding another factor and separating them?

On 10 Jan 2012, at 08:28 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

> Markus:
> 
> ok, i remain unconvinced that transclusion and navigation are the
> same, whether for H2M or M2M implementations, and i can see that you
> are quite sure they are.
> 
> i also doubt there is anything i can say right now to change our POV.
> 
> thanks for your time.
> 
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
> 
> On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 03:19, Markus Lanthaler
> <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> >> does your opinion hold the same:
> >>
> >> - when the target resources are not binary as in the example you
> >> supplied, but are instead text?
> >
> > Yes, that doesn't matter from the client's POV. It either has the required
> > codec to interpret the representation or not. According to you, what should
> > that change?
> >
> >
> >> - when there are multiple transclusion links in the same
> >> representation?
> >
> > Yes
> >
> >
> >> - when the client's goal is to compare several resources and produce
> >> output?
> >
> > Yes, because in both cases it has to dereference the resources and compare
> > the retrieved representations.
> >
> >
> >> - when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the
> >> result?
> >
> > This one might be a bit trickier because if you would really have LE which
> > is not dependent on a specific MIME-type you could generalize your client to
> > do just that task. But as far as I know, such a MIME type independent LE
> > doesn't exist and so again it is up to the client to understand the
> > semantics associated to that specific element in that specific MIME type to
> > proceed.
> > In HTML the LE as e.g. used in the <img> tag is necessary because the client
> > (browser) has a hardcoded knowledge of what an <img> is and how it should be
> > rendered.
> > Looking at the favicon it is not that clear weather that's LE or LO - or is
> > it? It would as well been possible to reuse the <img> tag in the header for
> > this. Instead a generic <link> was used and the information on how to
> > process it was moved into the "rel" attribute. Why was it done that way? IMO
> > to introduce without needing to change the MIME type, i.e., HTML in this
> > case. So the semantics in this case are out-of-band and not defined in the
> > MIME type and yet it works quite well in practice.
> >
> >
> > --
> > Markus Lanthaler
> > @markuslanthaler
> >
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18408
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 09:07:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Mike:

yes, in my use of the term, both your examples are transclusions (LE).

IOW, when analyzing representations, i ask "is this link here to lead the
client to offer a navigation experience or not?"

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 04:02, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> mike - does <link rel="stylesheet" ... /> count as transclusion?
>
> Does LE include embedding/framing of other resources ala HAL's resource or
> Atom's members? If not, is it possible or worth adding another factor and
> separating them?
>
> On 10 Jan 2012, at 08:28 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> Markus:
>
> ok, i remain unconvinced that transclusion and navigation are the
> same, whether for H2M or M2M implementations, and i can see that you
> are quite sure they are.
>
> i also doubt there is anything i can say right now to change our POV.
>
> thanks for your time.
>
> mca

>  <http://twitter.com@mamund>http://twitter.com@mamund
>  <http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me>http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

> On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 03:19, Markus Lanthaler
> < <markus.lanthaler%40gmx.net>markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> >> does your opinion hold the same:
> >>
> >> - when the target resources are not binary as in the example you
> >> supplied, but are instead text?
> >
> > Yes, that doesn't matter from the client's POV. It either has the
> required
> > codec to interpret the representation or not. According to you, what
> should
> > that change?
> >
> >
> >> - when there are multiple transclusion links in the same
> >> representation?
> >
> > Yes
> >
> >
> >> - when the client's goal is to compare several resources and produce
> >> output?
> >
> > Yes, because in both cases it has to dereference the resources and
> compare
> > the retrieved representations.
> >
> >
> >> - when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the
> >> result?
> >
> > This one might be a bit trickier because if you would really have LE
> which
> > is not dependent on a specific MIME-type you could generalize your
> client to
> > do just that task. But as far as I know, such a MIME type independent LE
> > doesn't exist and so again it is up to the client to understand the
> > semantics associated to that specific element in that specific MIME type
> to
> > proceed.
> > In HTML the LE as e.g. used in the <img> tag is necessary because the
> client
> > (browser) has a hardcoded knowledge of what an <img> is and how it
> should be
> > rendered.
> > Looking at the favicon it is not that clear weather that's LE or LO - or
> is
> > it? It would as well been possible to reuse the <img> tag in the header
> for
> > this. Instead a generic <link> was used and the information on how to
> > process it was moved into the "rel" attribute. Why was it done that way?
> IMO
> > to introduce without needing to change the MIME type, i.e., HTML in this
> > case. So the semantics in this case are out-of-band and not defined in
> the
> > MIME type and yet it works quite well in practice.
> >
> >
> > --
> > Markus Lanthaler
> > @markuslanthaler

Post ID:18409
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:


On 10 Jan 2012, at 07:54 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

> 
> - when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the result?

This should not affect whether or not a client can cache responses from transcluded resources. Or is that not what you mean here?
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18411
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 09:27:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 9:07 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

> Mike:
>
> yes, in my use of the term, both your examples are transclusions (LE).
>
> IOW, when analyzing representations, i ask "is this link here to lead the
> client to offer a navigation experience or not?"
>
>
So you agree that transclusion can be determined by the relation type
(rel=stylesheet) rather than the hypermedia control itself (link)? And,
apart from the impracticalities, would you agree there is no reason that
all others transclusions could be changed to follow this approach, i.e.
<link rel="image".. instead of <img.. etc?

Is it deliberate that H Factors cannot distinguish between 'framed'
embedded state and client-fetched embedded state? I think it would be
useful to have separate H Factors which distinguish between the two,
because the former is a very common and valuable optimisation technique
(particularly in m2m scenarios).





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18412
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 09:37:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

Caching is an constraint of the web (derived from REST),  why is this
not a given?

Isn't one of the objectives of caching that there should be no need to
store a combined result, because caching provides a standard mechanism
which can prevent subsequent recombinations from having to hit the
network? i.e. they are stored - but in their constituent parts, as
responses from separate URIs.

On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 9:22 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> caching is not assumed nor required in these examples.
>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
>
>
>
> On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 04:13, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>>
>>
>> On 10 Jan 2012, at 07:54 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> - when the client's goal is to combine several resources and store the
>> result?
>>
>>
>> This should not affect whether or not a client can cache responses from
>> transcluded resources. Or is that not what you mean here?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18413
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 09:45:12
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tuesday, January 10, 2012 5:08 PM, mike amundsen wrote: 
> IOW, when analyzing representations, i ask "is this link here to
> lead the client to offer a navigation experience or not?"  

I think this is the very essence of our different POVs.

What is an "navigation experience" in an M2M scenario. If there is a link
all I can do is to dereference it (by whatever method I choose to use) a
process the retrieved representation or ignore it. This is independent of
whether it is LE or LO according to your classification. Do you disagree?



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18414
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 09:54:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 9:45 AM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> On Tuesday, January 10, 2012 5:08 PM, mike amundsen wrote:
>> IOW, when analyzing representations, i ask "is this link here to
>> lead the client to offer a navigation experience or not?"
>
> I think this is the very essence of our different POVs.
>
> What is an "navigation experience" in an M2M scenario. If there is a link
> all I can do is to dereference it (by whatever method I choose to use) a
> process the retrieved representation or ignore it. This is independent of
> whether it is LE or LO according to your classification. Do you disagree?
>

fwiw, I agree apart from 'framing' LE mechanisms that actually prevent
subsequent requests from being necessary.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18415
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 10:14:33
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> > I think this is the very essence of our different POVs.
> >
> > What is an "navigation experience" in an M2M scenario. If there is a
> link
> > all I can do is to dereference it (by whatever method I choose to
> use) a
> > process the retrieved representation or ignore it. This is
> independent of
> > whether it is LE or LO according to your classification. Do you
> disagree?
> >
> 
> fwiw, I agree apart from 'framing' LE mechanisms that actually prevent
> subsequent requests from being necessary.

Yes, if it is guaranteed that dereferencing the "self" link of an embedded
resource (as in the HAL examples) returns exactly the same representation -
which usually isn't guaranteed. If just a subset is embedded it might still
be necessary to dereference to get all the data and then again it's just a
link.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18416
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 10:29:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 10:14 AM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
>> > I think this is the very essence of our different POVs.
>> >
>> > What is an "navigation experience" in an M2M scenario. If there is a
>> link
>> > all I can do is to dereference it (by whatever method I choose to
>> use) a
>> > process the retrieved representation or ignore it. This is
>> independent of
>> > whether it is LE or LO according to your classification. Do you
>> disagree?
>> >
>>
>> fwiw, I agree apart from 'framing' LE mechanisms that actually prevent
>> subsequent requests from being necessary.
>
> Yes, if it is guaranteed that dereferencing the "self" link of an embedded
> resource (as in the HAL examples) returns exactly the same representation -
> which usually isn't guaranteed. If just a subset is embedded it might still
> be necessary to dereference to get all the data and then again it's just a
> link.
>

Right, the embedded resources are effectively a form of link and
should be used that way by clients if the embedded representation is
not sufficient for their needs. HAL doesn't provide any  guarantee of
completeness for the same reason an HTTP response doesn't guarantee
anything about the target of Content-Location.

So you are agreeing here that 'framed' embedding is a form type of LE
that is distinct from LO, even in a m2m context?

In my experience it is a very common requirement to optimise
applications this way, which is why I put it into HAL.

Out of interest - is it possible to do this with RDFa? how would that work?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18417
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 10:50:12
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> Right, the embedded resources are effectively a form of link and
> should be used that way by clients if the embedded representation is
> not sufficient for their needs. HAL doesn't provide any  guarantee of
> completeness for the same reason an HTTP response doesn't guarantee
> anything about the target of Content-Location.
> 
> So you are agreeing here that 'framed' embedding is a form type of LE
> that is distinct from LO, even in a m2m context?

I'm not sure about this. You could also see that framed embedding as a form
of pagination which is in turn again LO in my opinion. So I'm still
struggling to see any form of LE. A link is a pointer to another resource
(or possibly also to the containing resource itself). You either have a
pointer to the data or directly the plain data.


> In my experience it is a very common requirement to optimise
> applications this way, which is why I put it into HAL.

Agree completely with that and that's one point where RESTful services
surely lack behind normal Web pages (think of image sprites).


> Out of interest - is it possible to do this with RDFa? how would that
> work?

Sure, you just include some triples of the other resource in the current
representation:

<div xmlns:foaf="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/" about="#me" rel="foaf:knows">
   <ul>
      <li about="http://example/markus#me" typeof="foaf:Person">
        <a property="foaf:name" rel="foaf:homepage"
href="http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/">Markus</a>
      </li>
      <li about="http://example/bob#me" typeof="foaf:Person">
        <a property="foaf:name" rel="foaf:homepage"
href="http://example.com/bob">Bob</a>
      </li>
   </ul>
</div>

I posted it also here where it might be easier to read:
http://pastebin.com/qwxXbE6U

Nothing prevents you to lookup http://example/markus#me for more information
about that embedded resource.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18418
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 10:59:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 10:50 AM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...t> wrote:
>> Right, the embedded resources are effectively a form of link and
>> should be used that way by clients if the embedded representation is
>> not sufficient for their needs. HAL doesn't provide any  guarantee of
>> completeness for the same reason an HTTP response doesn't guarantee
>> anything about the target of Content-Location.
>>
>> So you are agreeing here that 'framed' embedding is a form type of LE
>> that is distinct from LO, even in a m2m context?
>
> I'm not sure about this. You could also see that framed embedding as a form
> of pagination which is in turn again LO in my opinion. So I'm still
> struggling to see any form of LE. A link is a pointer to another resource
> (or possibly also to the containing resource itself). You either have a
> pointer to the data or directly the plain data.
>
>
>> In my experience it is a very common requirement to optimise
>> applications this way, which is why I put it into HAL.
>
> Agree completely with that and that's one point where RESTful services
> surely lack behind normal Web pages (think of image sprites).
>
>
>> Out of interest - is it possible to do this with RDFa? how would that
>> work?
>
> Sure, you just include some triples of the other resource in the current
> representation:
>
> <div xmlns:foaf="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/" about="#me" rel="foaf:knows">
>   <ul>
>      <li about="http://example/markus#me" typeof="foaf:Person">
>        <a property="foaf:name" rel="foaf:homepage"
> href="http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/">Markus</a>
>      </li>
>      <li about="http://example/bob#me" typeof="foaf:Person">
>        <a property="foaf:name" rel="foaf:homepage"
> href="http://example.com/bob">Bob</a>
>      </li>
>   </ul>
> </div>
>
> I posted it also here where it might be easier to read:
> http://pastebin.com/qwxXbE6U
>
> Nothing prevents you to lookup http://example/markus#me for more information
> about that embedded resource.

Ok thanks - how would you present that as JSON-LD?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18419
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-10 11:12:51
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
Message:

> > I posted it also here where it might be easier to read:
> > http://pastebin.com/qwxXbE6U
> >
> > Nothing prevents you to lookup http://example/markus#me for more
> information
> > about that embedded resource.
> 
> Ok thanks - how would you present that as JSON-LD?

It's quite similar (http://pastebin.com/f11Av1Jx), without using prefixes
you would end up with something like: 

{
  "@context": {
    "homepage": { "@id": "http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/homepage", "@type":
"@id" },
    "know": "http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/knows",
    "name": "http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name"
  },
  "@id": "#me",
  "know": [
    {
      "@id": "http://example/bob#me",
      "name": "Bob",
      "homepage": "http://example.com/bob"
    },
    {
      "@id": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/#me",
      "name": "Markus",
      "homepage": "http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"
    }
  ]
}

If you have multiple of these representations you might consider putting the
context in an external file and just reference it.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler
