-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18469
Sender:Peter Williams <pezra@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-18 19:34:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 10:02 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> "how would *you* then describe, characterize, etc. the elements
> HTML.IMG and HTML.A and how would *you* differentiate the two?

I would just say they are both links. They do have different document
layout semantics that are useful for visually presenting HTML encoded
documents. That does not imply to me that i should expect/look for
similar semantics in media types for other domains.

> for example, in identifying H-Factors, i choose to characterize them
> both as "link" elements. i choose to differentiate them based on the
> "shared understanding" (as defined in the HTML spec) that one
> indicates a transclusion and the other indicates a navigation.

To my mind that shared understanding is domain specific, rather than
an affordance that would necessarily be available in any other
context. Fundamentally, HTML provides a way to describe (graphical)
user interfaces. In that context there is a significant difference
between transclusion and navigation. In other visually oriented
domains i would also expect a significant differences between
transclusion and linking out. However, i find the distinction less
compelling once you move to describing domains (read: media types)
that are less visually oriented.

By analogy, i think categorizing media types by whether they have LE
affordances is a bit like categorizing all physical objects by whether
they have a feature that affords pulling. In some contexts (doors)
such a categorization can be useful, in others it is clearly not. So
while you certainly could ask the question "does this object have a
feature that affords pulling" for any physical object it is probably
not a very important way to segment the set of all physical objects.

Asking that question has negative impacts, though. It encourages
people to unnecessarily put pull handles on the sides of houses just
so they can check that box. It make some wonder if they have missed
something really important because the desk they just designed doesn't
have pull handle. It also causes them to get into long mailing list
discussions about whether the hitch on their trailer counts as pull
handle or not. ;)

Peter
barelyenough.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18470
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-18 20:48:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 14:34, Peter Williams <pezra@barelyenough.org> wrote:
> On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 10:02 AM, mike amundsen <mamund@yahoo.com> wrote:
>> "how would *you* then describe, characterize, etc. the elements
>> HTML.IMG and HTML.A and how would *you* differentiate the two?
>
> I would just say they are both links. They do have different document
> layout semantics that are useful for visually presenting HTML encoded
> documents. 

You're playing w/ me, right? 

> That does not imply to me that i should expect/look for
> similar semantics in media types for other domains.

no, it does not imply that you should expect/look, etc. where is this coming from?

>> for example, in identifying H-Factors, i choose to characterize them
>> both as "link" elements. i choose to differentiate them based on the
>> "shared understanding" (as defined in the HTML spec) that one
>> indicates a transclusion and the other indicates a navigation.
>
> To my mind that shared understanding is domain specific, rather than
> an affordance that would necessarily be available in any other
> context. 

so is this whole discussion about you telling me i have my "scoping" wrong?

> i find the distinction less
> compelling once you move to describing domains (read: media types)
> that are less visually oriented.

so, you think transclusion is only "compelling" if the output is visual, right?
and "compelling" is your term for measure?

>
> Peter
> barelyenough.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18471
Sender:Peter Williams <pezra@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-18 22:08:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 1:48 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>> That does not imply to me that i should expect/look for
>> similar semantics in media types for other domains.
>
> no, it does not imply that you should expect/look, etc. where is this coming from?

You list LE as one of the hypermedia factors. That implied to me that
you look for it (even if you don't necessarily expect it) in other
media types.

Until this conversation i was under the, apparently false, assumption
that the h-factors list was a collect them all sort of thing. The more
h-factors a media type has the better it is. The first line of the
page certainly seems to imply this, "The H Factor of a media-type is a
measurement of the level of hypermedia support and sophistication of a
media-type."

> so is this whole discussion about you telling me i have my "scoping" wrong?

I don't know, maybe. It is hard for me to tell for sure. Maybe i am
missing something really fundamental.

>> i find the distinction less
>> compelling once you move to describing domains (read: media types)
>> that are less visually oriented.
>
> so, you think transclusion is only "compelling" if the output is visual, right?

I do find embedding graphical elements in documents and user
interfaces (certainly a form a transclusion) compelling. However,
there are many other contexts in which various forms of transclusion
are useful (and therefore compelling. I used the embedded image
example because we have been using HTML as an example.

> and "compelling" is your term for measure?

Not exactly. A measure of hypermedia capability is compelling to me if
i think it would be reasonable and useful to ask the question of any
media type, regardless of domain.  For example, i find LT to be an
extremely compelling measure to consider when evaluating, comparing
and designing media types.

I think my concern comes down to the fact that i just don't see the
similarity between `<img src="..."/>` and `<link rel="stylesheet"
href="...">` (i assume this is considered an LE link) other than they
are often dereferenced automatically.

Hmm... does LE mean "the media type contains a flavor of link which
will be automatically dereferenced by the canonical consumer"?

Peter
barelyenough.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18472
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-18 22:53:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 17:08, Peter Williams <pezra@...> wrote:
> On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 1:48 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>>> That does not imply to me that i should expect/look for
>>> similar semantics in media types for other domains.
>>
>> no, it does not imply that you should expect/look, etc. where is this coming from?
>
> You list LE as one of the hypermedia factors. That implied to me that
> you look for it (even if you don't necessarily expect it) in other
> media types.

ok, yes. i *do* find them in other designs and _use_ them in my own
new designs. i guess i got hung up on "should" and "expect" in a way
you didn't mean. sure, these appear other places (transclusion,
navigation, URI templating, payload templating, non/idempotent
requests, protocol method selection, request header manipulation,
tokenizing of link actions, etc. while HTML offers common examples of
most of all of these, Atom, VoiceXML, URI-List, HAL, Collection-JSON,
etc. all show examples, too.

>
> Until this conversation i was under the, apparently false, assumption
> that the h-factors list was a collect them all sort of thing. The more
> h-factors a media type has the better it is. The first line of the
> page certainly seems to imply this, "The H Factor of a media-type is a
> measurement of the level of hypermedia support and sophistication of a
> media-type."

yep, that text about "sophisitication" is pretty weak, eh? i wrote it
early in my experiments and should really update the page, relegate
some text to archives, etc.

the list i present there is not meant to be definitive (all
inclusive). i'm open to new ideas on how to improve it; both at the
membership and the narrative levels. and the idea was definitely *not*
to create a hierarchy with which to judge designs. just as creating a
set of constraints (color, materials, processing) for any industrial
design can add structure and cohesion, the factor model was meant as
an aide in design and analysis, not as a measure of judgement.

>
>> so is this whole discussion about you telling me i have my "scoping" wrong?
>
> I don't know, maybe. It is hard for me to tell for sure. Maybe i am
> missing something really fundamental.

well, i suspect the two of us are not yet on the same wave-length for
general terms. the last few posts have helped to teach me more about
your POV and i suspect it will take more typing still, that's all.

>
>>> i find the distinction less
>>> compelling once you move to describing domains (read: media types)
>>> that are less visually oriented.
>>
>> so, you think transclusion is only "compelling" if the output is visual, right?
>
> I do find embedding graphical elements in documents and user
> interfaces (certainly a form a transclusion) compelling. However,
> there are many other contexts in which various forms of transclusion
> are useful (and therefore compelling. I used the embedded image
> example because we have been using HTML as an example.

yeah, my point here is that compelling or not, these things exist. i
have decided to *not* attempt to say one or more of these things
SHOULD or MUST only be used in certain cases (visual rendering only,
etc.). i have treated all the factors this way. for example, i do not
say HTML is inferior because it does not offer support for idempotent
actions. i do not say that Atom is flawed because it offers no native
affordance for templated queries, etc. so "compelling" didn't enter
into my decision on what is included in the H-Factor list.

>
>> and "compelling" is your term for measure?
>
> Not exactly. A measure of hypermedia capability is compelling to me if
> i think it would be reasonable and useful to ask the question of any
> media type, regardless of domain.  For example, i find LT to be an
> extremely compelling measure to consider when evaluating, comparing
> and designing media types.

compelling -> reasonable -> useful  it's good stuff, but not the kind
of measures i used when creating the list.

sure, you can create a media type design that uses _all_ these, just
one of these, etc. you can even create a really _ugly_, _unhelpful_
design with them!  my point is to document what's here and talk about
how they are used today.

so, yes, talking about how useful -> reasonable, etc. some of the
affordances are in some cases at some period of time for some apps,
etc. is great. that switches from talking about whether an item ought
to be on my H-Factor *list* to whether an item on my H-Factor list
ought to be in a particular *design*; very worthwhile stuff. and much
of that talk will use words like "compelling", "useful",
"appriopriate", "successful', etc. because that's how design
implementations are evaluated.

but if the talk is to be about whether an item should be on the
H-Factor list at all, then i think the way we talk about these
affordances is different; the measures are different, the
examples/evidence are different. do transclusion affordances exists in
some designs? if so, should this affordance be included in the list of
possible factors? if yes, why; if not, why?, etc.

> Hmm... does LE mean "the media type contains a flavor of link which
> will be automatically dereferenced by the canonical consumer"?

that's an interesting observation. i have not included details on
_how_ these affordances must be treated by clients; only that they
appear and have a shared understanding between client and server.
immediate, deferred, pre-fetched, etc. are not included in my
affordance criteria right now and i do not know of any media type
documentation that defines in-message affordances as having these
constraints.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18473
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-19 02:51:28
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wednesday, January 18, 2012 11:00 PM, Peter Williams wrote: 
> > [...]
> > I was not talking about LE or LO.
> 
> Ah. I misunderstood, sorry.
> 
> > I was talking about HTTP methods. AtomPub,
> > e.g., clearly specifies that how member URIs with a link relation of
> "edit"
> > should be used.
> 
> How is `<link rel="edit" ...` in an Atom document different than a
> property `http://example.com/vocab/modify-by-putting-here` that points
> to the "member" resource in RDF?

The difference is that the media type specifies the semantics. Whereas in
RDF the user specifies the semantics. You won't find them in the media type
specification of RDF/XML, Turtle, etc. The subject of this thread is
"formats with native hypermedia support going beyond GET".


> > Would you say the same is true for form@method="get" and
> form@method="post"?
> > I don't think any client out there will issue a GET when a POST is
> defined
> > or the other way round.. The same applies for a a@rel="edit" link in
> an Atom
> > document.
> 
> I don't think (m)any clients would try to get the resource from a POST
> form.  However, they are welcome to if they want. That is part of the
> uniform interface. Every resource responses to every method.

True, but it gives the server a way to show the client how to navigate
through his resource space. Sure, that's also possible with RDF and the like
but the semantics are shifted from the media type to the ontology.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18474
Sender:Peter Williams <pezra@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-19 19:30:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 3:53 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

> yeah, my point here is that [...] these things exist.

So does block quoting, but i don't use that as a way categorization
media types.

My point here is that some ways of categorizing are more useful than
others. I see "embedded" vs "navigation" distinction as less useful.
(And largely completely indistinguishable in m2m scenarios.)

I think my strong reaction was partly due to an misunderstanding of
what you mean by LE and how you use the h-factors technique. If
h-factors were usually treated as a set of categorizations any of
which might or might not be useful in the situation at hand (which i
am beginning to infer is how you use them) then i would have no
concerns. However, most of the discussions involving the h-factors of
media types do *not* have that flavor to me.

Peter
barelyenough.org

Post ID:18475
Sender:Peter Williams <pezra@...>

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Wed, Jan 18, 2012 at 7:51 PM, Markus Lanthaler

> The difference is that the media type specifies the semantics. Whereas in
> RDF the user specifies the semantics. You won't find them in the media type
> specification of RDF/XML, Turtle, etc. The subject of this thread is
> "formats with native hypermedia support going beyond GET".

Ah, i see your point now. So a media type that was defined as "data
encoded in the foo vocabulary and serialized as json-ld" could,
depending on the properties defined in the vocabulary, pass muster on
this front?

Why aren't all RDF properties (whose values are a resource) equivalent
to `<a>` tags but where the media type is saying that any method is
ok?

Peter
barelyenough.org

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18478
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-20 04:19:20
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Friday, January 20, 2012 3:57 AM, Peter Williams wrote:
> Ah, i see your point now. So a media type that was defined as "data
> encoded in the foo vocabulary and serialized as json-ld" could,
> depending on the properties defined in the vocabulary, pass muster on
> this front?
> 
> Why aren't all RDF properties (whose values are a resource) equivalent
> to `<a>` tags but where the media type is saying that any method is
> ok?

Even <a> tags in HTML don't disallow other methods than GET. The point is
that there's no way to define, e.g., the query parameters or the expected
body of a POST/PUT whereas HTML natively supports to describe such aspects
with forms. In RDF, that knowledge, again, has to be documented somewhere
out of band - possibly in an ontology.

So, coming back to my original question, does anyone knows other media types
which natively support hypermedia that goes beyond a simple GET?

The current list is:
- HTML (GET/POST/PUT)
- Atom+AtomPub (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE)
- WSDL (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE)
- WADL (GET/POST/PUT/HEAD/DELETE)
- Collection+JSON (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE)
- CCXML (GET/POST) - thanks to Erlend
- Shoji (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) - thanks to Robert


I have another list of media types with built-in support for a "semantic"
annotation of links (which can be used to support other methods by
describing the details out-of-band):
- HTML
- Atom+AtomPub
- HAL
- RDF/XML, Turtle, N3, JSON-LD, ...
- WADL/WSDL??



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18479
Sender:"Eric J. Bowman" <eric@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-20 04:49:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

"Markus Lanthaler" wrote:
> 
> Even <a> tags in HTML don't disallow other methods than GET.
>

Don't forget that method in hypertext, is also a function of URI.  I
wish this list was easier to search, I know I re-wrote the HTML 4.01
text concerning form methods and posted it here as an example, once.
Instead of HTTP methods, HTML should use tokens descriptive of sender
intent.  Because if the URI is mailto: the method won't be POST, will
it?  Even though that's what it says in the markup?

I'd rather see protocol-agnostic markup rather than bindings to specific
protocols, regardless of media type...

-Eric





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18480
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-20 13:10:39
Subject:Tips for idempotency
Message:

Idempotent operations are good for various reasons - for instance to avoid multiple creation of the same resource in the face of network errors. But how is it actually done in practice? What are your "tricks of the trade"?

Most implementations I have seen requires the client to create some kind of GUID and use that in a PUT operation. For instance in order to create a new "person" resource:

  PUT /person/{person-guid} HTTP/1.1
  Content-Type: ...

  ... user data ...

If it fails then the client can retry the PUT operation to the same URL. The server must then keep track of succeeded "person-guids" (is there any "best practice" for how this is done?).

What other tricks do we have? Did I even get the above pattern right :-)

Regards, Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18481
Sender:"Jakob Strauch" <jakob.strauch@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-20 14:42:22
Subject:Re: Tips for idempotency
Message:

Hello Jørn,

I think this is even not REST specific. It´s a common problem in distributed systems theory. Basically you can use message-ids (equivalent to your example) or use some ACK (acknowledge) technique / protocol (i think there is something like POE post once exactly).

I think the pattern you described is slighty different: You POST your request to some factory resource with a guid. It will return you the adress, where you can PUT the person resource. If i remember correctly... :-)

Jakob

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Jorn Wildt" <jw@...> wrote:
>
> Idempotent operations are good for various reasons - for instance to avoid multiple creation of the same resource in the face of network errors. But how is it actually done in practice? What are your "tricks of the trade"?
> 
> Most implementations I have seen requires the client to create some kind of GUID and use that in a PUT operation. For instance in order to create a new "person" resource:
> 
>   PUT /person/{person-guid} HTTP/1.1
>   Content-Type: ...
> 
>   ... user data ...
> 
> If it fails then the client can retry the PUT operation to the same URL. The server must then keep track of succeeded "person-guids" (is there any "best practice" for how this is done?).
> 
> What other tricks do we have? Did I even get the above pattern right :-)
> 
> Regards, Jørn
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18482
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-20 15:07:49
Subject:Re: Tips for idempotency
Message:

> I think the pattern you described is slighty different: You POST your request to some factory resource with a guid. It will return you the adress, where you can PUT the person resource. If i remember correctly... :-)

Ah, sounds better, it frees the client from creating an ID/URL. But, thinking about it, I guess it should be:

"You GET a URL from a factory resource and then you POST/PUT your person as many times you want to that resource - only the first successful POST/PUT has an effect.".

Better re-read my REST cookbook.

Thanks, Jørn

> >

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18483
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-21 13:21:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Tips for idempotency
Message:

On Jan 20, 2012, at 2:10 PM, Jorn Wildt wrote:

> Idempotent operations are good for various reasons - for instance to avoid multiple creation of the same resource in the face of network errors. But how is it actually done in practice? What are your "tricks of the trade"?
> 
> Most implementations I have seen requires the client to create some kind of GUID and use that in a PUT operation. For instance in order to create a new "person" resource:
> 
> PUT /person/{person-guid} HTTP/1.1
> Content-Type: ...
> 
> ... user data ...

This is only a useful option if you want to give the client control over the parts of the URI space (client determines GUID and hence chooses how the URI will look).

I'd use POST for creation because it gives more control to the server (over its own URI space).

Regarding idempotency, you have two options: 

- let the client provide a unique request ID, as outlined in the first half of http://www.prescod.net/reliable_http.html
- let the server provide a use-once-only POST accepting resource as described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-nottingham-http-poe/

HTH,

Jan

> 
> If it fails then the client can retry the PUT operation to the same URL. The server must then keep track of succeeded "person-guids" (is there any "best practice" for how this is done?).
> 
> What other tricks do we have? Did I even get the above pattern right :-)
> 
> Regards, Jørn
> 
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18484
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-22 02:28:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Tips for idempotency
Message:

hello.

On 2012-01-21 5:21 , Jan Algermissen wrote:
> Regarding idempotency, you have two options:
> - let the client provide a unique request ID, as outlined in the first half of http://www.prescod.net/reliable_http.html
> - let the server provide a use-once-only POST accepting resource as described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-nottingham-http-poe/

http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2011/11/creating-resources-with-get-put.html 
is another way how this can be accomplished. the goal is to provide 
POST-exactly-once semantics, and this goal can be achieved with a 
variety of interaction patterns based on standard HTTP.

cheers,

dret.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18485
Sender:Sean Kennedy <seandkennedy@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-23 18:01:58
Subject:enterprise migration from WS-* to REST - report/study/survey...?
Message:

Hi all,
     I have a presentation coming up and want to make the case for the shift in the enterprise from WS-* to REST. Points on my slide are:
	* Google SOAP Search API deprecated in 2006
	* Amazon SOAP API deprecated in 2011
	* www.programmableweb.com (last 60 days: 115 SOAP APIs registered versus 290 REST API's)
	* InformationWeek survey (2009) where SOA implementation trend was towards REST from SOAP (http://www.informationweek.com/news/214501922)
Are there other references (bear in mind that I am in an academic arena and need quality references). Is there a more recent report/survey than the 2009 one above?

Many thanks,
Sean.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sender:David Karr <davidmichaelkarr@...>

> Hi all,

>
> Google SOAP Search API deprecated in 2006
> Amazon SOAP API deprecated in 2011
> www.programmableweb.com (last 60 days: 115 SOAP APIs registered versus 290 REST API's)
> InformationWeek survey (2009) where SOA implementation trend was towards REST from SOAP (http://www.informationweek.com/news/214501922)
>
> Are there other references (bear in mind that I am in an academic arena and need quality references). Is there a more recent report/survey than the 2009 one above?

Another minor data point:

The latest version of Atlassian JIRA deprecates their SOAP API in
deference to their REST API.

Post ID:18487
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-23 19:52:47
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] enterprise migration from WS-* to REST - report/study/survey...?
Message:

Another, perhaps more, interesting question to ask is - how many of those 290 "REST" APIs are actually REST APIs? You know, the ones with hypermedia, discoverable resources, opaque URLs, and so on. Not just HTTP RPC SOAP in disguise ...

/Jørn

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Sean Kennedy 
  To: Rest Discussion Group 
  Sent: Monday, January 23, 2012 7:01 PM
  Subject: [rest-discuss] enterprise migration from WS-* to REST - report/study/survey...?


    

  Hi all,
       I have a presentation coming up and want to make the case for the shift in the enterprise from WS-* to REST. Points on my slide are:
    a.. Google SOAP Search API deprecated in 2006
    b.. Amazon SOAP API deprecated in 2011
    c.. www.programmableweb.com (last 60 days: 115 SOAP APIs registered versus 290 REST API's)
    d.. InformationWeek survey (2009) where SOA implementation trend was towards REST from SOAP (http://www.informationweek.com/news/214501922)
  Are there other references (bear in mind that I am in an academic arena and need quality references). Is there a more recent report/survey than the 2009 one above?


  Many thanks,
  Sean.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18488
Sender:Will Hartung <willh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-23 20:07:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] enterprise migration from WS-* to REST - report/study/survey...?
Message:

On Mon, Jan 23, 2012 at 11:52 AM, Jørn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:

> **
> Another, perhaps more, interesting question to ask is - how many of those
> 290 "REST" APIs are actually REST APIs? You know, the ones with hypermedia,
> discoverable resources, opaque URLs, and so on. Not just HTTP RPC SOAP in
> disguise ...
>

Yup.

The question you're not asking is whether you want to re-engineer your
enterprise to the REST architecture. Does it really offer you any value.

SOAP -> REST is not a drag and drop operation. It's a philosophical sea
change in design, planning, and operations.

How many of your interfaces are being used by external clients? What issues
are you having with the SOAP toolkits that you are using now?

Are you willing to give up the automation of the modern SOAP toolkits in
order to "hand craft" the payloads simply to stuff them over hand made HTTP
connection? Or are you willing to write your own tooling?

Do you have enough client and a long enough projection of services to
actually warrant re-engineering your system to the REST architecture? If
after N months of rework, where you get back to "where you started", do
perceived benefits warrant the N months stalling of work to reimplement
already deployed and operating systems. Or what kind of impedance mis-match
do you envision working in a mixed REST and SOAP world.

All sorts of issues in converting to REST. Better to create a stand alone
edge system (assuming REST is appropriate for it), perhaps, and have it
integrate with the existing back end.

Regards,

Will Hartung
(willh@...)

--

transmission may be confidential. If you are not an intended recipient, be 
aware that any disclosure, copying, distribution or use of the information 
contained in this transmission is prohibited and may be unlawful. If you 
have received this transmission in error, please notify us by email reply 
and then erase it from your computer system.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18489
Sender:Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-24 12:10:14
Subject:RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

The API I'm building seems to need several types of collections and I
think I've identified at least 3:

1) Collections of all the resource of a type (for example all the
users) where new resource can be created, destroyed and updated. This
seems to be the canonical RESTful collection where POST to the
collection URI creates the new resource and then PUT and DELETE to the
resource URI updates and destroys it.

2) Collections that represent relationships between resources (for
example the friends of a user). New relationships between resources
can be created with POST, but it's not clear how they should be
removed as the target resource should still exist, just no longer be
referenced.

3) Collections that represent queues of references (for example a TODO
list for a user). This is more complicated as the collection is
ordered and so elements in arbitrary positions need to be added or
removed and again the target resources should not be deleted.

If anyone could point me to nice patterns for implementing 2 and 3 I'd
be very grateful.

Cheers,

Jim





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18490
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-24 12:35:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On Tue, Jan 24, 2012 at 12:10 PM, Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
> The API I'm building seems to need several types of collections and I
> think I've identified at least 3:
>
> 1) Collections of all the resource of a type (for example all the
> users) where new resource can be created, destroyed and updated. This
> seems to be the canonical RESTful collection where POST to the
> collection URI creates the new resource and then PUT and DELETE to the
> resource URI updates and destroys it.
>
> 2) Collections that represent relationships between resources (for
> example the friends of a user). New relationships between resources
> can be created with POST, but it's not clear how they should be
> removed as the target resource should still exist, just no longer be
> referenced.
>
> 3) Collections that represent queues of references (for example a TODO
> list for a user). This is more complicated as the collection is
> ordered and so elements in arbitrary positions need to be added or
> removed and again the target resources should not be deleted.
>
> If anyone could point me to nice patterns for implementing 2 and 3 I'd
> be very grateful.
>
>
You can model both with PUT, where an omission/change-of-order by the
client implies the relationships have been removed/altered.

It's also possible to model the membership as a resource in its own right,
which presents something to clients which they can DELETE. Representing
this is easy if you have a quality hypermedia type e.g: here's how you
could represent a person and their friendships using application/hal+xml :

> GET /person/bob

< 200 OK
< Content-Type: application/hal+xml
< ....

<resource href="/person/bob">
  <name>Bob</name>
  <age>40</age>
  <resource rel="friendship" href="/person/bob/friendship/23675">
    <link rel="person" href="/person/dave" />
  </resource>
  <resource rel="friendship" href="/person/bob/friendship/87612">
    <link rel="person" href="/person/jane" />
  </resource>
</resource>

With the above clients now have the URI where they can DELETE (or update)
friendships individually as required.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18491
Sender:Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-24 13:52:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On 24 January 2012 12:35, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> You can model both with PUT, where an omission/change-of-order by the client
> implies the relationships have been removed/altered.

In both cases it would be nice to request changes to the collections,
rather than PUTing potentially large collections for each change.

> It's also possible to model the membership as a resource in its own right,
> which presents something to clients which they can DELETE.

This seems like a clean way to model it, but somewhat heavyweight and
would seems llike it would require a request per deletion or
modification. In the case of the queue example, presumably the
position in the queue would be a property of the relationship
resource?

It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
the uniform interface in a clean way.

Cheers,

Jim





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18492
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-24 14:08:35
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

> This seems like a clean way to model it, but somewhat heavyweight and
> would seems llike it would require a request per deletion or
> modification. In the case of the queue example, presumably the
> position in the queue would be a property of the relationship
> resource?
> 
> It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
> collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
> the uniform interface in a clean way.

You could use the PATCH method for it but you would have to define a media
type which describes the exact PATCH semantics. Of course you also always
fall back to the catch-all method POST. Since POST has no inherent semantics
you will not violate any of REST's constraints. But also there you should
define a media type documenting how to interpret such a request.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18493
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-24 15:05:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On Tue, Jan 24, 2012 at 1:52 PM, Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
In the case of the queue example, presumably the
> position in the queue would be a property of the relationship
> resource?
>

Sure, or the positions could be determined by the order in which the
relationship resources appear in a PUT to the queue

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18494
Sender:Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-24 18:12:31
Subject:REST vs SOAP services evolvability
Message:

Hello folks, this is my first post in rest-discuss, so please bear with me.

I get the benefits of changing link uris, but that's really not what this
post is about.

What I mean by evolvability is adding new features to a service or
modifying (when possible) existing ones and that's actually it.

SOAP isn't that bad as REST community tends to talk about it when it comes
to evolvability. For example:

   1. In REST we can add new rel - in SOAP we can add new method. Both
   types of old clients will continue working with new services.
   2. In REST we can add new form field and set its default value - in SOAP
   we could have service arguments as some ServiceArgs class and add a new
   field to ServiceArgs. That's ugly, but it works.


What are the evolvability examples when SOAP clients break and you can do
nothing about it, while REST clients are handling the situation gracefully?

-- 
Cheers,
Vitaly





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18495
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-23 20:26:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Tips for idempotency
Message:

Hi,
This brings to memory an article I read some time ago, that explained how a
sequence of several idempotent operations could be made roughly equivalent
to a relational database transaction.

In Eric's article Creating Resources with
GET/PUT<http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2011/11/creating-resources-with-get-put.html>
 it
is explained how to PUT using a nonce supplied by the server it a way so
that the new resource is PUT only once.

Performing a GET pointing to the newly created resource would close the
"transaction", if it returns the right values. Then the UI could tell the
user that the operation she intended ended happily.
-- 
Juan Lanus


On Sat, Jan 21, 2012 at 23:28, Erik Wilde <dret@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> hello.
>
>
> On 2012-01-21 5:21 , Jan Algermissen wrote:
> > Regarding idempotency, you have two options:
> > - let the client provide a unique request ID, as outlined in the first
> half of http://www.prescod.net/reliable_http.html
> > - let the server provide a use-once-only POST accepting resource as
> described in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-nottingham-http-poe/
>
>
> http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2011/11/creating-resources-with-get-put.html
> is another way how this can be accomplished. the goal is to provide
> POST-exactly-once semantics, and this goal can be achieved with a
> variety of interaction patterns based on standard HTTP.
>
> cheers,
>
> dret.
>
>  
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18496
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 08:38:50
Subject:What does a form tell my program?
Message:

There was a discussion here some weeks ago about the use of forms in REST services. Since then I have been wondering about how much such a form tells my program at *runtime*.

For this discussion I am focusing on HTML forms as we know them from the web. These includes:

- Action URL
- Encoding
- Operation
- Inputs

At runtime my program can parse the action URL, the encoding and the operation, and use these to dynamically create a HTTP request.

But what about the input definitions (the actual payload)? Are they useful at runtime? 

At compile-time (or "read the documentation time") the inputs are useful for telling my program (the developer) which values to that corresponds to what. As the developer I can see that the name of the person must be sent as "PersonName=xxx". But after this I don't see how the client program can use the input definitions for anything at runtime.

Have I overlooked some nice features of using forms?

One could decide to publish the identifiers for the input elements that is used. For instance saying that the input marked with id="name-of-person" defines the name of the input for the person's name. Like this:

  <input id="name-of-person" name="PersonName"/>

But I don't see how that really changes anything - its just one more indirection to follow.

Thanks, Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18497
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 10:04:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] What does a form tell my program?
Message:

so many questions raised by your post.

to start:

what is it that you see about inputs that is different than
"operations", "encoding", and "action URL" that renders them (inputs)
useless only at runtime?

and what is it about those other things (ops, encoding, URL) that
remains "useful' at runtime?

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund

Post ID:18499
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

On Fri, Jan 20, 2012 at 4:49 AM, Eric J. Bowman <eric@...>wrote:

> **

> >
> > Even <a> tags in HTML don't disallow other methods than GET.
> >
>
> Don't forget that method in hypertext, is also a function of URI. I
> wish this list was easier to search, I know I re-wrote the HTML 4.01
> text concerning form methods and posted it here as an example, once.
> Instead of HTTP methods, HTML should use tokens descriptive of sender
> intent. Because if the URI is mailto: the method won't be POST, will
> it? Even though that's what it says in the markup?
>
> I'd rather see protocol-agnostic markup rather than bindings to specific
> protocols, regardless of media type...
>
>
I think that's interesting.. but I'm not clear where and how you would map
these protocol-agnostic control elements to the various protocols/URI
schemes, if you don't do it in the media type.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18500
Sender:Erik Mogensen <erik@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 12:20:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On Tue, Jan 24, 2012 at 2:52 PM, Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...> wrote:

> **
> In both cases it would be nice to request changes to the collections,
> rather than PUTing potentially large collections for each change.
>

PUTting large collection-like resources works less well with concurrent
edits though. With even just a few concurrent editors your clients would
have to keep refreshing and merging changes and retrying.  If you go with
the one-resource-per-entry, then (if the server is careful not to expose
offsets in the collection in the URIs) two (or many) clients can
simultaneously modify a list without conflicts.

This way of working also allows clients to work on an outdated copy of a
collection, which helps in perceived performance, since clients don't need
to refresh the collection all the time...

This seems like a clean way to model it, but somewhat heavyweight and
> would seems llike it would require a request per deletion or
> modification. In the case of the queue example, presumably the
> position in the queue would be a property of the relationship
> resource?
>

+1. The "heavyweightness" is one of the tradeoffs of using REST. REST
doesn't have performance as its main goal, and trades efficiency for other
properties: "The trade-off, though, is that a uniform interface degrades
efficiency, since information is transferred in a standardized form rather
than one which is specific to an application's needs." — Fielding, 5.1.5

You must remember, though that the DELETE and 204 response would usually
both fit nicely within one TCP/IP packet.


> It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
> collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
> the uniform interface in a clean way.
>
>
Within the confines of the uniform interface, I would go with a GET or POST
and link to that resource, maybe using a form-like construct which tells
the clients e.g. two URIs which make a range of documents.

Client could GET a list of items (possibly a subset of the full list),
recognise a way of operating on a subset, and act on this.  This "way of
operating on a subset" could be a link relation which ends up in an
OpenSearch description where the client could search for items to operate
on, or simply a form where the client must fill out two URIs indicating the
range, and maybe some operation.
-- 
-mogsie-





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18501
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 12:30:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 12:20 PM, Erik Mogensen <erik@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
>> It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
>> collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
>> the uniform interface in a clean way.
>>
>>
> Within the confines of the uniform interface, I would go with a GET or
> POST and link to that resource, maybe using a form-like construct which
> tells the clients e.g. two URIs which make a range of documents.
>
>
It's also possible to do something along these lines which could work with
PUT:

<link rel="subset" href="/some_collection?from={
from_index}&to={to_index}&if-match=219837891723981723" />

Note, the if-match parameter is hard-coded into the representation by the
server to keep the request idempotent.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18502
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 15:18:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] What does a form tell my program?
Message:

On Jan 27, 2012, at 0:38, "Jorn Wildt" <jw@...> wrote:
> At compile-time (or "read the documentation time") the inputs are useful for telling my program (the developer) which values to that corresponds to what. As the developer I can see that the name of the person must be sent as "PersonName=xxx". But after this I don't see how the client program can use the input definitions for anything at runtime.

value ranges, default values, and hidden/disabled controls, all of them based on the context of the request. if you do this right, clients have to deal with a smaller set of options and have to make only the decisions that actually matter for their context.

cheers,

dret.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18503
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 16:12:50
Subject:Fwd: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

Jorn:

Erik's list is a good start:
- supply defaults
- provide a range (select)
- indicate whether to show to a human (hidden)
- indicate mutability (disabled inputs cannot be changed)

Also, HTML5 offers  very long list of other attributes with which
servers can use to communicate to the client input qualities value[1]

Certainly the mere _appearance_ of an input is "useful" is it not?

As an application evolves over time, servers can add/remove inputs at
selected points in the user-agent's interactions w/ the server, too.
These decisions can be completely context dependent. For example,
selected users (admins) might see diff inputs than others (guests).
During certain times (i.e. the DB is temporarily offline and does
support writes) inputs could simply be removed from forms for a time.
Workflows could be altered to move inputs from one form to another;
indicating when selected data elements are valid.

All of the variances I've listed here work with a "fixed" set of
inputs (or app-level vocabulary); IOW, there is no need to introduce
brand new input "names" That means the set of variances I've defined
work w/ user-agents there there is not human directly driving the
interactions (i.e. M2M cases).

If you add a human at runtime (i.e. H2M cases), you now have the
possibility of introducing entirely new inputs (i.e expanding the
app-level vocabulary) and continuing to evolve the app.

In fact, as Jon Moore (I think it was him) has pointed out, as long as
you code an M2M user-agent to treat all "unknown" input elements as
"pass through" (i.e. continue to include them in URI templates
(HTML.FORM@method="get") and body templates (HTML.FORM@method="post")
AND provide defaults for these brand-new input elements, then even M2M
use cases support evolution over time that includes "unknown" inputs.

Are there other features you have in mind that have not been included here?


[1] http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/the-input-element.html

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me





---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Jorn Wildt <jw@...>
Date: Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 05:21
Subject: Re: What does a form tell my program?
To: mike amundsen <mamund@...>


> what is it about those other things (ops, encoding, URL) that
> remains "useful' at runtime?

At runtime I can read action="{url}" and method="{method}" from the
<form ...> tag. From that my program can decide what the server wants
it to do. No need for a hard coded "post here" URL in my client. So
these elements are "useful" at runtime because it makes it possible
for the server to influence the client's behavior.

But I cannot see how tags like <input name="{name}"/> can change be
client's behavior at runtime. The client must have hard coded
knowledge of "{name}" - it cannot discover what "{name}" is at
runtime. So, at compile time, the developer reads the form, and using
his eyes and brain, decides what input tag is used for something. Then
he hard codes "{name}" into his client.

So, can the client discover something useful from <input
name="{name}"/> at runtime?

Did that explain it?

While writing this I was reminded of default values in <input> tags.
So, one useful, discoverable, feature of a input definition, is the
default value for that input. And hidden inputs adds other extra
values that the client need not know about. More?

/Jørn

 Seeing link tags (and headers) with URI templates in them made me throw up in my mouth a little bit.

On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 12:20 PM, Erik Mogensen <erik@...<mailto:erik@...>> wrote:

It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
the uniform interface in a clean way.


Within the confines of the uniform interface, I would go with a GET or POST and link to that resource, maybe using a form-like construct which tells the clients e.g. two URIs which make a range of documents.


It's also possible to do something along these lines which could work with PUT:

<link rel="subset" href="/some_collection?from={from_index}&to={to_index}&if-match=219837891723981723" />

Note, the if-match parameter is hard-coded into the representation by the server to keep the request idempotent.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18505
Sender:Jason Erickson <jason@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 16:35:44
Subject:Re: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

I'm not sure I understand exactly what you mean by "compile" time and "runtime" but I'll take a stab.  

The <select><option/></select> structure makes it possible for the server to provide a valid list of acceptable values at runtime.  If the choices were something like Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall, that could be taken care of in the documentation, but if the choices are dynamic, based on the state of the application, such as a list of people that who's names start with "a", or your 10 most recent deposits or something like that, it's quite convenient.  You could have a link with a @rel that indicated that it would provide you with the legitimate values for that field, but having it inline can be quite convenient.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18506
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 16:40:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 4:13 PM, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:

>   Seeing link tags (and headers) with URI templates in them made me throw
> up in my mouth a little bit.
>

Ok.

The if-match parameter could be called anything it's just a token that's
needed to keep the request idempotent. The subset resource is not being
retrieved so the client won't have an ETag for it.. I guess you could just
use the ETag from the collection and stick a corresponding If-Match in the
PUT request to the subset. Is that what you are getting at? It's definitely
easier from the clients point of view if it's just stuck in the URI, plus I
don't think it matters that much in this instance.. perhaps you can expand
on the problems it would cause?

As for URI templates in a link - a client of the app will know it is
dealing with a URI template because it's accessing the 'subset' relation..
what's the issue there?

Apologies for upsetting your stomach, once you've got yourself together
please could you expand a bit on what the actual issues are?

Cheers,
Mike


>  ------------------------------
> *From:* rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] on
> behalf of Mike Kelly [mikekelly321@...]
> *Sent:* 27 January 2012 12:30
> *To:* Erik Mogensen
> *Cc:* Jim Purbrick; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> *Subject:* Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
>
>
>
>
>
> On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 12:20 PM, Erik Mogensen <erik@...>wrote:
>
>> **
>>
>>
>>>   It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
>>> collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
>>> the uniform interface in a clean way.
>>>
>>>
>>  Within the confines of the uniform interface, I would go with a GET or
>> POST and link to that resource, maybe using a form-like construct which
>> tells the clients e.g. two URIs which make a range of documents.
>>
>>
>  It's also possible to do something along these lines which could work
> with PUT:
>
>  <link rel="subset" href="/some_collection?from={
> from_index}&to={to_index}&if-match=219837891723981723" />
>
>  Note, the if-match parameter is hard-coded into the representation by
> the server to keep the request idempotent.
>
>  Cheers,
> Mike
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18507
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 16:48:06
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

You introduce coupling to your definition to understand a link.

An atom link expects an identifier, not an identifier template. Same goes with rfc5988.

You establish with those known links a relationship between two resources, the current one and the resource /blah/{introyourtemplatehere}

Rewriting what identifiers mean (here, from identification to identification builder) is shoehorning concepts into one that should not be mucked about with (the identifier of a resource).

After that, if one wants to write a media type that has the same tag name as HTML and atom but puts into the target uri an identifier builder, and one doesn't care for introducing unnecessary confusion, or one decides that rewriting what identifying a resource means (and it's been attempted uselessly many times on this list and others), then one can of course write that media type in that way.

I highly doubt that anyone in that disposition would do so consciously and at the same time read that email, so for most intent and purposes no one actually need that reminder that templates are not identifiers and that putting templates of identifiers is like using chilli puree instead of hemorhoide cream, you'll manage to put it there but you completely missed the difference between the two.



________________________________
From: Mike Kelly [mikekelly321@gmail.com]
Sent: 27 January 2012 16:40
To: Sebastien Lambla
Cc: Erik Mogensen; Jim Purbrick; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?


On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 4:13 PM, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...<mailto:seb@...>> wrote:
 Seeing link tags (and headers) with URI templates in them made me throw up in my mouth a little bit.

Ok.

The if-match parameter could be called anything it's just a token that's needed to keep the request idempotent. The subset resource is not being retrieved so the client won't have an ETag for it.. I guess you could just use the ETag from the collection and stick a corresponding If-Match in the PUT request to the subset. Is that what you are getting at? It's definitely easier from the clients point of view if it's just stuck in the URI, plus I don't think it matters that much in this instance.. perhaps you can expand on the problems it would cause?

As for URI templates in a link - a client of the app will know it is dealing with a URI template because it's accessing the 'subset' relation.. what's the issue there?

Apologies for upsetting your stomach, once you've got yourself together please could you expand a bit on what the actual issues are?

Cheers,
Mike

________________________________
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com<mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com> [rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com<mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>] on behalf of Mike Kelly [mikekelly321@...<mailto:mikekelly321@...>]
Sent: 27 January 2012 12:30
To: Erik Mogensen
Cc: Jim Purbrick; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com<mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?





On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 12:20 PM, Erik Mogensen <erik@...<mailto:erik@...>> wrote:

It would be nice to be able to delete, add or update ranges in the
collections in a single request, but I can't see how to do this via
the uniform interface in a clean way.


Within the confines of the uniform interface, I would go with a GET or POST and link to that resource, maybe using a form-like construct which tells the clients e.g. two URIs which make a range of documents.


It's also possible to do something along these lines which could work with PUT:

<link rel="subset" href="/some_collection?from={from_index}&to={to_index}&if-match=219837891723981723" />

Note, the if-match parameter is hard-coded into the representation by the server to keep the request idempotent.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18508
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 17:03:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Fwd: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

Hi mike, I'm going to just focus on M2M.. CIL

On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 4:12 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> Jorn:
>
> Erik's list is a good start:
> - supply defaults
> - provide a range (select)
> - indicate whether to show to a human (hidden)
> - indicate mutability (disabled inputs cannot be changed)
>
> Also, HTML5 offers very long list of other attributes with which
> servers can use to communicate to the client input qualities value[1]
>
> Certainly the mere _appearance_ of an input is "useful" is it not?


For what? Improving the evolvability of M2M applications in a
significant way? I think more work is needed to prove this beyond
doubt.

It's certainly a more convoluted control to build automated agents against.

>
>
> As an application evolves over time, servers can add/remove inputs at
> selected points in the user-agent's interactions w/ the server, too.
> These decisions can be completely context dependent. For example,
> selected users (admins) might see diff inputs than others (guests).


Right, this is mostly an 'aesthetic' thing though, which would have
little/no value to M2M agents. The server side still needs security,
and agents will still be built against a specific role.

>
> During certain times (i.e. the DB is temporarily offline and does
> support writes) inputs could simply be removed from forms for a time.


If this was modeled without forms - the client would simply provide
the info which can't be processed but the server can just drop that
and deal with the bits it can, right ?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18509
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 17:16:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 4:48 PM, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:
> You introduce coupling to your definition to understand a link.

Yes, this is what link relations are for.

> An atom link expects an identifier, not an identifier template. Same goes
> with rfc5988.
>
> You establish with those known links a relationship between two resources,
> the current one and the resource /blah/{introyourtemplatehere}
>
> Rewriting what identifiers mean (here, from identification to identification
> builder) is shoehorning concepts into one that should not be mucked about
> with (the identifier of a resource).

.. so what are the actual problems you are foreseeing?

Afaict, the worst that will happen is clients are unaware of the
templated nature of the link (implied by the rel) will dereference it
as if it were a plain URI. Is that really a big deal?

'Shoehorning' is one (arguably pedantic) way of looking at it.. I just
look it as sensible re-use of existing mechanisms e.g. you can now
have templated/query links in the Link header for free, same with your
custom rels in Atom.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18510
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 17:24:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Fwd: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

Mike:

<snip>
>> Certainly the mere _appearance_ of an input is "useful" is it not?
>
>
> For what? Improving the evolvability of M2M applications in a
> significant way? I think more work is needed to prove this beyond
> doubt.
</snip>

"for what?" how about "hey, an input is expected here"? for my work,
this is "useful"

as to "improving evolvability" i can only assume what you are after
here. for the work i do, the ability to include inputs when needed,
have a client handle them (in whatever way that client deems
appropriate) is adequate for the use cases i encounter. that is the
only assertion i make.

i'm not sure what is needed to "prove beyond doubt" unless you expect
to me prove to _you_ that _I_ find them adequate for my use cases.

<snip>
>> As an application evolves over time, servers can add/remove inputs at
>> selected points in the user-agent's interactions w/ the server, too.
>> These decisions can be completely context dependent. For example,
>> selected users (admins) might see diff inputs than others (guests).
>
>
> Right, this is mostly an 'aesthetic' thing though, which would have
> little/no value to M2M agents. The server side still needs security,
> and agents will still be built against a specific role.
>
</snip>

adding/removing inputs in representations may "have little/no value"
for your use cases; i am not asserting to the contrary. i will say
again, this has value for my use cases; do you want to convince me the
opposite?

as for the example, replace "admin/guest" w/ any number of external or
internal contexts such as:
- clientA/clientB
- daytime/nighttime
- queue full/queue empty
- etc.

<snip>
>> During certain times (i.e. the DB is temporarily offline and does
>> support writes) inputs could simply be removed from forms for a time.
>
>
> If this was modeled without forms - the client would simply provide
> the info which can't be processed but the server can just drop that
> and deal with the bits it can, right ?
</snip>

absolutely. i am not saying that modeling these cases with forms is
the only/best way to do it. folks are free to implement interactions
using any media type designs that they wish.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18511
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 17:27:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTful Reference Collections and Queues?
Message:

So following your argument, there is really no reason whatsoever to standardise the link header with custom relationships, as if you don't understand the relationship you can do nothing with the link. The arc is not pointing to a resource anymore anyway so you've given up all value. 

In my pedantic view, breaking expectations won't work and shoehorning is an issue. 

Thanks god Firefox doesn't start understanding uri templates in href attributes, this would lead to fragmentation, and even non pedantic people would agree that it's not a good idea. 

--
Sebastien Lambla


On 27 Jan 2012, at 17:16, "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 4:48 PM, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:
>> You introduce coupling to your definition to understand a link.
> 
> Yes, this is what link relations are for.
> 
>> An atom link expects an identifier, not an identifier template. Same goes
>> with rfc5988.
>> 
>> You establish with those known links a relationship between two resources,
>> the current one and the resource /blah/{introyourtemplatehere}
>> 
>> Rewriting what identifiers mean (here, from identification to identification
>> builder) is shoehorning concepts into one that should not be mucked about
>> with (the identifier of a resource).
> 
> .. so what are the actual problems you are foreseeing?
> 
> Afaict, the worst that will happen is clients are unaware of the
> templated nature of the link (implied by the rel) will dereference it
> as if it were a plain URI. Is that really a big deal?
> 
> 'Shoehorning' is one (arguably pedantic) way of looking at it.. I just

> have templated/query links in the Link header for free, same with your
> custom rels in Atom.

Post ID:18512
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 17:42:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Fwd: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at 5:24 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> Mike:
>
> <snip>
>>> Certainly the mere _appearance_ of an input is "useful" is it not?
>>
>>
>> For what? Improving the evolvability of M2M applications in a
>> significant way? I think more work is needed to prove this beyond
>> doubt.
> </snip>
>
> "for what?" how about "hey, an input is expected here"? for my work,
> this is "useful"
>
> as to "improving evolvability" i can only assume what you are after
> here. for the work i do, the ability to include inputs when needed,
> have a client handle them (in whatever way that client deems
> appropriate) is adequate for the use cases i encounter. that is the
> only assertion i make.
>
> i'm not sure what is needed to "prove beyond doubt" unless you expect
> to me prove to _you_ that _I_ find them adequate for my use cases.

How significant their impact on evolvability is in real terms.

i.e. examples of changes in M2M application flow which are afforded by
forms and cannot be achieved via a more simple control (i.e. 'basic'
linking).

> <snip>
>>> As an application evolves over time, servers can add/remove inputs at
>>> selected points in the user-agent's interactions w/ the server, too.
>>> These decisions can be completely context dependent. For example,
>>> selected users (admins) might see diff inputs than others (guests).
>>
>>
>> Right, this is mostly an 'aesthetic' thing though, which would have
>> little/no value to M2M agents. The server side still needs security,
>> and agents will still be built against a specific role.
>>
> </snip>
>
> adding/removing inputs in representations may "have little/no value"
> for your use cases; i am not asserting to the contrary. i will say
> again, this has value for my use cases; do you want to convince me the
> opposite?

No no, just to share my perspective on whether or not they do - in the
hope that I can understand how, in practical terms, forms allow you to
achieve interactions and changes to your system which could not be
afforded with links.

> <snip>
>>> During certain times (i.e. the DB is temporarily offline and does
>>> support writes) inputs could simply be removed from forms for a time.
>>
>>
>> If this was modeled without forms - the client would simply provide
>> the info which can't be processed but the server can just drop that
>> and deal with the bits it can, right ?
> </snip>
>
> absolutely. i am not saying that modeling these cases with forms is
> the only/best way to do it. folks are free to implement interactions
> using any media type designs that they wish.
>

Sure, I guess my point was that this capability doesn't really set
forms apart, because this type interaction is already possible with
links and relations.

I think all of the above are important considerations, because
introducing forms into your application places additional requirements
on your clients.
For many, reducing the barrier to adoption by making consumption of
your application as easy as possible is important - so with stuff like
forms it's worth weighing this against their benefits.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18513
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 19:10:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Fwd: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

Mike:

When the implementation calls for the ability to provide support for
representing a varying set of possible inputs within a response, i use
the "form" pattern (URI Templates, Body Templates, whatever name you
like) that is appropriate to the selected media type (HTML.FORM,
XML.XFORMS, custom templating, etc.). This has proved "effective" and
"sufficient" for my work. In addition, it is "desirable", "useful",
etc. to my personal design sense.

I have yet to find other ways to model this varying set of inputs
within a response representation that are as (or more) "effective",
"sufficient", "desirable", "useful", etc.  I am not at all interested
in proving to anyone that they, too, should adopt my personal
valuation of this pattern for the same use cases I choose over any
other patterns. I am also open to learning new ways to support the
representation of varying sets of inputs within a response.

Yes, varability introduces additional complexity. whether the
variability is "needed", "useful", "worth the effort", etc. is a value
judgement each designer/implementor makes. This complexity may be
exacerbated when a human is not the primary driver of the client and
therefore the presence of humans as part of the "live evaluation" of
each representation is certainly a factor in making judgments about
suitability of a representation design (i.e. giving humans binary
representations to visual evaluate and interact w/ is proly
inappropriate).


mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

Post ID:18514
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-27 20:15:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Fwd: What does a form tell my program?
Message:

Lots of good feedback. Thank you guys. My thoughts were a bit along Mike 
Kellys' - why on earth would the server vary the set of inputs - the client 
would still be working with a specific goal in mind, and thereby be hard 
coded to use a specific set of inputs.

I don't have a clear picture of a good scenario for varying inputs in a M2M 
setup (and never mind that) - but I certainly accept that it can be relevant 
in exactly the same way as a varying set of links can be - just at another 
level that I haven't seen a use for yet.

Anyways, thanks for the input.

Mike A.:
> Certainly the mere _appearance_ of an input is "useful" is it not?

Well, that's what I was trying to figure out :-)

/Jï¿½rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18515
Sender:"Eric J. Bowman" <eric@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-28 00:44:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

Mike Kelly wrote:
>
> Eric J. Bowman wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> > "Markus Lanthaler" wrote:
> > >
> > > Even <a> tags in HTML don't disallow other methods than GET.
> > >
> >
> > Don't forget that method in hypertext, is also a function of URI. I
> > wish this list was easier to search, I know I re-wrote the HTML 4.01
> > text concerning form methods and posted it here as an example, once.
> > Instead of HTTP methods, HTML should use tokens descriptive of
> > sender intent. Because if the URI is mailto: the method won't be
> > POST, will it? Even though that's what it says in the markup?
> >
> > I'd rather see protocol-agnostic markup rather than bindings to
> > specific protocols, regardless of media type...
> >
> >
> I think that's interesting.. but I'm not clear where and how you
> would map these protocol-agnostic control elements to the various
> protocols/URI schemes, if you don't do it in the media type.
> 

Where does any such mapping exist for links in HTML?

http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/struct/links.html

Clearly, the semantics are retrieval, it's up to the client developer
what protocols to support over time, and map to the appropriate method
in the intermediary or user-agent code which implements the media type.
Browsers still understand the ftp: scheme, but dropped gopher: in 2010.

This change in scheme support affects all supported media types.  It is
orthogonal to media type, so don't protocol-bind your media types.  HTML
has seen protocols come and go, and will continue to be served over
HTTP 2.0 with yet another port # and URI scheme and perhaps different
method names -- this has always made its HTTP form bindings look rather
quaint, IOW method='get' should be operation='retrieve' with no more
discussion of protocol than for <a> and <link/>, as in none whatsoever.

-Eric





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18516
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-01-28 04:42:14
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Formats with native hypermedia support
Message:

> > I think that's interesting.. but I'm not clear where and how you
> > would map these protocol-agnostic control elements to the various
> > protocols/URI schemes, if you don't do it in the media type.
> >
> 
> Where does any such mapping exist for links in HTML?
> 
> http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/struct/links.html
> 
> Clearly, the semantics are retrieval

Is that really that clear? It is just the default behavior of browsers and
thus, by far, the most common one (at least for HTTP, what about mailto,
e.g.?). The semantics depend, on the rel and rev attributes according to
that document.


> This change in scheme support affects all supported media types.  It is
> orthogonal to media type, so don't protocol-bind your media types.
> HTML has seen protocols come and go, and will continue to be served over
> HTTP 2.0 with yet another port # and URI scheme and perhaps different
> method names

That's true.. but I don't know how feasible that really is. HTML sits on top
of an application level protocol (HTML or something else) which has its own
semantics that might not always match 1:1 to HTML semantics.. Again, think
of a mailto-link. How should a client retrieve such a "web resource"? It's
simple not possible, and yet mailto-links and even forms work.


> this has always made its HTTP form bindings look rather
> quaint, IOW method='get' should be operation='retrieve' with no more
> discussion of protocol than for <a> and <link/>, as in none whatsoever.

But it wasn't specified that way. It was clearly bound to the HTTP methods..
Nevertheless browsers are able map these HTTP semantics to other schemes -
is that really any different? There's still time to change that for HTML5 if
you think that it would be important to change this:

http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#attr-fs-method



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18517
Sender:Greg Young <gregoryyoung1@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-02-06 13:36:44
Subject:atom pub/high usage
Message:

Its pretty well known how to do a quick pub/sub with atom pub. If we
get loads and loads of consumers though it might be beneficial to say
hang a http connection and push results down the pipe in near real
time as opposed to polling (performance optimization only). This can
be done in a generic way, does anyone happen to know of a system that
just does that out of the box as opposed to building it?

-- 
Le doute n'est pas une condition agréable, mais la certitude est absurde.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18518
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-02-06 13:48:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] atom pub/high usage
Message:

On Feb 6, 2012, at 2:36 PM, Greg Young wrote:

> Its pretty well known how to do a quick pub/sub with atom pub. If we
> get loads and loads of consumers though it might be beneficial to say
> hang a http connection

Huh? Are you saying, you want to switch from polling to push when number of users grow?

I'd suggest that, the more number of users you have, the less is push a good architectural choice. Better to make use of HTTP caching to decrease umber of requests that actually hit your backend.

Look at archived feeds for this purpose <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5005> or check out <http://roy.gbiv.com/untangled/2008/paper-tigers-and-hidden-dragons> which I think is indeed a very practical solution despite its 'esoteric' appeal at first glance :-)

If you feel you must use push, then there are solutions already such as XMPP.


Jan


> and push results down the pipe in near real
> time as opposed to polling (performance optimization only). This can
> be done in a generic way, does anyone happen to know of a system that
> just does that out of the box as opposed to building it?
> 
> -- 
> Le doute n'est pas une condition agréable, mais la certitude est absurde.
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18519
Sender:Greg Young <gregoryyoung1@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-02-06 13:51:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] atom pub/high usage
Message:

There is good reason to switch to push as FREQUENCY of messages gets
higher. Try polling the twitter stream.

<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
