Post ID:18573
Sender:Craig McClanahan <craigmcc@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-01 20:54:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Where should I POST to?
Message:

On Wed, Feb 29, 2012 at 11:45 PM, Ruben Verborgh <ruben.verborgh@...>wrote:

> Hi everyone,
>
> A hypothetical blog application:
> - /posts/43 identifies a blog post resource
> - /posts/43/comments/3 identifies a comment resource on this blog post
>
> Here are different ideas to create a comment:
> - POST on /posts/43
>  According to the definition of POST [1], this should be acceptable under
> “annotation of existing resources”.
> - POST on /posts/43/comments
>  According to the definition of POST [1], this should be acceptable under
> “posting a message […]”
>
> The question: which one(s) of the above seem acceptable, which one is
> “best”?
>
> I tend to prefer the second approach for scenarios like this:

* POST /posts/43/comments is a well defined resource (it's a collection of
all the comments so far for this post)

* It is perfectly reasonable to support getting all the comments for a post
in a single call (GET /posts/43/comments),
  perhaps with optional query parameters to control filtering or pagination.

* If you have other sorts of resources related to your root resource, it's
straightforward to name
  additional collections ("POST /posts/43/attachments" will add an
attachment to that post)
  and I don't have any ambiguity if I want the attachments (GET
/posts/43/attachments) or
  the comments (GET /posts/43/comments).

In all cases, I'd suggest including the ".../comments" and
".../attachments" links (in whatever format you're using for
representations) as resource links in the post representation returned by
"GET /posts/43" so that a client doesn't have to know or care which choice
you made ... they just follow the provided links.

Craig





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18574
Sender:Jon Hanna <jon@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-02 13:51:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Where should I POST to?
Message:

On 2012-03-01 07:45, Ruben Verborgh wrote:
> - People will never GET /posts/43/comments, because the comments will be served along with every representation of the /posts/43 resource

One could choose to have a GET to /posts/43/comments 301 to 
/posts/43#comments. Or to just add a GET that returns an entity of just 
the comments, or simply say "well, if I made GET do anything it would be 
to return an entity that shows just the comments, but since it'll never 
be used I'm not going to bother implementing it".

The main reason I'd argue in favour of posting to /posts/43 is that the 
relationship between /posts/43 and /posts/43 is obvious, while the 
relationship between it and what is (relative to it) ./43/comments is 
less so. Had the post had the URI /posts/43/ with a trailing slash, then 
this would be less so pressing.

All of this is about niceties though. /adfs/d32rsdf/1ras89%20sfdakl 
would be just as good as either from a purely REST perspective, but 
niceties do matter.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18575
Sender:Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-03 13:57:38
Subject:Related resource: Inlined or linked
Message:

I think the first time I saw this pattern in Jon Moore's oredev talk on
Hypermedia APIs. In his demo he replaced links to subresources with their
full representations and the client continued to work.

Mike Amundsen in his hypermedia book talks about this approach as well.
Specifically:

"The code above assumes that a call to the initial UI will always return a
representation that contains the Collection+JSON template object. While
this is true for the implementation we are testing, that might not be true
for all servers. It is possible that servers will send only a link to the
template object..."

The part of documentation of the media type regarding the relation of the
resource containing the template and the template itself:

"The collection object MAY have a template object child property".

Note, nothing is mentioned about either template object is linked or
inlined. I assume it should be always inlined otherwise it's not clear what
the name of the link rel should be.

And then goes on with:

"It is important to review the semantic requirements fo the target media
type carefully in order to account for any possible variances in the way
representations may be presented by compliant servers. Never assume all
servers will implement the media type the same way."

It sounds like the related resource may be either linked or inlined -
whatever the server decides. I can understand the approach if the media
type explicitly says that there should be either a link OR an inlined
resource. But when it says there should be an inlined resource and the
server decides to return a link to it, then the server is not implementing
the media type anymore. And vice versa, when media type says there should
be a link, but the server returns an inline target resource.

So my question is rather broad, but please feel free to express any of your
thoughts on the topic: in which cases servers may decide to either go with
inlined or linked resource and clients should be expecting that possible
move from the servers?

-- 
Cheers,
Vitaly





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18576
Sender:Erlend Hamnaberg <ngarthl@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-05 07:32:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Related resource: Inlined or linked
Message:

On Sat, Mar 3, 2012 at 2:57 PM, Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> I think the first time I saw this pattern in Jon Moore's oredev talk on
> Hypermedia APIs. In his demo he replaced links to subresources with their
> full representations and the client continued to work.
>
> Mike Amundsen in his hypermedia book talks about this approach as well.
> Specifically:
>
> "The code above assumes that a call to the initial UI will always return a
> representation that contains the Collection+JSON template object. While
> this is true for the implementation we are testing, that might not be true
> for all servers. It is possible that servers will send only a link to the
> template object..."
>
> The part of documentation of the media type regarding the relation of the
> resource containing the template and the template itself:
>
> "The collection object MAY have a template object child property".
>
> Note, nothing is mentioned about either template object is linked or
> inlined. I assume it should be always inlined otherwise it's not clear what
> the name of the link rel should be.
>
> And then goes on with:
>
> "It is important to review the semantic requirements fo the target media
> type carefully in order to account for any possible variances in the way
> representations may be presented by compliant servers. Never assume all
> servers will implement the media type the same way."
>
> It sounds like the related resource may be either linked or inlined -
> whatever the server decides. I can understand the approach if the media
> type explicitly says that there should be either a link OR an inlined
> resource. But when it says there should be an inlined resource and the
> server decides to return a link to it, then the server is not implementing
> the media type anymore. And vice versa, when media type says there should
> be a link, but the server returns an inline target resource.
>
> So my question is rather broad, but please feel free to express any of
> your thoughts on the topic: in which cases servers may decide to either go
> with inlined or linked resource and clients should be expecting that
> possible move from the servers?
>
> --
> Cheers,
> Vitaly
>

Hi Vitaly.

In Atom it would be quite useful to have a summary representation in a feed
that represents a search result, but allow the full representation in a
"content-listing" resource. The summary would obviously link to the full
representation.

Switching to the full representation in a search result would also be
possible, but would need a separate URI, meaning a different resource.

--
Erlend





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18577
Sender:"Moore, Jonathan (CIM)" <jonathan_moore@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-05 14:26:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Related resource: Inlined or linked
Message:

You are correct that the media type definition has to allow for this degree of freedom or the server can't exercise it without potentially breaking compliant clients.

HTML5 microdata such as that described on http://schema.org/ would be an example media type; if an @itemprop is on an <a> tag, that's a pretty good indication that value is remote vs. inline; e.g.

<div itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
  <a itemprop="address" href="…"/> <!-- linked/remote postal address -->
</div>

Or:

<div itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
  <div itemprop="address" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">
    <!-- inlined postal address -->
   …
  </div>
</div>

Jon

From: Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@gmail.com<mailto:vitaly.st@...>>
Date: Sat, 3 Mar 2012 15:57:38 +0200
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com<mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>>
Subject: [rest-discuss] Related resource: Inlined or linked



I think the first time I saw this pattern in Jon Moore's oredev talk on Hypermedia APIs. In his demo he replaced links to subresources with their full representations and the client continued to work.

Mike Amundsen in his hypermedia book talks about this approach as well. Specifically:

"The code above assumes that a call to the initial UI will always return a representation that contains the Collection+JSON template object. While this is true for the implementation we are testing, that might not be true for all servers. It is possible that servers will send only a link to the template object..."

The part of documentation of the media type regarding the relation of the resource containing the template and the template itself:

"The collection object MAY have a template object child property".

Note, nothing is mentioned about either template object is linked or inlined. I assume it should be always inlined otherwise it's not clear what the name of the link rel should be.

And then goes on with:

"It is important to review the semantic requirements fo the target media type carefully in order to account for any possible variances in the way representations may be presented by compliant servers. Never assume all servers will implement the media type the same way."

It sounds like the related resource may be either linked or inlined - whatever the server decides. I can understand the approach if the media type explicitly says that there should be either a link OR an inlined resource. But when it says there should be an inlined resource and the server decides to return a link to it, then the server is not implementing the media type anymore. And vice versa, when media type says there should be a link, but the server returns an inline target resource.

So my question is rather broad, but please feel free to express any of your thoughts on the topic: in which cases servers may decide to either go with inlined or linked resource and clients should be expecting that possible move from the servers?

--
Cheers,
Vitaly





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18578
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-05 20:24:09
Subject:the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello RESTafarians.

http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/resource-profiles.html is a 
brief blog post about my plan to write up a I-D proposing a "profile" 
link relation type for the IANA registry. any comments on that idea 
would be highly appreciated, and if there is more support than pushback, 
then i expect to publish a first version within a week or two.

thanks  a lot and cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18579
Sender:"Eric J. Bowman" <eric@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-05 20:51:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

Erik Wilde wrote:
> 
> http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/resource-profiles.html is a 
> brief blog post about my plan to write up a I-D proposing a "profile" 
> link relation type for the IANA registry. any comments on that idea 
> would be highly appreciated, and if there is more support than
> pushback, then i expect to publish a first version within a week or
> two.
> 

I like it, specifically your notion of decoupling from media type.  If
@profile exists and is defined by the media type, it should take
precedence over a generic rel='profile'.  It's an excellent solution
for those of us who find HTML 5's dropping of @profile reprehensible.

-Eric





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18580
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-05 23:39:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello eric.

thanks for the feeback!

On 2012-03-05 12:51 , Eric J. Bowman wrote:
> I like it, specifically your notion of decoupling from media type.  If
> @profile exists and is defined by the media type, it should take
> precedence over a generic rel='profile'.  It's an excellent solution
> for those of us who find HTML 5's dropping of @profile reprehensible.

that's very good to hear! and i like the suggestion of defining how such 
a profile link may interact with a media-type specific profile 
mechanism, but the risk or challenge there is to figure out where this 
mechanism exists, and whether it "really means" the same thing. i guess 
we'll run into the finer points of this debate once we try to actually 
write down the semantics of the proposed link relation type.

thanks and cheers,

dret.

ps: comments on 
http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/resource-profiles.html will be 
easier accessible across mailing lists.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18581
Sender:Ruben Verborgh <ruben.verborgh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 09:12:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Where should I POST to?
Message:

Hi Jon,

> One could choose to have a GET to /posts/43/comments 301 to 
> /posts/43#comments. Or to just add a GET that returns an entity of just 
> the comments, or simply say "well, if I made GET do anything it would be 
> to return an entity that shows just the comments, but since it'll never 
> be used I'm not going to bother implementing it”.

Interesting option indeed.

> The main reason I'd argue in favour of posting to /posts/43 is that the 
> relationship between /posts/43 and /posts/43 is obvious, while the 
> relationship between it and what is (relative to it) ./43/comments is 
> less so. Had the post had the URI /posts/43/ with a trailing slash, then 
> this would be less so pressing.

True. It is easy to make the relationship from the blog post to a comment, and from each comment to the collection of all comments. But from the blog post to all comments is less convenient, all the more since we would serve all the comments in the post’s representation anyway.

> All of this is about niceties though. /adfs/d32rsdf/1ras89%20sfdakl 
> would be just as good as either from a purely REST perspective, but 
> niceties do matter.

I beg to differ here: the question is not about the exact URI used, but about the resource that is identified by that URI.

I my example /posts/43 was the resource “blog post 43” and /posts/43/comments the resource “comments to blog post 43”.
Now whether the URI to these resources is /posts/43 and /posts/43/comments or /bar and /foo doesn’t matter; but they *are* different resources.
Therefore, my question was to which resource I should POST, i.e., what resource does /adfs/d32rsdf/1ras89%20sfdakl identify?

Best,

Ruben





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18582
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 11:53:23
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

Hi Erik,

> http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/resource-profiles.html is a
> brief blog post about my plan to write up a I-D proposing a "profile"
> link relation type for the IANA registry. any comments on that idea
> would be highly appreciated, and if there is more support than
> pushback,
> then i expect to publish a first version within a week or two.

While I like the idea per se, I don't think it's a good idea to repeat the "mistake" of XML to use HTTP URIs for things that are not supposed to be dereferenced. Why do you? Either create a new URI scheme for that or provide some useful information - e.g. a HTML page describing the profile or just a page linking to the profile's description.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18583
Sender:"Moore, Jonathan (CIM)" <jonathan_moore@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 12:12:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

Specifying a URI allows you to use both non-dereferenceable URNs as well as dereferenceable URLs. Documenting the syntax as a URI makes it clear that the semantics treat this as an (opaque) identifier when processing.

Jon
........
Jon Moore


On Mar 6, 2012, at 6:54 AM, "Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...<mailto:markus.lanthaler@...>> wrote:



Hi Erik,

> <http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/resource-profiles.html> http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/resource-profiles.html is a
> brief blog post about my plan to write up a I-D proposing a "profile"
> link relation type for the IANA registry. any comments on that idea
> would be highly appreciated, and if there is more support than
> pushback,
> then i expect to publish a first version within a week or two.

While I like the idea per se, I don't think it's a good idea to repeat the "mistake" of XML to use HTTP URIs for things that are not supposed to be dereferenced. Why do you? Either create a new URI scheme for that or provide some useful information - e.g. a HTML page describing the profile or just a page linking to the profile's description.

--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

> URNs as well as dereferenceable URLs. Documenting the syntax
> as a URI makes it clear that the semantics treat this as an
> (opaque) identifier when processing. 

I agree. That's why I talked about *HTTP* URIs and using a different scheme
for non-dereferenceable ones. The I-D should be clear about that. That's all
I wanted to say..

Can you clarify the "mistake" you're referencing?  I'm not following how the distinction affects interoperability--can't a client treat a URL that happens to 404 (perhaps due to a temporary outage) the same way it would treat a URN here?

Jon

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18586
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 14:19:24
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

By "mistake" I meant creating invalid expectations. I'm quite sure most Web
developers out there don't know that namespaces in XML, e.g., are not and
were never expected to be dereferenced. I can't find the link now but quite
some time ago I tried to look one of those up and landed at a W3 page that
explained that they are getting tens of gigabytes of traffic a day because
tools try to continuously dereference those URIs.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

Message:

Markus:

I see you are concerned about a "mistake" (mixing de-ref and
non-de-ref URIs). I don't think this kind of distinction has been
discussed for other registered Lin Relation Values (anyone feel free
to point me to some helpful examples).

Is there a proposal/suggestion you have regarding this? i.e. "the
following text should appear" or "there should be some guarantee of
de-referenceability if the HTTP scheme is used...", etc.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18589
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 16:23:29
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

> I see you are concerned about a "mistake" (mixing de-ref and
> non-de-ref URIs). I don't think this kind of distinction has been
> discussed for other registered Lin Relation Values (anyone feel free
> to point me to some helpful examples).

A link relation's value doesn't have to be an IRI (in fact most of them
aren't) whereas the value of "profile" always has to be an IRI.

Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18591
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 17:56:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello markus.

On 2012-03-06 03:53 , Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> While I like the idea per se, I don't think it's a good idea to repeat the "mistake" of XML to use HTTP URIs for things that are not supposed to be dereferenced. Why do you? Either create a new URI scheme for that or provide some useful information - e.g. a HTML page describing the profile or just a page linking to the profile's description.

i don't think that a new URI scheme would be appropriate, since i am not 
proposing a new way of interacting with resources. and for the work we 
are doing, we will in fact try to make sure that all profile URIs 
resolve to something useful, but that's optional. if you're confident 
that you don't want to serve anything, then you're free to identify you 
profile by a non-resolvable URI such as some URN (or, as i used to joke 
with XML namespace URIs, use a tel: URI and then people can call you 
when they have questions about the namespace), but that's your decision 
and not something the general mechanism should prescribe.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18592
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 18:00:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello markus.

> I agree. That's why I talked about *HTTP* URIs and using a different scheme
> for non-dereferenceable ones. The I-D should be clear about that. That's all
> I wanted to say..

the I-D should be clear about what? the I-D is clear about the fact that 
making the profile URI dereferencable is optional, but that's a question 
of the link relation type semantics, and not of the URI scheme of the 
linked resource. it's too bad that the I-D submission window is 
currently closed, but maybe i will just publish version -00 on my site 
so that we can start discussing specific issues. give me an hour or two.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18593
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 18:08:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello.

thanks for the feedback everybody!

On 2012-03-06 07:48 , Julian Reschke wrote:
> On 2012-03-06 15:52, mike amundsen wrote:
>> I see you are concerned about a "mistake" (mixing de-ref and
>> non-de-ref URIs). I don't think this kind of distinction has been
>> discussed for other registered Lin Relation Values (anyone feel free
>> to point me to some helpful examples).
>> ...
> It's no "mistake". It might be a matter of taste.

so let's assume you don't like it (like markus). what would be an option 
to avoid this? prescribing non-dereferencable URIs by saying a profile 
MUST be identified by a URN? large parts of the goodness of the web are 
based on the fact that by identifying a resource, in most cases you also 
have a way of accessing it through a uniform interface.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18594
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 18:18:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello markus.

On 2012-03-06 08:23 , Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> A link relation's value doesn't have to be an IRI (in fact most of them
> aren't) whereas the value of "profile" always has to be an IRI.

i am a little bit confused by what you're saying.

- a *link relation type value* either is a registered name (which is 
what i am trying to do for 'profile'), or it has to be a URI, at least 
this is what RFC 5988 defines. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988#section-4

- the *target of any link* has to be a URI or IRI, based on the context 
of where the link appears. there is nothing any link relation type can 
change about this, this is how links work on the web.

could you please clarify what you mean by the above statement?

thanks and cheers,

dret.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18595
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 18:36:11
Subject:The 'profile' Link Relation Type", Internet Draft draft-wilde-profile-link-00
Message:

hello.

http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil12a is where i have "published" 
the first draft of the "The 'profile' Link Relation Type, Internet Draft 
draft-wilde-profile-link-00". specifically, here are the links for the 
two available versions:

- HTML: http://dret.net/netdret/docs/draft-wilde-profile-link-00.html
- ASCII: http://dret.net/netdret/docs/draft-wilde-profile-link-00.txt

this is not a properly published I-D (yet), because the I-D submission 
window closed yesterday. however, i will submit this -00 version as soon 
as submission opens again by the end of march, and any comments and 
changes to this -00 version will be incorporated in a new -01 version to 
be published in early april.

thanks and cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |

Post ID:18596
Sender:Tim Williams <williamstw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-06 19:08:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The 'profile' Link Relation Type", Internet Draft draft-wilde-profile-link-00
Message:

On Tue, Mar 6, 2012 at 1:36 PM, Erik Wilde <dret@...> wrote:
> hello.
>
> http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil12a is where i have "published"
> the first draft of the "The 'profile' Link Relation Type, Internet Draft
> draft-wilde-profile-link-00". specifically, here are the links for the
> two available versions:
>
> - HTML: http://dret.net/netdret/docs/draft-wilde-profile-link-00.html
> - ASCII: http://dret.net/netdret/docs/draft-wilde-profile-link-00.txt
>
> this is not a properly published I-D (yet), because the I-D submission
> window closed yesterday. however, i will submit this -00 version as soon
> as submission opens again by the end of march, and any comments and
> changes to this -00 version will be incorporated in a new -01 version to
> be published in early april.
>
> thanks and cheers,

In the "Security" section, "truly believed" seems out of place.  Maybe
something more objective:

"The 'profile' relation type is not known to introduce any new
security issues not already discussed in RFC 5988 [1] for generic use
of Web linking mechanism. "

Thanks,
--tim

existing use of profile URIs.

Post ID:18601
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>

Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

Hi Erik,

> [..] for the work we
> are doing, we will in fact try to make sure that all profile URIs
> resolve to something useful, but that's optional. 

Great. Would be interested in hearing more about it :-)


> if you're confident
> that you don't want to serve anything, then you're free to identify you
> profile by a non-resolvable URI such as some URN (or, as i used to joke
> with XML namespace URIs, use a tel: URI and then people can call you
> when they have questions about the namespace), but that's your decision
> and not something the general mechanism should prescribe.

Fully agree and that's what I meant by make it clear in the I-D. As I've seen, you did that already.

I think the draft would benefit from a couple of examples..



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18602
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-07 18:10:38
Subject:Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

HI all

One topic that keeps coming up in my recent conversations is about the
scope of REST and whether it applies both to client and server i.e. is the
application the server, or is it the combination of client and server? Yes
definitely REST is a client-server architectural style...

Assume I have implemented my server in a RESTful way i.e. it adheres to all
the constraints / is hypermedia driven.


   - If I have no clients actively consuming me can I say the application
   is RESTful? i.e. is the RESTfulness determined by the server.
   - Is each client + server combination considered an application?
      - If I have two clients, one which consumes my application using
      hypermedia and other that doesn't / hardcodes dependencies on my
URIs then
      is the entire application non-RESTful?
      - Or, is it that really there are multiple applications (client1 +
      server, client2 + server) with one being RESTful the other not.
      - Are there actually three applications? one the server app, and the
      other two composites of client and server?


Interested in your thoughts and this is not a leading question :-)

Thanks
Glenn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18603
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-07 19:27:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

<snip>
If I have no clients actively consuming me can I say the application is 
RESTful? i.e. is the RESTfulness determined by the server. 
</snip>
If you create a painting in the Cubist style and no one but you sees it, is 
it still Cubist?

"application"
"client"
"server"
"composites"
this is all really vague, IMO. ripe for trouble<g>.

here's how i see it:
- i implement a service in a REST-[like|ful|ish] style. done.
- anyone can implement a client that uses that service. it's up to them to 
decide what "style" they want to use for their implementation.

if someone implements a client app that hardcodes URIs and workflow and 
ignores the affordance details I supply from the service, that does not 
"diminish" the "REST-itude" of my efforts.

that's me.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me





On Wed, Mar 7, 2012 at 13:10, Glenn Block <glenn.block@gmail.com> wrote:

> application the server, or is it the combination of client and server? Yes 
> definitely REST is a client-server architectural style...

> all the constraints / is hypermedia driven.
>
>
>    - If I have no clients actively consuming me can I say the application 
>    is RESTful? i.e. is the RESTfulness determined by the server. 
>    - Is each client + server combination considered an application?
>       - If I have two clients, one which consumes my application using 
>       hypermedia and other that doesn't / hardcodes dependencies on my URIs then 
>       is the entire application non-RESTful? 
>       - Or, is it that really there are multiple applications (client1 +

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18604
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-07 22:19:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

hello.

On Mar 7, 2012, at 11:27, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> if someone implements a client app that hardcodes URIs and workflow and ignores the affordance details I supply from the service, that does not "diminish" the "REST-itude" of my efforts.

well said. as illustration, imagine the many ways in which browsers can be broken and sometimes are. such as not making @src links on q/blockquote elements navigable. or firefox' recent decision to not display anymore that a page has associated feeds. all cases where no matter how you publish your data, poorly implemented clients can diminish its usefulness.

cheers,

dret.

Post ID:18606
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-07 22:37:47
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Glenn:

> What about the counter view that each client and server combo is the 'application'

first, i'm not sure that is a "counter view" of what i said. IOW, how
does this run "counter" to my POV?

second, the term "application" can be applied lots of ways.
- a single component running on a singe machine,
- a group of components running on a single machine
- a group of machines running components
- etc.

finally, what is the "end game" here? IOW, why pursue this line of
convo? what positive things can result?

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me

Post ID:18607
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 06:26:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello markus.

On 2012-03-07 02:44 , Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>> [..] for the work we
>> are doing, we will in fact try to make sure that all profile URIs
>> resolve to something useful, but that's optional.
> Great. Would be interested in hearing more about it :-)

nothing fixed yet, but essentially a profile description should define 
how it is specializing a media type, so we may create some (fairly 
loose) schema for how to capture documentation about this. nothing 
that's strictly a machine-readable schema, though, i would assume, and 
probably just for the kinds of profiles we're interested in.

> I think the draft would benefit from a couple of examples..

good point, but are there any existing profile URIs i could use without 
having to make them up? i like the podcast example, but there is no 
profile URI for them (and sadly, they don't even use atom...).

thanks for the feedback! cheers,

dret.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18608
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 12:41:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Wed, Mar 7, 2012 at 10:37 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Glenn:
>
>
> > What about the counter view that each client and server combo is the
> 'application'
>
> first, i'm not sure that is a "counter view" of what i said. IOW, how
> does this run "counter" to my POV?
>
> second, the term "application" can be applied lots of ways.
> - a single component running on a singe machine,
> - a group of components running on a single machine
> - a group of machines running components
> - etc.
>
> finally, what is the "end game" here? IOW, why pursue this line of
> convo? what positive things can result?
>
>
>
Ok so let's move away from 'application' and talk about a 'system'..
 client behaviour has a direct impact on the nature of interactions in your
system and therefore the extents to which it can evolve. So if your clients
consume your service in a way "that hardcodes URIs and workflow and ignores
the affordance details I supply from the service", this will absolutely
have an impact on the "REST-itude" of your system since it is an emergence
of interaction in your system which directly violates the hypertext
constraint.

As a service provider, you can govern your clients through deliberate
designs that constrain their behaviour and that will help ensure they 'do
the right thing' - if you don't manage to do this and your clients do the
wrong thing then I think that does diminish the quality of your effort.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18609
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 15:21:41
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

> > I think the draft would benefit from a couple of examples..
> 
> good point, but are there any existing profile URIs i could use without
> having to make them up?

Unfortunately I'm not aware of any. Haven't seen profile being used in practice so far.


Cheers,
Markus


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18610
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 15:50:56
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Hi Mike, Mike and Glenn.
This is my humble take:
1. Application is far more that just a component. My definition includes business goals and the like, so I won't enter there.

2. A system includes not only the components but the inter-relationships, interfaces and externally visible properties. As I once stated in this forum, a client is a role, and can be played by one component inside a system A, and by another system B consuming services on System A. So we can have a system of systems, where their components can be playing different roles, one of them being a client.

3. That clarified, REST is an architectural style that defines component roles and rules of engagement to achieve a set of quality properties. Theory says that one component not playing the role or not following the rules, may affect the property quality achievement. Clear?

4. Now, in any modern architecture development, we architects should not focus only in functional requirements, but in quality properties too. That means making decisions about how things are going to work, stating policies and making sure those policies are enforced. Following this line of thinking, implementing an architectural conception that follows REST style, but that does not enforce the rules or does not even detect a rule is being broken (a governance problem), I should say it is a weak implementation. And if we are not in control of all components (other people creating their services and clients) then we may not achieve the quality properties after all.

5. But all that is not REST fault, and shouldn't care less. That is the work of the architect, designers and developers and other stakeholders. REST is not an out-of-the-box solution you get when you install a framework and use it. A framework may help, but the actual success of delivering business value comes from the work of all people. You will get nowhere if a bunch of your developers keep not following the rules. If an external "client" enters the system, and is not playing the rules, may affect the quality properties, and sure it will suffer itself from that, when the server changes the uri namespace or the flow, then it becomes a problem of the spoiled client. 

My two cents.

William Martinez Pomares
--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18611
Sender:Will Hartung <willh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 16:06:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

As Mike says, and part of generic matra REST for me is that a bad client
does not invalidate a good REST design. By the nature of REST, many of the
aspects of the architecture are in fact designed to benefit the client. And
other aspects simply cannot be counted on by the server in the wild anyway.

The HATEOS is a client advantage. If a client cares about the robustness of
their implementation, they will leverage HATEOS in order to help keep their
systems running without interruption. Many applications that offer HATEOS,
don't per se take advantage of it right off as it's mostly a future
proofing mechanism. You have simple apps on a single machine with a few,
solid services that will "never change" vs an app that is an aggressive
user of HATEOS, and pretty much forces a client to leverage as well (i.e.
no URL will ever be the same kind of thing). Those are opposite extremes.
Most fall in the former sense, they're just easier to design and manage
unless you have a very compelling reason to do otherwise.

So, you can see how a "dumb" client can easily get by with the first type
of application, but fail miserably with the latter.

Caches are another important aspect of the architecture that the system may
or may not be able to leverage. If your system implements their own caches,
then you can expect to see a benefit and plan around it. At this point a
bad client (i.e. one the completely ignores the caching constraints) can
put an excessive load on your core system. They're still a REST client, in
fact they can be an external cache themselves (perhaps a badly configured
one).

Now, if you're not providing you own caching layer, and effectively hoping
to leverage external caches, then you have no room to complain when you get
several clients that perhaps ignore the caching aspect. When you're relying
on external systems that you have no control over, you're on the borderline
of "serendipitous reuse". The bright side of SU is the new value it can
provide, the down side is the "serendipitous" part.

And finally, you can address the serendipitous reuse aspect. That too, is a
benefit of the client. It lets someone use the data in ways not envisioned
by the application designers. Thus providing added value to the client
Whether it's added value to the application is a different issue (maybe you
didn't want or plan for all of this new traffic, then again maybe you're
excited to be offering new value that you didn't have to code and design).

So, yes, it takes good corporation between the clients and the servers to
get the highest level of benefits from the architecture, but the simple
truth is much of the design is really there for the clients in the first
place and they're only hurting themselves in the long run by not playing
along.

Regards,

Will Hartung
(willh@...)

-- 
CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: The information contained in this electronic 
transmission may be confidential. If you are not an intended recipient, be 
aware that any disclosure, copying, distribution or use of the information 
contained in this transmission is prohibited and may be unlawful. If you 
have received this transmission in error, please notify us by email reply 
and then erase it from your computer system.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18612
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 16:31:31
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

If you have an open application that many 3rd parties consume, you don't
really have control to enforce how they use the system. It is not just a
question of  internal policy.

Sent from my Windows Phone
------------------------------
From: William Martinez Pomares
Sent: 3/8/2012 7:51 AM
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness
of an application?




Hi Mike, Mike and Glenn.
This is my humble take:
1. Application is far more that just a component. My definition includes
business goals and the like, so I won't enter there.

2. A system includes not only the components but the inter-relationships,
interfaces and externally visible properties. As I once stated in this
forum, a client is a role, and can be played by one component inside a
system A, and by another system B consuming services on System A. So we can
have a system of systems, where their components can be playing different
roles, one of them being a client.

3. That clarified, REST is an architectural style that defines component
roles and rules of engagement to achieve a set of quality properties.
Theory says that one component not playing the role or not following the
rules, may affect the property quality achievement. Clear?

4. Now, in any modern architecture development, we architects should not
focus only in functional requirements, but in quality properties too. That
means making decisions about how things are going to work, stating policies
and making sure those policies are enforced. Following this line of
thinking, implementing an architectural conception that follows REST style,
but that does not enforce the rules or does not even detect a rule is being
broken (a governance problem), I should say it is a weak implementation.
And if we are not in control of all components (other people creating their
services and clients) then we may not achieve the quality properties after
all.

5. But all that is not REST fault, and shouldn't care less. That is the
work of the architect, designers and developers and other stakeholders.
REST is not an out-of-the-box solution you get when you install a framework
and use it. A framework may help, but the actual success of delivering
business value comes from the work of all people. You will get nowhere if a
bunch of your developers keep not following the rules. If an external
"client" enters the system, and is not playing the rules, may affect the
quality properties, and sure it will suffer itself from that, when the
server changes the uri namespace or the flow, then it becomes a problem of
the spoiled client.

My two cents.

William Martinez Pomares
--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>
> On Wed, Mar 7, 2012 at 10:37 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>
> > **
> >
> >
> > Glenn:
> >
> >
> > > What about the counter view that each client and server combo is the
> > 'application'
> >
> > first, i'm not sure that is a "counter view" of what i said. IOW, how
> > does this run "counter" to my POV?
> >
> > second, the term "application" can be applied lots of ways.
> > - a single component running on a singe machine,
> > - a group of components running on a single machine
> > - a group of machines running components
> > - etc.
> >
> > finally, what is the "end game" here? IOW, why pursue this line of
> > convo? what positive things can result?
> >
> >
> >
> Ok so let's move away from 'application' and talk about a 'system'..
> client behaviour has a direct impact on the nature of interactions in your
> system and therefore the extents to which it can evolve. So if your
clients
> consume your service in a way "that hardcodes URIs and workflow and
ignores
> the affordance details I supply from the service", this will absolutely
> have an impact on the "REST-itude" of your system since it is an emergence
> of interaction in your system which directly violates the hypertext
> constraint.
>
> As a service provider, you can govern your clients through deliberate
> designs that constrain their behaviour and that will help ensure they 'do
> the right thing' - if you don't manage to do this and your clients do the
> wrong thing then I think that does diminish the quality of your effort.
>
> Cheers,
> Mike
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18613
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 16:33:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Thu, Mar 8, 2012 at 4:06 PM, Will Hartung <willh@...> wrote:

> **
>
> The HATEOS is a client advantage.
>

No, the server has just as much to gain from hypertext, as it will have a
direct impact on how it is able to improve/adjust/evolve its application.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18614
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 16:36:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

There are strategies you can use within a system that mitigate the risk of
poor client consumption.

For example; your testing and/or sandbox environment can intentionally
obfuscate all of the URIs - which will help to weed out client which are
constructing URIs.

Cheers,
Mike

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18617
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 16:45:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Hi Mikes & All,

IMHO the RESTfulness is a property of the published services and, as it was
already said, it can't be affected by the clients.

On the other hand,
    application = client + server
(at least), where the clients can exhibit diverse levels of compliance with
HATEOAS or whatever.

So, back to the first MIke's first question, I doubt that the RESTfulness
could be said of the whole application combo; it only pertains to the back
end.
--
Juan Lanus





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18618
Sender:Will Hartung <willh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 16:46:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Thu, Mar 8, 2012 at 8:33 AM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

>
>
> On Thu, Mar 8, 2012 at 4:06 PM, Will Hartung <willh@...> wrote:
>
>> **
>>
>> The HATEOS is a client advantage.
>>
>
> No, the server has just as much to gain from hypertext, as it will have a
> direct impact on how it is able to improve/adjust/evolve its application.
>

The parts that suffer from server change are the clients. Clearly, the
server is better utilized when clients perform properly, and clearly, when
the server makes changes that the the clients don't recognize (and thus
break), the server support team ends up eating the phone calls.

But in the end, the clients are the ones consuming the services. They're
consuming these services for their own advantage, so while HATEOS makes the
relationship between the server and client more manageable, in the end,
it's the clients the win by leverage HATEOS moreso than the server. Who
wants to make those phone calls to the server team in the first place?

--

and then erase it from your computer system.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18620
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 19:15:19
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Will, I completely agree with your thoughts about the client and the validation of the REST design, at least of what I understand. My point a subtlety different. Anyway, I understand REST was designed to meet some quality properties that were needed, and the benefits of the client are just collateral damage due to its role of service consumer and display agent (yes, it says so in the dissertation).

An architectural style is not a complete definition of the architecture, but just the ideas to achieve quality attributes. 

I often say to my students that a system can implement perfectly all the functional requirements, and meet all the quality property standards required, but if it does not deliver business value, it is a failure.

In the same sense, just one level down: The good REST design badge is achieved by implementing the REST constrains in your part of the system. But that badge will not assure the REST qualities are achieved in the whole system, or even in the system of systems above. 
Even more: having a completely perfect REST design and execution at all components, doesn't mean the app will give the business value and as such be a success. It may also fail.

So, to answer the original question, and a couple more I answered without being questioned:
1. Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application? Yes if the client is part of the application. It will not invalidate the RESTFulness of the server, but it may do so for the whole system.

2. Does designing an app server side to be compliant with REST rules delivers the goals of REST. Not necessarily, we need a compliant client and complaint interim layers (yup, REST is a layered architecture).

3. Does having a fully compliant REST architecture implemented is enough to be a success. No, it isn't. 

Those were the points I wanted to share.

Cheers

William Martinez.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Will Hartung <willh@...> wrote:
>
> As Mike says, and part of generic matra REST for me is that a bad client
> does not invalidate a good REST design. By the nature of REST, many of the
> aspects of the architecture are in fact designed to benefit the client. And
> other aspects simply cannot be counted on by the server in the wild anyway.
> 
> The HATEOS is a client advantage. If a client cares about the robustness of
> their implementation, they will leverage HATEOS in order to help keep their
> systems running without interruption. Many applications that offer HATEOS,
> don't per se take advantage of it right off as it's mostly a future
> proofing mechanism. You have simple apps on a single machine with a few,
> solid services that will "never change" vs an app that is an aggressive
> user of HATEOS, and pretty much forces a client to leverage as well (i.e.
> no URL will ever be the same kind of thing). Those are opposite extremes.
> Most fall in the former sense, they're just easier to design and manage
> unless you have a very compelling reason to do otherwise.
> 
> So, you can see how a "dumb" client can easily get by with the first type
> of application, but fail miserably with the latter.
> 
> Caches are another important aspect of the architecture that the system may
> or may not be able to leverage. If your system implements their own caches,
> then you can expect to see a benefit and plan around it. At this point a
> bad client (i.e. one the completely ignores the caching constraints) can
> put an excessive load on your core system. They're still a REST client, in
> fact they can be an external cache themselves (perhaps a badly configured
> one).
> 
> Now, if you're not providing you own caching layer, and effectively hoping
> to leverage external caches, then you have no room to complain when you get
> several clients that perhaps ignore the caching aspect. When you're relying
> on external systems that you have no control over, you're on the borderline
> of "serendipitous reuse". The bright side of SU is the new value it can
> provide, the down side is the "serendipitous" part.
> 
> And finally, you can address the serendipitous reuse aspect. That too, is a
> benefit of the client. It lets someone use the data in ways not envisioned
> by the application designers. Thus providing added value to the client
> Whether it's added value to the application is a different issue (maybe you
> didn't want or plan for all of this new traffic, then again maybe you're
> excited to be offering new value that you didn't have to code and design).
> 
> So, yes, it takes good corporation between the clients and the servers to
> get the highest level of benefits from the architecture, but the simple
> truth is much of the design is really there for the clients in the first
> place and they're only hurting themselves in the long run by not playing
> along.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Will Hartung
> (willh@...)
> 
> -- 
> CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: The information contained in this electronic 
> transmission may be confidential. If you are not an intended recipient, be 
> aware that any disclosure, copying, distribution or use of the information 
> contained in this transmission is prohibited and may be unlawful. If you 
> have received this transmission in error, please notify us by email reply 
> and then erase it from your computer system.
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18621
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 19:38:54
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Thanks William

I agree with everything you said. The true benefits of REST are only
realized if both client and server understand the constraints. However the
fact some clients may not adhere to those constraints is orthagonal to the
server. However system is at many levels. Each combination of client and
server is a system itself.

The one thing that is very clear is that the server is the gate. If the
server doesn't adhere to the constraints then all the "macro" level systems
are not RESTful.

My point in all of this was to reach a better understanding of where the
RESTFulness of a system is defined / exhibited and what defines the
boundaries of the system.

Sent from my Windows Phone
------------------------------
From: William Martinez Pomares
Sent: 3/8/2012 11:15 AM
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness
of an application?



Will, I completely agree with your thoughts about the client and the
validation of the REST design, at least of what I understand. My point a
subtlety different. Anyway, I understand REST was designed to meet some
quality properties that were needed, and the benefits of the client are
just collateral damage due to its role of service consumer and display
agent (yes, it says so in the dissertation).

An architectural style is not a complete definition of the architecture,
but just the ideas to achieve quality attributes.

I often say to my students that a system can implement perfectly all the
functional requirements, and meet all the quality property standards
required, but if it does not deliver business value, it is a failure.

In the same sense, just one level down: The good REST design badge is
achieved by implementing the REST constrains in your part of the system.
But that badge will not assure the REST qualities are achieved in the whole
system, or even in the system of systems above.
Even more: having a completely perfect REST design and execution at all
components, doesn't mean the app will give the business value and as such
be a success. It may also fail.

So, to answer the original question, and a couple more I answered without
being questioned:
1. Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application? Yes if
the client is part of the application. It will not invalidate the
RESTFulness of the server, but it may do so for the whole system.

2. Does designing an app server side to be compliant with REST rules
delivers the goals of REST. Not necessarily, we need a compliant client and
complaint interim layers (yup, REST is a layered architecture).

3. Does having a fully compliant REST architecture implemented is enough to
be a success. No, it isn't.

Those were the points I wanted to share.

Cheers

William Martinez.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Will Hartung <willh@...> wrote:
>
> As Mike says, and part of generic matra REST for me is that a bad client
> does not invalidate a good REST design. By the nature of REST, many of the
> aspects of the architecture are in fact designed to benefit the client.
And
> other aspects simply cannot be counted on by the server in the wild
anyway.
>
> The HATEOS is a client advantage. If a client cares about the robustness
of
> their implementation, they will leverage HATEOS in order to help keep
their
> systems running without interruption. Many applications that offer HATEOS,
> don't per se take advantage of it right off as it's mostly a future
> proofing mechanism. You have simple apps on a single machine with a few,
> solid services that will "never change" vs an app that is an aggressive
> user of HATEOS, and pretty much forces a client to leverage as well (i.e.
> no URL will ever be the same kind of thing). Those are opposite extremes.
> Most fall in the former sense, they're just easier to design and manage
> unless you have a very compelling reason to do otherwise.
>
> So, you can see how a "dumb" client can easily get by with the first type
> of application, but fail miserably with the latter.
>
> Caches are another important aspect of the architecture that the system
may
> or may not be able to leverage. If your system implements their own
caches,
> then you can expect to see a benefit and plan around it. At this point a
> bad client (i.e. one the completely ignores the caching constraints) can
> put an excessive load on your core system. They're still a REST client, in
> fact they can be an external cache themselves (perhaps a badly configured
> one).
>
> Now, if you're not providing you own caching layer, and effectively hoping
> to leverage external caches, then you have no room to complain when you
get
> several clients that perhaps ignore the caching aspect. When you're
relying
> on external systems that you have no control over, you're on the
borderline
> of "serendipitous reuse". The bright side of SU is the new value it can
> provide, the down side is the "serendipitous" part.
>
> And finally, you can address the serendipitous reuse aspect. That too, is
a
> benefit of the client. It lets someone use the data in ways not envisioned
> by the application designers. Thus providing added value to the client
> Whether it's added value to the application is a different issue (maybe
you
> didn't want or plan for all of this new traffic, then again maybe you're
> excited to be offering new value that you didn't have to code and design).
>

> get the highest level of benefits from the architecture, but the simple
> truth is much of the design is really there for the clients in the first
> place and they're only hurting themselves in the long run by not playing
> along.
>
> Regards,

Post ID:18622
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 19:52:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

<snip>
My point in all of this was to reach a better understanding of where the
RESTFulness of a system is defined / exhibited and what defines the
boundaries of the system.
</snip>

I think it's important to consider whether "a system" has more than one
"server" in it and whether that "system" could be judged as a "REST system"
only if all the machines acting in a "server role" sufficiently exhibited
the "REST style." This is particularly challenging when you consider that
any machine in "the system" can adopt the "client" or "server" role at any
time.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me





On Thu, Mar 8, 2012 at 14:38, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> server. However system is at many levels. Each combination of client and
> server is a system itself.

> server doesn't adhere to the constraints then all the "macro" level systems
> are not RESTful.

> RESTFulness of a system is defined / exhibited and what defines the
> boundaries of the system.

> Sent from my Windows Phone
> ------------------------------
> From: William Martinez Pomares
> Sent: 3/8/2012 11:15 AM
> To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness
> of an application?

> validation of the REST design, at least of what I understand. My point a

>
> In the same sense, just one level down: The good REST design badge is
> achieved by implementing the REST constrains in your part of the system.
> But that badge will not assure the REST qualities are achieved in the whole
> system, or even in the system of systems above.
> Even more: having a completely perfect REST design and execution at all
> components, doesn't mean the app will give the business value and as such
> be a success. It may also fail.
>
> So, to answer the original question, and a couple more I answered without
> being questioned:
> 1. Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application? Yes if
> the client is part of the application. It will not invalidate the
> RESTFulness of the server, but it may do so for the whole system.
>
> 2. Does designing an app server side to be compliant with REST rules
> delivers the goals of REST. Not necessarily, we need a compliant client and
> complaint interim layers (yup, REST is a layered architecture).
>
> 3. Does having a fully compliant REST architecture implemented is enough
> to be a success. No, it isn't.
>
> Those were the points I wanted to share.
>
> Cheers
>
> William Martinez.
>
> --- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Will Hartung <willh@...> wrote:
> >
> > As Mike says, and part of generic matra REST for me is that a bad client
> > does not invalidate a good REST design. By the nature of REST, many of
> the
> > aspects of the architecture are in fact designed to benefit the client.
> And
> > other aspects simply cannot be counted on by the server in the wild
> anyway.
> >
> > The HATEOS is a client advantage. If a client cares about the robustness
> of
> > their implementation, they will leverage HATEOS in order to help keep
> their
> > systems running without interruption. Many applications that offer
> HATEOS,
> > don't per se take advantage of it right off as it's mostly a future
> > proofing mechanism. You have simple apps on a single machine with a few,
> > solid services that will "never change" vs an app that is an aggressive
> > user of HATEOS, and pretty much forces a client to leverage as well (i.e.
> > no URL will ever be the same kind of thing). Those are opposite extremes.
> > Most fall in the former sense, they're just easier to design and manage
> > unless you have a very compelling reason to do otherwise.
> >
> > So, you can see how a "dumb" client can easily get by with the first type
> > of application, but fail miserably with the latter.
> >
> > Caches are another important aspect of the architecture that the system
> may
> > or may not be able to leverage. If your system implements their own
> caches,
> > then you can expect to see a benefit and plan around it. At this point a
> > bad client (i.e. one the completely ignores the caching constraints) can
> > put an excessive load on your core system. They're still a REST client,
> in
> > fact they can be an external cache themselves (perhaps a badly configured
> > one).
> >
> > Now, if you're not providing you own caching layer, and effectively
> hoping
> > to leverage external caches, then you have no room to complain when you
> get
> > several clients that perhaps ignore the caching aspect. When you're
> relying
> > on external systems that you have no control over, you're on the
> borderline
> > of "serendipitous reuse". The bright side of SU is the new value it can
> > provide, the down side is the "serendipitous" part.
> >
> > And finally, you can address the serendipitous reuse aspect. That too,
> is a
> > benefit of the client. It lets someone use the data in ways not
> envisioned
> > by the application designers. Thus providing added value to the client
> > Whether it's added value to the application is a different issue (maybe
> you
> > didn't want or plan for all of this new traffic, then again maybe you're
> > excited to be offering new value that you didn't have to code and
> design).
> >
> > So, yes, it takes good corporation between the clients and the servers to
> > get the highest level of benefits from the architecture, but the simple
> > truth is much of the design is really there for the clients in the first
> > place and they're only hurting themselves in the long run by not playing
> > along.
> >
> > Regards,
> >
> > Will Hartung
> > (willh@...)
> >
> > --
> > CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: The information contained in this electronic
> > transmission may be confidential. If you are not an intended recipient,
> be
> > aware that any disclosure, copying, distribution or use of the
> information
> > contained in this transmission is prohibited and may be unlawful. If you
> > have received this transmission in error, please notify us by email
> reply
> > and then erase it from your computer system.
> >
>
>
>
> 
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18623
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 20:28:58
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Hey, Mike.
You just multiplied the exponent of the complexity by 2.

A system is a set of components. An architectural style defines the structure, roles and rules that will govern those components. They are very clear in REST.

Actually, I feel REST does not constrain the roles of the components in a system, it simply defines the roles it requires and how will they interact. There may be other components not following the roles or rules that may work in the system too. Problem is we need the interaction rules between non-REST component and the true REST ones. Allowing alien components in the system is the architect's responsibility and should be done with complete rationale and knowledge of the impact in the quality properties we need to achieve. A golden rule in architecture is you can break the rules if it is needed to obtain the business value. 
That means, we can accept non-REST servers in our system if we provide a way to communicate them with our REST-complaint ones without affecting that much what we are looking for. That may not make the REST-like architecture less RESTfull, in my opinion.

William. 

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>
> <snip>
> My point in all of this was to reach a better understanding of where the
> RESTFulness of a system is defined / exhibited and what defines the
> boundaries of the system.
> </snip>
> 
> I think it's important to consider whether "a system" has more than one
> "server" in it and whether that "system" could be judged as a "REST system"
> only if all the machines acting in a "server role" sufficiently exhibited
> the "REST style." This is particularly challenging when you consider that
> any machine in "the system" can adopt the "client" or "server" role at any
> time.
> 
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Thu, Mar 8, 2012 at 14:38, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
> 
> >
> >
> > Thanks William
> >
> > I agree with everything you said. The true benefits of REST are only
> > realized if both client and server understand the constraints. However the
> > fact some clients may not adhere to those constraints is orthagonal to the
> > server. However system is at many levels. Each combination of client and
> > server is a system itself.
> >
> > The one thing that is very clear is that the server is the gate. If the
> > server doesn't adhere to the constraints then all the "macro" level systems
> > are not RESTful.
> >
> > My point in all of this was to reach a better understanding of where the
> > RESTFulness of a system is defined / exhibited and what defines the
> > boundaries of the system.
> >
> >
> > Sent from my Windows Phone
> > ------------------------------
> > From: William Martinez Pomares
> > Sent: 3/8/2012 11:15 AM
> > To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness
> > of an application?
> >
> >
> >
> > Will, I completely agree with your thoughts about the client and the
> > validation of the REST design, at least of what I understand. My point a
> > subtlety different. Anyway, I understand REST was designed to meet some
> > quality properties that were needed, and the benefits of the client are
> > just collateral damage due to its role of service consumer and display
> > agent (yes, it says so in the dissertation).
> >
> > An architectural style is not a complete definition of the architecture,
> > but just the ideas to achieve quality attributes.
> >
> > I often say to my students that a system can implement perfectly all the
> > functional requirements, and meet all the quality property standards
> > required, but if it does not deliver business value, it is a failure.
> >
> > In the same sense, just one level down: The good REST design badge is
> > achieved by implementing the REST constrains in your part of the system.
> > But that badge will not assure the REST qualities are achieved in the whole
> > system, or even in the system of systems above.
> > Even more: having a completely perfect REST design and execution at all
> > components, doesn't mean the app will give the business value and as such
> > be a success. It may also fail.
> >
> > So, to answer the original question, and a couple more I answered without
> > being questioned:
> > 1. Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application? Yes if
> > the client is part of the application. It will not invalidate the
> > RESTFulness of the server, but it may do so for the whole system.
> >
> > 2. Does designing an app server side to be compliant with REST rules
> > delivers the goals of REST. Not necessarily, we need a compliant client and
> > complaint interim layers (yup, REST is a layered architecture).
> >
> > 3. Does having a fully compliant REST architecture implemented is enough
> > to be a success. No, it isn't.
> >
> > Those were the points I wanted to share.
> >
> > Cheers
> >
> > William Martinez.
> >

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18624
Sender:Steve Klabnik <steve@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 22:36:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

>  I feel REST does not constrain the roles of the components in a system,

Some things for you to ponder:

> This chapter introduces and elaborates the Representational State
Transfer (REST) architectural style for distributed hypermedia systems,
describing the software engineering principles guiding REST and the
**interaction constraints** chosen to retain those principles, while
contrasting them to the constraints of other architectural styles.

- http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/rest_arch_style.htm

> An architectural style is a coordinated set of architectural constraints
that restricts the roles/features of architectural elements and the allowed
relationships among those elements within any architecture that conforms to
that style.

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/software_arch.htm#sec_1_5

Post ID:18625
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 06:06:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
Message:

hello julian.

On 2012-03-08 08:59 , Julian Reschke wrote:
> On 2012-03-08 16:21, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>> Unfortunately I'm not aware of any. Haven't seen profile being used in
>> practice so far.
> hcard. dc-html...
> They are even produced by rfc2629.xslt when you format your Internet
> Draft :-)

http://dret.net/netdret/docs/draft-wilde-profile-link-00.html doesn't 
have that, but maybe that's because i produced it at the xml2rfc site 
and not by running the stylesheet myself? but thanks a lot for the 
examples, so we do have at least two existing profile URIs in the wild:

hcard: http://microformats.org/profile/hcard
dublin core: http://dublincore.org/documents/2008/08/04/dc-html/

both resolve to useful documentation, which is nice. i'll add those to 
the examples section in -01.

thanks and cheers,

dret.

Post ID:18627
Sender:"developerbob" <rbinion@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-08 17:19:12
Subject:REST Professional Services
Message:

I am working on a project that is attempting to implement a RESTful service layer (including HATEOAS) for a customer facing web application/portal (followed by other applications and integrations leveraging said service layer). We are looking for some professional consulting to review our approach and provide us some guidance on the architecture and implementation.

I thought I might be worth reaching out to this group to see if anyone could point me in the right direction for qualified -expert- REST consulting.

We are progressing fairly well in our implementation, but unfortunately we are by no means REST (implementation) experts, so we definitely could benefit from the advice of someone/someones who has "been there, and done that".





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18628
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 16:17:02
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Good points!
But then we are talking about REST constrains to achieve REST goals, in an architecture. That is true. But REST does not say you can't build systems any other way, and does not say any other system may not communicate with you. What it says is, you need to talk to me this way to achieve this. If I talk differently, then I put in jeopardy that goal. Maybe the sentence is badly formulated, or read out of context sounds like there is no constrain.

What I mean is you follow REST constrains to get REST goals, if there are things that are not perfect, you loose a little. But with any architectural style, you may need to combine.

It may be a good discussion of whether REST badge may be removed if there is just one non-complaint component in the system. When I think of SOA, I'm perfectly aware that not all components are going to be services, that won't make it less SOA for that. We can make the same analysis with REST. Don't you think?

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Steve Klabnik <steve@...> wrote:
>
> >  I feel REST does not constrain the roles of the components in a system,
> 
> Some things for you to ponder:
> 
> > This chapter introduces and elaborates the Representational State
> Transfer (REST) architectural style for distributed hypermedia systems,
> describing the software engineering principles guiding REST and the
> **interaction constraints** chosen to retain those principles, while
> contrasting them to the constraints of other architectural styles.
> 
> - http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/rest_arch_style.htm
> 
> > An architectural style is a coordinated set of architectural constraints
> that restricts the roles/features of architectural elements and the allowed
> relationships among those elements within any architecture that conforms to
> that style.
> 
> http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/software_arch.htm#sec_1_5
>
