Post ID:18629
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 17:49:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

@William : agree ... as when you slightly denormalize a relational data
base in order to achieve much greater performance: does it stops being
"relational"?

@All: In a client-servar applicaction with a relational DB, if the client
did nasty things would it make the database less relational? No, it's not
affected in its relational-ness.
IMO a client can't make a service less RESTful by being naughty.
--
Juan

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18630
Sender:Steve Klabnik <steve@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 18:01:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

> What I mean is you follow REST constrains to get REST goals, if there are things that are not perfect, you loose a
>  little. But with any architectural style, you may need to combine.


Yes. I often tell people "Just because your RESTful APIs aren't really
RESTful doesn't mean I don't like working with them. It's still WAAAAY
better than SOAP or something random."


> It may be a good discussion of whether REST badge may be removed if there is just one non-complaint component in > the system. When I think of SOA, I'm perfectly aware that not all components are going to be services, that won't make > it less SOA for that. We can make the same analysis with REST. Don't you think?


I _do_ think that if you don't have all of the constraints, you are no
longer RESTful. You might have a great system. It might solve your
problems well. But it's not RESTful. I'd argue that the status of
'code-on-demand' implies that all of the other constraints are
required. Fielding also describes them in a way that implies to me
that they're all required.

> REST consists of a set of architectural constraints chosen for the properties they induce on candidate architectures.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18631
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 18:06:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

hello.

On 2012-03-09 09:49 , Juan Lanus wrote:
> @All: In a client-servar applicaction with a relational DB, if the
> client did nasty things would it make the database less relational? No,
> it's not affected in its relational-ness.
> IMO a client can't make a service less RESTful by being naughty.

i agree with this, but depending on how you as the service provider 
inform and support your clients, they might tend to use the service in a 
better or in a worse way. for example, if you document all the URI 
patterns you are currently exposing, just FYI and with giant note 
advising consumers not not hardcode those patterns, clients will still 
do that, and when they break, they will very loudly complain that your 
change broke them. it didn't, but you will still have to deal with 
broken clients and unhappy customers. so apart from the design and your 
ability to design things well, i think it also is very important to make 
sure that clients understand what you're doing, and use the affordances 
(this one is for you, mike ;-) you provide them, instead of hacking 
around your actual model. i think an excellent way of doing this is to 
always expose a browsable HTML version, even if it is very primitive and 
has no UI design to it at all. ideally, just provide an XSLT and link 
that to your XML API representations, so that browsers supporting 
client-side transforms will allow developers to surf the API and 
understand the way in which it is supposed to be used.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |

Message:

Hmm I don't think the REST 'badge' matters at all. I am trying to
understand the forces/components that influence the system.

------------------------------
From: William Martinez Pomares

of an application?



Good points!
But then we are talking about REST constrains to achieve REST goals, in an
architecture. That is true. But REST does not say you can't build systems
any other way, and does not say any other system may not communicate with
you. What it says is, you need to talk to me this way to achieve this. If I
talk differently, then I put in jeopardy that goal. Maybe the sentence is
badly formulated, or read out of context sounds like there is no constrain.

What I mean is you follow REST constrains to get REST goals, if there are
things that are not perfect, you loose a little. But with any architectural
style, you may need to combine.

It may be a good discussion of whether REST badge may be removed if there
is just one non-complaint component in the system. When I think of SOA, I'm
perfectly aware that not all components are going to be services, that
won't make it less SOA for that. We can make the same analysis with REST.
Don't you think?

William.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18633
Sender:Steve Klabnik <steve@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 18:46:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

> Hmm I don't think the REST 'badge' matters at all.
>

Then why ask if such a system is RESTful? Your question is a more general
systems and architecture question, I guess. Which is 100% valid, but the
form of the question doesn't reflect what you were actually asking, I guess.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18634
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 18:53:57
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Professional Services
Message:

Before everybody responds with "Me, me!", I just threw this table
together with the intent of having all you REST consultants add
yourselves to it;

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/database?method=reportRows&tbl=1

P.S. love the ironic URL 8-)

Mark.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18635
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 19:07:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

I think Glenn meant that an I-am-a-server-and-I-am-officially-RESTful badge
doesn't matter if the overall system that emerges from the exposed
application does not actually conform to the constraints.

On Fri, Mar 9, 2012 at 6:46 PM, Steve Klabnik <steve@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
>
>
>> Hmm I don't think the REST 'badge' matters at all.
>>
>
> Then why ask if such a system is RESTful? Your question is a more general
> systems and architecture question, I guess. Which is 100% valid, but the
> form of the question doesn't reflect what you were actually asking, I guess.
>
>  
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18636
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-09 20:33:59
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Correct!

A component with a REST Badge will not make the whole system to earn its own badge. 

If the discussion is about naming or achieving a badge, then I guess it is very subjective.

If the discussion is about the impact of having those hybrid systems, and how different is the impact depending on which component is the one that is not complaint, then it is clear that we need to analyze case by case. And there is where clarifications like "what is a client?", an internal client, a server in the client role, an external client of a system; and also that app != system != server != API, become important. My views are related to Systems, not apps, services or APIs.

Cheers.

William.
--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>
> I think Glenn meant that an I-am-a-server-and-I-am-officially-RESTful badge
> doesn't matter if the overall system that emerges from the exposed
> application does not actually conform to the constraints.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18637
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 01:06:06
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

My point was that this is not a contest of who can earn the REST badge. The
question I am seeking clarification on is whether or not the RESTfulness of
a system is confined to the server or not / what defines the scope of the
system.

My understanding up until now is that REST really is confined to how the
server is implemented and does not directly include the client However I am
questioning that understanding. The discertation clearly speaks about both
client and server components.

So my only goal is to get more understanding. The result can impact how I
speak/educate about REST and also how I build RESTful systems. For example
as Mike mentioned, you can create opaque uris to prevent the client from
coupling to the uri space.

Sent from my Windows Phone
------------------------------

Sent: 3/9/2012 10:46 AM
To: Glenn Block
Cc: William Martinez Pomares; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the
RESTfulness of an application?

>

Then why ask if such a system is RESTful? Your question is a more general
systems and architecture question, I guess. Which is 100% valid, but the
form of the question doesn't reflect what you were actually asking, I guess.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18638
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 12:58:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

This discussion helped me understand that ...

   - RESTful is the service, not the system, and
   - the client can leverage such restfulness at varying levels (sometimes
   conditioned by circumstances).

The proof , in one gedanken experiment, is that one could implement equal
clients (from the user's standpoint) with totally different backends.
As I'm an IxD guy (but with a many year development background), my vision
might be different.
--
Juan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18639
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 19:34:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Mar 7, 2012, at 7:10 PM, Glenn Block wrote:

>  is the application the server, or is it the combination of client and server?

I try to explain this in slides 9 through 19 of

http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/res-tful-httppatternsantipatterns

You see all the build-transitions in one slide,but I still hope you get the idea. It is, BTW, an aspect of Roy's work and the work he builds upon) I only understood years down the line. Reading those sections of the dissertation *very* carefully is quite rewarding - at least it was for me.

Jan

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18641
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 21:06:20
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:

a. Yes if you define RESTFulness as a badge that certifies you follow the rules. Yes, you can earn that badge only in your server and forget about the client.

b. NO, if you define RESTFulness as the achievement of the expected quality properties you seek for when using REST. And that NO is because the rules are made to achieve a way of interaction between the components, and one of those components is the client. 

In other words, client matters.

As I had been posting here, one component may not behave by the rules, but if that is free license the architect is aware of and it is reasonable so that the impact will not break the business goals, that is fine. But if you need a system where clients behave correctly, and you don't control the clients, then your architecture must have controls and policy enforcement to avoid those spoiled clients from ruining you day. If not, your system will not get to its goal and it will be a failure, even if your server is made by the REST book. 

REST stops when it defines the constrains and promises quality properties, but life goes on, and the rest of the system is still to be constructed. Having just one server following REST rules is just one step. And let me clarify this: It should not be part of the server's job to assure the client is working as it should. It may help, but we can have several layers that can add controls and enforce policies. There is far more in an system than just one server and one client.

Finally: I feel the discussion confuses an App, with a Server, with a System, with a API. When we talk about a server doing its part, sounds like we are talking about an API. Is it that? Yes, we can expose a REST like API, but then we need a client to consume it. A system is something far more complex, where all components, including clients, may affect other components. Butterfly effect, that is called.

Well, this was not a short and sweet answer, and I feel I'm repeating myself here. But it is truly a more deep discussion than just earning a badge.

Cheers

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>
> My point was that this is not a contest of who can earn the REST badge. The
> question I am seeking clarification on is whether or not the RESTfulness of
> a system is confined to the server or not / what defines the scope of the
> system.
> 
> My understanding up until now is that REST really is confined to how the
> server is implemented and does not directly include the client However I am
> questioning that understanding. The discertation clearly speaks about both
> client and server components.
> 
> So my only goal is to get more understanding. The result can impact how I
> speak/educate about REST and also how I build RESTful systems. For example
> as Mike mentioned, you can create opaque uris to prevent the client from
> coupling to the uri space.
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18643
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 21:18:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Mar 10, 2012, at 10:06 PM, Glenn Block wrote:

> 
> Thanks Jan
> 
> If am reading the deck properly you are saying the application includes the client / server components, the client is not separate. Is that correct?

Yes, the *user agent* ('client' is the term for the connector, not the component) is just another component of the application that realizes some use case.

There is conceptually no difference between a monolithic application and a networked application. It is just that in the latter the components reside on different hosts (e.g. your PC and Amazon's server host).

Note how the configuration of the app is different! A monolithic application is configured (assembled) at compile time, a unix commandline is configured when you type it (search for 'invisible hand' in the dissertation) and an HTTP (browser based) application is configured when you type the URI(s) in your browser window(s).

Not browser-based HTTP applications are configured when the user agent component (e.g. the crawler that checks some online shops) is configured with its start URIs.

Jan


> 
> Thanks
> Glenn
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 11:37 AM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
> 
> On Mar 10, 2012, at 8:34 PM, Jan Algermissen wrote:
> 
> >
> > On Mar 7, 2012, at 7:10 PM, Glenn Block wrote:
> >
> > > is the application the server, or is it the combination of client and server?
> >
> > I try to explain this in slides 9 through 19 of
> >
> > http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/res-tful-httppatternsantipatterns
> >
> > You see all the build-transitions in one slide,
> 
> Just remembered that
> 
> http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/understanding-the-role-of-media-types-in-restful-applications actually shows the builds one-slide-by-one.
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18644
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 21:21:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Thanks for the explanation William.

Here's my tough take aways on this convo:

   - A RESTful system has a shared set of responsibilities between client
   and server. To truly realize the benefits of REST both client and server
   have to be good citizens.
   - The server is the critical path. It's responsibility is to expose
   resources in a manner that is consistent with adhering to the constraints.
   That means it sticks to the uniform interface (headers, media types),
   supports caching, uses hypermedia etc.
   - The client must also adhere to REST constraints. If it does not, then
   the overall benefits of REST are not achieved within that system. It's
   responsibility is to consume resources in a RESTful manner, i.e. use the
   uniform interface, consumes hypermedia, obeys caching requirements, etc.
   - A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all
   benefits of REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client.
   - Not enough emphasis is put on this division of responsibilities when
   talking about REST.

Thoughts?

Thanks
Glenn


On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 1:06 PM, William Martinez Pomares <
wmartinez@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:
>
> a. Yes if you define RESTFulness as a badge that certifies you follow the
> rules. Yes, you can earn that badge only in your server and forget about
> the client.
>
> b. NO, if you define RESTFulness as the achievement of the expected
> quality properties you seek for when using REST. And that NO is because the
> rules are made to achieve a way of interaction between the components, and
> one of those components is the client.
>
> In other words, client matters.

> if that is free license the architect is aware of and it is reasonable so

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18646
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 21:24:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Mar 10, 2012, at 10:18 PM, Jan Algermissen wrote:

> 
> On Mar 10, 2012, at 10:06 PM, Glenn Block wrote:
> 
>> 
>> Thanks Jan
>> 
>> If am reading the deck properly you are saying the application includes the client / server components, the client is not separate. Is that correct?
> 
> Yes, the *user agent* ('client' is the term for the connector, not the component) is just another component of the application that realizes some use case.

And also note, that the user agent component 'extends' all the way to the user. It is the component, the user interacts[1] with, not just the HTTP lib with caching and such magic.

[1] Even if that interaction only takes place at use case execution start time and use case result review time. Some use cases involve lots of user action steps (e.g. purchasing a book at Amazon), some don't (e.g. automatically crawling 10 shops and placing an automatic order at lowest price found).


> 
> There is conceptually no difference between a monolithic application and a networked application. It is just that in the latter the components reside on different hosts (e.g. your PC and Amazon's server host).
> 
> Note how the configuration of the app is different! A monolithic application is configured (assembled) at compile time, a unix commandline is configured when you type it (search for 'invisible hand' in the dissertation) and an HTTP (browser based) application is configured when you type the URI(s) in your browser window(s).
> 
> Not browser-based HTTP applications are configured when the user agent component (e.g. the crawler that checks some online shops) is configured with its start URIs.
> 
> Jan
> 
> 
>> 
>> Thanks
>> Glenn
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 11:37 AM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
>> 
>> On Mar 10, 2012, at 8:34 PM, Jan Algermissen wrote:
>> 
>>> 
>>> On Mar 7, 2012, at 7:10 PM, Glenn Block wrote:
>>> 
>>>> is the application the server, or is it the combination of client and server?
>>> 
>>> I try to explain this in slides 9 through 19 of
>>> 
>>> http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/res-tful-httppatternsantipatterns
>>> 
>>> You see all the build-transitions in one slide,
>> 
>> Just remembered that
>> 
>> http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/understanding-the-role-of-media-types-in-restful-applications actually shows the builds one-slide-by-one.

Post ID:18647
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 21:31:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 1:24 PM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...
> wrote:

>
> On Mar 10, 2012, at 10:18 PM, Jan Algermissen wrote:
>
> >
> > On Mar 10, 2012, at 10:06 PM, Glenn Block wrote:
> >
> >>
> >> Thanks Jan
> >>
> >> If am reading the deck properly you are saying the application includes
> the client / server components, the client is not separate. Is that correct?
> >
> > Yes, the *user agent* ('client' is the term for the connector, not the
> component) is just another component of the application that realizes some
> use case.
>
> And also note, that the user agent component 'extends' all the way to the
> user. It is the component, the user interacts[1] with, not just the HTTP
> lib with caching and such magic.
>
> [1] Even if that interaction only takes place at use case execution start
> time and use case result review time. Some use cases involve lots of user
> action steps (e.g. purchasing a book at Amazon), some don't (e.g.
> automatically crawling 10 shops and placing an automatic order at lowest
> price found).
>
> GB: Yes that makes sense. Client is an overloaded term as often when
general developers speak about client they mean the user agent i.e.
Silverlight client, Flash client, web client etc. I was using it in that
sens.


>
> >
> > There is conceptually no difference between a monolithic application and
> a networked application. It is just that in the latter the components
> reside on different hosts (e.g. your PC and Amazon's server host).
> >
> > Note how the configuration of the app is different! A monolithic
> application is configured (assembled) at compile time, a unix commandline
> is configured when you type it (search for 'invisible hand' in the
> dissertation) and an HTTP (browser based) application is configured when
> you type the URI(s) in your browser window(s).
>

GB: Sure, but from an HTTP perspective all I care about is what is going
across the wire / or passing through intermediaries.

> >
> > Not browser-based HTTP applications are configured when the user agent
> component (e.g. the crawler that checks some online shops) is configured
> with its start URIs.
> >
> > Jan
> >
> >
> >>
> >> Thanks
> >> Glenn
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 11:37 AM, Jan Algermissen <
> jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
> >>
> >> On Mar 10, 2012, at 8:34 PM, Jan Algermissen wrote:
> >>
> >>>
> >>> On Mar 7, 2012, at 7:10 PM, Glenn Block wrote:
> >>>
> >>>> is the application the server, or is it the combination of client and
> server?
> >>>
> >>> I try to explain this in slides 9 through 19 of
> >>>
> >>>
> http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/res-tful-httppatternsantipatterns
> >>>
> >>> You see all the build-transitions in one slide,
> >>
> >> Just remembered that
> >>
> >>
> http://www.slideshare.net/algermissen/understanding-the-role-of-media-types-in-restful-applicationsactually shows the builds one-slide-by-one.
> >>
> >> Jan
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >
> >
> >
> > ------------------------------------
> >
> > Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18648
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 21:51:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

"A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits of
REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."

The more i think about this, the more I realize that is probably not
entirely true. The client not being RESTful can remove some benefits but
not all. For example as long as the server implements GET in an
idemponent/safe manner then that means the response can safely be cached.
Nothing the client does can prevent that fact.

However, if the client couples to the uri space rather than following
hypermedia AND it is the only client, or it is one of the predominantly
used clients then it can impact the ability of the server to evolve as if
the server changes the uri scheme, a significant set of users are shut out
until the client is updated.

On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 1:21 PM, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> Thanks for the explanation William.
>
> Here's my tough take aways on this convo:
>
>    - A RESTful system has a shared set of responsibilities between client
>    and server. To truly realize the benefits of REST both client and server
>    have to be good citizens.
>    - The server is the critical path. It's responsibility is to expose
>    resources in a manner that is consistent with adhering to the constraints.
>    That means it sticks to the uniform interface (headers, media types),
>    supports caching, uses hypermedia etc.
>    - The client must also adhere to REST constraints. If it does not,
>    then the overall benefits of REST are not achieved within that system. It's
>    responsibility is to consume resources in a RESTful manner, i.e. use the
>    uniform interface, consumes hypermedia, obeys caching requirements, etc.
>    - A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all
>    benefits of REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client.
>    - Not enough emphasis is put on this division of responsibilities when
>    talking about REST.
>
> Thoughts?
>
> Thanks
> Glenn
>
>
> On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 1:06 PM, William Martinez Pomares <
> wmartinez@...> wrote:
>
>> **
>>
>>
>> Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:
>>
>> a. Yes if you define RESTFulness as a badge that certifies you follow the
>> rules. Yes, you can earn that badge only in your server and forget about
>> the client.
>>
>> b. NO, if you define RESTFulness as the achievement of the expected
>> quality properties you seek for when using REST. And that NO is because the
>> rules are made to achieve a way of interaction between the components, and
>> one of those components is the client.
>>
>> In other words, client matters.
>>
>> As I had been posting here, one component may not behave by the rules,
>> but if that is free license the architect is aware of and it is reasonable
>> so that the impact will not break the business goals, that is fine. But if
>> you need a system where clients behave correctly, and you don't control the
>> clients, then your architecture must have controls and policy enforcement
>> to avoid those spoiled clients from ruining you day. If not, your system
>> will not get to its goal and it will be a failure, even if your server is
>> made by the REST book.
>>
>> REST stops when it defines the constrains and promises quality
>> properties, but life goes on, and the rest of the system is still to be
>> constructed. Having just one server following REST rules is just one step.
>> And let me clarify this: It should not be part of the server's job to
>> assure the client is working as it should. It may help, but we can have
>> several layers that can add controls and enforce policies. There is far
>> more in an system than just one server and one client.
>>
>> Finally: I feel the discussion confuses an App, with a Server, with a
>> System, with a API. When we talk about a server doing its part, sounds like
>> we are talking about an API. Is it that? Yes, we can expose a REST like
>> API, but then we need a client to consume it. A system is something far
>> more complex, where all components, including clients, may affect other
>> components. Butterfly effect, that is called.
>>
>> Well, this was not a short and sweet answer, and I feel I'm repeating
>> myself here. But it is truly a more deep discussion than just earning a
>> badge.
>>
>> Cheers
>>
>> William.
>>
>>
>> --- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>> >
>> > My point was that this is not a contest of who can earn the REST badge.
>> The
>> > question I am seeking clarification on is whether or not the
>> RESTfulness of
>> > a system is confined to the server or not / what defines the scope of
>> the
>> > system.
>> >
>> > My understanding up until now is that REST really is confined to how the
>> > server is implemented and does not directly include the client However
>> I am
>> > questioning that understanding. The discertation clearly speaks about
>> both
>> > client and server components.
>> >
>> > So my only goal is to get more understanding. The result can impact how
>> I
>> > speak/educate about REST and also how I build RESTful systems. For
>> example
>> > as Mike mentioned, you can create opaque uris to prevent the client from
>> > coupling to the uri space.
>> >
>> > Sent from my Windows Phone
>> > ------------------------------
>>
>> > From: Steve Klabnik
>> > Sent: 3/9/2012 10:46 AM
>> > To: Glenn Block
>> > Cc: William Martinez Pomares; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
>> > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the
>> > RESTfulness of an application?
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > > Hmm I don't think the REST 'badge' matters at all.
>> > >
>> >
>> > Then why ask if such a system is RESTful? Your question is a more
>> general
>> > systems and architecture question, I guess. Which is 100% valid, but the
>> > form of the question doesn't reflect what you were actually asking, I
>> guess.
>> >
>>
>>  
>>
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18649
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-10 22:23:51
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Glenn, totally agree with the point, nice summary!
And about the last part, any non-complaint component will affect the goals depending on what is the constrain it is not adhering to, what component that is, how many relationships it has with other components, etc. In other words, there are not absolutes here, everything depends and it is the job of the architect to know how much impact one little change means.

Cheers!

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>
> "A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits of
> REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."
> 
> The more i think about this, the more I realize that is probably not
> entirely true. The client not being RESTful can remove some benefits but
> not all. For example as long as the server implements GET in an
> idemponent/safe manner then that means the response can safely be cached.
> Nothing the client does can prevent that fact.
> 
> However, if the client couples to the uri space rather than following
> hypermedia AND it is the only client, or it is one of the predominantly
> used clients then it can impact the ability of the server to evolve as if
> the server changes the uri scheme, a significant set of users are shut out
> until the client is updated.
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18650
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-11 13:25:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

> "A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits
of
> REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."

I don't get this. For example, if I had a fully RESTful server publishing a
public service consumed by one and only one fully REST-compliant client,
and somebody created another client which is not REST-compliant, then what?
Would the service be deprived of it's badge?
Of course it won't!

IMO this thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
idea which IMO is a wild horse, the RESTful certificate is only for
services (the server) and clients can leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
without affecting the service's quality.

The client can't be RESTful, as it does not communicate with its (human
client) user through HTTP.
--
JL





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18651
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-11 18:19:44
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

I think you are misunderstanding what I am saying. The client does not
remove any badge from the server. It can diminish/significantly impact the
OVERALL benefit though from a REST perspective if the client does not
adhere to the constraints.

Sent from my Windows Phone
------------------------------

I don't get this. For example, if I had a fully RESTful server publishing a
public service consumed by one and only one fully REST-compliant client,
and somebody created another client which is not REST-compliant, then what?
Would the service be deprived of it's badge?
Of course it won't!

idea which IMO is a wild horse, the RESTful certificate is only for
services (the server) and clients can leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
without affecting the service's quality.

The client can't be RESTful, as it does not communicate with its (human
client) user through HTTP.

I don't get this. For example, if I had a fully RESTful server publishing a
public service consumed by one and only one fully REST-compliant client,
and somebody created another client which is not REST-compliant, then what?
Would the service be deprived of it's badge?
Of course it won't!

IMO this thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
idea which IMO is a wild horse, the RESTful certificate is only for
services (the server) and clients can leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
without affecting the service's quality.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18653
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-11 19:07:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Hi Glenn, All,
No, there is not an agreement, not at all. But IMO this interesting thread
is are moving in the direction of one.
It looks to me that it might be something like

   - RESTful are the services, in the server,
   - that RESTfulness is not affected by the lack of it in the client, and
   - calling a client *RESTful *actually means that it leverages to a great
   extent the advantages of the server's RESTfulness.

--
Juan

On Sun, Mar 11, 2012 at 15:21, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> "IMO this thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
> idea which IMO is a wild horse"
>
> Is it? I don't think there is general agreement on that statement as Jan
> and others have pointed out.
>
>
> Sent from my Windows Phone

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18654
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-11 20:47:29
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

I think we are basically on the same page but expressing it with different
words. I agree that a clients lack of adhering to the constraints does not
diminish the server. My point is that the client not playing well does
diminish the overall benefit. For example it might mean the client is
broken when the server evolves.

Sent from my Windows Phone
------------------------------
From: Juan Lanus
Sent: 3/11/2012 12:08 PM
To: Glenn Block
Cc: William Martinez Pomares; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the
RESTfulness of an application?

Hi Glenn, All,
No, there is not an agreement, not at all. But IMO this interesting thread
is are moving in the direction of one.
It looks to me that it might be something like

   - RESTful are the services, in the server,
   - that RESTfulness is not affected by the lack of it in the client, and
   - calling a client *RESTful *actually means that it leverages to a great
   extent the advantages of the server's RESTfulness.

--
Juan

On Sun, Mar 11, 2012 at 15:21, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> idea which IMO is a wild horse"

> and others have pointed out.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18655
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-11 21:30:35
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Sorry Juan, but the very last sentence you said, IMHO, is not that correct.

One thing is the REST badge = Complaint of all constrains.
Another one is the quality of the system/service. If you have components that do not play by the rules, you loose what the rules were intended for, and thus the quality of service suffers. If the service is good or bad, well used or not, that impacts the system somehow. So, a misbehaving client should be taken seriously into account, even if it doesn't take your badge away. 

To me, the REST certificate is useless beyond marketing and selling points. It will not give much if the architecture is not controlled and governed as it should.

Finally, and to be fair that is my line of thinking "out of the bun", I have a presentation of a talk I gave at the SOA and Cloud Symposium, Brazil, where I explained why a RESTful service may come with a little of impedance mismatch, and as such is not suitable for many business cases. In that sense, the service may have its implementation in perfect REST, with a perfect client, and still the quality may be poor.

Maybe the main point here is not the badge thing, but agreeing that there are concerns that are deeper and far more important that the actual badge itself. What do you think?

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...> wrote:
>
> > "A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits
> of
> > REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."
> 
> I don't get this. For example, if I had a fully RESTful server publishing a
> public service consumed by one and only one fully REST-compliant client,
> and somebody created another client which is not REST-compliant, then what?
> Would the service be deprived of it's badge?
> Of course it won't!
> 
> IMO this thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
> idea which IMO is a wild horse, the RESTful certificate is only for
> services (the server) and clients can leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
> without affecting the service's quality.
> 
> The client can't be RESTful, as it does not communicate with its (human
> client) user through HTTP.
> --
> JL
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18656
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-11 21:37:48
Subject:Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Juan, Glenn.
I think you are actually in two different pages.
Juan is talking about the REST certificate, and the actual quality of the service from the server point of view. 
Glenn is talking, as Juan correctly notes, about the quality of the system. 
Both may be right. 
The only thing I disagree is with Juan's notion of service quality. To me, for the service to be great, it has to assure the correct use and handle bad use, as clients are on the wild out there. Working great only with nice behaving clients and blaming bad clients does not mean good quality for me. But that said, it is my POV.

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>
> I think we are basically on the same page but expressing it with different
> words. I agree that a clients lack of adhering to the constraints does not
> diminish the server. My point is that the client not playing well does
> diminish the overall benefit. For example it might mean the client is
> broken when the server evolves.
> 
> Sent from my Windows Phone
> ------------------------------
> From: Juan Lanus
> Sent: 3/11/2012 12:08 PM
> To: Glenn Block
> Cc: William Martinez Pomares; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the
> RESTfulness of an application?
> 
> Hi Glenn, All,
> No, there is not an agreement, not at all. But IMO this interesting thread
> is are moving in the direction of one.
> It looks to me that it might be something like
> 
>    - RESTful are the services, in the server,
>    - that RESTfulness is not affected by the lack of it in the client, and
>    - calling a client *RESTful *actually means that it leverages to a great
>    extent the advantages of the server's RESTfulness.
> 
> --
> Juan
> 
> On Sun, Mar 11, 2012 at 15:21, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
> 
> > "IMO this thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
> > idea which IMO is a wild horse"
> >
> > Is it? I don't think there is general agreement on that statement as Jan
> > and others have pointed out.
> >
> >
> > Sent from my Windows Phone
> > ------------------------------
> > From: Juan Lanus
> > Sent: 3/11/2012 6:26 AM
> > To: William Martinez Pomares
> > Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the
> > RESTfulness of an application?
> >
> >
> >
> > > "A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits
> > of
> > > REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."
> >
> > I don't get this. For example, if I had a fully RESTful server publishing
> > a public service consumed by one and only one fully REST-compliant client,
> > and somebody created another client which is not REST-compliant, then what?
> >  Would the service be deprived of it's badge?
> > Of course it won't!
> >
> > IMO this thread is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
> > idea which IMO is a wild horse, the RESTful certificate is only for
> > services (the server) and clients can leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
> > without affecting the service's quality.
> >
> > The client can't be RESTful, as it does not communicate with its (human
> > client) user through HTTP.
> > --
> > JL
> >
> >  
> >
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18657
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-12 01:11:08
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

 I'd argue that if a client doesn't follow the usage that is provided by a service, then they ought to be aware of the cost of doing so in the future. It has no impact whatsoever on the quality of the system per se if clients chose to bypass the contract defined in a media type.

In B2B we'd make compliance part of the SLA.
________________________________
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] on behalf of Mike Kelly [mikekelly321@...]
Sent: 08 March 2012 12:41
To: REST-Discuss Discussion Group
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?





On Wed, Mar 7, 2012 at 10:37 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...<mailto:mamund@...>> wrote:


Glenn:


> What about the counter view that each client and server combo is the 'application'

first, i'm not sure that is a "counter view" of what i said. IOW, how
does this run "counter" to my POV?

second, the term "application" can be applied lots of ways.
- a single component running on a singe machine,
- a group of components running on a single machine
- a group of machines running components
- etc.

finally, what is the "end game" here? IOW, why pursue this line of
convo? what positive things can result?



Ok so let's move away from 'application' and talk about a 'system'..  client behaviour has a direct impact on the nature of interactions in your system and therefore the extents to which it can evolve. So if your clients consume your service in a way "that hardcodes URIs and workflow and ignores the affordance details I supply from the service", this will absolutely have an impact on the "REST-itude" of your system since it is an emergence of interaction in your system which directly violates the hypertext constraint.

As a service provider, you can govern your clients through deliberate designs that constrain their behaviour and that will help ensure they 'do the right thing' - if you don't manage to do this and your clients do the wrong thing then I think that does diminish the quality of your effort.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18658
Sender:Juan Lanus <juan.lanus@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-12 11:28:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
Message:

Seems we are all starting to agree.

As of my POV on the client, two points:

   - it doesn't inpact the RESTfulness of the service, and
   - bad clients make bad systems (the aggregate) despite the quality og
   the server: the chain is as strong as its eweakest link.

In fact, I'm a client guy. I understand that a RESTful backend is the best
way known to decouple front-end development from back-end development.
REST sets a set of clear and crisp rules on how to build the services
disregarding the specifics of the client's design.
This is a VERY GOOD thing. Decoupling is good because it slashes system
complexity at the exponent level.
This allows a team to design a really usable UI (this is my area of
knowledge) using for example HTML5 and jQuery (any other technology would
do) and let the client tell its services needs.
The client designer must be aware of the REST way of doing things, as it
came out from this thread. The good news is that REST is easy to teach and
understand.
--
Juan Lanus





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18659
Sender:"nikonguy74" <choclabs74@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-19 17:40:47
Subject:Rel attributes?
Message:

I'm currently embarking on a question to fully understand REST so i can move my company towards architectural independence :). Once we design the back end (service) we will be able to just any device we want to communicate with our systems (IPAD,IPhone,Android,WPF,ect...)

I'm currently reading "REST In Practice" by Oreilly. I'm sure a lot in this group have read the book. I just finished chapter 5 "Hypermedia Services" which is arguably one of the most important and most difficult concepts to understand with REST. I found myself getting lost while reading the chapter but i kept reading hoping by the time i got to the end everything would make sense. Well everything doesn't. Some concepts are still really really fuzzy. I'm going to reread the chapter and post questions as i start to get confused (there probably will be quite a few).

I know one of the first questions i had was on rel link. I understand the basic premise behind rel attributes(to provide a general documentation for how to interact with the link provider). The question is what would you see if you go to the rel link? Is it something a person is suppose to interact with (say to get documentation for new links added to a specific response) or something code can interact with to determine what it needs to do? Unfortunately in the book they don't give an example of what a "rel" page would look like. For example the link:
<link rel="http://relations.restbucks.com/payment"
      href:="http://restbucks.com/payment/1234" />

If you typed in "http://relations.restbucks.com/payment" into your web browser what would you see? 

thanks...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18660
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-19 19:58:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rel attributes?
Message:

On Mar 19, 2012, at 6:40 PM, nikonguy74 wrote:
> 
> I know one of the first questions i had was on rel link. I understand the basic premise behind rel attributes(to provide a general documentation for how to interact with the link provider).

The premise of the rel attribute on links is (in the case of the HTML or Atom media types) to provide information about the meaning of the link beyond 'this is a link'. If you register your rel name in the IANA registry, you can use the short name you registered, e.g. 'next' or 'up'. If you did not register your rel, you need to provide a URI. Simply for the matter of making your rel unambiguous.

If that URI points to a human readable page explaining the relation, then that is even better.

There is no magic (not even in REST :-) that removes the need to implement in code (or configure) what the user agent should do when it sees your link rel value.

<link rel="http://foo/customerDetails" ... /> is conceptually the same as <link rel="working-copy" .../> and also as HTML's <img src="..."/> or AtomPub's <collection href="..."/>. It is just hypermedia ... that a user agent needs to be programmed to do something with ... in order to have it do something with it.

IOW, your browser downloads that image because it is programmed to do so. This same concept also applies to other hypermedia - your user agent component will act on the hypermedia it comes across in the way it is programmed (or configured) to do.

No magic.

The effect of the hypermedia constraint is actually more felt in the obligations you have as a client side programmer (to react to the hypermedia you actually come across instead of the one you presume to come across) than it is felt in the aspect of loose coupling.

REST mostly makes explicit that there isn't any control over the server side in networked systems. REST encourages you to deal with that rather than magically solves a problem that cannot be solved. And on top of that, REST provides a number of mechanism that optimize for *dealing with* the problem (e.g. content negotiation).

HTH,

Jan

> The question is what would you see if you go to the rel link? Is it something a person is suppose to interact with (say to get documentation for new links added to a specific response) or something code can interact with to determine what it needs to do? Unfortunately in the book they don't give an example of what a "rel" page would look like. For example the link:
> <link rel="http://relations.restbucks.com/payment"
> href:="http://restbucks.com/payment/1234" />
> 
> If you typed in "http://relations.restbucks.com/payment" into your web browser what would you see? 
> 
> thanks...
> 
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18661
Sender:Philippe Mougin <pmougin@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-20 02:03:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rel attributes?
Message:

Le 19 mars 2012 à 18:40, nikonguy74 a écrit :

> I know one of the first questions i had was on rel link. I understand the basic premise behind rel attributes(to provide a general documentation for how to interact with the link provider). The question is what would you see if you go to the rel link? Is it something a person is suppose to interact with (say to get documentation for new links added to a specific response) or something code can interact with to determine what it needs to do? Unfortunately in the book they don't give an example of what a "rel" page would look like. For example the link:
> <link rel="http://relations.restbucks.com/payment"
> href:="http://restbucks.com/payment/1234" />
> 
> If you typed in "http://relations.restbucks.com/payment" into your web browser what would you see? 
> 
Typically, an HTTP 404 error message. 
The values of such rel attributes do not need to be dereferencable. They are used as mere names for identifying the nature of the link. 
For added fun, you can optionally make them dereferencable, providing for instance a human readable documentation about the semantic of that particular type of link, or whatever suits you, but this isn't required.  

Best,

Philippe Mougin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18662
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-20 05:30:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rel attributes?
Message:

Actually, dereferencing the URL rel-values is discuraged (in order to avoid overburdening the server). See chapter 4.2 in http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988 (Web Linking): 

4.2.  Extension Relation Types

   Applications that don't wish to register a relation type can use an
   extension relation type, which is a URI [RFC3986] that uniquely
   identifies the relation type.  Although the URI can point to a
   resource that contains a definition of the semantics of the relation
   type, clients SHOULD NOT automatically access that resource to avoid
   overburdening its server.
/Jørn

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: nikonguy74 
  To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, March 19, 2012 6:40 PM
  Subject: [rest-discuss] Rel attributes?


    
  I'm currently embarking on a question to fully understand REST so i can move my company towards architectural independence :). Once we design the back end (service) we will be able to just any device we want to communicate with our systems (IPAD,IPhone,Android,WPF,ect...)

  I'm currently reading "REST In Practice" by Oreilly. I'm sure a lot in this group have read the book. I just finished chapter 5 "Hypermedia Services" which is arguably one of the most important and most difficult concepts to understand with REST. I found myself getting lost while reading the chapter but i kept reading hoping by the time i got to the end everything would make sense. Well everything doesn't. Some concepts are still really really fuzzy. I'm going to reread the chapter and post questions as i start to get confused (there probably will be quite a few).

  I know one of the first questions i had was on rel link. I understand the basic premise behind rel attributes(to provide a general documentation for how to interact with the link provider). The question is what would you see if you go to the rel link? Is it something a person is suppose to interact with (say to get documentation for new links added to a specific response) or something code can interact with to determine what it needs to do? Unfortunately in the book they don't give an example of what a "rel" page would look like. For example the link:
  <link rel="http://relations.restbucks.com/payment"
  href:="http://restbucks.com/payment/1234" />

  If you typed in "http://relations.restbucks.com/payment" into your web browser what would you see? 

  thanks...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18663
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-20 06:37:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rel attributes?
Message:

On 2012-03-20 16:30 , JÃ¸rn Wildt wrote:
> Actually, dereferencing the URL rel-values is discouraged (in order to
> avoid overburdening the server). See chapter 4.2 in
> http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988 (Web Linking):
>     Applications that don't wish to register a relation type can use an
>     extension relation type, which is a URI [RFC3986] that uniquely
>     identifies the relation type.  Although the URI can point to a
>     resource that contains a definition of the semantics of the relation
>     type,*clients SHOULD NOT automatically access*  that resource to avoid
>     overburdening its server.

just to make that crystal clear: *automatically dereferencing them* 
every time you encounter such a URI is discouraged, and it would be a 
pretty bad idea because they are primarily identifiers, not references. 
but *making them dereferencerable* and providing useful information 
(links to spec, examples, code, products, contact info) is actually a 
good idea. and if you set caching parameters right on that info, then 
even bad implementations should mainly create load for intermediaries, 
and not necessarily for the origin server.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |

> just to make that crystal clear: *automatically dereferencing them* 
> every time you encounter such a URI is discouraged

Good point. Thanks.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18665
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-20 17:17:56
Subject:Re: Rel attributes?
Message:

Hi nikonguy74!
Just to complement what Jan is saying:
1. Links represent resources you can work with. The idea of links is that you can usually follow them (issuing a GET operation), but then there are lots of questions you may have about them: what do I do with the actual resource (say, web page) I'm in? What is this link referring to? What other operations apart from GET can I execute with it? Can I add query parameters to it? What media type will it return? What media type may it expect if I can issue a POST?, etc...

2. rel is an attribute to add more information about a link. I denotes a value, keyword, hint of what relation the link has with the current resource/IRI. Say you are in a book page, that is your current resources and it has a URI. A link with rel="next" will hint that following that link will get you to the next page of the book. 

3. It is important to understand that the rel is the relation the resource identified by the link's URI, has with the actual resource/uri/document. It is not good if you use rel to denote other information, like saying rel="CreateWithPost" to hint the agent to use the link's URI with a POST to create something. That is not the intended use and it is a bad practice.

4. You may need actual business intelligence in your client. If you are looking at a blog comment, a rel="parent" will tell you the links points to the actual blog post. Having that information, you can start asking that parent for information, or even send a comment to it using POST operation. That is natural simply because much of this interaction is already designed in the specs, and the agent may not need to be statically programmed, but it will need intelligence.

5. So, you have there standard metainformation (like how to handle media types, the semantics of POST and PUT, the semantics or link and rel), etc. Plus, you have business specific semantics (the actual value of the rel may mean something applicable only to, say, banking applications). With that info you can program intelligent clients.

6. Finally, some other "link" tags like anchor and image are special links that have a standard meaning and established processing. If you found an <img> tag you automatically know that link is referring to an image, and if you are in HTML page in a browser, the supposed processing it to fetch that image with a GET and display it based on context and additional attributes. All that is told by the tag name, and everybody in the world knows it.  So, links are difficult to understand at first but once you have it clear they are simple to use. Only don't expect the link rel attribute will tell you everything.

Cheers

William Martinez.
--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...> wrote:

Post ID:18666
Sender:Alessandro Nadalin <alessandro.nadalin@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 12:43:31
Subject:Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
Message:

Hi folks,

might be wrong on this, that's why I ask it here.

Today I took a look at HTML5 cache for offline browsing and
prefetching resources:
http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/appcache/beginner/

What's your opinion about that? Am I assuming correctly - if you use
the manifest you drop support for the original HTTP cache spec[1]?

"Once an application is offline it remains cached until one of the
following happens:

1. The user clears their browser's data storage for your site.
2. The manifest file is modified. Note: updating a file listed in the
manifest doesn't mean the browser will re-cache that resource. The
manifest file itself must be alternated."

Given this, I don't see the point of HTML5 cache.
Please open my eyes :)

[1] http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec13.html

-- 
Nadalin Alessandro
www.odino.org
www.twitter.com/_odino_





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18667
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 13:05:46
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
Message:

Hi Alessandro,

> Today I took a look at HTML5 cache for offline browsing and
>
> [..]
>
> What's your opinion about that? Am I assuming correctly - if you use
> the manifest you drop support for the original HTTP cache spec[1]?

You don't drop support but you basically override it. That's completely fine
for a client to do. If you download a file you also "cache" it forever on
your hard disk.


> "Once an application is offline it remains cached until one of the
> following happens:
> 
> 1. The user clears their browser's data storage for your site.
> 2. The manifest file is modified. Note: updating a file listed in the
> manifest doesn't mean the browser will re-cache that resource. The
> manifest file itself must be alternated."
> 
> Given this, I don't see the point of HTML5 cache.
> Please open my eyes :)

You can run the application offline :-) That (and the increased performance)
is the whole point of it. If you want to update certain parts of your
application you normally change that resources IRI which forces the client
to download it. This is similar to nowadays best practice of caching, e.g.,
your CSS files for a very long time. If you need to change them, you would
have to change their IRI and reference the new ones from your website.


Hope this helps,
Markus


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18668
Sender:Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:00:01
Subject:Alternate media types for different methods?
Message:

We're coming up with a relatively common problem in our API where we
define a media type then need to make different parts of it optional
for GET (remove references that are not valid to allow HATEOAS) and
POST (leave out parts of the media type that are filled in by the
server when creating a new resource).

Rather than defining all of the attributes as optional (which often
makes most of the media type optional) and requiring clients and
servers to check for the existence of many attributes, it seems better
to instead define vnd.mycorp.myapp.Widget (used for GET and PUT) and
vnd.mycorp.myapp.NewWidget (used for POST) as separate media types
which make different parts of the representation optional.

This seems like the most RESTful/HTTP friendly way to solve the
problem, does anyone see any problems with it (other than it creating
lots of similar media types)?

Cheers,

Jim





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18669
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:24:34
Subject:Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

A part of my current project is management of simple key/value properties (string/string) for (more or less) any resource in the system.

My use-cases/scenarios are:

1) Some resource in the system contains a link with the rel-type "additional-properties". This link points to the list of additional properties for that resource (at the URL "{additional-properties}").

2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value properties for reading.

3) For each key/value in the list there will be links for a) editing the value of the key, and 2) deleting the key.

3a) Editing is as simple as PUTing a new value to the URL.

3b) Deleting a key is as simple as a HTTP DELETE of the URL.

4) The list also contains a link for adding new properties.

What would be a suitable (simple) media-type for this?

I am considering ATOM (which is nice for lists), but that seems like quite a bit of overkill. HTML might also be useful (but does not support PUT, but POST would be okay too). A home-grown application/vnd.abc+xml is also a possibility.

What would you guys do?

Thanks, Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18670
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:26:50
Subject:Re: Alternate media types for different methods?
Message:

Does your input need to be a vendor media-type? How about sending application/x-www-form-urlencoded, multipart/form-data, JSON or plain XML? What would you loose/gain from that?

/Jørn

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Jim Purbrick <jimpurbrick@...> wrote:

> define a media type then need to make different parts of it optional
> for GET (remove references that are not valid to allow HATEOAS) and
> POST (leave out parts of the media type that are filled in by the
> server when creating a new resource).
> 
> Rather than defining all of the attributes as optional (which often
> makes most of the media type optional) and requiring clients and
> servers to check for the existence of many attributes, it seems better
> to instead define vnd.mycorp.myapp.Widget (used for GET and PUT) and
> vnd.mycorp.myapp.NewWidget (used for POST) as separate media types
> which make different parts of the representation optional.
> 
> This seems like the most RESTful/HTTP friendly way to solve the
> problem, does anyone see any problems with it (other than it creating
> lots of similar media types)?
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Jim
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18671
Sender:"Robert Brewer" <fumanchu@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:50:59
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

Jorn Wildt wrote:
> A part of my current project is management of simple key/value
> properties (string/string) for (more or less) any resource in the
> system.
> 
> My use-cases/scenarios are:
> 
> 1) Some resource in the system contains a link with the rel-type
> "additional-properties". This link points to the list of additional
> properties for that resource (at the URL "{additional-properties}").
> 
> 2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value
> properties for reading.
> 
> 3) For each key/value in the list there will be links for a) editing
> the value of the key, and 2) deleting the key.
> 
> 3a) Editing is as simple as PUTing a new value to the URL.
> 
> 3b) Deleting a key is as simple as a HTTP DELETE of the URL.
> 
> 4) The list also contains a link for adding new properties.
> 
> What would be a suitable (simple) media-type for this?
> 
> I am considering ATOM (which is nice for lists), but that seems like
> quite a bit of overkill. HTML might also be useful (but does not
> support PUT, but POST would be okay too). A home-grown
> application/vnd.abc+xml is also a possibility.

Atom is for feeds, and HTML is for layout markup. You need something
designed for transactional entities. Shoji [1] is a JSON-based protocol
and media type designed for that, and it includes entity collections
("catalogs") as a bonus. Every Shoji Entity automatically includes the
concept of using PUT to edit each attribute at its own URL (the server
is free to return 405 for attributes where that method is not allowed).
DELETE is specified for Entities, not Values as you describe above, but
there's nothing stopping you from using DELETE that way.

Shoji even covers the concept of "additional properties" for you;
they're called "fragments" in Shoji.


Robert Brewer
fumanchu@...

[1] http://www.aminus.org/rbre/shoji/shoji-draft-02.txt





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18672
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:51:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
Message:

On Wed, Mar 21, 2012 at 1:05 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...>wrote:

> **
>
>
> > "Once an application is offline it remains cached until one of the
> > following happens:
> >
> > 1. The user clears their browser's data storage for your site.
> > 2. The manifest file is modified. Note: updating a file listed in the
> > manifest doesn't mean the browser will re-cache that resource. The
> > manifest file itself must be alternated."
> >
> > Given this, I don't see the point of HTML5 cache.
> > Please open my eyes :)
>
> You can run the application offline :-) That (and the increased
> performance)
> is the whole point of it. If you want to update certain parts of your
> application you normally change that resources IRI which forces the client
> to download it. This is similar to nowadays best practice of caching, e.g.,
> your CSS files for a very long time. If you need to change them, you would
> have to change their IRI and reference the new ones from your website.
>

Ok, but this doesn't address why they need to invent an entirely separate
cache-control mechanism, instead of reusing and extending what we already
have around HTTP.

The stale-if-error directive introduced by the Cache-Control Extensions for
Stale Content[1] already gives us most of what they are trying to achieve.

[1] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5861





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18673
Sender:Alessandro Nadalin <alessandro.nadalin@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:51:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
Message:

On Wed, Mar 21, 2012 at 2:05 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> Hi Alessandro,
>
>> Today I took a look at HTML5 cache for offline browsing and
>>
>> [..]
>>
>> Given this, I don't see the point of HTML5 cache.
>> Please open my eyes :)
>
> You can run the application offline :-) That (and the increased performance)
> is the whole point of it. If you want to update certain parts of your
> application you normally change that resources IRI which forces the client
> to download it. This is similar to nowadays best practice of caching, e.g.,
> your CSS files for a very long time. If you need to change them, you would
> have to change their IRI and reference the new ones from your website.

Hi Markus,

but that's, basically, already doable with the existing caching spec,
right? It's just a browser limitation that doesn't allow you to surf a
resource which could be cached (let's say Cache-Control: public,
max-age=84600), right?

I only see a basic advantage on using it for static content (assets,
CSSes and so on), using the version in the querystring, as you
mentioned.

Nadalin Alessandro
www.odino.org
www.twitter.com/_odino_

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18675
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 14:56:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

a while back, i did an implementation of an idea that Roy posted to a
list regarding managing properties of a resource. w/o his assent, i
named this pattern "Fielding Property Maps"[1]

it's another possibility you might consider as it does not require a
dedicated media type design to implement it cleanly. in fact, it could
work in almost any media type design.

this might be exactly what you need, but maybe it gives you some ideas.


[1] http://www.amundsen.com/examples/fielding-props/

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Wed, Mar 21, 2012 at 10:24, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:
> A part of my current project is management of simple key/value properties (string/string) for (more or less) any resource in the system.
>
> My use-cases/scenarios are:
>
> 1) Some resource in the system contains a link with the rel-type "additional-properties". This link points to the list of additional properties for that resource (at the URL "{additional-properties}").
>
> 2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value properties for reading.
>
> 3) For each key/value in the list there will be links for a) editing the value of the key, and 2) deleting the key.
>
> 3a) Editing is as simple as PUTing a new value to the URL.
>
> 3b) Deleting a key is as simple as a HTTP DELETE of the URL.
>
> 4) The list also contains a link for adding new properties.
>
> What would be a suitable (simple) media-type for this?
>
> I am considering ATOM (which is nice for lists), but that seems like quite a bit of overkill. HTML might also be useful (but does not support PUT, but POST would be okay too). A home-grown application/vnd.abc+xml is also a possibility.
>
> What would you guys do?
>
> Thanks, Jørn
>
>
>
> ------------------------------------
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18676
Sender:"Robert Brewer" <fumanchu@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 15:03:50
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Alternate media types for different methods?
Message:

Jim Purbrick wrote:
> We're coming up with a relatively common problem in our API where we
> define a media type then need to make different parts of it optional
> for GET (remove references that are not valid to allow HATEOAS) and
> POST (leave out parts of the media type that are filled in by the
> server when creating a new resource).
> 
> Rather than defining all of the attributes as optional (which often
> makes most of the media type optional) and requiring clients and
> servers to check for the existence of many attributes, it seems better
> to instead define vnd.mycorp.myapp.Widget (used for GET and PUT) and
> vnd.mycorp.myapp.NewWidget (used for POST) as separate media types
> which make different parts of the representation optional.
> 
> This seems like the most RESTful/HTTP friendly way to solve the
> problem, does anyone see any problems with it (other than it creating
> lots of similar media types)?

I've found that simply partitioning off a section of the resource works
very well for this. In one of our JSON-based media types, the entity
looks something like:

{"self": "http://somewhere.example/things/123/",
 "parent": "/things/18/",
 "user": "/users/jimpurbrick/",
 "body": {
    "status": "active",
    "foo": "bar"
 }
} 

It's part of the API that everything in the "body" member is mutable on
update, while "parent", and "user" are only mutable on insert (and
"self" isn't mutable at all at that URI). The client can still send
"parent" and "user" members, and probably should if they're using PUT
instead of PATCH, but the server will replace those supplied values with
the existing ones to make the resource consistent with its internal
constraints.


Robert Brewer
fumanchu@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18677
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 15:19:18
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
Message:

>> Ok, but this doesn't address why they need to invent an
>> entirely separate cache-control mechanism, instead of 
>> reusing and extending what we already have around HTTP.
>>
>> The stale-if-error directive introduced by the Cache-Control
>> Extensions for Stale Content[1] already gives us most of
>> what they are trying to achieve.
>
> *Boom*, that's exactly my point.

It's different I would say. The app cache is really for applications. You
include all your app assets and code and then "install" it. It doesn't make
that much sense to have parts with different lifetimes in such a scenario
and the manifest is more or less just a way to create a package. It also
gives you APIs to check the state of your cache and so on..

How else would you achieve that in a browser? Since the browser doesn't know
what belongs together it would probably delete a huge JS file at some point
while still keeping the other stuff. This would break your app. So perhaps
think of it more in terms of an app than in terms of caching.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18678
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 15:37:55
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
Message:

Those are orthogonal concern. The manifest defines which of the assets ought to be made available offline, aka persisted in the cache for a duration that is not tied to the duration of the max-age but of the installed app. *That said*, the behavior in deciding to do a conditional request or not based on existing caching validation function would make a lot of sense.

More so, it makes a lot of sense for an app that can be used both offline and online to have the caching semantics sematics of resources being present and respected, for until a user "installs" the app, the app will react like any HTTP application.

For me, appCache can (and probably ought to) simply extend and override the semantics of caching controls to ensure that whatever caching sematics, the cached (and maybe stale) resource state  is available for however long the application is installed.

 
________________________________________
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] on behalf of Markus Lanthaler [markus.lanthaler@...]
Sent: 21 March 2012 15:19

Cc: 'REST-Discuss'
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
