>> entirely separate cache-control mechanism, instead of
>> reusing and extending what we already have around HTTP.
>>
>> The stale-if-error directive introduced by the Cache-Control
>> Extensions for Stale Content[1] already gives us most of
>> what they are trying to achieve.
>
> *Boom*, that's exactly my point.

It's different I would say. The app cache is really for applications. You
include all your app assets and code and then "install" it. It doesn't make
that much sense to have parts with different lifetimes in such a scenario
and the manifest is more or less just a way to create a package. It also
gives you APIs to check the state of your cache and so on..

How else would you achieve that in a browser? Since the browser doesn't know
what belongs together it would probably delete a huge JS file at some point
while still keeping the other stuff. This would break your app. So perhaps
think of it more in terms of an app than in terms of caching.

Isn't that how it is supposed to work as currently specified? As long as I
don't install/download the application, all the HTTP caching mechanisms will
continue to work as usual.

>>> Extensions for Stale Content[1] already gives us most of
>>> what they are trying to achieve.
>>
>> *Boom*, that's exactly my point.
>
> It's different I would say. The app cache is really for applications. You
> include all your app assets and code and then "install" it. It doesn't make
> that much sense to have parts with different lifetimes in such a scenario

> gives you APIs to check the state of your cache and so on..

> while still keeping the other stuff. This would break your app.

Yes, we need some way for servers and clients to negotiate storage
allocation for caching. My point was that the solution should be
designed so that it reuses stuff we already have, like stale-if-error.

Besides that, application/x-www-form-urlencoded is the way to go if you want a key/value format

Jan

For a general-purpose key-value payload, I'd use application/json.
On Mar 21, 2012 4:24 AM, "Jorn Wildt" <jw@...> wrote:

> A part of my current project is management of simple key/value properties
> (string/string) for (more or less) any resource in the system.
>
> My use-cases/scenarios are:
>
> 1) Some resource in the system contains a link with the rel-type
> "additional-properties". This link points to the list of additional
> properties for that resource (at the URL "{additional-properties}").
>
> 2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value
> properties for reading.
>
> 3) For each key/value in the list there will be links for a) editing the
> value of the key, and 2) deleting the key.
>
> 3a) Editing is as simple as PUTing a new value to the URL.
>
> 3b) Deleting a key is as simple as a HTTP DELETE of the URL.
>
> 4) The list also contains a link for adding new properties.
>
> What would be a suitable (simple) media-type for this?
>
> I am considering ATOM (which is nice for lists), but that seems like quite
> a bit of overkill. HTML might also be useful (but does not support PUT, but

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18685
Sender:Ben Niven-Jenkins <ben@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-21 22:51:45
Subject:Question on explicit link relations in REST
Message:

Folks,

I've defined a read only API where links to other resources follow an Atom like model and include the media-type & relation as well as the URI, so they look something like this in JSON:

links: [ { href: "/foo", type: "fooType", rel: "self" },
         { href: "/bar", type: "barType", rel: "http://example.com/customeRel" ]

In a conversation with someone who is not entirely into the whole REST thing they commented

"including the type & relation in the link is extra complexity, if we did it in XML we could just figure that out implicitly from the schema when we GET the linked resource"

Leaving aside XML Vs JSON arguments (which aren't relevant to my question) I justified it with an argument that explicitly including the relation meant you didn't need to GET the resource to know what the relationship was (as the same type could have different relations to different resources, e.g. parent vs child relations) and including the type meant the client could know what it was going to GET without actually getting it - e.g. "I don't need to know about barTypes right now so I won't bother getting them until I need to know about them"

But afterwards I thought to myself while my arguments above seem reasonable there must be other good reasons (that I can't immediately think of) for being explicit with types & relations in links in RESTful APIs.

Can you help me with your thoughts on what those other good reasons are?

Thanks
Ben





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18686
Sender:mike amundsen <mamund@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-22 02:03:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Question on explicit link relations in REST
Message:

Ben:

FWIW, I use {href:"...", rel:"..."} sufficient decoration for most all
cases (i.e. no "type" decoration). my clients are "coded to the rel"
and that's all.

Also, I am usually wary of people who say things like "we could just
figure that out implicitly" as this often introducing "coupling based
on assumption" that can limit future mods/enhancements down the line.

Finally, I don't use a "type" decoration since this leads my client
apps into expecting strongly-typed "objects" in the response
representation. I try to avoid this expectation. What clients get back
is a representation in the agree media type. Clients are then able to
process the representation using the media type rules and compute,
render, and when appropriate, activate the hypermedia in the response.
The "type" is not needed for those steps.

In your case, what is it that the "type" value is used for by the client apps?

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Wed, Mar 21, 2012 at 18:51, Ben Niven-Jenkins
<ben@niven-jenkins.co.uk> wrote:
> Folks,
>
> I've defined a read only API where links to other resources follow an Atom like model and include the media-type & relation as well as the URI, so they look something like this in JSON:
>
> links: [ { href: "/foo", type: "fooType", rel: "self" },
>         { href: "/bar", type: "barType", rel: "http://example.com/customeRel" ]
>
> In a conversation with someone who is not entirely into the whole REST thing they commented
>
> "including the type & relation in the link is extra complexity, if we did it in XML we could just figure that out implicitly from the schema when we GET the linked resource"
>
> Leaving aside XML Vs JSON arguments (which aren't relevant to my question) I justified it with an argument that explicitly including the relation meant you didn't need to GET the resource to know what the relationship was (as the same type could have different relations to different resources, e.g. parent vs child relations) and including the type meant the client could know what it was going to GET without actually getting it - e.g. "I don't need to know about barTypes right now so I won't bother getting them until I need to know about them"
>
> But afterwards I thought to myself while my arguments above seem reasonable there must be other good reasons (that I can't immediately think of) for being explicit with types & relations in links in RESTful APIs.
>
> Can you help me with your thoughts on what those other good reasons are?
>
> Thanks
> Ben

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18687
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-22 06:26:21
Subject:Re: Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

Thanks for all the interesting inputs. I think I will go with the "fielding" properties approach - using x-www-form-urlencoded for the payload.

At first I though Mike was suggesting the client should be hard coded to know that it could add ";props" to all URLs, which is not exactly in line with his work on hypermedia APIs ...

Then I saw Fielding's comment: "Note that the entire URI prefix is determined by the origin server, so the properties might even be on a different server than the resource." and figured that the server has to supply the exact link. Much better :-)

So, for now it becomes:

1) Some resources in the system contains a link with the rel-type "additional-properties". This link points to the list of additional properties for that resource (at the URL "{additional-properties}").
 
2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value properties for reading. That "list" is represented with x-www-form-urlencoded.

3) The whole set of properties for one resource can be updated by PUTing a set of values (using form-urlencoded again) to the "{additional-properties}" URL.

4) The whole set of properties for one resource can be delete by DELETing the "{additional-properties}" URL.

5) It is not possible to update a single key/value pair by itself. Neither is that required in out current use cases (which allows a user to edit the whole set of values at once).

Thanks, JÃ¸rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18688
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-23 20:26:43
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

Although I'd highly recommend reminding yourself that multipart/form-data was created because of the shortcomings of form-urlencoded, such as not supporting encodings properly, and browsers going against the spec on that one (and the spec being outdated).

Dragons ahead.

-----Original Message-----
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jan Algermissen
Sent: 21 March 2012 20:11
To: mike amundsen
Cc: Jorn Wildt; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Media-type for simple key/value store?


On Mar 21, 2012, at 3:56 PM, mike amundsen wrote:

> a while back, i did an implementation of an idea that Roy posted to a 
> list regarding managing properties of a resource. w/o his assent, i 
> named this pattern "Fielding Property Maps"[1]
> 
> it's another possibility you might consider as it does not require a 
> dedicated media type design to implement it cleanly. in fact, it could 
> work in almost any media type design.
> 
> this might be exactly what you need, but maybe it gives you some ideas.
> 
> [1] http://www.amundsen.com/examples/fielding-props/


In any case, Roy's design (and Mike's 'specification' around it) is a very educating use case - make sure you have a look.

Besides that, application/x-www-form-urlencoded is the way to go if you want a key/value format

Jan






> 
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.com@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
> 
> On Wed, Mar 21, 2012 at 10:24, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:
> > A part of my current project is management of simple key/value properties (string/string) for (more or less) any resource in the system.
> >
> > My use-cases/scenarios are:
> >
> > 1) Some resource in the system contains a link with the rel-type "additional-properties". This link points to the list of additional properties for that resource (at the URL "{additional-properties}").
> >
> > 2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value properties for reading.
> >
> > 3) For each key/value in the list there will be links for a) editing the value of the key, and 2) deleting the key.
> >
> > 3a) Editing is as simple as PUTing a new value to the URL.
> >
> > 3b) Deleting a key is as simple as a HTTP DELETE of the URL.
> >
> > 4) The list also contains a link for adding new properties.
> >
> > What would be a suitable (simple) media-type for this?
> >
> > I am considering ATOM (which is nice for lists), but that seems like quite a bit of overkill. HTML might also be useful (but does not support PUT, but POST would be okay too). A home-grown application/vnd.abc+xml is also a possibility.
> >
> > What would you guys do?
> >
> > Thanks, Jørn
> >
> >
> >
> > ------------------------------------
> >
> > Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> 



------------------------------------

Yahoo! Groups Links

Post ID:18689
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-26 10:04:46
Subject:"The 'profile' Link Relation Type" (draft-wilde-profile-link-00) published
Message:

hello.

"The 'profile' Link Relation Type" 
http://www.ietf.org/id/draft-wilde-profile-link-00.txt is now officially 
published as an I-D. it is the version that i made available on my 
server a little earlier, and some comments were already posted here 
earlier this month 
http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/18578 . 
additional comments are very welcome, and i plan to publish a new 
version (incoporating the previous rest-discuss comments and any new 
ones) as soon as possible.

thanks a lot and cheers,

dret.

erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |

Post ID:18690
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-26 12:16:49
Subject:Re: Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

Good point Sebastien.

You don't happen to know if specifying charset like below is valid (or simply "widely accepted")?

  Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded;charset=UTF-8

/Jørn

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:
>
> Although I'd highly recommend reminding yourself that multipart/form-data was created because of the shortcomings of form-urlencoded, such as not supporting encodings properly, and browsers going against the spec on that one (and the spec being outdated).
> 
> Dragons ahead.
>

> > >
> > > 2) The URL "{additional-properties}" returns a list of key/value properties for reading.
> > >

Post ID:18691
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-03-28 10:21:30
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Media-type for simple key/value store?
Message:

I need to look at the openrasta code. The lowdown is that I believe browsers send it in whatever charset format of the containing html page, without adding the charset and without using the default specified by the specification.

The rest of the issues are I believe summarized at the beginning of the spec on multipart/form-data.

Seb

________________________________________
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] on behalf of Jorn Wildt [jw@...]

Subject: [rest-discuss] Re: Media-type for simple key/value store?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18692
Sender:Ruben Verborgh <ruben.verborgh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-02 10:44:30
Subject:REST <=> follow your nose?
Message:

Hi REST people,

Some simple questions that might lead to interesting discussions:

How far do you agree that REST and hypermedia are about following one’s nose?
Is the “following your nose” thing an essential part of REST?
And what is there more to REST than can be explained by “following your nose”?

All input welcome!

Best,

Ruben

PS This post was inspired by Erik Wilde’s blogpost about describing REST – http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/rest-layers.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18693
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-02 17:04:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST <=> follow your nose?
Message:

hello ruben.

On 2012-04-02 3:44 , Ruben Verborgh wrote:
> How far do you agree that REST and hypermedia are about following oneâ€™s nose?
> Is the â€œfollowing your noseâ€ thing an essential part of REST?
> And what is there more to REST than can be explained by â€œfollowing your noseâ€?

i think it's essential, it means that when you're exploring hyperlinked 
resources, both the links and the resources need to follow an agreed-on 
framework of self-description (link relation types and media types, on 
the web). anybody designing within that framework can create new link 
relations and/or media types, and clients navigating through that space 
have an easy way to understand that they follow paths with known 
semantics ("i know that link relation") or encounter resources with 
known semantics ("i know that media type").

what's important for a service provider in addition to that might be to 
give clients an understanding of the set of link relations and media 
types they might encounter for a "service web" at a given point in time. 
for example, thinking back to 10 years ago, how would you have 
communicated the fact that "the web" back then was mostly HTML, GIF, 
JPEG, RSS? today, you might add PNG and Atom to this list, and maybe 
feed paging.

our goal is to have a simple way of bundling these concepts (link 
relation types and media types) and communicating them to clients as a 
guide to what might happen when they follow their nose in the hypermedia 
space exposed by our services. "this is what you definitely should 
accept, and of course, you should always expect unknown things to show 
up as well", this is what we as service providers would like to be able 
to say, and in addition to that, they might even want to provide an 
actual map (a subset) of the resources they are serving, which would be 
the sitemap model. such a servicemap would pretty much point your nose 
at very many resources immediately, and you could either just be happy 
with those resources, or you might follow links from them to more 
resources. i think it is important to keep in mind that a sitemap, 
looked at as a resource, is a very RESTful thing in itself, it contains 
a (large) set of links, and clients can find such a map and use such a 
map purely by "follow your nose" principles.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18694
Sender:Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-02 19:07:44
Subject:Building a web app/api
Message:

I'm about to build a web app that should expose its functionality via API
and I'm trying to find the most effective way to do that and would like to
hear your thoughts on the topic.
The functionality of the 'website' and the API intersect, with API having
additional features that should not be available from the website (from
browser). A traditional approach to building such systems seems to be
building a website and an API as two separate projects, probably even using
different technologies. That seems ineffective as there are 2 places
(website and api) which have to invoke the same business logic with all the
joys as a result. For example, adding a feature that should be exposed in
both requires adding it to 2 places. Basically you should always think
about keeping your website and API in sync. Not fun.

And I don't want to have browsers and machine clients to work with the same
html as it can easily become too verbose.

Another way is to have the same set of resources that a browser and
programmatic clients communicate with and use content negotiation to either
return text/html (for browser) or application/vnd.whatever+json (for
programmatic clients). With this approach only the code that converts
resource objects to representations have to differ. I have a couple of
concerns with this approach as well:

   1. There are features that should be available via api only, meaning
   html representations may not have the same links available in json for the
   specific resource. I'm not sure this is correct as depending on which media
   type the client asks it may get completely different features. Feels kinda
   wrong, but is it?
   2. Earlier or later the two media types will start to diverge,
   specifically when we have to take care about evolvability of the 'machine'
   media type, while that is not a concern for 'humans' html. And here we go
   again  having to have different links between html and json representations.
   3. Browsers do only GET and POST. But that can be pretty easily
   overridden by X-HTTP-Method-Override to do PUT and DELETE.

What are your overall thoughts and experience on the topic?

Thanks,
Vitaly





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18695
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-02 20:46:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Building a web app/api
Message:

Ruby on rails has decent conventions for dealing with this stuff, probably
worth checking it out

On Mon, Apr 2, 2012 at 8:07 PM, Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...> wrote:

>    specifically when we have to take care about evolvability of the 'machine'

Post ID:18696
Sender:Nick Gall <nick.gall@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-02 20:53:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST <=> follow your nose?
Message:

There's a lot more to REST than just "follow your nose." IMO, the most
important REST principle is the principle of generality. See
http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/8873 .

Also, "follow your nose" may not mean exactly what you think it means. See
http://www.w3.org/wiki/FollowYourNose and
http://www.w3.org/wiki/FollowLinksForMoreInformation .

-- Nick

Nick Gall
Phone: +1.781.608.5871
Other Contact Info: http://profiles.google.com/NickGall/about


On Mon, Apr 2, 2012 at 6:44 AM, Ruben Verborgh <ruben.verborgh@...>wrote:

> Hi REST people,
>
> Some simple questions that might lead to interesting discussions:
>
> How far do you agree that REST and hypermedia are about following one’s
> nose?
> Is the “following your nose” thing an essential part of REST?
> And what is there more to REST than can be explained by “following your
> nose”?
>
> All input welcome!
>
> Best,
>
> Ruben
>
> PS This post was inspired by Erik Wilde’s blogpost about describing REST –
> http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2012/03/rest-layers.html

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18697
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-02 21:11:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST <=> follow your nose?
Message:

hello.

On 2012-04-02 13:53 , Nick Gall wrote:
> Also, "follow your nose" may not mean exactly what you think it means.
> See http://www.w3.org/wiki/FollowYourNose and
> http://www.w3.org/wiki/FollowLinksForMoreInformation .

just to avoid any confusion: these are semweb definitions of what as 
link and following a link means or should mean, and there is quite a 
difference between how links are conceptualized in REST and in semweb.

cheers,

dret.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18698
Sender:Ruben Verborgh <ruben.verborgh@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 07:05:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST <=> follow your nose?
Message:

Hi Erik,

> i think it's essential

Fully agree on that ;-)

> it means that when you're exploring hyperlinked resources, both the links and the resources need to follow an agreed-on framework of self-description (link relation types and media types, on the web). anybody designing within that framework can create new link relations and/or media types, and clients navigating through that space have an easy way to understand that they follow paths with known semantics ("i know that link relation") or encounter resources with known semantics ("i know that media type”).

That brings me to an interesting point: somehow, “following your nose” and “specific media types” have always felt like some kind of contradiction to me.
Fielding puts emphasis on media type definition:
“A REST API should spend almost all of its descriptive effort in defining the media type(s) used for representing resources and driving application state, or in defining extended relation names and/or hypertext-enabled mark-up for existing standard media types.”

So the paradox to me here is:
- the more specific a media type (or relation name) is, the better a client can follow its nose
- but if a media type is specific, it can only be consumed by specific agents that have been programmed for that task, so in how far are they following their nose?

> what's important for a service provider in addition to that might be to give clients an understanding of the set of link relations and media types they might encounter for a "service web" at a given point in time. for example, thinking back to 10 years ago, how would you have communicated the fact that "the web" back then was mostly HTML, GIF, JPEG, RSS? today, you might add PNG and Atom to this list, and maybe feed paging.

Also agree here (not coincidentally because I’m working on service descriptions that indeed try to contain the expectations about possible links).

> our goal is to have a simple way of bundling these concepts (link relation types and media types) and communicating them to clients as a guide to what might happen when they follow their nose in the hypermedia space exposed by our services.

Interesting, and that’s not unlike what we are doing.
Although I know that some people are skeptical about the idea. As in: is it really “following your nose” if you already explain beforehand what’s going to happen?
I think it is, but maybe not everyone’s convinced.

> i think it is important to keep in mind that a sitemap, looked at as a resource, is a very RESTful thing in itself, it contains a (large) set of links, and clients can find such a map and use such a map purely by "follow your nose" principles.

They can, provided they understand the link relations.
To what extent you think this is possible with generic clients?

Best,

Ruben





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18699
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 08:15:39
Subject:Re: REST <=> follow your nose?
Message:

Comments inline:

> > i think it is important to keep in mind that a sitemap, looked at as a resource, is a very RESTful thing in itself, it contains a (large) set of links, and clients can find such a map and use such a map purely by "follow your nose" principles.
> 
> They can, provided they understand the link relations.
> To what extent you think this is possible with generic clients?

In order to answer this question you must first define how you interpret "generic client"? Here is one interpretation:

A "generic client" is a client that understands the "processing model" of a various media-types. It knows how to 1) parse data, and 2) discover hyper-media controls (affordances) like links and forms. It does not know what the data represents in more domain specific terms (like sales orders, persons, weather maps and so on).

Generic clients can only handle generic tasks. Like Google - it knows how to 1) parse HTML (and more), and 2) follow links. Thus it can "understand" the data in a broad generic way and extract words without any domain specific knowledge.

So, to answer your question, yes, generic clients can follow a site map, given that it is represented in a standard format with hyper-media controls (this excludes plain XML and JSON). It can discover all available links and follow them, but given that it is a generic client it can, not suprisingly, only do generic stuff with it - it knows the "HOW to work with this data", but not the "WHAT is this data anyway".

> That brings me to an interesting point: somehow, "following your nose" and "specific media types" have always felt like some kind of contradiction to me.

> So the paradox to me here is:
> - the more specific a media type (or relation name) is, the better a client can follow its nose

I think it is important to avoid mixing media types and relation names. Again, a media-type defines the "HOW to work with the data" in terms of 1) parsing and 2) discovering hyper-media controls. Once the hyper-media controls have been located you can start working with link-rels independently of original media-type.

Then you can add very specific link-rels, but any client that understands the underlying media-type will be able to "follow its nose", no matter how specific or generic the link-rels are - in the end they always represent a named link and nothing more. The name can be very specific but the link will always be generic.

> - but if a media type is specific, it can only be consumed by specific agents that have been programmed for that task, so in how far are they following their nose?

I assume that by "more specific media type" you think of media-types that express domain specific semantics like "this is a sales order/person/weather map/other". You don't need that for a client to "follow its nose" - all you need is a generic media-type with well defined hyper-media controls.

With link-rels the server can show the client how to change its application state, by going from one resource to another. It does not matter how the client got those link relations - it could be from an extremely domain specific media-type or a very broad one.

The important thing is that the server is in control and the client only "follows its nose" - as opposed to be programmed with a specific hard coded flow that assumes knowledge of all URLs involved in the steps.

/JÃ¸rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18700
Sender:"Jorn Wildt" <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 08:29:33
Subject:REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

It seems like there is an ongoing debate/mismatch/battle/whatever between REST and Linked Data (if I am interpreting various Tweets correct). Could anyone share a link to something that can enlighten me on what this is about?

Thanks, Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18701
Sender:Bob Ferris <zazi@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 08:35:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Hi Jorn,

unfortunately, I don't have the time to follow the current discussions 
and debates about this topic right now. However, I somehow started a 
discussion re. that topic some time ago. You may have a look at this 
thread at answers.semanticweb.com, which also includes some links to 
parallel and related discussions here at rest-discuss:

http://answers.semanticweb.com/questions/2763/the-relation-of-linked-datasemantic-web-to-rest

Cheers,


Bo


On 4/3/2012 10:29 AM, Jorn Wildt wrote:
> It seems like there is an ongoing debate/mismatch/battle/whatever
> between REST and Linked Data (if I am interpreting various Tweets
> correct). Could anyone share a link to something that can enlighten me
> on what this is about?
>
> Thanks, Jï¿½rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18702
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 10:11:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

I'll have a stab at it..

Linked Data is concerned with using hypertext to construct an
intelligible graph from the web that is publicly available and can be
analysed/queried.

REST is concerned with using hypertext to expose applications so that
their evolution can be managed efficiently over time.

Basically, they use hypertext as a means to different ends. REST is
about directing the flow of the web's applications, LD is about
establishing a structure to the web's data.

One important LD-related technology is RDF, although it's not the only
way to do LD it does seem to have unearthed some of the fundamental
differences between LD and REST, so I'll share my perspective on that:

RDF, in the quest for web-intelligibility, does not seem to cope very
well with the ambiguous and messy reality of The Web. This has led to
a lot of controversy and demands from the RDF community for solutions
to problems that apparently don't exist for REST or anyone else
outside of 'RDF land' - a good example of a this is range-14. This has
produced lots of long-winded and confused philosophical debate, but
one of my favourite insights is a post from 2002 by Roy:

http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2002Jul/0090.html

Cheers,
Mike

On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 9:29 AM, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> It seems like there is an ongoing debate/mismatch/battle/whatever between REST and Linked Data (if I am interpreting various Tweets correct). Could anyone share a link to something that can enlighten me on what this is about?
>
> Thanks, Jørn
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18703
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 12:05:50
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

There was an interesting paper at last year's WS-REST:

K. R. Page, D. C. De Roure, and K. Martinez, “REST and Linked Data: a match
made for domain driven development?,” in Proceedings of the 2nd
International Workshop on RESTful Design (WS-REST 2011), 2011, pp. 22-25.

http://ws-rest.org/2011/proc/a5-page.pdf


I personally distinguish between the traditional "Semantic Web" and "Linked
Data". Linked Data, for me, is just interlinked structured data and, as
that, a great match to RESTful systems.

I think most of the "debate/mismatch/battle/whatever between REST and Linked
Data" stems from the AI-heavy history of the Semantic Web efforts. So
developers are often afraid to use it/learn it - even though heaps of them
are using those technologies without even knowing it (think Facebook's Open
Graph annotations). I usually use the term Semaphobia to describe this fear
:-)


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18705
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 12:15:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 11:11 AM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> **
>
> RDF, in the quest for web-intelligibility, does not seem to cope very
> well with the ambiguous and messy reality of The Web. This has led to
> a lot of controversy and demands from the RDF community for solutions
> to problems that apparently don't exist for REST or anyone else
> outside of 'RDF land' - a good example of a this is range-14.
>

httpRange-14, as its name suggests, is an HTTP issue not an RDF one. RDF is
useful to describe informational and non-informational resources in a
uniform way. Linked Data, in using RDF with HTTP, encounters this issue but
does not cause it.

Barry





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18706
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 12:35:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 1:15 PM, Barry Norton <barrynorton@...> wrote:
>
>
> On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 11:11 AM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>>
>> RDF, in the quest for web-intelligibility, does not seem to cope very
>> well with the ambiguous and messy reality of The Web. This has led to
>> a lot of controversy and demands from the RDF community for solutions
>> to problems that apparently don't exist for REST or anyone else
>> outside of 'RDF land' - a good example of a this is range-14.
>
>
> httpRange-14, as its name suggests, is an HTTP issue not an RDF one. RDF is
> useful to describe informational and non-informational resources in a
> uniform way. Linked Data, in using RDF with HTTP, encounters this issue but
> does not cause it.

That weird forced distinction between informational vs
non-informational resources is fabricated by RDF-think.  HTTP has no
requirement to make this distinction otherwise, therefore range-14 is
addressing a would-be-non-issue-for-http that is inflicted on the web
by RDF.

Basically, in range-14, the issue for HTTP is that it is the
unfortunate victim of RDF's web-insanity being taken way too
seriously.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18707
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 12:53:39
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

So your answer is nothing to do with interpretation of HTTP status codes
200 and 303, etc. (i.e. range14), but about distinguishing things about
documents about them in general?

I didn't think that REST was such a house of cards it couldn't accommodate
this distinction. Is that the general opinion?

Barry

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18708
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 13:03:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Apr 3, 2012 10:15 PM, "Barry Norton" <barrynorton@...> wrote:
> httpRange-14, as its name suggests, is an HTTP issue not an RDF one.

Ahem, no, that would be a bit of a red herring, I'm afraid. The name stems
from dereferencing function in HTTP, and it was from the W3C issue tracker,
issue 14, where it's the other way around; it's the RDF community which has
/ had issues with HTTP for *their* purposes.

I admittedly have a foot in three camps; HTTP/REST, RDF and Topic Maps, a
kind of tripod from War of the Webs, and I think the "problem" that's
flaring up these days are remnants and additional context to what
httpRange-14 was about, but not the same thing;

Identity management. And the problem is RDF's lack of a vocabulary (and
framework) that reflect that HTTP used as identifiers are ambiguous,
faulty, flaky, human and fallible. Topic Maps has a vocabulary that reflect
this, and that world don't struggle with this as much. HTTP/REST already
know they are, too, and they have no problem either.

> Linked Data, in using RDF with HTTP, encounters this issue
> but does not cause it.

They "encounter this issue" only by virtue of needing it to be something it
was never designed to be. HttpRange-14 was an amazingly bad "solution", and
LinkedData is poking a sore not yet healed.

IMHO, of course. :)

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18709
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 13:07:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

But, again, there's: RDF; the things that we want to describe using RDF;
and the way that HTTP may be used to distinguish and relate them.

Can we respect this and fling stones only with the message: "I don't
believe a document about a car is different from the car", versus "I don't
like the solution in HTTP", versus "RDF is weird"?

Barry

Post ID:18710
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 13:09:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 1:53 PM, Barry Norton <barrynorton@...> wrote:
>
> I didn't think that REST was such a house of cards it couldn't accommodate
> this distinction. Is that the general opinion?
>

No. REST is robust enough that it can deal with the ambiguities
inherent to the web (and reality) and does not have to demand insane
kludges just to get its house of cards erected in the first place.
Unlike RDF. Hence the creation of range-14.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18712
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 13:23:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

I think it serves to illustrate the point very well.

The Linked Data Community would like to do more with RDF than just
retrieval (HTTP GET). The REST community ought to be able to provide
guidance, but are unable to get over a few basic fundamentals of modelling
(and would mud-sling about the implementation in HTTP, everything else
being 'too philosophical').

Meanwhile the two extremes of universally-defined (link) relations and
non-shared local data schema trudges on (just like XML since the 90s)
avoiding any contact with extensible shared schemas and ontologies.

That's a real shame.

Barry



On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 2:16 PM, Jorn Wildt <jw@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Gentlemen, I only asked for a few pointers (and thank you for those) - not
> to carry the debate over on rest-discuss :-)

> /JÃ¸rn

Post ID:18713
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 14:04:29
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

All this reminds me of the numerous discussions about media-types - whether or not they should carry any domain specific information, something which I have always had a hard time trying to understand fully.

Is it fair to say that those who think media-types can and should carry some kind of domain semantics thinks in terms of the semantic web - they want the resources to be self descriptive, but not only in terms of the processing model - also in terms of the semantics?

I myself have belonged to that group without knowing it - having that feeling of, hmmm, how can you work with resources without knowing what they actually represent? But some valuable input from Darrel Miller and Mike Kelly (https://groups.google.com/d/msg/hypermedia-web/V0hcWwQet3I/FdYY1PGUTgMJ) and this (to me) recent focus on REST vs. SemWeb has helped quite a bit understanding the differences. Thanks.

/Jørn

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jorn Wildt 
  To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, April 03, 2012 10:29 AM
  Subject: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data


    
  It seems like there is an ongoing debate/mismatch/battle/whatever between REST and Linked Data (if I am interpreting various Tweets correct). Could anyone share a link to something that can enlighten me on what this is about?

  Thanks, Jørn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18714
Sender:Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 16:32:51
Subject:Re: Building a web app/api
Message:

OK, after thinking about it I came to conclusion that my original thought
to distinguish api requests from UI requests and therefore returning
different links in responses based on the requested media type was kinda
wrong. That decision should be based on how clients identify themselves to
the service. That way UI and API responses will be returned by exactly the
same code base, which is the goal.

With respect to implementation, most web frameworks support additional
routing features based on get/post/put/delete if not out of the box than
with some oss help.

On 2 April 2012 22:07, Vitaly Stakhov <vitaly.st@...> wrote:

> I'm about to build a web app that should expose its functionality via API
> and I'm trying to find the most effective way to do that and would like to
> hear your thoughts on the topic.
> The functionality of the 'website' and the API intersect, with API having
> additional features that should not be available from the website (from
> browser). A traditional approach to building such systems seems to be
> building a website and an API as two separate projects, probably even using
> different technologies. That seems ineffective as there are 2 places
> (website and api) which have to invoke the same business logic with all the
> joys as a result. For example, adding a feature that should be exposed in
> both requires adding it to 2 places. Basically you should always think
> about keeping your website and API in sync. Not fun.
>
> And I don't want to have browsers and machine clients to work with the
> same html as it can easily become too verbose.
>
> Another way is to have the same set of resources that a browser and
> programmatic clients communicate with and use content negotiation to either
> return text/html (for browser) or application/vnd.whatever+json (for
> programmatic clients). With this approach only the code that converts
> resource objects to representations have to differ. I have a couple of
> concerns with this approach as well:
>
>    1. There are features that should be available via api only, meaning
>    html representations may not have the same links available in json for the
>    specific resource. I'm not sure this is correct as depending on which media
>    type the client asks it may get completely different features. Feels kinda
>    wrong, but is it?
>    2. Earlier or later the two media types will start to diverge,
>    specifically when we have to take care about evolvability of the 'machine'
>    media type, while that is not a concern for 'humans' html. And here we go
>    again  having to have different links between html and json representations.
>    3. Browsers do only GET and POST. But that can be pretty easily
>    overridden by X-HTTP-Method-Override to do PUT and DELETE.
>
> What are your overall thoughts and experience on the topic?
>
> Thanks,
> Vitaly
>



-- 
Cheers,
Vitaly





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18715
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 16:40:39
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello.

On 2012-04-03 5:15 , Barry Norton wrote:
> httpRange-14, as its name suggests, is an HTTP issue not an RDF one. RDF
> is useful to describe informational and non-informational resources in a
> uniform way. Linked Data, in using RDF with HTTP, encounters this issue
> but does not cause it.

i strongly disagree. the issue has been punted to HTTP by RDF, and 
another attempt was to punt it to URIs using hash URIs. the issue does, 
however, originate in RDF and its goal to be able to clearly separate 
two ontologically different classes of HTTP-identified resources, the 
information and the non-information resources. on the web, this is not 
even an issue that exists: you identify by URI whatever you deem 
appropriate, and if you need to distinguish described and description 
resources, you introduce describedby/described relations and manage them 
and serve them to whoever is interested and you're done. the current 
debate around this issue is caused by the fact that for 1% of the web, 
the semweb/linkeddata community, not being able to clearly distinguish 
between information and the non-information resources is a very real 
pain. for the 99% of the web, however, it is not even a problem, and if 
some community decided it wants to be really disciplined about it, it 
could start using describedby/described (and maybe even register those 
link relations, one of them actually already is), and the problem is 
solved on the web without having to change the web. so the issue is 
definitely not one that is inherent to HTTP, it is one that is caused by 
the specific way in which RDF has decided to use HTTP identifiers.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18716
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 16:55:42
Subject:Re: more charter changes, and do you like "RESTful" ?
Message:

hello sandro.

(i am cross-posting this to rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, but please 
direct responses to public-ldp@... only! thanks!)

On 2012-04-03 9:25 , Sandro Hawke wrote:
> I'm getting some pushback on using the term "RESTful" at all.  I guess
> the recent TAG meeting brought up some of the differences between Roy
> Fielding's idea of REST and the various ways to term is used and misused
> today.   If anyone would care to suggest alternative terminology or
> voice support for terms currently in the charter, please do so soon.

we have had (long and eventually fruitless) discussions around this in 
the WS-REST workshops. the problem is as follows:

- technically speaking, REST is an architectural style, and we don't 
want to refer to just this style, because that would allow us to build 
something other than the web, and we don't want to do that.

- what we usually want to refer to by "REST is" "the web used 
correctly", which means using the basic standards URI and HTTP and the 
supporting fabric of registered URI schemes, media types, and link 
relations. but unfortunately, there is no term for that other than "the 
web used correctly".

so we (the WS-REST participants) ended up concluding that even though 
"RESTful" is a somehow incorrect name, it is the best we have. for what 
we really want to say, there is no better name than "the web used 
correctly", and that sounds very awkward. so we continue to say 
"RESTful", even though i do agree that it is not the best name to use.

thanks and cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18717
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 17:08:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello markus.

On 2012-04-03 5:05 , Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> I personally distinguish between the traditional "Semantic Web" and "Linked
> Data". Linked Data, for me, is just interlinked structured data and, as
> that, a great match to RESTful systems.

that's what one might naively think, reading the term as the combination 
of the two words "linked" and "data". it turns out that the community 
that brands itself as "linked data" is not quite as open in its 
interpretation, and claims that only RDF can be linked data:

http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2009/11/the-linked-data-police.html

whether that's a good definition or not is a different discussion and 
not one we should have here, but i have learned my lesson from this 
episode and now expect that if people refer to "linked data", they refer 
to RDF. ymmv.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18718
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-03 17:26:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Erik, while largely agreeing with you technically, again this conflates the
issues.

"RDF has decided to use HTTP identifiers" - no, Linked Data (Principle 2)
has chosen to use HTTP identifiers. RDF, as you know, is perfectly
compatible with using non-HTTP (non-'URL') IRIs.

As it goes I'm perfectly open (if expressivity is not lost) to using
"describedby/described" relations, and am not tied (if consensus shifts) to
the HTTP-range14 solution, for publishing/consuming Linked Data.

On the other hand, when people complain about the thing/document
distinction (preferring ambiguity), and throw in the name HTTP-range14 as
if that's an RDF necessity, then that's disingenuous, as no solution is
going to work for them. They prefer to ignore the distinction altogether.
This I can not even entertain.

Barry




On Tue, Apr 3, 2012 at 5:40 PM, Erik Wilde <dret@...> wrote:

> hello.
>
>
> On 2012-04-03 5:15 , Barry Norton wrote:
>
>> httpRange-14, as its name suggests, is an HTTP issue not an RDF one. RDF
>> is useful to describe informational and non-informational resources in a
>> uniform way. Linked Data, in using RDF with HTTP, encounters this issue
>> but does not cause it.
>>
>
> i strongly disagree. the issue has been punted to HTTP by RDF, and another
> attempt was to punt it to URIs using hash URIs. the issue does, however,
> originate in RDF and its goal to be able to clearly separate two
> ontologically different classes of HTTP-identified resources, the
> information and the non-information resources. on the web, this is not even
> an issue that exists: you identify by URI whatever you deem appropriate,
> and if you need to distinguish described and description resources, you
> introduce describedby/described relations and manage them and serve them to
> whoever is interested and you're done. the current debate around this issue
> is caused by the fact that for 1% of the web, the semweb/linkeddata
> community, not being able to clearly distinguish between information and
> the non-information resources is a very real pain. for the 99% of the web,
> however, it is not even a problem, and if some community decided it wants
> to be really disciplined about it, it could start using
> describedby/described (and maybe even register those link relations, one of
> them actually already is), and the problem is solved on the web without
> having to change the web. so the issue is definitely not one that is
> inherent to HTTP, it is one that is caused by the specific way in which RDF
> has decided to use HTTP identifiers.
>
> cheers,
>
> dret.
>
> --
> erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
>           | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
>           | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18719
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 00:53:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello barry.

On 2012-04-03 10:26 , Barry Norton wrote:
> "RDF has decided to use HTTP identifiers" - no, Linked Data (Principle
> 2) has chosen to use HTTP identifiers. RDF, as you know, is perfectly
> compatible with using non-HTTP (non-'URL') IRIs.

you're right here, and my apologies for not being crystal-clear about 
this. and this is where the trouble started. conflating identifiers and 
interaction traded easily demoable cuteness for a more robust solution 
that would allow identity and interactions to be clearly and cleanly 
separated, allowing described things and descriptions to be distributed 
in any way applications would like to do it. this design decision has 
caused all kinds of fallout, and httpRange-14 is only one of them. 
band-aids such as VoID are another one.

> As it goes I'm perfectly open (if expressivity is not lost) to using
> "describedby/described" relations, and am not tied (if consensus shifts)
> to the HTTP-range14 solution, for publishing/consuming Linked Data.

that's great to hear, so could you please have a very brief look at 
http://www.jenitennison.com/blog/node/168#comment-11727 and say whether 
you think you're losing anything in such a setting? in fact, i would 
even claim you win a lot because now having descriptions of descriptions 
becomes very cleanly covered, which is sort of a problem for the hash 
URI or 303 approaches. also, we can just use the existing machinery 
(link relation type registry) and don't have to meddle with 
well-established principles such as URI opacity or overload HTTP status 
codes.

> On the other hand, when people complain about the thing/document
> distinction (preferring ambiguity), and throw in the name HTTP-range14
> as if that's an RDF necessity, then that's disingenuous, as no solution
> is going to work for them. They prefer to ignore the distinction
> altogether. This I can not even entertain.

well, the fact is that for the vast majority of people it simply is not 
a problem, so they don't ignore it because they dislike it; it just 
doesn't matter. and for those more nuanced users where this distinction 
matters, i'd say that the distinction always is contextual and thus 
should be provided as context and not as indistinguishable part of 
identity (as in hash URIs), and then the web's existing mechanisms 
handle this effortlessly by allowing you to register link relations and 
relate the thing/document pairs that in your application context need to 
be related in that way.

i would really appreciate if you tried to explain what is wrong with 
such an approach, and why the describedby/describes relation is so 
radically different from other relation types that it cannot be treated 
like other links that applications would like to establish between web 
resources.

thanks a lot and cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18720
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 11:22:53
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Hi Erik,

> > I personally distinguish between the traditional "Semantic Web" and
> "Linked
> > Data". Linked Data, for me, is just interlinked structured data and,
> as
> > that, a great match to RESTful systems.
> 
> that's what one might naively think, reading the term as the
> combination
> of the two words "linked" and "data". it turns out that the community
> that brands itself as "linked data" is not quite as open in its
> interpretation, and claims that only RDF can be linked data

I know.. but insisting in something like this is just as naive. If you build a system that can't handle such ambiguities it just won't work at web scale. There are numerous examples.. one of them - perhaps not the best - are browser and their (sometimes insane) efforts to display your broken HTML. Where would the Web be if just 100% valid markup would have been allowed - I frankly don't know but can't really believe that it would have been to the better.

But that's just my humble opinion which won't interest the "Linked Data police" :-)



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18721
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 12:16:10
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wednesday, April 04, 2012 7:56 PM, Barry Norton wrote:

> Have you noticed that still not a word has been said
> here about RDF as a data model (let alone the 'Semantics'
> approach to schemas)?

Yes, and that's the dilemma. You can't talk about RDF without these negative
connotations. This is the very reason why we tried really hard to "hide" RDF
as much as possible in the JSON-LD spec [1]. We went even so far to formally
define what define Linked Data is in the context of JSON-LD [2].


> RDF can, and does, 'deal with the ambiguity of the Web'. 
> Witness OpenGraph Protocol, and RDF-based solutions using it
> (despite the IR/NIR ambiguity).
>
> This whole range14 thing is just a red herring.

I agree and there are numerous examples showing that.. but unfortunately the
RDF/Linked Data community doesn't really communicate that - range14 actually
communicates quite the opposite.

Let's once for all stop discussing these things and move on and bring the
REST community and the Linked Data community together. I'm sure there are
more common interests than disagreements and that both communities would
benefit a lot from each other.


[1] http://json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-syntax/
[2] http://json-ld.org/requirements/latest/#linked-data



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18722
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 12:25:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 1:16 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...>wrote:

> We went even so far to formally
> define what define Linked Data is in the context of JSON-LD [2].
>
>
Careful, the next stumbling block, once people run out of steam on NIR/IR,
is serialisation.

Before anyone should give a damn about serialising IRs, and publishing
NIRs, you have to grok that what RDF actually is is a directed graph model,
just like the web, where relationships are disambiguated with
URI-identified, reusable properties.

Therefore that descriptions are uniformly made with these properties, in
RDF triples (specifying which property relates which resource to which
other resource), not spread across centralised semi-standardised link
relations and non-reused ambiguous relations in tree-like data models
(JSON, XML, etc.)

That's where the discussion should surely focus, not on range14 and
serialisation. These are side issues.

Barry





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18723
Sender:Alexander Johannesen <alexander.johannesen@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 12:27:56
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> Let's once for all stop discussing these things and move on
>and bring the REST community and the Linked Data community
> together.

I'm fine with moving on, just remember that there's more to "RDF" than what
the W3C RDF community is harping on about the httpRange-14 issue, including
lots of people who use other technologies mixed with RDF, where the
ambiguity of URI identifiers aren't a problem.

Also, the RDF data model isn't *that* huge of a problem, as well as it
depends on what one mean by the RDF data model (RDF, RDFS, the OWL tripod,
and so on). You don't have to accept a lot of the RDF model to use the data
semantically with other technologies, Linked Data or otherwise.

Just a gentle reminder. :)

Regards,

Alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18724
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 12:35:10
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Not sure if I understand what you are trying to say Barry. JSON-LD is
exactly that, a serialization format for labeled directed graphs.

 

 

 

From: Barry Norton [mailto:barrynorton@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, April 04, 2012 8:26 PM

define what define Linked Data is in the context of JSON-LD [2].

 

 

Careful, the next stumbling block, once people run out of steam on NIR/IR,
is serialisation.

 

Before anyone should give a damn about serialising IRs, and publishing NIRs,
you have to grok that what RDF actually is is a directed graph model, just
like the web, where relationships are disambiguated with URI-identified,
reusable properties.

 

Therefore that descriptions are uniformly made with these properties, in RDF
triples (specifying which property relates which resource to which other
resource), not spread across centralised semi-standardised link relations
and non-reused ambiguous relations in tree-like data models (JSON, XML,
etc.)

 

That's where the discussion should surely focus, not on range14 and
serialisation. These are side issues.

 

Barry

Post ID:18726
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 13:00:29
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

The problem with JSON-LD is that it is way too complex.

Most people are just looking for conventions for linking to
and representing containment/embeddedness of other resources, and leaving
resource state alone as plain old JSON properties.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18727
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 13:00:47
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Only that by linking the JSON-LD spec (and, don't get me wrong, I like RDF
via JSON, as opposed to RDF via XML) you're in danger of steering people
down this cul de sac.

The question of whether RDF, and RDF Schemas, can play nicely with REST is
not about redirects or serialisation formats, it's about whether a uniform,
simple data model can fit with a uniform, simple architecture.

The rest is noise.

Barry

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18728
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 13:07:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:00 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> The problem with JSON-LD is that it is way too complex.
>
>
Voila. Moving on...



> Most people are just looking for conventions for linking to
> and representing containment/embeddedness of other resources, and leaving
> resource state alone as plain old JSON properties.
>
>
See, that's exactly the point on which I realised last year that my own
reconciliation with what I thought REST was, with Linked Data, had missed
where the REST community had moved in the meantime.

I thought REST was about identifying resources and interacting with them
using a uniform interface (commonly via HTTP). In the meantime it's about
accepting that a common centralised bunch of link relations are all the
shared semantics that are needed and the rest can just be pushed into local
schemas with no sharing.

Am I being unfair?

Barry





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18729
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 13:24:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:07 PM, Barry Norton <barrynorton@...> wrote:
>
>
> On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:00 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>>
>> The problem with JSON-LD is that it is way too complex.
>>
>
> Voila. Moving on...
>
>
>>
>> Most people are just looking for conventions for linking to
>> and representing containment/embeddedness of other resources, and leaving
>> resource state alone as plain old JSON properties.
>>
>
> See, that's exactly the point on which I realised last year that my own
> reconciliation with what I thought REST was, with Linked Data, had missed
> where the REST community had moved in the meantime.
>
> I thought REST was about identifying resources and interacting with them
> using a uniform interface (commonly via HTTP). In the meantime it's about
> accepting that a common centralised bunch of link relations are all the
> shared semantics that are needed and the rest can just be pushed into local
> schemas with no sharing.
>
> Am I being unfair?

Yes you are, there are lots of ways to employ hypertext under REST.
JSON-LD is impractical for most people creating RESTful applications
because it is too complex, but (afaik) it isn't "wrong".

What do you mean by 'centralised bunch of link relations'? Would you
use the same terminology if the link relations in question are URIs?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18730
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 13:36:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:24 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

>
> What do you mean by 'centralised bunch of link relations'? Would you
> use the same terminology if the link relations in question are URIs?
>
>
It depends. In this hypothetical could I assume that they're resolvable?

Would their representation be available in a data model I could understand?
And give me a description of their domains, ranges, more general properties
and alignments to properties defined by others?

If so, I can see that working.

RDF(S) makes that work.

Barry





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18731
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 13:56:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:36 PM, Barry Norton <barrynorton@...> wrote:
>
> On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:24 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>>
>>
>> What do you mean by 'centralised bunch of link relations'? Would you
>> use the same terminology if the link relations in question are URIs?
>>
>
> It depends. In this hypothetical could I assume that they're resolvable?
>
> Would their representation be available in a data model I could understand?
> And give me a description of their domains, ranges, more general properties
> and alignments to properties defined by others?

It could have many representations, but HTML is the obvious choice
because that's the most sensible way to communicate the necessary
information that the _human_ needs to write the automated client code
which traverses the application.

There is no reason additional machine-readable representations could
not be introduced further down the line, I've seen applications using
link relation URIs to expose schema documents that can be applied to
the target resource.

Personally, I'm fine just HTML.

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18732
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 14:01:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

While I'm *not* happy writing and re-writing the same code, in every
language I use, to map from your choice to use a given name for a relation
while someone else uses a different one.

And I'm not happy waiting for an authority to decide which is the right
one, and wait for everyone to (be forced to) catch up.

I want the database to do it all for me and let me uniformly query across
your descriptions and the other guy's.

Barry



On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:56 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> >> There is no reason additional machine-readable representations could
> >> not be introduced further down the line, I've seen applications using
> >> link relation URIs to expose schema documents that can be applied to
> >> the target resource.
> >>
> >> Personally, I'm fine just HTML.
> >>
> >> Cheers,
> >> Mike
> >
> >
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18735
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 14:18:30
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Mike, I would be very interested to hear why you think it "is way too
complex". It's not set in stone yet and I think we all are open for good,
constructive suggestions.

 

 

 

From: Mike Kelly [mailto:mikekelly321@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, April 04, 2012 9:00 PM
To: Markus Lanthaler
Cc: Barry Norton; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data

 

The problem with JSON-LD is that it is way too complex.

 

Most people are just looking for conventions for linking to and representing
containment/embeddedness of other resources, and leaving resource state
alone as plain old JSON properties.

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 1:35 PM, Markus Lanthaler <markus.lanthaler@...>
wrote:

  

Not sure if I understand what you are trying to say Barry. JSON-LD is
exactly that, a serialization format for labeled directed graphs.

 

 

 

From: Barry Norton [mailto:barrynorton@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, April 04, 2012 8:26 PM
To: Markus Lanthaler
Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data

 

 

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 1:16 PM, Markus Lanthaler <markus.lanthaler@...>
wrote:

We went even so far to formally

define what define Linked Data is in the context of JSON-LD [2].

 

 

Careful, the next stumbling block, once people run out of steam on NIR/IR,
is serialisation.

 

Before anyone should give a damn about serialising IRs, and publishing NIRs,
you have to grok that what RDF actually is is a directed graph model, just
like the web, where relationships are disambiguated with URI-identified,
reusable properties.

 

Therefore that descriptions are uniformly made with these properties, in RDF
triples (specifying which property relates which resource to which other
resource), not spread across centralised semi-standardised link relations
and non-reused ambiguous relations in tree-like data models (JSON, XML,
etc.)

 

That's where the discussion should surely focus, not on range14 and
serialisation. These are side issues.

 

Barry



 
<http://groups.yahoo.com/;_ylc=X3oDMTJkdWpiYzdzBF9TAzk3NDc2NTkwBGdycElkAzQzM
TkyNTUEZ3Jwc3BJZAMxNzA1NzAxMDE0BHNlYwNmdHIEc2xrA2dmcARzdGltZQMxMzMzNTQyOTE4>

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

All of it that has nothing to do with representing links to, and
containment of, other resources.. which is quite a lot?

Cheers,
Mike

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 3:18 PM, Markus Lanthaler

> complex“. It’s not set in stone yet and I think we all are open for good,
> constructive suggestions.

> and representing containment/embeddedness of other resources, and leaving

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18737
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 14:31:42
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wednesday, April 04, 2012 10:24 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
> 
> All of it that has nothing to do with representing links to, and
> containment of, other resources.. which is quite a lot?

Linking to other resources:

{
  "@context": "/context.jsonld",
  "@id": "http://example.com/markus",
  "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
  "knows": "http://example.com/mike"
}


Embedding resources:

{
  "@context": "/context.jsonld",
  "@id": "http://example.com/markus",
  "name": "Markus Lanthaler",
  "knows": {
    "@id": "http://example.com/mike",
    "name": "Mike Kelly"
  }
}


All you have to do is to define your context once, and store it somewhere:

"@context": {
    "foaf: "http://...",
    "name": "foaf:name",
    "knows": { "foaf:knows", "@type": "@id" }
}


Too complex?



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
