-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18741
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 18:14:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello barry.

On 2012-04-04 6:07 , Barry Norton wrote:
> I thought REST was about identifying resources and interacting with them
> using a uniform interface (commonly via HTTP). In the meantime it's
> about accepting that a common centralised bunch of link relations are
> all the shared semantics that are needed and the rest can just be pushed
> into local schemas with no sharing.

at least from my understanding of what we've been doing over the last 
couple of years, we never "changed" what REST is about. the uniform 
interface always was and still is a central building block of REST, it's 
what works because of URIs. but before you can use the uniform interface 
of a resource that has been identified, you have been linked there, by a 
typed linked that tells you about that resource in the context of the 
application scenario, and thus what it means to interact with that 
resource ("if you GET that picture, it is something that you can embed 
in the rendering of the HTML you're currently trying to display."). 
typed links always have been another essential building block of REST, 
because without them, you would never be pointed to a resource in the 
first place, and then be able to use its uniform interface. if you look 
at HTML's link types 
(http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2009/10/links-in-html.html), i think 
it's fair to say that "a centralized bunch of link relations" (in that 
case defined as part of HTML and not as standalone link types) have been 
at the very core of how the web works, why it works, and why it has been 
successful. without those link types (i.e., with an HTML only containing 
untyped generic links), the web certainly would have been a radically 
different thing, and personally, i don't think it would have succeeded. 
anyway, the point i am trying to make here is that link relation types 
are and have always been essential to REST, and whether they are defined 
as an integral part of a media type, or externally and thus can be 
reused across media types, is more of a side issue.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18742
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 18:26:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello barry.

On 2012-04-04 6:36 , Barry Norton wrote:
> On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:24 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...
> <mailto:mikekelly321@...>> wrote:
>     What do you mean by 'centralised bunch of link relations'? Would you
>     use the same terminology if the link relations in question are URIs?
> It depends. In this hypothetical could I assume that they're resolvable?

RFC 5988 very specifically says that they should not be treated as being 
resolvable (first paragraph of 
http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988#section-4.2). these URIs are 
identifiers and not links.  it is essential to make that difference, 
because not all the things that can be identified can be interacted 
with. that is one of the principles of web architecture. you'll find 
that in various places and it always annoys people (just look at XML 
namespaces and how often people complain about those URIs just being 
identifiers ;-), but even though it does annoy people, it's just how it 
is, on the web. linked data tries to change that, and whether that's a 
good design starting point or not is not something we should discuss 
here. but when looking at web things (outside of the linked data realm) 
there really is no point to take things that are *designed* to be 
identifiers, *claim* that they should be links, and then say something 
is not working as it should. it may not be what you would do following 
linked data principles, but that's a different design space.

pointing finger from linked data to the greater web and vice versa and 
claiming "you got it all wrong" will not really move us forward, and i 
think both communities have to be accepting of the design constraints of 
the other one.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18743
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 18:32:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 7:26 PM, Erik Wilde <dret@...> wrote:

> hello barry.
>
>
> On 2012-04-04 6:36 , Barry Norton wrote:
>
>> On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 2:24 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...
>> <mailto:mikekelly321@...**>> wrote:
>>    What do you mean by 'centralised bunch of link relations'? Would you
>>    use the same terminology if the link relations in question are URIs?
>> It depends. In this hypothetical could I assume that they're resolvable?
>>
>
> RFC 5988 very specifically says that they should not be treated as being
> resolvable (first paragraph of http://tools.ietf.org/html/**
> rfc5988#section-4.2 <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988#section-4.2>)


That's not my reading. For pragmatic reasons it says you shouldn't hammer
the server, but explicitly allows that they can:
"point to a resource that contains a definition of the semantics of the
relation type"

It actually seems quite close to RDF versus Linked Data. RDF says the
relationship should be a URI (and for years people used identifiers that
wouldn't resolve, even though they were defined by ontologies somewhere).
Linked Data says they should.

No one actually resolves the predicate every time they see it appear in
Linked Datasets.

Barry





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18744
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 18:41:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello barry.

On 2012-04-04 11:32 , Barry Norton wrote:
> That's not my reading. For pragmatic reasons it says you shouldn't
> hammer the server, but explicitly allows that they can:
> "point to a resource that contains a definition of the semantics of the
> relation type"

it can, but it doesn't have to, and even if it did, for most of the 
relations you find on the non-RDF web, that definition would be prose, 
like mike (i think) pointed out. but my point was that the definition 
says it's an identifier and not a link. that some identifiers may be 
links is a convenience function and not a requirement.

and frankly, i am not quite sure what you want to say here. obviously, 
you know the specs. so the specs allow you to treat the identifier as a 
link for your applications, and if you want to design your application 
like that, that's fine. and by the way, that's what we do for our 
internal systems, because i also happen to think it's a good idea. but 
that still does not imply that if somebody does use unresolvable 
identifiers that their design is wrong. it is 100% correct, it just 
happens to follow a pattern that you don't like.

cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |

> and thus can be reused across media types, is more of a side issue.

(potential) bar at the entry point.

Post ID:18746
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 18:46:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

My point is just: what happens when you take the important parts of REST
and the important parts of Linked Data together and apply uniform interface
principles for interaction with, not just retrieval of, resources that are
represented using graph data under self-describing, extensible
(inference-bearing) schemas.

I don't know the answer. I don't know enough about REST. (My message
earlier was as much a confession as a provocation.)

Barry

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18747
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 18:51:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

hello barry.

On 2012-04-04 11:41 , Barry Norton wrote:
>     link relation types are and have always been essential to REST, and
>     whether they are defined as an integral part of a media type, or
>     externally and thus can be reused across media types, is more of a
>     side issue.
> ... but as we know, one man's side issue (e.g. range14) is another man's
> (potential) bar at the entry point.

ok, so what you're saying is that link relation types defined as part of 
a media type (such in HTML) seems to make sense to you, but having them 
as reusable components (as in the IANA link relation type registry) is 
less convincing? that a very concrete starting point for a discussion, i 
think, so what issue do you have with that? RFC 5988 was established 
fairly recently and mostly in an attempt to make link relations more 
reusable across media types, because experience showed that some link 
relations make sense for a variety of media types, and not just one. to 
me, this was mostly cleaning up the sometimes messy landscape of one 
media type saying it used the link relations defined by another media 
type, and simply establishing a framework for factoring these out of the 
media types. to me, this did not change anything about what links mean 
and how links work, it simply made it easier to engineer thing cleanly. 
to you, it seems you see a more important difference. could you explain 
what that difference is, and why you think it introduces problem?

thanks and cheers,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18748
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-04 22:33:12
Subject:REST client library for C#
Message:

Back in december 2009 I asked for some feedback on the implementation of a 
generic REST client library in C# 
(http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/14110). I got some 
valuable feedback then and during the last three years I have been working 
on and off on something - and now, at last, it is stable and ready for use 
by any one who are consuming REST services in C#.

It is already in use at the company I work for (www.cbrain.com) where I am 
implementing a REST service for our case management system. Here Ramone is 
used to simplify the automated test code, and also in some internal 
integration service that moves data to and from another sub-system.

I have blogged a few pieces about the library here: 
http://soabits.blogspot.com/2012/04/consuming-web-apis-in-c-with-ramone.html, 
http://soabits.blogspot.com/2012/04/introducing-ramone-c-library-for-web.html 
and 
http://soabits.blogspot.com/2012/04/ramone-consuming-hyper-media-rest.html.

The code is released at Github, https://github.com/JornWildt/Ramone, under 
the Open Source MIT license.

Thanks for all the help I have gotten from this list - now its time to give 
something back :-)

Hopefully





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18749
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 10:52:28
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Wednesday, April 04, 2012 11:35 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
 
> > On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 4:01 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
> > I'm not trying to argue against you, but to understand. I believe we
> have
> > quite similar goals, but follow different approaches to achieve them.
> > It would definitely help me if you could be a bit more concrete. So,
> what's
> > the additional stuff JSON-LD drags along?
> >
> 
> I don't know why the spec(s) is/are so long or how something that
> should be simple is made to appear so convoluted, but my assumption is
> that this is due to 'additional stuff'?

Well that's an another point then which has nothing to do with JSON-LD
itself.

There are basically two reasons for this. First of all, we wanted to make
the spec very clear and understandable, therefore we probably described more
than would be really necessary. The other thing is that it is still a work
in progress. We have been working on it for quite some time and it just grew
to that size. If you check you'll actually see that most of the text are in
fact examples. I'm quite sure before we consider it as stable - which
hopefully happens soon - we will be able to shorten the spec quite a bit. Of
course is also has some features which other approaches don't have, e.g.,
string internationalization. But you don't need to use them if you don't
need them.

And by the way.. I've never heard someone arguing that, e.g., HTML is too
complex because the spec is too long.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18750
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 11:19:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 11:52 AM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> On Wednesday, April 04, 2012 11:35 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>
>> > On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 4:01 PM, Markus Lanthaler wrote:
>> > I'm not trying to argue against you, but to understand. I believe we
>> have
>> > quite similar goals, but follow different approaches to achieve them.
>> > It would definitely help me if you could be a bit more concrete. So,
>> what's
>> > the additional stuff JSON-LD drags along?
>> >
>>
>> I don't know why the spec(s) is/are so long or how something that
>> should be simple is made to appear so convoluted, but my assumption is
>> that this is due to 'additional stuff'?
>
> Well that's an another point then which has nothing to do with JSON-LD
> itself.
>
> There are basically two reasons for this. First of all, we wanted to make
> the spec very clear and understandable, therefore we probably described more
> than would be really necessary. The other thing is that it is still a work
> in progress. We have been working on it for quite some time and it just grew
> to that size. If you check you'll actually see that most of the text are in
> fact examples. I'm quite sure before we consider it as stable - which
> hopefully happens soon - we will be able to shorten the spec quite a bit. Of
> course is also has some features which other approaches don't have, e.g.,
> string internationalization. But you don't need to use them if you don't
> need them.
>
> And by the way.. I've never heard someone arguing that, e.g., HTML is too
> complex because the spec is too long.
>

The difference being, HTML has a lot more to concern itself with than
(what should be) a few conventions on top of JSON.

The JSON-LD spec says "RDF can be expressed using JSON-LD".. Is this a
requirement for JSON-LD? Or could you strip it down to bear minimum
and forfeit that capability?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18751
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 12:55:07
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

> The JSON-LD spec says "RDF can be expressed using JSON-LD".. Is this a
> requirement for JSON-LD? Or could you strip it down to bear minimum
> and forfeit that capability?

It is not a requirement but it was a goal to be able to be as expressive as
RDF. We currently have these special keywords in the spec:

@context - to link JSON keys to IRIs,
@id - to denote what is an IRI,
@value and @language - to specify the language of a string (I18N),
@type - to denote the type of an object/property (this is probably the most
RDFish one),
and @container with possible values of @list and @set to describe whether an
array should be considered as list or as unordered set

So there's really not that much in the end. Perhaps you could drop
@container with @list/@list but as most of the time arrays are used as sets
in JSON while the JSON spec defines them to be ordered we wanted to support
both and be explicit about what was meant buy the author. If you don't need
I18N you could also drop @language - but since some of us are from Europe
(me included) we decided to support it as it is quite important in a lot of
use cases.

What do you think could/should be dropped? I would really appreciate to hear
your opinion on that.


Cheers,
Markus



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18752
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 13:39:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 1:55 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
>> The JSON-LD spec says "RDF can be expressed using JSON-LD".. Is this a
>> requirement for JSON-LD? Or could you strip it down to bear minimum
>> and forfeit that capability?
>
> It is not a requirement but it was a goal to be able to be as expressive as
> RDF. We currently have these special keywords in the spec:
>
> @context - to link JSON keys to IRIs,
> @id - to denote what is an IRI,
> @value and @language - to specify the language of a string (I18N),
> @type - to denote the type of an object/property (this is probably the most
> RDFish one),
> and @container with possible values of @list and @set to describe whether an
> array should be considered as list or as unordered set
>
> So there's really not that much in the end. Perhaps you could drop
> @container with @list/@list but as most of the time arrays are used as sets
> in JSON while the JSON spec defines them to be ordered we wanted to support
> both and be explicit about what was meant buy the author. If you don't need
> I18N you could also drop @language - but since some of us are from Europe
> (me included) we decided to support it as it is quite important in a lot of
> use cases.
>
> What do you think could/should be dropped? I would really appreciate to hear
> your opinion on that.
>

I can't see any ways to pick apart JSON-LD to make it significantly
simpler (logically or aesthetically) because its whole design has been
affected by its goal of being 'as expressive as RDF'. Sorry I can't be
more specific than that, I just can't see how you can solve that
problem.

I have some more questions for you, if that's alright:

Is something like hal+json Linked Data?

Do you agree that hal+json is simpler than JSON-LD?

Is there anything about hal+json that you consider insufficient or
'wrong' as a means to expose a REST application to machines?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18753
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 13:45:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

An interesting point of comparison is the WikiData model doing the rounds
this morning:
http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikidata/Data_model_in_JSON

I'm pretty worried by "this simplifies some aspects of the data model
(e.g., the entity is just a short string ID, not an Entity, not even an
IRI). In general, this is possible as long as the type of the data is known
implicitly"

Sounds like they're going, for 'simplicity', down the route of URI
construction by the client. Surely even the REST community would see this
as a step too far, no?

Barry


On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 2:39 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 1:55 PM, Markus Lanthaler
> <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> >> The JSON-LD spec says "RDF can be expressed using JSON-LD".. Is this a
> >> requirement for JSON-LD? Or could you strip it down to bear minimum
> >> and forfeit that capability?
> >
> > It is not a requirement but it was a goal to be able to be as expressive
> as
> > RDF. We currently have these special keywords in the spec:
> >
> > @context - to link JSON keys to IRIs,
> > @id - to denote what is an IRI,
> > @value and @language - to specify the language of a string (I18N),
> > @type - to denote the type of an object/property (this is probably the
> most
> > RDFish one),
> > and @container with possible values of @list and @set to describe
> whether an
> > array should be considered as list or as unordered set
> >
> > So there's really not that much in the end. Perhaps you could drop
> > @container with @list/@list but as most of the time arrays are used as
> sets
> > in JSON while the JSON spec defines them to be ordered we wanted to
> support
> > both and be explicit about what was meant buy the author. If you don't
> need
> > I18N you could also drop @language - but since some of us are from Europe
> > (me included) we decided to support it as it is quite important in a lot
> of
> > use cases.

> > your opinion on that.

> simpler (logically or aesthetically) because its whole design has been
> affected by its goal of being 'as expressive as RDF'. Sorry I can't be

> problem.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18754
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 14:26:32
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

> I can't see any ways to pick apart JSON-LD to make it significantly
> simpler (logically or aesthetically) because its whole design has been
> affected by its goal of being 'as expressive as RDF'. Sorry I can't be
> more specific than that, I just can't see how you can solve that
> problem.

Well, I don't see any problem with it.. but apparently you do and I'm still
not sure I understand what the problem really is.


> I have some more questions for you, if that's alright:
> 
> Is something like hal+json Linked Data?

That's a difficult question to answer but I would tend to say no as you
treat the data as an opaque block. The properties in there have no meaning
and there's no way to, e.g., describe that two properties in two different
representations are about the same thing.


> Do you agree that hal+json is simpler than JSON-LD?

Not really, but that depends on what you mean by simpler. If you are just
talking about extracting hyperlinks then, yeah, maybe, because you just have
to look for "_links" whereas in JSON-LD potentially every value could be an
IRI (by setting the type of that property to @id). But in the end that's
just a "trick" since you split every link in a "rel" and "href" part whereas
in JSON-LD the "rel" is the property itself and its value is the "href".


> Is there anything about hal+json that you consider insufficient or
> 'wrong' as a means to expose a REST application to machines?

There's nothing wrong with it but I think it's expressivity is quite
limited.



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

I think you slightly misunderstood it. At least I read it as "This example
simplifies some aspects..."

 

If you look at http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikidata/Data_model#Values an
"Entity" actually has IRI as identifier.

Markus Lanthaler

An interesting point of comparison is the WikiData model doing the rounds
this morning:

http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikidata/Data_model_in_JSON

 

I'm pretty worried by "this simplifies some aspects of the data model (e.g.,
the entity is just a short string ID, not an Entity, not even an IRI). In
general, this is possible as long as the type of the data is known
implicitly"

 

Sounds like they're going, for 'simplicity', down the route of URI
construction by the client. Surely even the REST community would see this as
a step too far, no?

 

Barry

 

 

On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 2:39 PM, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

  

On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 1:55 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@... <mailto:markus.lanthaler%40gmx.net> > wrote:
>> The JSON-LD spec says "RDF can be expressed using JSON-LD".. Is this a
>> requirement for JSON-LD? Or could you strip it down to bear minimum
>> and forfeit that capability?
>

> It is not a requirement but it was a goal to be able to be as expressive
as
> RDF. We currently have these special keywords in the spec:
>
> @context - to link JSON keys to IRIs,
> @id - to denote what is an IRI,
> @value and @language - to specify the language of a string (I18N),
> @type - to denote the type of an object/property (this is probably the
most
> RDFish one),
> and @container with possible values of @list and @set to describe whether
an
> array should be considered as list or as unordered set
>
> So there's really not that much in the end. Perhaps you could drop
> @container with @list/@list but as most of the time arrays are used as
sets
> in JSON while the JSON spec defines them to be ordered we wanted to
support
> both and be explicit about what was meant buy the author. If you don't
need
> I18N you could also drop @language - but since some of us are from Europe
> (me included) we decided to support it as it is quite important in a lot
of
> use cases.
>
> What do you think could/should be dropped? I would really appreciate to
hear
> your opinion on that.
>

I can't see any ways to pick apart JSON-LD to make it significantly
simpler (logically or aesthetically) because its whole design has been
affected by its goal of being 'as expressive as RDF'. Sorry I can't be
more specific than that, I just can't see how you can solve that
problem.

I have some more questions for you, if that's alright:

Is something like hal+json Linked Data?

Do you agree that hal+json is simpler than JSON-LD?

Is there anything about hal+json that you consider insufficient or
'wrong' as a means to expose a REST application to machines?

Cheers,
Mike



 
<http://groups.yahoo.com/;_ylc=X3oDMTJkbjI4b2Y1BF9TAzk3MzU5NzE0BGdycElkAzQzM

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18756
Sender:Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 15:01:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

On Thu, Apr 5, 2012 at 3:26 PM, Markus Lanthaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
>> Is something like hal+json Linked Data?
>
> That's a difficult question to answer but I would tend to say no as you
> treat the data as an opaque block. The properties in there have no meaning
> and there's no way to, e.g., describe that two properties in two different
> representations are about the same thing.
>

The approach with HAL is that the meaning of a resource and its
properties are given to it by the link relation which led to its
discovery. So if you follow a link relation 'user' and you get back a
representation of a resource that includes the property 'age' - you
know the meaning of that property is 'the age of this user (resource)'
because the user rel has documentation which tells you that.

Personally, I think that approach is sufficient - buf if you
desperately felt the need to have your HAL representations explicitly
typed so that they can 'stand on their own' and not require a
preceding link relation, then you could use a profile link to do this
job (a la dret's ongoing work). I think that's a poor design decision,
but it is perfectly possible.


>> Do you agree that hal+json is simpler than JSON-LD?
>
> Not really, but that depends on what you mean by simpler. If you are just
> talking about extracting hyperlinks then, yeah, maybe, because you just have
> to look for "_links" whereas in JSON-LD potentially every value could be an
> IRI (by setting the type of that property to @id). But in the end that's
> just a "trick" since you split every link in a "rel" and "href" part whereas
> in JSON-LD the "rel" is the property itself and its value is the "href".
>

That isn't a "trick", it's just a good way of emulating Atom/HTML's
<link> and @rel with JSON.

>> Is there anything about hal+json that you consider insufficient or
>> 'wrong' as a means to expose a REST application to machines?
>
> There's nothing wrong with it but I think it's expressivity is quite
> limited.

What would you like to do that you couldn't with HAL?

Cheers,
Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18757
Sender:Barry Norton <barrynorton@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 15:08:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Entities have IRIs in the data model, but they're not communicated in the
JSON messages as far as I can see.

Insofar as I understood from Kingsley Idehen (though I'll confirm with
Denny Vrandecic), as I said, the client to the API is supposed to
reconstruct the URIs.

Barry

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18758
Sender:=?iso-8859-1?Q?J=F8rn_Wildt?= <jw@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-05 19:14:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data
Message:

Hi Mike

> The approach with HAL is that the meaning of a resource and its
> properties are given to it by the link relation which led to its
> discovery. So if you follow a link relation 'user' and you get back a
> representation of a resource that includes the property 'age' - you
> know the meaning of that property is 'the age of this user (resource)'
> because the user rel has documentation which tells you that.

We have recently been going through this discussion on another mailing list 
and, yes, I agree with you that this approach works for a lot of 
applications. But for some uses link-rels just ain't enough - and Linked 
Data seems to be one of them. I am no expert at LD but I believe I 
understand the triple <subject, predicate, object> conecpt - which is very 
much similar to link-rels <origin-resource, relation, target-resource>.

In HAL's world view a relation tells not only HOW a resource is related to 
another - it also tells WHAT the other resource is. But some relations do 
not work like this.

Take the link-rel or predicate "likes", meaning the subject X likes the 
object Y, or in HAL/REST - resource X has a "likes" relation to resource Y. 
What does that tell about Y? Nothing. The Y resource can be a dog, a movie, 
a place - anything - a client following "likes" won't have a clue about the 
type of resource in the other end, and a property called "Age" could refer 
to just about anything.

> buf if you
> desperately felt the need to have your HAL representations explicitly
> typed so that they can 'stand on their own' and not require a
> preceding link relation, then you could use a profile link to do this
> job (a la dret's ongoing work). I think that's a poor design decision,
> but it is perfectly possible.

Yes. It is perfectly possible and solves the problem above. But it is not 
fair to call it a poor design decision - there are certain use cases that 
requires it - Linked Data seems to be one of them.

The conflict seems to stem from two different view points: data as plain 
messages in a well known interaction versus data as typed resources taking 
part of the semantic web.

/Jï¿½rn





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18759
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-06 09:49:34
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST client library for C#
Message:

Ooooh. MIT means I can steal some of that code for OpenRasta.Client without having multiple licenses, yay :)

-----Original Message-----
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jørn Wildt
Sent: 04 April 2012 23:33
To: Rest Discussion List
Subject: [rest-discuss] REST client library for C#

Back in december 2009 I asked for some feedback on the implementation of a generic REST client library in C# (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/14110). I got some valuable feedback then and during the last three years I have been working on and off on something - and now, at last, it is stable and ready for use by any one who are consuming REST services in C#.

It is already in use at the company I work for (www.cbrain.com) where I am implementing a REST service for our case management system. Here Ramone is used to simplify the automated test code, and also in some internal integration service that moves data to and from another sub-system.

I have blogged a few pieces about the library here: 
http://soabits.blogspot.com/2012/04/consuming-web-apis-in-c-with-ramone.html,
http://soabits.blogspot.com/2012/04/introducing-ramone-c-library-for-web.html
and
http://soabits.blogspot.com/2012/04/ramone-consuming-hyper-media-rest.html.

The code is released at Github, https://github.com/JornWildt/Ramone, under the Open Source MIT license.

Thanks for all the help I have gotten from this list - now its time to give something back :-)

Hopefully 



------------------------------------

Yahoo! Groups Links





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18760
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-06 16:09:34
Subject:Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for feedback and help
Message:

Hi All.

A couple of days ago DeveloperFusion published an article of mine that is the first part of an idea about evaluation of REST Frameworks.
That is the first part, where we simply explain as quickly as we can what REST is, then make a list of what a REST APP may require, and then we made up a maturity model for frameworks based on how much support for achieving those requirements they offer.

Any feedback is appreciated, as the model idea may benefit a lot from fresh views. I publicly thank Glenn Block for his insight and ideas in the article. So that is the first part of my request here, I know you all may have something to comment :D

The second part of my request is regarding the second part of the article: After we have the model, we need to provide an evaluation of the current frameworks! That evaluation I did long ago and without the model. Now, I do not use all the frameworks of course, so it will be great if some of you may take a look at the model, then review the framework you most work with or know, and let me know what level of support (based on the model) do you think that framework offers. It will be great including all platforms, from PHP tp Java, .NET, Ruby and any other scripting language around. Now, please bear in mind this is not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning. 

Thanks to all and I'll appreciate any comment, be that here or in the article at DeveloperFusion. Thanks a lot!

William Martinez.
Article Link: http://www.developerfusion.com/article/141194/evaluating-rest-frameworks-part-1-a-maturity-model/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18761
Sender:Sebastien Lambla <seb@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-06 19:22:45
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for feedback and help
Message:

I'd highly disagree that a fx to be efficient ought to have a client part. There are many http-friendly client frameworks out there, why wouldn't combining them with a server implementation be enough?

I mean asking for both client and server implementations feels like it's going in the complete opposite direction to the whole point of http as an application, so the contract is shared rather than the implementation?

Plus in my neck on the wood it would disqualify everybody bar the Microsoft implementation, or maybe servicestack if they do have a client (not sure).

-----Original Message-----
From: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com [mailto:rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of William Martinez Pomares
Sent: 06 April 2012 17:10
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for feedback and help

Hi All.

A couple of days ago DeveloperFusion published an article of mine that is the first part of an idea about evaluation of REST Frameworks.
That is the first part, where we simply explain as quickly as we can what REST is, then make a list of what a REST APP may require, and then we made up a maturity model for frameworks based on how much support for achieving those requirements they offer.

Any feedback is appreciated, as the model idea may benefit a lot from fresh views. I publicly thank Glenn Block for his insight and ideas in the article. So that is the first part of my request here, I know you all may have something to comment :D

The second part of my request is regarding the second part of the article: After we have the model, we need to provide an evaluation of the current frameworks! That evaluation I did long ago and without the model. Now, I do not use all the frameworks of course, so it will be great if some of you may take a look at the model, then review the framework you most work with or know, and let me know what level of support (based on the model) do you think that framework offers. It will be great including all platforms, from PHP tp Java, .NET, Ruby and any other scripting language around. Now, please bear in mind this is not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning. 

Thanks to all and I'll appreciate any comment, be that here or in the article at DeveloperFusion. Thanks a lot!

William Martinez.
Article Link: http://www.developerfusion.com/article/141194/evaluating-rest-frameworks-part-1-a-maturity-model/

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18762
Sender:Erik Wilde <dret@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-06 19:18:04
Subject:Re: Feedback on draft-wilde-profile-link-00
Message:

hello mark.

thanks a lot for the feedback! i am cross-posting this response to 
rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, because it may be interesting for that 
community as well. too bad that the IETF drafts don't have commenting 
support on the IETF page itself, that would be really useful!

On 2012-04-05 09:25 , Mark Nottingham wrote:
> Overall, I'm really happy to see this draft; have been considering doing something along these lines too.
> *** Major issues
> * "Resource Profiles" - this spec defines the profile is being about the *resource* of its context. This is too loose; in HTML and other uses I've seen, profiles are about the *representation* they occur within.

actually, most of the abstract talks about the profile qualifying a 
representation, but you're correct that this should be made very clear, 
and that it should be about the specific representation containing the 
profile link. i'll rewrite all the places where the text says that 
profiles are about resources.

> In other words, the common idea of a profile, IME, is that it describes the conventions, extensions, etc. that are used in a particular document, but it doesn't say anything about the resource that the document was retrieved from.

yes, that is how it should be. only that i really would not want to say 
"describes" here, to clearly avoid the expectation that a 'profile' link 
MUST resolve to some sort of description. i'd say it "identifies" 
conventions, extensions, etc., and the only dependable operation on a 
'profile' link is to compare the URI to known profile URIs.

> That's a good design, because link relations are already a defined mechanism to talk about resource behaviours; having two such mechanisms isn't a good idea (at least without some discussion).
> E.g., when I interact with a resource, I know it supports particular behaviours, because it's been linked to with relation "Foo." When I get a representation from the "Foo" resource, it will have a media type that describes the format, and also a profile ("Bar") that describes additional features / conventions of that document (such as a particular use of JSON or XML), but that profile won't -- and shouldn't! -- be an additional way of describing the behaviours of the "Foo" resource.

now i am little bit confused. taking your example, i am not concerned 
with the link relation that was used to discover 'foo' at all. all i am 
concerned with is that if i am retrieving 'foo' and i find a 'bar' 
profile identifier in the representation, i know that it follows 
constraints and conventions beyond the 'foo' media type. one example i 
am currently considering adding is atompub. currently, when you retrieve 
a feed, there's no way to tell it's atompub-capable just by looking at 
it. that could be easily remedied by adding a 'profile' link identifying 
the support of atompub. that's the kind of scenario i have in mind, but 
it sounds to me you're thinking about something else, or am i just 
misunderstanding you?

> *** Nits / minor feedback:
> * """This link relation type is independent of the resource representation it is used in (but the representation must support types links for this mechanism to work)"""
> I'd state this in terms of "context", as per the link RFC.

"This link relation type is independent of the context in which it is 
used (however, the representation must support typed links for this 
mechanism to work)"

> * s/must support types links/must support typed links/

done.

> * """
>     In fact, for the purpose of this
>     specification, the URI does not necessarily have to link to a
>     dereferencable resource, and clients can treat the occurrence of a
>     specific URI in the same sense as a namespace URI and invoke specific
>     behavior based on the assumption that a specific profile URI signals
>     that a resource follows a specific profile.
> """
> Here, I'd state this in terms of "target URIs", as does the link RFC.

"In fact, for the purpose of this specification, the target URI does not 
necessarily have to identify a dereferencable resource (or even use a 
dereferencable URI scheme), and clients can treat the occurrence of a 
specific URI in the same way as an XML namespace URI and invoke specific 
behavior based on the assumption that a specific profile target URI 
signals that a resource representation follows a specific profile."

> * Your Security Considerations section isn't going to pass muster; if it were me, I'd talk about how software shouldn't make security-sensitive assumptions based upon profiles.

any specific suggestions on how to phrase that? ;-)

> *"""
>     As one example, consider the case of podcasts, a specific kind of
>     feed using additional fields for media-related metadata.  Using a
>     'profile' link, it would be possible for a client to understand that
>     a specific feed is supposed to be a podcast feed, and that it may
>     contain entries using podcast-specific fields.  This may allow a
>     client to behave differently when handling such a feed (such as
>     rendering a UI), even when the current set of entries in the feed may
>     not contain any podcast entries.
> """
> This is an interesting use case. My use cases for "profile" tend to be things like "links that this document contain follow *this* convention". More examples would be good.

to me, it's both about those links and about conventions followed in the 
document itself. i am currently planning to include three examples in 
the next version of the draft:

- HCard
- Dublin Core
- AtomPub

particularly this last one might be what you're looking for, right? if 
you have any suggestions what to add to this list, please let me know.

thanks a lot for the feedback! i'll continue working on the examples, 
and as soon as these are finished, i am planning to publish -01 and see 
whether the additional examples make it easier to understand what this 
draft is trying to accomplish, and there might be more feedback.

cheers and happy easter everybody,

dret.

-- 
erik wilde | mailto:dret@...  -  tel:+1-510-2061079 |
            | UC Berkeley  -  School of Information (ISchool) |
            | http://dret.net/netdret http://twitter.com/dret |





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18763
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-06 22:56:34
Subject:Re: Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for feedback and help
Message:

Hi Sebastien.
Thanks for the comment!. It will help me to clarify two little
misconceptions (that even after 4 revisions to the article's text,
almost rewriting it, still prevail):

1. The model is not to disqualify anything! As I said, a level 1 still
provides support for REST even if the developer needs to write or use
other frameworks to complete his job. Nor it is saying that level 4 or 5
is the most efficient. What we are depicting here is all the support a
framework can offer. They ARE ALL REST frameworks, but some offer more
support than others, and some offer support in different ways.

2. Yes, I Glen also commented against having the client part included,
even after the discussion in this same list about the client being part
of the REST system or not. Truth is that we cannot simply say the client
part is not part of REST and that is why some frameworks are actually
offering client support (yes, far more that just MS). In M2M scenarios,
one server can actually be client of another server. The last REST
substyle is the layered one, meaning we can have several layers of
client-server and they should follow the same rules. Now, we are not
asking for a client and server implementation. We are asking for support
on development. That is a little different.

Finally, as it has been discussed before, we can have two different
developers. Glen mentioned the case of the server being implemented in
one particular language/platform, and then the framework supporting all
the other languages out there fot the client part? Makes no sense and he
is right. But if we have two developers, one creating the server with
one framework, and the other one creating the client, we cannot FORCE
the client developer to use the server framework, that is against REST
idea. But then we cannot doom the client guy to write all HTTP
interactions and conneg from scratch everytime either! If we have a
framework that help us with the client part, great!. Nobody is saying we
need the same framework!

Now think of me creating a server that needs to consume other REST
interface in another server I'm not creating. I can use two frameworks,
or use one that allows me to create the server and also connect to the
other server.

What I'm trying to say is client is an important part, and we cannot
left it out just to allow all the frameworks out there to be level 5.

The client part is controversial, I know, but we have to treat it
somewhere. Any ideas of improvements, beyond just kicking it out?

Thanks.

William Martinez.
--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:
>
> I'd highly disagree that a fx to be efficient ought to have a client
part. There are many http-friendly client frameworks out there, why
wouldn't combining them with a server implementation be enough?
>
> I mean asking for both client and server implementations feels like
it's going in the complete opposite direction to the whole point of http
as an application, so the contract is shared rather than the
implementation?
>
> Plus in my neck on the wood it would disqualify everybody bar the
Microsoft implementation, or maybe servicestack if they do have a client
(not sure).
>

Sent from my Windows Phone
From: William Martinez Pomares
Sent: 4/6/2012 9:09 AM
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
feedback and help
Hi All.

A couple of days ago DeveloperFusion published an article of mine that is t=
he first part of an idea about evaluation of REST Frameworks.
That is the first part, where we simply explain as quickly as we can what R=
EST is, then make a list of what a REST APP may require, and then we made u=
p a maturity model for frameworks based on how much support for achieving t=
hose requirements they offer.

Any feedback is appreciated, as the model idea may benefit a lot from fresh=
 views. I publicly thank Glenn Block for his insight and ideas in the artic=
le. So that is the first part of my request here, I know you all may have s=
omething to comment :D

The second part of my request is regarding the second part of the article: =
After we have the model, we need to provide an evaluation of the current fr=
ameworks! That evaluation I did long ago and without the model. Now, I do n=
ot use all the frameworks of course, so it will be great if some of you may=
 take a look at the model, then review the framework you most work with or =
know, and let me know what level of support (based on the model) do you thi=
nk that framework offers. It will be great including all platforms, from PH=
P tp Java, .NET, Ruby and any other scripting language around. Now, please =
bear in mind this is not a competition, where higher level means that frame=
work wins. As stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only=
 the developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are loo=
king for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the framework mak=
ers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It is like suggestin=
g a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.=20

Thanks to all and I'll appreciate any comment, be that here or in the artic=
le at DeveloperFusion. Thanks a lot!

William Martinez.
Article Link: http://www.developerfusion.com/article/141194/evaluating-rest=
-frameworks-part-1-a-maturity-model/


--B6BB8F1PNeBpnU2a-mZC0n7eszHWVxedoV1gAm2

      <p>Hi All.<br>
<br>
A couple of days ago DeveloperFusion published an article of mine that is t=
he first part of an idea about evaluation of REST Frameworks.<br>
That is the first part, where we simply explain as quickly as we can what R=
EST is, then make a list of what a REST APP may require, and then we made u=
p a maturity model for frameworks based on how much support for achieving t=
hose requirements they offer.<br>
<br>
Any feedback is appreciated, as the model idea may benefit a lot from fresh=
 views. I publicly thank Glenn Block for his insight and ideas in the artic=
le. So that is the first part of my request here, I know you all may have s=
omething to comment :D<br>
<br>
The second part of my request is regarding the second part of the article: =
After we have the model, we need to provide an evaluation of the current fr=
ameworks! That evaluation I did long ago and without the model. Now, I do n=
ot use all the frameworks of course, so it will be great if some of you may=
 take a look at the model, then review the framework you most work with or =
know, and let me know what level of support (based on the model) do you thi=
nk that framework offers. It will be great including all platforms, from PH=
P tp Java, .NET, Ruby and any other scripting language around. Now, please =
bear in mind this is not a competition, where higher level means that frame=
work wins. As stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only=
 the developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are loo=
king for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the framework mak=
ers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It is like suggestin=
g a tool and testing it in the field for tuning. <br>
<br>
Thanks to all and I'll appreciate any comment, be that here or in the artic=
le at DeveloperFusion. Thanks a lot!<br>
<br>
William Martinez.<br>
Article Link: <a href=3D"http://www.developerfusion.com/article/141194/eval=
uating-rest-frameworks-part-1-a-maturity-model/">http://www.developerfusion=
.com/article/141194/evaluating-rest-frameworks-part-1-a-maturity-model/</a>=
<br>
<br>
</p>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18765
Sender:"Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-07 04:36:13
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for feedback and help
Message:

Hi William,

Looks to be an interesting "project".


> Now, please bear in mind this is
> not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As
> stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the
> developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are
> looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the
> framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It
> is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.

It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it would
make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of
using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for routing
and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.

You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and 5??
Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to
change that as the article has already been published..



--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler

Post ID:18767
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-07 09:28:05
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
Message:

 feedback and help
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
 boundary="K0HeR43ak8okUEeQaSR-AkwhpJqyKDf7oLMsCYh"

--K0HeR43ak8okUEeQaSR-AkwhpJqyKDf7oLMsCYh
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Yeah, Richardson's model is a very clear progression and relates mostly
to uris and methods. Which actually the more i think about it is
lacking as REST is much more than that.

In this case i wonder if a point based scoring system would be better.
In particular because we are talking about how well the fwk supports
REST rather than the system itself that uses it.

Sent from my Windows Phone
From: Markus Lanthaler
Sent: 4/6/2012 9:36 PM
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
feedback and help

> not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As
> stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the
> developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are
> looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the
> framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It
> is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.

It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it would
make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of
using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for routing
and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.

You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and 5??
Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to
change that as the article has already been published..

<html><head><meta content=3D"text/html; charset=3Dutf-8" http-equiv=3D"Cont=
ent-Type"></head><body><div><div style=3D"font-family: Calibri,sans-serif; =
font-size: 11pt;">Yeah, Richardson's model is a very clear progression and =
relates mostly to uris and methods. Which actually the more i think about i=
t is lacking as REST is much more than that.<br><br>In this case i wonder i=
f a point based scoring system would be better. In particular because we ar=
e talking about how well the fwk supports REST rather than the system itsel=
f that uses it.<br><br>Sent from my Windows Phone<br></div></div><hr><span =
style=3D"font-family: Tahoma,sans-serif; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold=
;">From: </span><span style=3D"font-family: Tahoma,sans-serif; font-size: 1=
0pt;">Markus Lanthaler</span><br><span style=3D"font-family: Tahoma,sans-se=
rif; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold;">Sent: </span><span style=3D"font-=

<div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;">
  <div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;">
<!--~-|**|PrettyHtmlEndT|**|-~-->

    <div id=3D"ygrp-text" >
     =20
     =20
      <p>Hi William,<br>
<br>
Looks to be an interesting "project".<br>
<br>
> Now, please bear in mind this is<br>
> not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As<br=
>
> stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the<br>
> developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are<br>
> looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the<br>
> framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It=
<br>
> is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.<br>
<br>
It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it would=
<br>
make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of<br>
using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for routin=
g<br>
and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.<br>
<br>
You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and 5?=
?<br>
Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to<b=
r>
change that as the article has already been published..<br>
<br>
--<br>
Markus Lanthaler<br>
@markuslanthaler<br>
<br>
</p>

    </div>
    =20

    <!--~-|**|PrettyHtmlStart|**|-~-->
    <div style=3D"color: #fff; height: 0;"></div>
<!--~-|**|PrettyHtmlEnd|**|-~-->

</body>

    width: 400px;

    text-decoration: none;

    text-decoration: none;

    width: 400px;
  }

le-title a:visited {
    text-decoration: none;

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18768
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-07 21:23:25
Subject:Re: Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for feedback and help
Message:

Markus, that is a very important point. Thanks.
Now, it is very difficult to add points to such a broad set of implementations. I like the matrix idea, but with a twist, using it like we are using a competency framework at IASA.

We can put a set of features and a list of levels for each. Say, in architecture, viewpoints. The architect may 1. never heard of them, 2. know the theory, 3. used them once or twice. 4. can't live without using them, 5. He invented them.

Likewise, levels for each feature would be 1. no support, 2. can be done somehow, 3. offers a special component for it, 4. Fully automated. 

That matrix can be a better tool for deciding, based on what do I need from the framework, I read the matrix's scorecard for the framework and I may know the tool with the best combination of features.

The maturity model idea was simply because I visualize the tool at early stages only offering basic http support for a simple REST service, and at latest stage in evolution offering support for complex systems, that is why the levels are incremental, and each level may improve the support on the lower levels features. I'm risking here one tool offering a non balanced solution with support for on-demand code  and at the same time very basic http support. The actual evaluation of current frameworks would give us an idea of that, if there is one FW that comes out to be in more that one level.

No worries about the article published, as nothing is written in stone and there is always a "...revisited" kind of article possibility.

Do you use any framework? Where would you put it using the model's levels?

Cheers!

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Markus Lanthaler" <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
>
> Hi William,
> 
> Looks to be an interesting "project".
> 
> 
> > Now, please bear in mind this is
> > not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As
> > stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the
> > developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are
> > looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the
> > framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It
> > is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.
> 
> It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it would
> make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of
> using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for routing
> and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.
> 
> You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and 5??
> Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to
> change that as the article has already been published..
> 
> 
> 
> --
> Markus Lanthaler
> @markuslanthaler
>

> > Looks to be an interesting "project".

> >> Now, please bear in mind this is
> >> not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As
> >> stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the
> >> developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are
> >> looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the
> >> framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It
> >> is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.
> >
> > It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it would
> > make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of
> > using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for routing
> > and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.
> >
> > You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and 5??
> > Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to
> > change that as the article has already been published..

Post ID:18770
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-07 21:30:19
Subject:Re: Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
Message:

Thanks Glen!
Oops, It seems you phone broke a little the thread :D
I actually think a points based model would be like a next level measurement tool. One is a broad way of categorizing the tools, then other one a fine valuation of how well that tool performs in the actual level it is located. 
Creating that model may require much more detail and discussion, which is something we should engage in a near future.

William

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>
>  feedback and help
> MIME-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
>  boundary="K0HeR43ak8okUEeQaSR-AkwhpJqyKDf7oLMsCYh"
> 
> --K0HeR43ak8okUEeQaSR-AkwhpJqyKDf7oLMsCYh
> Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"
> Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
> 
> Yeah, Richardson's model is a very clear progression and relates mostly
> to uris and methods. Which actually the more i think about it is
> lacking as REST is much more than that.
> 
> In this case i wonder if a point based scoring system would be better.
> In particular because we are talking about how well the fwk supports
> REST rather than the system itself that uses it.
> 
> Sent from my Windows Phone
> From: Markus Lanthaler
> Sent: 4/6/2012 9:36 PM
> To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
> feedback and help
> Hi William,
> 
> Looks to be an interesting "project".
> 
> 
> > Now, please bear in mind this is
> > not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As
> > stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the
> > developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are
> > looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the
> > framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It
> > is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.
> 
> It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it would
> make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of
> using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for routing
> and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.
> 
> You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and 5??
> Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to
> change that as the article has already been published..
> 
> 
> 
> --
> Markus Lanthaler
> @markuslanthaler

>   .bold a {
>     text-decoration: none;
>   }
> 
>   dd.last p a {
>     font-family: Verdana;
>     font-weight: 700;
>   }
> 
>   dd.last p span {
>     margin-right: 10px;
>     font-family: Verdana;
>     font-weight: 700;
>   }
> 
>   dd.last p span.yshortcuts {
>     margin-right: 0;
>   }
> 
>   div.attach-table div div a {
>     text-decoration: none;
>   }
> 
>   div.attach-table {
>     width: 400px;
>   }
> 
>   div.file-title a, div.file-title a:active, div.file-title a:hover, div.fi=
> le-title a:visited {
>     text-decoration: none;
>   }
> 
>   div.photo-title a, div.photo-title a:active, div.photo-title a:hover, div=
> .photo-title a:visited {
>     text-decoration: none;
>   }
> 
>   div#ygrp-mlmsg #ygrp-msg p a span.yshortcuts {
>     font-family: Verdana;
>     font-size: 10px;
>     font-weight: normal;
>   }
> 
>   .green {
>     color: #628c2a;
>   }
> 
>   .MsoNormal {
>     margin: 0 0 0 0;
>   }
> 
>   o {
>     font-size: 0;
>   }
> 
>   #photos div {
>     float: left;
>     width: 72px;
>   }
> 
>   #photos div div {
>     border: 1px solid #666666;
>     height: 62px;
>     overflow: hidden;
>     width: 62px;
>   }
> 
>   #photos div label {
>     color: #666666;
>     font-size: 10px;
>     overflow: hidden;
>     text-align: center;
>     white-space: nowrap;
>     width: 64px;
>   }
> 
>   #reco-category {
>     font-size: 77%;
>   }
> 
>   #reco-desc {
>     font-size: 77%;
>   }
> 
>   .replbq {
>     margin: 4px;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-actbar div a:first-child {
>    /* border-right: 0px solid #000;*/
>     margin-right: 2px;
>     padding-right: 5px;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg {
>     font-size: 13px;
>     font-family: Arial, helvetica,clean, sans-serif;
>     *font-size: small;
>     *font: x-small;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg table {
>     font-size: inherit;
>     font: 100%;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg select, input, textarea {
>     font: 99% Arial, Helvetica, clean, sans-serif;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg pre, code {
>     font:115% monospace;
>     *font-size:100%;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg * {
>     line-height: 1.22em;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg #logo {
>     padding-bottom: 10px;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-mlmsg a {
>     color: #1E66AE;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-msg p a {
>     font-family: Verdana;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-msg p#attach-count span {
>     color: #1E66AE;
>     font-weight: 700;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-reco #reco-head {
>     color: #ff7900;
>     font-weight: 700;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-reco {
>     margin-bottom: 20px;
>     padding: 0px;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-sponsor #ov li a {
>     font-size: 130%;
>     text-decoration: none;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-sponsor #ov li {
>     font-size: 77%;
>     list-style-type: square;
>     padding: 6px 0;
>   }=20
> 
>   #ygrp-sponsor #ov ul {
>     margin: 0;
>     padding: 0 0 0 8px;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-text {
>     font-family: Georgia;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-text p {
>     margin: 0 0 1em 0;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-text tt {
>     font-size: 120%;
>   }
> 
>   #ygrp-vital ul li:last-child {
>     border-right: none !important;=20
>   }=20
>   -->
>   </style>
> </head>
> 
> <!--~-|**|PrettyHtmlEnd|**|-~-->
> </html>
> <!-- end group email -->
> 
> 
> --K0HeR43ak8okUEeQaSR-AkwhpJqyKDf7oLMsCYh--

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18771
Sender:Glenn Block <glenn.block@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-07 21:35:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
Message:

Apologies for my phone :-)

Possibly. I didn't think of this as much when I was reviewing the article.
The problem I see with the progression model is that it has a black and
white sense to it, you are either level 0, level 1, level 2. The more I
think about it though it breaks down.

For example take the hypermedia case. You can build a hypermedia based
system that is not RESTful. I can have a framework that makes it easy to
offer up links, but yet it does not support the other constraints of REST.

Another example is the whole client thing. OK, my REST framework supports
an HTTP client, but the server implementation is pretty lousy. What level
is it? And how is that information useful?

Have some sort of point system across different categories helps me to make
an informed decision about how well this framework will support my needs if
I am looking to build a RESTful system.

My $.02

Thanks
Glenn

On Sat, Apr 7, 2012 at 2:30 PM, William Martinez Pomares <
wmartinez@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Thanks Glen!
> Oops, It seems you phone broke a little the thread :D
> I actually think a points based model would be like a next level
> measurement tool. One is a broad way of categorizing the tools, then other
> one a fine valuation of how well that tool performs in the actual level it
> is located.
> Creating that model may require much more detail and discussion, which is
> something we should engage in a near future.
>
> William
>
>
> --- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> > feedback and help

> >
> > Yeah, Richardson's model is a very clear progression and relates mostly
> > to uris and methods. Which actually the more i think about it is
> > lacking as REST is much more than that.
> >
> > In this case i wonder if a point based scoring system would be better.
> > In particular because we are talking about how well the fwk supports
> > REST rather than the system itself that uses it.
> >
> > Sent from my Windows Phone
> > From: Markus Lanthaler
> > Sent: 4/6/2012 9:36 PM
> > To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
> > feedback and help
> > Hi William,
> >
> > Looks to be an interesting "project".
> >
> >
> > > Now, please bear in mind this is
> > > not a competition, where higher level means that framework wins. As
> > > stated in the article, even level 1 fully supports REST, only the
> > > developer may need to do some extra work to get there. What we are
> > > looking for is evaluating the frameworks in a way that helps the
> > > framework makers and the users to identify the needs and solutions. It
> > > is like suggesting a tool and testing it in the field for tuning.
> >
> > It's quite normal that people use those levels as ranking. I think it
> would
> > make the intention much clearer if you would create a matrix instead of
> > using these (maturity) levels. So, e.g., framework X has support for
> routing
> > and media types whereas framework Y has hypermedia/semantics support.
> >
> > You can't do that that easily with levels. Framework X is on level 3 and
> 5??
> > Is it then also on 4? What about 1 and 2 then? But maybe it's too late to
> > change that as the article has already been published..
> >
> >

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:18772
Sender:"William Martinez Pomares" <wmartinez@...>
Post Date/Time:2012-04-07 21:48:21
Subject:Re: Evaluating REST Frameworks - Request for
Message:

You just gave a great point to think about, Glen!
A framework may give you support for just one constrain in REST, but lacks support for all the other ones. You may still be able to achieve a truly RESTful system with this, but you may also end up with an RPC based thing. The question is if we can blame the framework? Should we also take into account the restrictions the framework can add to avoid this situation?

Interesting!

William.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>
> Apologies for my phone :-)
> 
> Possibly. I didn't think of this as much when I was reviewing the article.
> The problem I see with the progression model is that it has a black and
> white sense to it, you are either level 0, level 1, level 2. The more I
> think about it though it breaks down.
> 
> For example take the hypermedia case. You can build a hypermedia based
> system that is not RESTful. I can have a framework that makes it easy to
> offer up links, but yet it does not support the other constraints of REST.
> 
> Another example is the whole client thing. OK, my REST framework supports
> an HTTP client, but the server implementation is pretty lousy. What level
> is it? And how is that information useful?
> 
> Have some sort of point system across different categories helps me to make
> an informed decision about how well this framework will support my needs if
> I am looking to build a RESTful system.
> 
> My $.02
> 
> Thanks
> Glenn
> 
> On Sat, Apr 7, 2012 at 2:30 PM, William Martinez Pomares <
> wmartinez@
